column2: WASHINGTON, April 8 President Nixon will not stand alone in history for having his Supreme Court nominations rejected.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The United States and the countries of Latin America are nearing agreement on a major increase in the lending resources of the Inter-American Development Bank. WASHINGTON, April 8 Profits of manufacturing corporations in the last quarter of 1969 were about 6 per cent below those of a year earlier, both before and after taxes, the Federal Trade Commission and Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., April 9--Dr. Arthur E. Dome, former controller of the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York, died Monday at Ocean View Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old and had recently moved here.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Senators who voted yesterday to reject the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court reacted angrily to President Nixon's statement today that the judge had been rejected solely because he was a Southerner and interpreted the Constitution cautiously.

TIME was when rugs were hung on walls to ward off drafts. But the current interest in hanging woven or tufted carpeting on walls is inspired more by fashion, the art and poster boom and the appeal of supergraphics. Regal Rugs was well aware of the popularity of boldly
Theodore H. Thiesing, an international lawyer and a leader in German-American organizations here, died Wednesday night in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 912 Fifth Avenue.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 1--"This is quite a thing for us," said a government official. "Ten years ago it was all barren. Now it's going to be a lovely garden city."

At Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater, a City College philosophy major With an armful of books recently paid $2 and sat in a $9 seat for "Camino Real." That same week, a Pratt Institute student sporting an Indian headband watched the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from a $5.95 orchestra seat. He had paid $1 admission.

WASHINGTON, April 9-- Caspar W. Weinberger, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, suggested today that the commission might, in the future, use consent settlements "more sparingly" in its cases against business for illegal restraint of trade.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9 (UPI)--A temporary restraining order issued today by a Federal judge ended a wildcat strike by shopcraft employes against the Louisville Nashville Railroad.

The Times-Mirror Company of Los Angeles was reported yesterday to have decided to acquire controlling interest in Newsday, Inc., of Garden City, L. I., the nation's biggest suburban newspaper, despite opposition from Newsday's minority stockholders.

A sweeping policy statement urging revisions in the Davis Cup, player categories, scoring system and administration of the sport is being prepared by Alastair B. Martin, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
WASHINGTON, April 9--The American Bar Association's system of passing on the qualifications of Supreme Court nominees may be changed significantly by the time Presi dent Nixon's new nominee is named.

PARIS, April 9--Insufficient research, low profit margins, a shortage of outside investment, financing difficulties of French multinational companies and the burden of exchange controls are combining to inhibit France's development as a successful industrial nation.
MOSCOW, April 9--An influential Soviet newspaper today sharply attacked a recently published novel that has drawn the ire of liberal intellectuals here.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 9-- United States Attorney John Briggs said tonight that the Federal Government would take control of the Manatee County schools despite a barricade of armed state troopers and a threat from the office of Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. that Federal marshals would be fired upon.

"We'll have to give them a real good rub-up," said Henry Moore briskly, gazing at his marbles in the velvetdraped back room of Knoedler's, 14 East 57th Street. Suiting action to words, he borrowed a bystander's handkerchief and began industriously to dust "Square Form With Cut," a curved form of black serpentine that sat on a knee-high base.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission began a crackdown on unwanted mail advertising today by charging a major seller of mailing lists with duping consumers through misleading questionnaires.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 9 -- After a night in which some 150 black students tore through the Cornell University campus, breaking windows and overturning two cars, the university today obtained an injunction against "further acts of force, violence, damage or disruption."

The morning started routinely enough with oatmeal and a newspaper full of depressing news in a crowded subway. And the meeting scheduled for 9:30 in Room 1247 at Ogilvy Mather seemed to promise nothing out of the ordinary.

The Utah Development Company, a subsidiary of the Utah Construction and Mining Company, will receive $19,950,000 for the sale of 10 per cent of its stock to Utah Mining Australia, Ltd., an Australian concern, it was announced yesterday.
STOCKHOLM--There is something decidedly American about the developing drug-abuse problem in Sweden.
The first step toward a possible expansion of the City Council to increase its Negro and Puerto Rican membership was scheduled this week.

In a new strategy aimed at ending the 16-day walkout of Federal air traffic controllers, the Government announced yesterday that it would ask 16 courts around the country to make "sick" controllers prove they are ill to doctors.

The central facts about the Supreme Court, despite all the turmoil, are the same today as they were before the Senate vote on Judge Carswell. All the Senate has said is that the highest court in the land deserves an outstanding man. Within this single reasonable principle, President Nixon is free to choose from a very large company of distinguished conservatives and is clearly in command of the situation.

WASHINGTON, April 9--The Justice Department will move to drop the criminal conspiracy case against the Rev. William Sloan Coffin Jr. and Mitchell Goodman, who were convicted in 1968 with Dr. Benjamin Spock of conspiring to counsel evasion of the draft.

OSAKA, Japan, April 9 (UPI)--The police said today that a gas leak was reported four days ago in a subway construction site where gas main explosions yesterday killed 73 persons and injured 282 others.
Hospitals across the state-- both public and private--have done virtually nothing to prepare for the demand that is expected when and if the liberalized legislation on abortion goes into effect.
Bache Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, announced a number of highlevel management changes yesterday, including the formal appointment of John E. Leslie as chief executive officer.
"It' easier now" is the unanimous comment of a group of New Yorkers who carry on one of the more nerve-wracking occupations here--driving the municipal buses.

The two-day-old strike of operators of telephone answering services ended abruptly yesterday when balloting of workers in New York City and others in Nassau and Suffolk Counties showed a majority approval of a contract offer.
NEWTON, N.J., April 9-- Frank E. Dunker Sr., chairman and former president of the Newton Trust Company, died yesterday in Newton Memorial Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 31 Liberty Street.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP)--A $2.5-million damage suit was filed yesterday on behalf of Charles O. Finley, an insurance man, charging that the ParvinDohrmann Company, Inc., and some of its directors had conspired to make stock in the company appear more valuable than it was.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 9--Robin James, an old Etonian with a ginger mustache who is a political enemy of Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, said in an interview the other day: "Race is not an issue in this election campaign."
WASHINGTON, April 9--The White Houso announced today that President Nixon would report to the nation on Vietnam in a nationally televised address next Thursday.
SANA, Yemen, April 9 (AP) --An Amercan diplomat has arrived in Yemen to handle United States interests for the first time in more than two years.

While South Vietnamese troops have been extending their operations into Cambodia in contravention of declared American policy, a new incident has raised similar questions about Washington's control over allied military activities elsewhere in Southeast Asia. That incident was a recent air action over North Vietnam in which an American figister-interceptor, escorting an unarmed reconnaissance plane, shot down a North Vietnamese MIG-21.
JERUSALEM, April 9--Israeli bombers returned to the Suez Canal region tonight, a day after a raid there that the Egyptians said had killed 30 schoolchildren.

Premier Golda Meir acted rashly and, in our view, most unwisely in torpedoing--by making public-- a private invitation to a distinguished Israeli citizen to meet with President Nasser in Cairo. Her move, together with the Israeli Cabinet's flat rejection of the proposal, makes more difficult than ever any behindthe-scenes maneuvers that could lead toward Arab Israeli peace.
PITTSBURGH, April 9 (UPI) --Lee Handley, who played eight seasons as an infielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.
Increases in basic aluminum prices swept rapidly through the industry yesterday as major producers followed the lead given late Wednesday by the Kaiser. Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.

THE PLAINS, Va., April 9 --Miss Nena Powell Bowman was married here this afternoon to First Lieut. John Buchanan Adams Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Adams of Fairfield. The Rev. Robert Pierce performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.
The following review originally appeared on Sept. 20, 1969, when the film was shown at the New York Film Festival. The movie is being exhibited here commercially.

Reflecting a 14-week strike that ended in February, the General Electric Corporation incurred a loss of $42.6-million, or 47 cents a share, in this year's first quarter, Fred J. Borch, chairman, reported yesterday. This contrasted with earnings of $77,516,000, or 86 cents a share in the initial three months of 1969.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Following is the text of a formal statement issued by President Nixon late this afternoon:

RICHMOND, April 9--The Department of Justice told a Federal court today that Nixonadministration policy permitted the existence of predominantly Negro schools in urban areas and that it was time the Supreme Court decided whether judicial policy would do the same.

IT is always rash to use superlatives, but it does most forcibly occur to me that "The Nest," which boldly calls itself a play and even more boldly opened last night at the Mercury Theater, must be on any reasonable short list of the worst plays I have ever seen. I feel there is very little to add.

The 1970 Bancroft prizes for distinguished works in American history, diplomacy and international affairs were presented to three authors last evening at an award dinner in Low Library of Columbia University. Awards were presented to Dan T. Carter for "Scottsboro: a tragedy of the American South," Charles Coleman Sellers for "Charles Wilson Peale," and Gordon S. Wood for "The Creation of The American Republic, 1776-1787."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 9--Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the United States Attorney General, telephoned The Arkansas Gazette at 1 A.M. (2 A.M. Washington time) today and urged the newspaper to "crucify" Senator J. W. Fullbright for his vote against confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the United States Supreme Court.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- Tommy Aaron, the slim Georgian who is still seeking his first triumph on the United States pro circuit, began his bid for the Masters golf title today with a 68.

The city's 1969 Rent Stabilization Law, which regulates rents and evictions in 375,000 relatively new apartments here, was declared unconstitutional yesterday by the Ap pellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9--Allied forces in South Vietnam suffered their highest number of combat deaths last week in nearly a year, according to official reports today.
MADISON. Wis., April 9--The University of Wisconsin teaching assistants voted 534 to 348 today to end a 25-day strike against the University of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, April 9-- The House Government Operations Committee approved unanimously today an unpublished report by one of its subcommittees that urges the Government to force the detergent industry to remove phosphates from its products by 1972.
MOSCOW, April 9--The Soviet Union is nearing Lenin's centenary with a sudden shift in the political atmosphere that has stirred an unusual amount of speculation in the Western diplomatic community.

Loeb, Rhoades Co., one of Wall Street's largest and best known investment banking and brokerage bonuses, took a vigorous stand yesterday against institutional membership on the New York Stock Exchange.

The State Racing Commission approved yesterday the request of the New York Racing Association to institute exacta betting at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga, the three tracks under direction of the N.Y.R.A.
WASHINGTON, April 9--A bill raising the pay of postal workers and other Federal employes was rushed through the House today in an effort to head off new postal strikes. The vote was 370 to 7.
Dr. Harold Full, associate professor of education at Queens College of the City University of New York, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday. He was 50 years old.

TRENTON, April 9--Gov. William T. Cahill urged a joint session of the Legislature today to approve a $47-million education program for New Jersey that would embody two sharply controversial measures -- nearly $10-million in state aid to private and parochial schools and a teacher incentive system based on merit pay increases.

TEAMS headed by Jeff Rubens and Murray Schnee, both of New York, will meet in one semifinal of the Greater New York Double Knockout Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy, while groups headed by Peter Leventritt and Harry Fishbein, also of New York, clash in the other.

Credit conditions eased markedly over the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed. But most of the change appeared to be due to complications arising from the Easter holiday and slowdowns related to the mail strike and the air controllers' "sick-in" rather than a change in policy.

WHEN a fight to save a stream, a marsh or a pond from pollution or development is carried on by a local organization, this is often the only approach possible in the limited time available. Whether that approach will result in the desired result is sometimes questionable. Obviously, sheer numbers and the prestige of the organization involved have a bearing on the outcome.

WASHINGTON, April 9--The United States today rejected Canadian claims to jurisdiction over extensive areas of arctic waters and said that it would not recognize Canada's right to control American vessels on the "high seas" in the far north.
ALBANY, April 9--The dramatic last-minute switching of a single vote in the Assembly today moved New York State a step closer to the reform of its abortion law.

WASHINGTON, April 9--The Nixon Administration's principal program for attacking crime in the streets, already under fire from Congress and urban groups, suffered another blow today with the resignation of its administrator and another high official.

The Philco-Ford Corporation has a new president--its fourth in the eight years since the Ford Motor Company took it over. Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the parent, Ford Motor, announced yesterday that Philip Caldwell, a vice president of Ford Motor, would be president of Philco-Ford "with direct re sponsibility for consumer prodducts and industrial electronics operations."

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 9 --The Cambodian military authorities have withdrawn all troops from the tip of the section of Svayrieng Province known as the Parrot's Beak, abandoning it for the time, being to the Vietnamese Communists, according to high military sources.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended April 4 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
PITTSBURGH, April 9--Dock Ellis of the Pittsburgh Pirates outpitched Jerry Koosman, struck out 13 batters and defeated the New York Mets tonight, 2--1.
Dr. Samuel B. Gould resigned yesterday as chancellor of the State University of New York, effective Oct. 1.
LYDDA, Israel, April 9--The first plane designed and produced in Israel, the Arava, made its inaugural flight here today in a ceremony heavy with military overtones.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 9 (AP) --Defying a state no-strike law and a court restraining order, more than half of the Minneapolis public school teachers abandoned classrooms today to enforce demands in next year's work contract.

THE HAGUE--Willy Brandt is an imposing, eminent and popular statesman and therefore as he arrives in Washington for the official part of his state visit he may properly look forward to an enthusiastic reception.
LONDON, April 9 (UPI)-- A former convict has published a five-star guide to major prisons in Britain, recommending them on the basis of food, atmosphere and surroundings.
A high school junior in mod clothes, wearing his long black hair in a Custer cut, shouted into the microphone on the assembly floor at Martin Van Buren High School yesterday morning.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 9 --The skipper and some of the crew of Gretel II, the potential Australian challenger for the America's Cup, were announced tonight. It was reported that the yacht was running into difficulties in its preparation for a sailoff against France later this year.

BOSTON, April 9--New breakthroughs in contraceptive technology comparable in impact to birth control pills will require greater emphasis on basic research into the reproductive process, Dr. Roy Hertz, a researcher, said here today.

VANCOUVER, British Colum- bia, April 5--An Edmonton, Alberta, man: "It's time that the western Canadians should have full control of our resources and capital and the responsibility of building our own future."

LEW ALCINDOR is not the first of the magnificent giants to assume a dominating role in professional basketball. Wilt Chamberlain and Bill Russell already have preceded him. But the time is not too distant when the oversized rookie of the Milwaukee Bucks will be greater than either. Fortunately for the New York Knickerbockers, that day has not yet arrived.

CINCINNATI, April 9 (AP)-- Brian Job, Stanford University freshman, cracked the American 100-yard breast-stroke record twice today in the Amateur Athletic Union national men's and women's swimming championship.
ALBANY, April 9--Without debate, the Senate passed and sent to the Assembly today a bill cutting the waiting period for a divorce from two years to one.
JERUSALEM, April 9 -- There are certain people in this country who don't like me, no matter what I do," Dr. Nahum Goldmann said--nearly a decade ago.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9-- When the starter on the first tee announced, "Juan Rodriguez," the skinny little golfer in the white straw hat commented, "Better known as Chi Chi." The nearby spectators laughed, and he kept them laughing throughout his two-under-par 70 in today's opening round of the Masters tournament.
Dr. William J. McGill, who will take office as president of Columbia University in the fall, was heckled yesterday as he met a large group of Columbia students for the first time.

GENEVA, April 9--Mrs. Alva Myrdal of Sweden suggested today that the disarmament conference meeting has conclude a separate international agreement that would require the signers to report whether they were developing substances that could be used in chemical or bacteriological warfare.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 9-- Federal Judge Alfonzo J. Zirpoli has signed an order limiting the Federal Government's power of subpoena on Earl Caldwell, a New York Times correspondent.

Hilton Kramer, art news editor of The New York Times, has been named winner of the third annual Elsie O. and Philip D. Sang prize for critics of the fine arts, it was annouced yesterday by Knox College, a private, nondenominational, coeducational liberal art college in Galesburg, Ill.
BOSTON, April 9--The inability to perform the act known as scoring that affects the Rangers in the Stanley Cup Playoffs helped bury them again tonight against the suddenly tame Bruins.
Two of the big three companies in the department storecatalogue chain field reported yesterday minimal sales gains during the just-ended Easter season.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9-- Nine security officers accompanied Gary Player throughout the South African golfer's opening round today in the Masters tournament.
MADISON, Wis.. April 9 (UPI)--A Federal district judge ruled today that the Wisconsin Assembly violatad the constitutional rights of the Rev. James E. Groppi last year when it cited him for contempt.
Bobby Murcer wants an eye examination but Ray Culp would insist that his eyesight is 20-20, at worst.

The American Jewish Committee charged yesterday that Jews were "apparently" being excluded from 60 per cent of a sample of 139 cooperative apartment buildings the committee investigated on Manhattan's East Side.

Negotiations for the sale of the New York Jets to a group that included Allie Sherman, the former Giants coach, were terminated yesterday and ownership will be retained by the present group headed by Philip H. Iselin, with Weeb Ewbank as general manager and head coach.

Former Chief Justice Earl Warren chastised the bar of the nation yesterday as he appealed to the legal profession to awake to its responsibility to help end "the divisiveness which is plaguing us" and bring "the spirit of justice" into "every courtroom in our land."

The Chemical New York Corporation, the holdingcompany parent of the Chemical Bank, reported yesterday a 21.3 per cent decline in net income for the first quarter, reflecting heavy losses in securities transactions.

In one of his Proverbs of Hell, the poet William Blake said, "He who desires but acts not, breeds pestilence." There can be no doubt that President Nixon desires an end to the plague of inflation. But he acts not--not even on the findings of his own study groups.
Public television's station managers and programers got a preview yesterday of what they can expect in national programing next season. They liked what they saw.

The bond market quieted down yesterday, and it held its ground. As much as anything, it settled down to wait for the terms of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $1.57-billion debenture offering next Monday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 9 (UPI)--The Los Angeles Lakers, paced by Elgin Baylor and Wilt Chamberlain bounced back from a 3-1 playoff deficit tonight as they wrapped up the Western Division semifinals with a 129-94 rout of the Phoenix Suns.

About 600 persons are expected at the Plaza on April 26 when the American Musical and Dramatic Academy holds a benefit dinner dance to cushion the expense of moving to new quarters, establish a scholarship fund and honor its former director, Philip Burton.

RED BANK, N.J., April 9 --Mr. and Mrs. Francis Lobdell have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Adams Lobdell, to Kingsley Chamberlain Norris 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley F. Norris of Locust.
CONCORD, N. H., April 9 (AP)--The New Hampshire House has passed, 337 to 5, a measure designed to lead toward annual sessions of the legislature.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Chicago's independent truck driver unions signed a new contract today with local carriers, nearly doubling the wage and fringe benefits that were included in the tentative agreement last week between the national trucking industry and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 9 --The eight Ivy League athletic directors concluded two days of fiscal meetings today aimed at finding ways to cut expenses.
WASHINGTON, April 9--The Senate called upon President Nixon today to propose to the Soviet Union an immediate suspension in further deployment of offensive and defensive strategic weapons.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (AP) -- Steve Whitaker's tworun single highlighted a fiverun eighth inning for San Francisco today as the Giants beat the Houston Astros, 7-4.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved a $4.1-biltion school money bill today, adding freedom-of-choice and antibusing amendments aimed at blunting the drive for desegregation.

WITH sailing places along the East Coast getting uglier and uglier, according to the American Littoral Society, boatyards and yacht clubs are now being shown what they can do about it. A southport, Conn., couple, not waiting for Earth Day (April 22), set sail last month
Reports from Saigon indicate that substantial numbers of South Vietnamese troops have been fighting alongside Cambodian forces against North Vietnamese and Vietcong units in Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, April 9--A spokesman for the Defense Department, in response to inquiries about an American officer seen in Cambodia, said today that military advisers in South Vietnam have been authorized to cross the border into Cambodia for "protocol" meetings.

Two new officials of the Environmental Protection Administration were sworn in at City Hall yesterday to enable the city to take swift action against a growing pollution danger-- insulating asbestos that is sprayed in the construction of new buildings.
Eleven pounds of pure cocaine, with a street value of more than $2.5-million, was seized yesterday afternoon in a raid at a midtown apartment house.

Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Robert H. Finch played a familiar role this week in upholding the views of a small and despondent liberal cell within the Administration when he pledged redoubled efforts to promote desegregation within the nation's schools.
The leaders of some newspaper unions showed impatience yesterday with the lack of progress on economic issues in their negotiations with the city's four major papers.

THERE have been no hairpulling matches about them. No sales campaigns. No fashion ambassadors such as Mrs. Georges Pompidou to help put them across. Even women who are ready to battle designers and stores about long hemlines for themselves, raise few objections if a man wears a midicoat.

Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., became the first publicly owned member of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday with the sale of 800,000 of its common shares through an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation.

A retrospective series of 90 Japanese feature films produced over the last 50 years, making it the most comprehensive showing in the history of the Museum of Modern Art, will be shown starting Sunday and continuing through July 20. Few ofthe films have ever been seen in this country. They represent the work of 32 directors.

Judge Justine Wise Polier of Family Court ruled yesterday that the mother of a 12-year-old boy who died last year of heroin poisoning could keep her remaining children with her, subject to court supervision.

FOR a while, it looked as if a nasty situation might be shaping up. There was Ocean Technology, a tiny Detroit-based mutual fund, with a fifth of its assets in a company called International Proteins.

WASHINGTON, April 9--Dr. Nahum Goldmann, a leading figure among an older generation of Zionists, is openly questioning whether the presentday state of Israel is truly the realization of the Zionist dream.
An attentive group of consumer-minded, and possibly consumer-wary, businessmen and women were given the following guidance yesterday by a vice president of a major retail-store complex:

DETROIT, April 9--The General Motors Corporation asked its stockholders today to vote against two proposals from The project on Corporate Responsibility, a committee interested in consumer affairs and the environment.

PARIS, April 9--Twentyfive newsmen covering the Vietnam peace talks here appealed to the four delegations today to do what they could to establish the whereabouts and to obtain the release of 10 journalists missing in Laos and Cambodia while on assignment.
If all there is to choral singing is limpid tone, transparent sonority, graceful nuance and accurate rhythm, the Madrigal Singers of Wahington University are a paragon of their kind.

NORWALK, Conn., April 9-- Dr. Jean Van Tassel Smith, state veterinarian for the Connecticut Department of Agricul-, ture and Natural Resources for the last 18 years, died today of a heart attack at Norwalk Hospital. He was 64 years old.
GEEVA, April 9--An intergovernmental European organization for the promotion of research into molecular biology has announced that Israel is being accepted as a member state.

Lee D. Sherman, president since 1939 of L. D. Sherman Co., Inc., 52 Broadway, dealer in over-the-counter securities, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 120 East 90th Street.

LINDEN, N.J., April 9--William G. Townsend, an assistant treasurer of the First National City Bank of New York, died yesterday at Memorial General Hospital, Union, after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived here at 66 Berlant Avenue.
Doris Hart, the top-ranking women's tennis player in the United States in 1954 and 1955, was named captain of the United States Wightman Cup team yesterday.
An East Harlem school district that had been testing school children for sickle cell anemia said it was told to stop by the state Department of Education, the program's sponsor.
Cash prices of soybean oil and meal were strong yesterday and this led to a demand for all soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9 --Mr, and Mrs. Robert E. Martin have announced the engagement of their daugher, Miss Ruth Victoria Martin, to William Samuel Kies 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kies Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Juno Beach, Fla.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- In a speech at George Washington University, Stokely Carmichael, black-militant spokesman today denounced Israel as a "colony of European Jews" illegally settled on Arab land.

THE spokes of a rapidly spinning wheel do not appear to be moving at all because motion viewed from sufficient distance creates the illusion of stillness. In her new novel, her first to appear in fifteen years, Eudora Welty has employed this principle of optics to remarkable effect.

Jasper Rhodes, a retired patrolman, said to be the third Negro to become a member of the New York Police Department, died Monday in Morrisania Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 938 St. Nicholas Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --Dr. Margaret Mead warned antipollution crusaders yesterday to avoid the doomsday approach for fear of straining credulityt or inducing a fatal istic belief the situation is beyond hope.
The American Stock Exchange's price-change index dropped to its lowest level in almost two years yesterday as the list continued to decline in slightly stepped-up trading.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Senator John G. Tower defended the F-111 attack plane today as the world's best for its mission.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Miss Terry Ellen Rhodes and Geoffrey Lewis Jr., who are working with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's Head Start project here, plan to be married in September.
The stock market was characterized yesterday by steadiness in the blue chips, a mixed pattern among the glamour issues and selling pressure on stocks of several companies with foreign interests.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 9 (AP)--Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard was buried here today following a private funeral service.

Miss Roberta Rosenstock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Rosenstock of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Thomas Platts-Mills, a physician. He is a son of John Platts-Mills, a lawyer and... former Labor member of Parliament, and Mrs. PlattsMills of London.

Dance Theater Workshop has a chameleon-like knock for interestingly diverse programming and last night at the Manhattan School of Music presented five works, four of which were premieres. They ranged in style from the casual "NonStructured Improvisation" of Art Bauman's to the 'precisely athletic "Poison Variations" of Elizabeth Keen's.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 9--Apollo 13 countdown preparations continued tonight, but mission officials were still not sure whether to attempt the launching on Saturday with a substitute astronaut or to postpone the moon-landing flight for a month.

Mayor Lindsay proposed a 75 per cent increase yesterday in taxes on resident job holders and an average 400 per cent rise in commuter levies. It appeared unlikely, however, that the plan would be approved by the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Nixon denounced today the Senators who rejected his two nominees to the Supreme Court and declared that the Senate as "presently constituted" would not approve a Southern conservative. Therefore, he said, he will look outside the South for a candidate to fill the vacancy on the Court.
BOSTON, April 9 (AP)--The transcript of testimony and the inquest report on the death of Mary Jo Kopechne may be released Wednesday, Superior Court Judge Wilfred J. Paquet ruled today.

LOS ANGELES, April 9 (UPI) --Johnny Bench broke up a scoreless game with a leadoff home run in the seventh and Wayne Simpson hurled a twohitter after retiring the first 16 men he faced in his first major league appearance tonight as the Cincinnati Reds scored 3-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Morris B. Abram, former president of Brandeis University, withdrew yesterday as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator and endorsed Theodore C. Sorensen.
STOCKHOLM, April 9 (Reuters)--Dr. Jerome H. Holland, the new United States Ambassador to Sweden, arrived here today and was met by scores of policemen and about 100 demonstrators at the airport.
CAIRO, April 9--The United States was accused here today

BUFFALO, April 9--Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the author and critic, and his wife were found guilty by a six-man jury today of maintaining premises where marijuana was used, a misdemeanor for which they could be sentenced to a year in jail.
The London stock market moved moderately higher yesterday as selective demand offset uncertainties over the new national budget.

Herman Badillo, the former Bronx Borough President, announced his candidacy for the House of Representatives yesterday in the new 21st Congressional District, which includes parts of the Bronx, Manhattan and Queens.
The world rights to "Stomp," the multimedia protest musical environment entertainment, have been acquired by Michael Butler, producer of "Hair."

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP)--Pit Martin's tie-breaking goal with less than 5 minutes to play and Dennis Hull's insurance score with a little more than a minute left lifted the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in a quarterfinal game of the Stanley Cup playoff.
BOCA RATON, Fla., April 9 --Alfred A. Roetken, a former radio consultant at Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., died Tuesday at his home here. He was 67 years old.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 9-- The Laotian Government today formally answered the Pathet Lao's terms for peace with counterproposals that showed wide divergence between the views of the two sides and left scant prospects of an early settlement of the war.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Joseph D. Tydings urged President Nixon today to withdraw one of the two American infantry divisions in South Korea as evidence of his intention to implement the Nixon Doctrine of reducing the American military presence in Asia.

PARIS, April 9--Le Duc Tho, a member of the politburo of North Vietnam's Workers' (Communist) party and a key figure in the negotiations that led to the agreement to hold peace talks, will return to Hanoi tomorrow without having made contact with the American delegation during his stay here of more than two months.
A tense truce went into effect at Hunter College yesterday following the suspension of classes at noon.

GEORGE SZELL rounded out his New York Phil harmonic season last night with a program by that perennial best-seller, Beethoven. There was not a vacant seat in the house, and outside Philharmonic Hall people were pleading for tickets. Part of the frenzy, of course, could be attributed to the conductor. Mr. Szell is believed by many to be the greatest living Beethoven specialist.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 10 (AP) Brian Fairlie of New Zealand upset fourth-seeded Tom Edlefsen of Los Angeles, 6-2, 6-4, today to gain the semifinals of the Masters invitation tennis match.
A young woman, member of the crew of a Soviet fishing trawler, was evacuated by a Coast Guard helicopter yesterday afternoon.

The London stock market closed quietly lower yesterday. Pre-budget uncertainties again came to the fore and checked the mild rally that had developed near the close on Thursday. The new national budget will be announced next Tuesday.
A leading British car manufacturer has issued a call for international standards governing automotive safety, noise and exhaust emissions.

EARLIER this season there was a play called "The Jumping Fool," in which a man having a nervous breakdown is obsessed by an acrobat. Last night a play called "And I Met a Man" opened and in it a woman having a nervous breakdown is possessed by a guru. Beneath the overplay of mysticism both are small domestic traumas.
Cardinal Cooke called passage of the abortion bill in Albany yeterday a "threat to our state and our country" and a "direct attack on the sanctity of human life and the welfare of our society."

BALTIMORE, April 10 (UPI) Brooks Robinson's two-out single in the bottom of the 10th scored Frank Robinson from second base to lift the Baltimore Orioles to a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers today in their home opener before a crowd of 33,638.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 10 (UPI) Governor Kirk allowed Federal marshals to serve subpoenas on nine of his aides today and told the Supreme Court there was "grave danger of loss of life" among both Federal and state officials in the school confrontation.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, warned yesterday that the possibility of a shutdown of the newspaper was "rapidly approaching" because of a labor crisis.
FIGHT women sat upright and fiercely attentive in the living room of a midtown Manhattan apartment one evening last week. They were sustained by coffee and mutual need.

TRIPOLI, Libya, April 5 More than a half a year after a handful of angry young officers overthrew the Libyan monarchy, their proudest accomplishment remains the rather quick agreement by the United States and Britain to withdraw from their military bases.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 10 At least 89 Vietnamese civilians, including many women and children, were killed late last night during what Cambodian military sources described as a Vietnamese Communist attack on the border village of Prasot.

Three new tax proposals that would affect city motorists were proposed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay the first installment of a budget-balancing package that city officials were working out in private negotiations with aides of Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The Army today ordered hearings to determine if Capt. Ernest L. Medina will be courtmartialed on charges in connection with the alleged massacre at Songmy, South Vietnam.

GUATEMALA, April 10 (AP) Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany delivered a protest today to the President of Guatemala for having failed to prevent the terrorist killing of Bonn's mbassador, Count Karl von Spreti.

Samuel Joseph Melville, already under a Federal indictment alleging that he conspired to bomb Government property here, was indicted by a New York County grand jury yesterday that accused him of having a role in the bombings of six buildings in the summer and fall of 1969.
ROME, April 10 Premier Mariano Rumor's two-week-old Cabinet won its first vote of confidence in the Italian Senate today.

HOLLYWOOD, April 10 (AP) Cobina Wright, former society hostess of prominence, who later turned to journalism and wrote of both the Hollywood scene and of cultural happenings, died yesterday after having suffered a stroke on Easter Sunday. Her age was never made public.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 10 (AP) A South Vietnamese relief battalion fought its way into the American-led camp at Dakseang today, easing a 10day enemy siege. But to the north near the demilitarized zone, North Vietnamese attacked another outpost led by American Green Berets.

ALBANY, April 10 The advice and pressure on Assemblymen who voted for and against abortion reform yesterday were as personal as a midnight chat with a wife and as sensitive as a personal call from a monsignor.
PARIS, April 10 Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., sought today to reassure its salesmen and investors of the soundness of its operations.
VIENNA, April 10 Gogo Nushi, an Albanian Communist leader who had belonged to the French Communist party before World War II, died in Tirana yesterday at the age of 56.

Jack Moore is a choreographer who combines mystical calm with muscular balance and last night at the Manhattan School of Music he presented the New York premiere of his three-part dance "Rocks," a piece for six girls and three men, which he originally showed three years ago at Bennington College.
NHONTRACH, South Vietnam, April 8 Phuhoi and Nhonthanh are two villages only a few miles apart in the Nhontrach district southeast of Saigon.
The downward trend continued unabated on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as prices fell to a two-year low in quiet trading.

The New York City Ballet orchestra has authorized its negotiating committee, deadlocked in labor talks with the ballet management since November, to call a strike "if it became necessary," the musicians' attorney said yesterday.

Lawrence K. Grossman, president of Forum Communications, Inc., the challenger in the WPIX, Channel 11, broadcastlicense contest, asserted yesterday that the forthcoming hearings on the dispute would test for the first time the Federal Communications Commission's recent ruling that requires that licensees show "substantial and solid performance" before they receive renewals.

WASHINGTON, April 10 A key staff member of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, while expressing objections to some aspects of pending legislation on onebank holding companies, said today that there was a no alternative to enactment of legal resrictions on holding company acquisitions.

WASHINGTON, April 10 The nation's unemployment rate rose further in March, to 4.4 per cent of the labor force from 4.2 per cent in February, the Labor Department re ported today. At 3,733,000, the number of people out of work last month was a little below the February level. But normally there is a big drop in March; thus, on a seasonally adjusted basis, the unemployment rate rose again.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) A campaign aide of the murdered mine union candidate, Joseph A. Yablonski, filed an unfair labor practice charge today against the United Mine Workers for requiring retired miners to pay union dues to qualify for pensions.
I.B.M. was the star of a drab stock market yesterday, while American Telephone showed weakness in the final session before terms of its huge financing are set.

H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who has made two trips to Southeast Asia on behalf of American war prisoners, returned from the second trip yesterday and said he believed public opinion in the United States could change North Vietnam's views and might even obtain release of some of the 1,500 American prisoners believed to be held in North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Three professional organizations denounced today a proposal, which has won President Nixon's personal interest, to predict potential criminality by giving psychological tests to every 6, 7, and 8 year old child.

CAIRO, April 10 Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco arrived in Cairo tonight for talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser and other Egyptians on the complex aspects of a peaceful settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
An industrial chemical called FCB, which is chemically similar to DDT, has worried scientists for some time because, like DDT, it is persistent and can hamper the reproductive capacity of animals.
NEW HAVEN, April 10 Three Black Panthers pleaded not guilty today to kidnapping and murdering Alex Rackley, a Panther who was suspected of being an informer for the police.
Donnie Marshall, one of the Rangers' senior citizens, came tripping down the stairs into the locker room after the team's workout yesterday, sat down across from Ed Giacomin and told the goalie:
MEXICO CITY, Appril 10 (UPI) Twenty entries, including American Eagle, were set to start tomorrow in the Sol Al Sol Regatta from St. Petersburg, Fla., to Isla Mujeres, Mexico.
A new dance work by Phyllis Lamhut, "Extended Voices," or the choreographer a comedienne, was presented last night at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse.

SKAGWAY, Alaska About 750 persons live in this dusty port town ringed by snowcapped mountains and most depend for their livelihood on the one-track railroad that snakes southward through the Coast Mountains from the Yukon, bringing minerals to the tidewater.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 There was one mystery at the Masters golf tournament today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP) Woody Fryman held the Pittsburgh Pirates without a hit for 7 1/3 innings and finished with a four-hitter today as Philadelphia Phillies triumphed, 2-0, on Deron Johnson's two-run homer.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., April 10 Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiaries plan to spend a record total of $135.4-million on expansion over the next five years, Charles H. Tenney 2d, chairman, told some 225 stockholders at today's annual meeting at the company's headquarters. He indicated that $35-million would be spent this year and $100-million over the next four years.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Peter C. Goldmark, pres ident of C.B.S. Laboratories, and three co-inventors were granted a patent this week for a teaching machine that has enabled pupils in a Brooklyn school to improve their reading skill. Called the AVS10, the portable audio-visual device protected by Patent 3,504,445 is about the size of an overnight case and can be used on a desk top.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 10 (AP) A helicopter hovering over the Apollo 13 spaceship after it lands in the Pacific April 21 hopes to relay the first live closeup television pictures of the recovery of a team of American astronauts.

HOUSTON, April 10 The scientific experiments to be carried out by the Apollo 13 astronauts and by means of the instruments they leave on the moon may prove to be the most revealing in man's early exploration of that body.
Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan yesterday approved the sale of R. Hoe Co.'s press division to Wood Industries, Inc. R. Hoe has been in Chapter 10 reorganization proceedings since last July.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The Treasury Department approved today the first merger of New Jersey's "grossly undersized" banks under the state's new branching and merger law. The law divides the state into three banking districts.

VIENIANE, Laos, April 10 The Laotian Government made public today the text of a letter delivered to the local Pathet Lao representative yesterday in which the Government proposed a cease-fire and the immediate supervised withdrawal of all foreign military forces from Laos.
WASHINGTON, April 10 The Food and Drug Administration has taken a step toward re-evaluating a large number of food additives authorized as usable between 1938 and 1958.

VILA, New Hebrides, March 26 Growing political consciousness has become a strange new force in the normally placid life of these coconut-growing and cattleraising islands governed jointly by Britain and France.

Confrontation eyeball to Adam's apple with basketball's basic problem begins for the New York Knickerbockers today when they face supertall Lew Alcindor and the Milwaukee Bucks in the opening game of a fourof-seven National Basketball Association playoff series.
ALBANY, April 10 Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed the abortion reform bill today.

The brief grand jury "investigation" into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne has ended with no indictments and no diminution of the mystery surrounding the plunge from a narrow bridge on Chappaquiddick Island last summer of a car driven by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

TORONTO, April 10 (UPI) Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan announced a ban today on fishing in Lake St. Clair and the St. Clair River "as a precautionary measure" due to contamination there. Canada ordered a ban last week.
Three house tours here, today, tomorrow and Tuesday, will raise money for two schools and the Mount Holyoke Club of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 10 United Fund and Community Chest organizations were told today that they would lose the support of big business unless they redirected their efforts toward the human issues behind national protests.
IF you have bought mutual fund shares since the be ginning of 1969, chances are your head is bloody, even bowed.

FOR the past four years, summer travelers at Ken nedy Airport have been startled to see dozens of teenagers trouping through the terminal carrying ski equipment, High school students, they are members of Ski Tour Camp, Inc., a group that skis through June and into August in the French, Swiss and Italian Alps when the rest of the world seems to be heading for the beach.
DETROIT, April 10 (AP) The tempo of United States auto production picked up a bit this week but output for the year to date still was more than 500,000, cars behind last year's pace.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Vice President Agnew charged today that the Senate had rejected the nomination of G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court on the basis of "subjective judgements" after its members had been "snowed" by material in "the liberal media" and subjected to "formidable, almost incredible pressures from organized labor and civil rights activists.

WASHINGTON, April 10 When the Apollo 13 astronauts touch down on the moon Wednesday they are expected to land in a gently rolling, crater-pocked upland region where the surface has been largely intact for four billion years.

The staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art informally started the museum's centennial birthday celebration yesterday afternoon, undeterred by the absence of a malfunctioning 25feet-tall birthday cake especially constructed for the occasion and for a candle-lighting ceremony on its pinnacle.
LONDON, April 10 Labor party gains in voting for the Greater London Council raised the Government's hopes today and increased the possibility of an early general election.
William T. Smith, a vice president of Dominick Dominick, Inc., an investment banking and brokerage firm, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 200 East 64th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 10 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to repeal the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution, which was frequently cited by President Johnson as Congressional authorization for the United States military involvement in Vietnam.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 10 (AP) James A. Lovell Jr. and Fred W. Haise Jr., Apollo 13 astronauts will be able to take sips of water when they walk on the moon's surface.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 Miss Barbara Louise McKenna and Bruce Wiegand plan to be married July 18 in the Heinz Chapel. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William J. McKenna, parents of the brideto-be, whose fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Louis Wiegand Jr.

YONKERS, April 10 Lucky Creed was one of 20 Australian standardbreds that arrived at Kennedy airport this morning. All 20 were vanned to the United States Department of Agriculture quarantine station at Clifton, N.J.

Activities. The President greeted West German Chancellor Willy Brandt and gave a state dinner in honor of the Chancellor and Mrs. Brandt. Later in the afternoon, the President met with Laurance S. Rockefeller, chairman of the Citizens' Committee on Environmental Quality.

The New York Shipping Association lost an appeal yesterday from a Federal District Court ruling that ordered it and the International Longshoremen's Association to stop inducing others in the Port of New York not to do business with an independent containercargo consolidator.
TAMPA, Fla., April 10 While a student at the University of Florida in the late nineteen-thirties, Isaac Benjamin Krentzman Jr. began a lasting friendship with a young man named George A. Smathers.

After years of patient effort and emotion-charged debate, New York State is expected soon to have on the books an abortion-reform law that leaves the decision on abortions, up to the 24th week of pregnancy, where it rightfully belongs with the woman and her physician.
ST. LOUIS, April 10 Richie Allen, Astroturf and the New York Mets made their debuts in the home of the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, and the Mets came off second best.

Justice William O. Douglas had a cautionary word yesterday for detractors upset by his latest book, which warns that violence may prove to be "the only effective response" to the country's ills. He said they would like his future writings even less.

CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) John Kinsella, a Hinsdale (Ill.) High School senior, posted his second free-style victory in consecutive nights tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championship.
Chicago trucking companies locked out 32,000 drivers yesterday in an effort to counter the divide-and-conquer tactics of union negotiators trying to wreck a tentative national wage agreement.

Benjamin Altman, the city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, said yesterday that a ceiling of 3.3 per cent on rent increases seemed to be in order to allow landlords to pay expected wage rises for building maintenance employes, whose contracts expire April 20. The present ceiling is 2.5 per cent.

Fried. Krupp G.m.b.H., the huge German industrial complex whose financial woes in the nineteen sixties helped end the absolute family control of the company, has completed a phase of consolidation and is now looking for renewed expansion.

DETROIT Barry Robinson sat in a friend's small room over a used furniture store, looked down at the floor and said in despair: "Just about the time I got straightened out they laid me off. I'm out on the street again."
The executive committee of the Needham Packing Company, Inc., announced yesterday the resignation of James L. Needham as president and chief executive officcer, effective immediately.

WASHINGTON, April 10 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the settlement of a suit involving alleged sale of unregistered securities by the former management of the Goldfield Corporation.

LONDON Robert H. Jackson, who lived through the great Roosevelt struggle over the Supreme Court and later became a Justice himself, regarded the Court's survival as something of a phenomenon. The Court had been in controversy again and again in our history, he said. Popular Presidents attacked it, the public repudiated certain decisions. Yet the institution lived.

SPACE CENTER, Houston, April 10 (UPI) One man from the first two American moon landing crews has left the space program for a job elsewhere in Government. The five others remain eligible for repeat moon flight assignments, and one of them, Richard F. Gordon, is on the backup crew for Apollo 15 next year.

WASHINGTON, Apri1 10 (AP) The National Portrait Gallery unveiled last night a portrait, painted from life, of Harry S. Truman. The portrait was shown at a reception attended by many members of Mr. Truman's Cabinet and one of his admirers, former President Lyndon B.Johnson.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 Behind him, against a backdrop of towering pine trees, was the tee sign. In its center, painted in green on a white background, was a circled "16," above that it read "190 yds" and below, "par 3."
One of the most eagerly awaited first public stock offerings in years failed to kindle a spark in the new issue market this week.

ALBANY, April 10 The State Senate, after more than two hours of quiet but emotional debate, voted 31 to 26 today to accept an Assembly bill that strikes the state's 140-year-old abortion law from the books.
HOUSTON, April 10 (AP) Dr. Frank E. Vandiver has resigned as acting president of the Rice University but the school's trustees apparently have not rejected or acccpted the resignation.

Robert Rice, the first of the so-called "Harlem Six" defendants to be retried for the 1964 slaying of a Hungarian shopkeeper and the knifing of her husband, has again seen convicted of first-degree murder.
MADRID, April 10 The political difficulties faced by the Spanish Government increased today with the reported resignation of the Public Works Minister, Federico Silva Munoz.

Winthrop Knowlton, executive vice president of Harper Row, was elected president and chief executive officer of the 152-year-old book publishing company yesterday in a special meeting of the board of directors.
EUROPE will be the scene of much international bridge activity this year.
A pair of prizefighters from Washington restored a measure of fistic prestige to the National Capitol last night in The Felt Forum by scoring convincing knockout victories.

WASHINGTON, April 10 The available clues suggest that President Nixon thought himself caught in another of his self-conscious "crises" when the Senate rejected the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court.
JERUSALEM, Apil 10 Fighting was renewed on the Israeli-Jordanian front today with heavy shelling of Israeli settlements and an air strike against Jordan.

The Columbia varsity crew, which won two races over half a dozen southern eights during its spring vacation period in Florida, will row against the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today in the feature event on the Harlem River.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 10 Apollo 13 was cleared today for launching here tomorrow afternoon with a substitute pilot in the spacecraft's center seat for the nation's third manned mission to the moon.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Several hundred residents of the New York City metropolitan area marched near the Capitol today to urge stronger efforts by the Federal government to combat the narcotics traffic.

THIS weekend Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company completes its second New York season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It performs tonight and twice tomorrow. You should go and see it. In the present day and age o feconomic pressures, quite frankly, you may never have another chance. For that matter you may never deserve another chance.

LONDON, April 10 (UPI) Three weeks ago the Leeds United soccer team would have been a firm favorite to beat Chelsea in tomorrow's Football Association Cup final. Now Leeds is no better than even money.
LEVITTOWN, Pa., April 10 Rabbi Herbert Hendel, spiritual leader of Temple Shalom, died of a heart attack yesterday at Lower Bucks County Hospital. He was 53 years old.

PARIS, April 10 Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Vetnamese Politburo left here today for Moscow and Hanoi after a two-month stay. As he left, he warned France against supporting the new leadership in Cambodia.
MONTPELIER, Vt., April 10 Lieut. Gov. Thomas L. Hayes, conceding that he would be a "distinct underdog," announced today he would challenge Gov. Deane C. Davis in the Republican primary this year.

Eastern Airlines, following the slaying of one of its copilots last month, has started a broad new security program to deter hijackings. A byproduct of the tightened antihijacking security efforts has been the apprehension of passengers carrying narcotics and of fugitives from the police.

MOSCOW, April 10 The Soviet Union marked Astronautics Day today with a Kremlin meeting extolling Soviet space exploits, but the attention of Western diplomats was focused on a Politburo member, Aleksandr N. Shelepin, who made his first public appearance in more than a month.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 10 The Smithtown Unit of the American Cancer Society will welcome 450 guests tomorrow to its Jewel Ball, at the Smith-Haven Mall on Jericho Turnpike, an event planned for only 400 guests. Tickets to the ball $25 each.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department has decided to review its longstanding regulations allowing beef processors to carve out "cancer eye" and similar tumors from cattle and sell the rest of the meat to consumers.
The International Business Machines Corporation resumed its advance in gross income and earnings in the first quarter this year following the slight decline shown in the final quarter of 1969.

LAFAYETTE, Calif., April 10 Miss Amy Melville Furth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Furth, plans to be married in May to Frank Forrester Church 4th, son of Senator and Mrs. Church of Boise, Idaho, and Bethesda, Md.

TAMPA, Fla., April 10 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. vacated the Manatee County school board offices tonight, but neither he nor his staff would say if he was giving up his defiance of court orders imposing racial integration in the county's schools.

With air travel curtailed over much of the nation for the third consecutive weekend, there was no sign of a break yesterday in the 17-day deadlock between the Federal Aviation Administration and the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today a 1970 winter wheat crop of 1,065,000000 bushels, down 7 per cent from last year's production of 1,147,646,000 bushels.

"THE ART OF ANCIENT ITALY," an exhibition of sculpture, frescoes and decorative objects dating as early as the eighth century B.C., is currently being shown at the Andre Emmerich Gallery where contemporary art is usually featured.
HOUSTON, April 10 (UPI) Henry Aaron hit the 13th grandslam home run of his career, most among active players, to give the Atlanta Braves a 5-0 victory tonight over Houston in the Astros' home opener.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 10 Mrs. Laura Weinstein Perelman, wife of S.J. Perelman, the humorist, author and playwright, died here today at the Hunterdon Medical Center. She was 58 years old and lived in Erwinna, Pa.

BOSTON, April 10 Therapeutic abortions can be performed simply, safely and inexpensively without requiring overnight hospitalization of the woman, a California medical team has concluded after a sixmonth study of the procedure.
Howard (Buddy) Jacobson's attorney said yesterday he felt the controversial trainer should abandon the court appeal of his 45-day suspension by the New York State Racing Commission.

PRICES are dancing around as much as hemlines on Seventh Avenue these days, except that the hemline movement is mostly downward. The cost of clothes, like everything else, is going up, but manufacturers are finding various means of countering this trend.

ALBANY, April 10 The Assembly, in a waspish session that haggled on late into the evening, today passed a bill requiring colleges that receive state funds to suspend students convicted of offenses committed on campus.
LONDON, April 10 Paul McCartney said today he had broken with the Beatles over a series of differences.
The faculty members of Hunter College High School have voted to grant student demands for equal representation with teachers on governing boards at the school.

John de J. Pemberton Jr. announced yesterday that he was resigning as executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, the country's leading organization in its field.

TOKYO, April 10 Premier Eisaku Sato warned the Japanese people today against "great-powerism." While praising the quantitative economic successes of the last decade, he said the nineteen-seventies should be devoted to building up social capital and in solving the problems of modern socity high prices, pollution, dehumanization and the generation gap.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 Bob Goalby and Roberto de Vicenzo, who were involved in the memorable scorecard controversy here two years ago, were among several noted golfers who failed to qualify today for the final 36 holes of the Masters golf tournament.

DURBAN, South Africa, April 10 (Reuters) The former Wimbledon champions, Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia and Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., qualified today to meet in the women's singles final of the Natal open tennis championships.

At first glance the cavernous third-floor gallery of the Whitney Museum looks as if Uris Brothers had moved in with a load of raw matterials for a construction project. MIAMI, April 10 (UPI) Federal Judge Charles Fulton has agreed with Pan American World Airways that Celio Diaz Jr. just did not qualify as a stewardess.
sixteen students from 15 to 19 years old attending James Madison High School in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn were arrested yesterday for allegedly either selling or possess ing heroin.

MIAMI, April 10 Maj. William Kennelly, a New York real estate executive and former president of the New York Athletic Club, died of cancer at the Veterans Hospital here yesterday. He was 84 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale. He leaves his wife, the former Marian H. Paine.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 10 The Rhodesian Front party, led by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, was overwhelmingly returned to power today in elections for a new republican parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Leaders of the bipartisan opposition in the Senate that defeated Judge G. Harrold Carswell urged President Nixon today to reconsider his decision not to nominate a Southerner to the Supreme Court.

Many of Columbia University's leading scholars and teachers have formed an organization of tenured faculty members to fight campus violence, which they attribute to "the actions of a minuscule group of extremists."
WASHINGTON, April 14 The Government unofficially estimated today that retail sales last month were $29,877billion seasonally adjusted, down slightly from $29,942billion in February.

The Excelsior Handicap, for older horses at a mile and an eighth, will occupy the main spot in the Aqueduct card today. A field of nine has been named for the event, which will have its 62d running. With nine competing, the Excelsior will have a gross value of $57,800, the winner getting $37,570.

The Time-Life News Service said yesterday that representatives of the North Vietnamese Government and of the Vietcong had agreed to make inquiries into the disappearance of a number of newsmen on assignment in Laos and Cambodia.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa-- Southern Africa is not just South Africa. There are three fascinating backwaters that can be visited quickly and economically from a Johannesburg base: Swaziland, Lesotho and Botswana. All three are within about an hour's flight from Johannesburg's Jan Smuts International Airport at a cost of under $60 for the round trip.

THE United Nations will issue two types of medals to mark its 25th anniversary this year. There will be a limited number of solid sterling silver pieces released on April 25 to commemorate the opening of the United Nations Conference on International Organization, held in California in 1945.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 11--Seton Hall University capitalized on 20 hits, eight walks, a hit batsman and six Fairleigh Dickinson errors today for a 23-0 Metropolitan Conference baseball victory. It was the third straight triumph for the Pirates, whose won-lost mark is 4-2.

AMONG the painters who made up the original Impressionist group, the oldest was Camill Pissarro. He was born in 1830 and died in 1903. John Rewald has called him "the dean of the Impressionist painters," and he certainly occupies a special position in the history of the movement.

THE standard choral works stay with us, more or less. But in an unusual combination of events, New York will be hearing three brand new, full-scale compositions for chorus and orchestra next Friday and Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11-- Tiny Dropsie University, a community of scholars, will announce at a 60th anniversary diner Tuesday the creation of a Center for the Study of Communication of Man's Humanity.

With the blessings of Mayor Lindsay, whose service is improving, and Commission August Heckscher, whose game is rated just fair, the Parks Department opened its 503 tennis courts for the outdoor season yesterday.

For the last 134 years Manhattan's Union Theological Seminary has been sending out socially conscious graduates-- including war critic William Sloane Coffin Jr. and Chicago Seven defendant David Dellinger--to do battle at the front lines of protest and social change.

WILKINSON Sword Tools, manufactured in England, have introduced a small solid stainless steel digging fork, called the border fork. It has a four-tined head that is eight and three-quarter inches long; over-all weight is three pounds. The tubular steel shaft is sleeved in tough plastic and strong polypropylene hand grips provide added comfort. $44.95. (Wilkinson Sword, Inc. 1121 Bristol Road, Mountainside, N.J. 07092.)

WASHINGTON, April 11-- Spokesmen for the coal mining industry complained today that new Federal regulations to protect the health and safety of mine workers were paralyzing production, forcing hundreds of small mines to close and hastening the likelihood of disruptions in coal-fueled electrical service to millions of consumers.
LANSING, Mich., April 11-- Rebellion flared in the Michigan Legislature this week over steps by the Detroit authorities to decentralize and integrate further the city's 295,000-pupil school system.

TANCANH, South Vietnam, April 11 (AP)--The North Vietnamese still have 1,500 soldiers around the shell-battered Special Forces camp at Dakseang, and a South Vietnamese general warned today that new attacks might come in a week.

DESIGNS of the two additional United Nations stamps valid for use only at its Ge neva, Switzerland, headquarters, and of a pair of stamps with the theme "Fight Cancer," have been released by Robert W. Maxwell, Chief, United Nations Postal Administration.
BELLEVILLE, Ill., April 11 (AP)--America's four outstanding young farmers were named here this week by representatives of the United States Jaycees.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11-- Thomas A. Marshall Jr., man aging director of the American Society for Testing and Materials, died Thursday of cancer in Hahnemann Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Radnor.

In a bleak time, the career of Eudora Welty is instructive. Her dedication and artistic integrity, her clarity of vision, her persistence are altogether remarkable. Since 1936, when her first story was published, she has given us four books of stories, two novellas, a novel, several uncollected stories in The New Yorker over the past few years, and now "Losing Battles," a major work of the imagination and a gift to cause general rejoicing.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., April 11--James C. Sheers, a producer and writer of television documentaries, died at the General Hospital here Thursday night of injuries from a fall at a friend's home here last Saturday. He was 45 years old, and lived at 337 Old Long Ridge Road in Stanford.

ALMOST the eeriest thing that happened at the opening performance of Harold Pinter's two new plays, "Silence" and "Landscape," at the Forum here was the sound of one man--one man only--applauding as the lights went up to start the evening. The man continued to applaud though no one joined him. By the time he had subsided, the mood of the plays--faraway, echochambered, discontinuous, gray on white--had been established as if by prearranged collusion.

Dr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Lowy of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Renee Lowy to Richard Alexander Adler, son of Mrs. Ira Guilden of New York and Sidney Adler of Los Angeles.
TOKYO, April 11 (AP)--The 1970 Japanese professional baseball season opened today with only one game played at Fukuoka in southern Japan. The five other scheduled games were rained out.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11-- Just as he did a year ago, Billy Casper led the Masters golf field today after 54 holes by a one-stroke margin on a total of 208.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 11-- Cornell's lightweight oarsmen opened their season today by sweeping both races from Pennsylvania and regaining the Matthews Cup. The Quakers took the cup for the first time last year.

Soon he was completely visible, his face swinging from side to side in that familiar march that has appeared on television sets on an almostweekly basis for more than a decade.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 12 (AP) Cesare Maniago, Minnesota goalie, foiled the highscoring St. Louis skaters and Bill Goldsworthy continued his torrid scoring pace as the North Stars defeated the St. Louis Blues, 4-0, today to even their West Division National Hockey League Stanley Cup series at two games apiece.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 (AP) Maj, Hugh A. Davis, 37 years old, an Air Force pilot assigned to a support squadron at Tansonnhut Air Base in Saigon, was found innocent today of smuggling opium from Thailand, but was convicted of illegal possession of United States currency.

Buoyed by two consecutive top-notch performances in games that called for nothing less, the New York Knicks will attempt to sustain their momentum and maintain the home-court advantage as they face the Milwaukee Bucks tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Mrs. Estelle Mulqueen Reilly, an author and a leader in Roman Catholic charity work, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 1 Lexington Avenue. Her husband, John S. Reilly, is a retired food company executive.

Thomas Schmidt, the pianist, presented himself last night in Carnegie Recital Hall for his New York solo debut. Although not a demon virtuoso at the keyboard, he commands an efficient technical facility. He maneuvered his way through a difficult program with ease and assurance.

Free time on export cargo at the Port of New York and Philadelphia has been fixed by the Federal Maritime Commission at a maximum of 10 days, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays.

LONDON One of the great joys of England, and surprises, is the survival of rural villages unspoiled by the industrial revolution or the population curve or even the automobile. A few miles from a main road, among the farms, one comes upon a small street of stone houses and an old church-a village with a sense of historical identity, the sort of place whose eccentricities Miss Jane Marple would enjoy.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 A pair of golfing pals, Billy Casper and Gene Littler, will play off for the Masters title tomorrow. The Californians, who learned the game as juniors in the San Diego area, finished with 72-hole totals of 279.

WASHINGTON, April 12 Earl Foreman, owner of the Washington Capitols of the American Basketball Association, said tonight that the announcement yesterday of a merger agreement between the committees of his league and the National Basketball Association was "premature."

JERUSALEM, April 12 The Israeli Cabinet decided today that a rare collection of Egyptian papyrus documents offered for sale in Jerusalem was authentic, generally in excellent condition but too highly priced.
WARREN, N.J., April 12 C. Earl Moran of Mountain Avenue, who retired in 1958 as secretary-treasurer of the Anaconda Company, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Scotch Plains. He was 78 ears old.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., April 12 (AP) Michael A. Donaldson, who was awarded the Medal of Honor for rescuing six men from enemy fire in World War I, died at the Veteran's Administration Hospital in Montrose today. He was 86 years old.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 12 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr., faced with the threat of fines of $10,000 a day for contempt of court, bowed tonight to the power of the Federal courts and said that he would return control of Manatee County schools to local officials.
HONOLULU, April 8 They drift along on Kalakaua Avenue in Waikiki on Saturday night, wandering with the crowd and watching the hours slip through their fingers.

It will be said once again, with a condescending indulgence which honest members of the student generation ought to resent, that because legitimate grievances had existed, the lawlessness was a necessary prelude to reform.
Plans for an expansion program that would provide more than a third again as much space for the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been completed.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (AP) John Bench's two-run, sixth inning triple and the steady pitching of Gary Nolan led the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-2 victory and a sweep of their double-header with the San Francisco Giants today.
