ATHENS, April 12 The chief defendant in the Athens sedition trial was sentenced to life in prison today and 26 of the 33 other defendants were also found guilty.
The funeral of John O'Hara will be held at noon Thursday at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. Dr. Ernest Gordon, the chaplain of the university, will conduct the service.

BALTIMORE, April 12 (UPI) Joe Niekro allowed six hits in 8 2-3 innings and got a tworun triple during a five-run fourth-inning outburst today to score his second straight victory as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 7-2.

The National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing said in a report last week that the exclusion of blacks and Puerto Ricans from housing in the suburbs has created labor shortages in new factories springing up around New York City.
MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) Today was National Astronauts Day in the Soviet Union, but Russians found little to celebrate as Apollo 13 headed toward the moon.

A TEAM led by Stephen Dunko of New York won a decisive victory in the finals of the Greater New York Bridge Association's double knockout championship played here Saturday. This event, which has been in progress for six months, is limited to players with less than 100 Master points and is therefore dominated by those with limited experience but much enthusiasm.
The chairman of the state Public Service Commission declared yesterday that "the gas supply situation in New York is tight."

ABADAN, Iran, April 12 In an unusual move, the Western governments of the international oil companies operating in Iran may be called in to provide economic aid to help meet part of the $1,155,000,000 oil revenues being demanded by the Iranian Government for the coming year.
Dr. James A. Oliver, a former director of the Bronx Zoo and of the American Museum of Natural History, has been appointed director of the New York Aquarium, to succeed Dr. Ross F. Nigrelli on June 1.

EVER since he was a boy in Chicago in the nineteen-twenties, and the pet of the boarders in his mother's work ing-class rooming house, Louis "Studs" Terkel has been listening in on people and transmitting their sound. For years he has jockeyed his own disk show, "The Wax Museum," on Chicago's station ...

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) The Government reported "a continuing improvement" today in the situation caused by the "sick-out" of the nation's air traffic controllers, ordered by a Federal judge to return to work or produce evidence that they were really ill.

ADVENTURES in television are not exactly numerous. Late yesterday afternoon there was offered something of a small feast in the offbeat, not all readily comprehensible and subject as usual to the demand that the viewer divine what the producer had in mind.

HOUSTON, April 12 The Apollo 13 astronauts cruised quietly and smoothly toward the moon today, passing the halfway point in their outbound voyage before sharpening their aim with a short blast of the spaceship's rocket.
DARIEN, Conn., April 12 Talisman, Robin Bacon's smartstepping 6-year-old chestnut gelding, won his fifth championship in six shows this season today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.
PARIS, April 8 Alcoholism, wild driving and housewives worries contribute to what the Government has now declared to be one of France's main problems the sparseness of the country's population.

The Chicago area trucking industry continued its lockout of 35,000 drivers yesterday, the eve of a threatened all-out strike by local teamsters demanding a wage settlement higher than that in a proposed national contract.

The 25th anniversary of Richard Tucker's debut at the Metropolitan Opera was celbrated by the company Saturday night with a gala program featuring the tenor in acts from three operas with which he has been closely identified during his long Metropolitan tenure.
JERUSALEM, April 12 An Arab resident of the Gaza Strip was shot and killed today by Israeli soldiers, adding to one of the highest death tolls in the Arab-Israeli conflict.
"It was 25 years ago to the day and I remember I seized the loudspeaker and began shouting: 'You are free.'"

JERUSALEM, Monday, April 13 Israeli spokesmen were unavailable early today for comment, but it was apparent that the site shown to foreign correspondents by Egyptian authorities as the one hit in an Israeli raid last Wednesday was not the one that the Israelis said they had hit.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 12 Colombia today ended a presidential campaign that had become a class struggle without benefit of Karl Marx.
Victor Trivas, a screenwriter and artist, died of a heart attack at his home, 315 East 72d Street, yesterday. He was 74 years old.

EVANSTON, Ill., April 12 Supporters of Dr. Gregory C. Coffin, superintendent of Evanston's elementary schools, were defeated last night in a bitterly fought school board election that has polarized this affluent Chicago suburb.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 (UPI) Wes Parker singled in two men to lead a four-run first inning that started the Los Angeles Dodgers off to a 6-0 victory over the San Diego Padres today. The triumph snapped, a five-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, accused the White House today of suppressing an Administration-requested report that concludes that the supersonic transport, in Mr. Reuss's words, "is economically wasteful and environmentally harmful."

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., April 12 Mrs. Gertrude Bovee Johnson, widow of Owen Johnson, the author who wrote about life at the Lawrenceville School and Yale, died Friday of cancer at her home here. She was 81 years old.

BERLIN, April 12 East Germany disclosed today that it has conducted large-scale defense maneuvers in the southwestern part of the country, the area where Chancellor Willy Brandt met with Premier Willi Stoph at Erfurt last month.

MADRID, April 12 The marriage of Leonor March Cencillo and Francisco Chicao de Guzman y Giron, performed yesterday in Palma de allorca's cathedral by the island's Bishop, the Most Rev. Rafael Alvarez Lara, united two illustrious Spanish families.
WESTFIELD, N.Y., April 12 Ray A. Marshall, purchasing agent for Welch's Foods, Inc., and Mayor of Westfield in 1961-62, died yesterday of a coronary attack. He was 57 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Joseph Califano, general counsel for the Democratic National Committee, called today for reform of the American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary.
TULSA, Okla., April 7 In the Depression days of the nineteenthirties, Joseph Petta worked his way through college by teaching arts and crafts after school to earn his $400 tuition.

Hunter College has suspended classes for today and tomorrow, but is urging students and faculty members to attend discussions on how to end the disturbances that have plagued the school for the last three weeks.

For its centennial celebration the Metropolitan Museum has come up With a giant birthday cake that can be sliced two ways. The skillful design for completing its physical plant, part of a carefully studied master plan for its second century, is a rational, thoughtful and architecturally sensitive solution.

Mrs. Miriam Stiglitz Saperstein, who toured the United States and Europe as a saxophonist in all-girl bands, including Ina Ray Hutton's during the nineteen-thirties and forties, died of cancer Friday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. She was 63 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn., April 12 Miss Kathryn Ann Kohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Lyon Kohn, was married at the Tumble Brook Country Club here last evening to Michael Benjamin Masius, a project director with the New York City Housing Development Administration.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 12 Arthur Ashe of the United States won the Bacardi open invitational round-robin tennis tournament today and the $2,250 first prize by defeating Yugoslavia's No. 1 player, Zeljko Franulovic, 8-6, 7-5.

COVINGTON, Ky., April 12 (AP) Joe Heving, who pitched for four major league teams during his 16 seasons in baseball, died yesterday at St. Elizabeth Hospital here. He was 65 years old. He leaves his wife, Mary; two daughters and a son.
Icelandic Airlines is surrendering its role as last of the all-prop traps-Atlantic airlines, but without abandoning its claim to distinction as the bargain basement of the North Atlantic.

DETROIT, April 12 (AP) The Chicago Black Hawks eliminated the Detroit Red Wings from the National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoffs today with their fourth straight 4-2 victory over the Wings for a four-game sweep.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 North Vietnamese troops were reported to have opened a heavy attack today on a second United States Special Forces camp.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 12 The New York Nets stormed from behind in the second half to turn back the Miami Floridians, 113-111, in an American Basketball Association game at Island Garden today. The Nets finished their seasons' work with the Floridians, leading 8 games to 3.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 Because of South Africa's racial separation policy, the United Negro College Fund has decided against accepting Gary Player's offer to play exhibition matches with American Negro golfers for the benefit of the fund. The decision was announced today by Vernon Jordan, executive director of the fund.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., April 13 Eugene Bird Coler, a retired bank executive, died of cancer at his home here yesterday. He was 79 years old and was the son of Bird S. Coler, former New York City Welfare Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The Justice department chided Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida today for disobeying a Federal district judge's order for the desegregation of the public schools in Manatee County.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Chairman Wilbur D. Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee introduced today an omnibus trade bill that would sharply limit imports of textiles and shoes under a new quota system.
CINCINNATI, April 13 (AP) Mark down Gary Hall and Susie Atwood as two of the eight choices for an American swimming squad that will tour Europe this summer.

Anniversaries inevitably prompt nostalgia. This being the case, it was hardly expected that the Metropolitan Museum of Art now in the midst of its massive centennial celebrations would resist the temptation to succumb to this most soporific of all sentiments. In the event, alas, it hasn't.

ATLANTA, April 13 The National Education Association expelled its predominantly white Mississippi affiliate today because, it said, the state group refused to merge with a black teachers organization.

MANY of the knockout and double-knockout champi onships that began in the metropolitan area during the winter are being finished this month. The Westchester double-knockout event, for example, ended Sunday when a foursome from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., captured the title.

HOUSTON, Tuesday, April 14 The Apollo 13 astronauts, their lives threatened by a serious oxygen leak, were forced to evacuate their command ship late last night and use their intended moon-landing craft as a "lifeboat" for a fast return to the earth.
Hofstra University's lacrosse team has scored 93 goals in seven games and Steve Dauses has had a hand in 47.
DES MOINES, Iawo, April 13 Vice President Agnew said tonight that the best students in the United States constitued a "natural aristocracy" that should be given special academic treatment.

Joe Robbie, the managing general partner of the Miami Dolphins, violated the National Football League's rules against tampering when he hired the head coach, Don Shula, away from the Baltimore Colts last winter. The penalty will be the Dolphins' first draft choice next year and at will go to the Colts.

When the new Cambodian leaders sought to demonstrate the extent of Communist Vietnamese penetration of their country last week by encouraging foreign newsmen to visit border areas, the Communists retaliated by seizing eight journalists, including two Americans.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (Reuters) Net working capital of United States corporations fell $400-million to $214.2-billion in the final 1969 quarter, following a $1.7-billion drop the previous quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commis-, sion reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 13 Merriman Smith, the chief White House correspondent for United Press International, was found dead this evening at his home. He apparently had shot himself in the head.

Net profit of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in the first quarter of this year rose 11 per cent to $28,365,000, or 71 per cents a share, from $25,526,000, or 65 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year, it was reported yesterday.

Almost a year after Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel announced the immediate start of planning on the Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor, the project remains little more than a sand castle.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 13 (AP) Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. ordered National Guard units to active duty tonight to deal with possible labor strife in Palm Beach County.

WASHINGTON--The Demo crats may be in social limbo here now, but you'd never know it judging from the entertaining done by Mrs. William McCormick Blair Jr., whose husband worked for Adlai E. Stevenson, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson.

Wheat future price dropped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of the United States Department of Agriculture's increased estimate of the winter wheat production, made public on Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 13 Arthur J. Goldberg today advocated a two-term limit for Governors of New York.

John Galbreath, the Columbus, Ohio, business executive with many and varied interests, took time out of a heavy schedule yesterday to visit Aqueduct. And he was glad that he did, too, for he saw his 4-yearold colt, Master Hand, win the feature race.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 13 The Rhodesian Government seems determined to press ahead with a plan to reduce spending on primary education for black Africans, a move that will probably force the closing of most Christian missionary schools.

LONDON, April 13 Handley Page, Ltd., Britain's oldest aircraft company, appears to be going out of business despite the rescue attempts of various Americans, including Howard Hughes and Robert Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration.

BONN, April 13 (AP) The West German Government paid tribute today in the Bundestag to Count Krl von Spreti, its ambassador to Guatemala, who was murdered by leftist guerrillas in the Central American nation last week.

ATHENS, April 13 Mikis Theodorakis, Greece's leading contemporary composer and a political prisoner for 20 months, was unexpectedly set free today and was allowed to fly to Paris at once for treatment of tuberculosis.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Administration sources reported today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was expected to issue a formal invitation to the Warsaw Pact countries next month for a conference on mutual reduction of conventional military forces in Europe.
MADISON, Wis., April 13 Wisconsin Attorney General Robert Warren sought today a Circuit Court injunction to halt work stoppages at two state mental hospitals.

WASHINGTON, April 13, Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels and touched the lowest levels since March 23, the Government reported last this afternoon.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 13 The Manatee County school superintendent, Jack L. Davidson, was restored to office today and predicted that a courtordered racial integration plan would be put into effect tomorrow morning without any violence.
John M. Fisher has joined Curran, Anthony Co., Inc., as chairman of the board. He succeeds Joseph C. Byrne, who will now devote all of his time to being chief executive of the company.

Teamsters in Chicago began an all-out strike yesterday against trucking companies to press their demands for a wage settlement 55 cents an hour higher than a tentative national agreement, The Associated Press reported.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 Billy Casper's deft putting carried him to a major golfing triumph in another playoff today. Using only 12 strokes on the greens for the first nine holes of the Augusta National Golf Club to gain a five-stroke lead, Casper went on to defeat Gene Littler in the 18 extrahole session for the Masters crown, 69 to 74.

WASHINGTON, April 13(AP) The Nixon Administration proposed today a 50 per cent increase in Federal spending for buying and developing new parks and recreation areas.

A high-level committee studying the Special Trust Fund of the New York Stock Exchange is considering a recommendation to increase the fund's assets as much as 10fold, to $75-million, to insure against customer losses in case of brokerage-house insolvencies.

Mayor Lindsay stepped into the negotiations between land-lords and building service employes yesterday by assigning his Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, Benjamin Altman, to sit in on the bargaining sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The United States delegation left today for a crucial round of arms-limitation talks with the Soviet Union amid continuing complaints from Capitol Hill that the Administration was jeopardizing the negotiations by proceeding with the Safeguard missile defense system.

NEW DELHI There are scores of exciting dishes to be found in both Old and New Delhi and one of the greatest of the lot is tandoori chicken, which could be called the national dish of India. The name does not relate to a town or region or state as many people believe but rather to the word tandoor, the Indian word for oven.
Nine members of the women's liberation movement were arrested yesterday after they invaded the offices of Grove Press, a pioneer publisher of erotic literature.
The formation of a new container terminal organization with pier facilities on the Jersey side of Upper New York Bay was announced here yesterday.

In the most spectacular game yet of a spectcular set of playoff games, the New York Knickerbockers squeezed by the Milwaukee Bucks, 112-111, at Madison Square Garden last night and took a 2-0 lead in the four-of-seven series that will lead to another such series for the championship of the National Basketball Association.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 13 E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.'s first-quarter sales rose by 7 per cent to $935million, Charles M. McCoy, president, told some l,500 stockholders at the 167th annual meeting here today.

KYOTO, Japan, April 13 The governing Liberal-Democratic party suffered a humiliating defeat today in a key gubernatorial election in which the incumbent, Torazo Ninagawa, a Marxist, won in a landslide over Mamoru Shibata, a former Government official.
Heroes were plentiful and spirit was running wild in the New York Knicks' dressing room last night after their excrutiatingly exciting and highly important victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

ALBANY, April 13 An extensive revision of the state's Code of Criminal Procedure, containing hundreds of changes in nearly every facet of the criminal justice process, passed the Senate by a vote of 40 to 13 today and was sent to the Assembly.
The Miami Floridians were taken over by the American Basketball Assocation yesterday.
GENEVA, April 13 Monetary authorities of the major Western nations are losing interest in proposed changes designed to provide for greater flexibility of currencies in exchange markets.
In the manner of a reiuvenated dowager with unlimited life expectancy, the Metropolitan Museum of Art gave itself a bang-up 10th birthday party yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13 Ohio's fishing industry temporarily shut down today in response to Gov. James A. Rhodes's formal proclamation banning the commerical taking and selling of all fish from the Ohio waters of Lake Erie.
SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, April 13 (UPI) The United States munitions ship Columbia Eagle, hijacked March 16 and held in Cambodia until last Wednesday, arrived here today.
WASHINGTON, April 13 The Pentagon reported signs today that a Soviet nuclear submarine had sunk in rough waters of the Atlantic. The site was between 400 and 600 miles northwest of Spain.

Pretrial hearings for 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places were adjourned yesterday to tomorrow because of a fire over the weekend in the building in which three defense lawyers have offices.
Commissioner Walter Kennedy of the National Basketball Association fined Coach Richie Guerin of the Atlanta Hawks $1,000 yesterday for "conduct, detrimental to professional basketball."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 14 (AP) Four enemy rockets plunged into the heart of Saigon just before last midnight, missing by just a few blocks the United States Embassy and the official residence of President Nguyen Van Thieu. One of the 100-pound rockets crashed through the roof of a theater where a play was under way.
WASHINGTON, April 13 A bipartisan group of Representatives will press for a House investigation of Justice William O. Douglas's fitness to continue serving on the Supreme Court.

MOSCOW, April 13 Theodore C. Sorensen, who is the choice of the New York Democratic state committee for the party's Senate nomination, told a Soviet audience today many things that New York voters might like to hear but that the Russians did not seem to appreciate.

Helena Rubinstein, Inc., manufacturer of cosmetics and toiletries, announced yesterday, it had reached an agreement in' principle to acquire 80 per cent of the stock of Parfums Rochas, S.A., a leading French perfume house, and 100 per cent of other related companies of Rochas situated throughout the world, for more than $37-million.

WHEN the New York Mets made their last appearance at Shea Stadium they were engulfed by the eu phoria that comes from just having won the championship of the world. Out on the field the deliriously happy Met fans were ripping the joint apart, gouging out the turf with clawing fingers in a totally senseless display of misplaced enthusiasm.

MOSCOW, April 13 Henry Ford 2d began talks today with high Soviet officials. A Ford Motor Company spokesman said the talks were expected to result in an invitation to the company to establish operations in the Soviet Union.
Crimes reported to the police increased 4.8 per cent in February as compar ed with the same month last year, the Police Department said yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay proposed an unspecified increase in real property taxes and city fees last night in a televised "Message to the People" on the fiscal plight of the city.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Bernard G. Segal, president of the American Bar Association, said today that the public interest would be served if President Nixon would consult with the association on potential nominees to the Supreme Court before nominating them.

It was black tie inside and out at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night. As the 3,000 formally clad guests prepared to ascend the granite stairway into the building for a Centennial Ball, a smaller group, many of them also in black tie, picketed along Fifth Avenue in what they termed a "quiet, nonaction, dignified" demonstration.

STRASBOURG, France, April 13 A Council of Europe report made public here today criticized what it called "the generalization and exaggeration of the practice of overbooking" in European air transport.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., April 13 Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Onorati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Francine Paula Onorati, to William Edwin Crawford, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Crawford of Chicago and Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, April 13 It is too bad that the Democratic and Republican national chairmen have fired away at each other as to whether Clark Mollenhoff, a White Douse assistant, should have the right to inspect individual income tax returns. Since Democratic Chairman L.F. O'Brien raised the question and Republican Chairman Rogers Morton responded that the Democrats were "unduly sensitive to investigation," it may indeed look as if Mr. O'Brien's party has something to hide.
Mediators in the newspaper dispute made a new effort yesterday to head off a strike threatened for today at The New York Post by members of the Newspaper Guild.

PRINCETON, N.J. Yale's coeds are not alone in their complaints. The 167 women at Princeton University have been outnumbered by men 20 to 1, somewhat socially isolated and on the psychological defensive since they arrived last September as the first women undergraduates in the university's 223-year history.
Plans for a three-day, $1million rock festival to be held in Northern New York State June 26 through 28 were announced here yesterday by a group of theatrical and rock promoters.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 13(AP) The head of Uruguay's police intelligence branch was shot to death by machine gunners here today, and the police authorities began searching for a left-wing terrorist group believed to have killed six other policemen since last July.

HOUSTON, April 13 (AP) The Apollo 13 spacecraft gets its primary power from three fuel-cell power plants located in the service module that is attached to the cone-shaped command module. Two of these fuel cells went out tonight.

ALBANY, April 13 The Assembly passed a toughened bill against blockbusting today that would place designated areas of racial tensions in New York City off limits to solicitations by real-estate brokers.
A woman and her three children were killed in a fire that swept through a two-story frame house on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens last night.
An exhibition by Afro-American artists will be held next year in the Rath Museum in Geneva, Henri Ghent, director of the Community Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum, announced yesterday.
ALBANY, April 13 The State Senate voted final legislative approval today of a bill that would prohibit the mailing of credit cards to the public unless they were requested specifically in writing.

ALBANY, April 13 (AP) Ellmore C. Patterson of Bedford Village and Thomas H. Hawks of Rochester were named today by Governor Rockefeller to the State Banking Board for terms expiring March 1, 1973. They will succeed Gabriel Hauge of New York and Albert F. Martin of Schenectady.

Mrs. L'avinia Bray Korsmeyer, widow of the long-time editorial writer of The Wall Street Journal, died at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., yesterday of a heart attack, after an operation. She was 90 years old. Her husband, Frederick A. Korsmeyer, retired from The Journal in 1956, after working there for 45 years. He died in 1961.
While the Mets finished making plans to raise the world championship flag at Shea Stadium today, the Minnesota Twins waved a flag of their own yesterday a flag of surrender.

A series of minor earthquakes that gently nudged residents of Jefferson Township, N.J., last summer and fall has been attributed to movement along a fault under Lake Hopatcong, 35 miles northwest of New York City.

The economic slowdown, combined with inflationary pressures, reduced first-quarter earnings of the RCA Corporation 36 per cent to $27.4-million from the record $42.5-million in 1969's first quarter, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and president, reported yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP) The San Francisco Warriors rehired Coach Al Attles today, giving him what was termed a "multiyear" contract.

Three of the nation's top dozen banking organizations reported net income for the first quarter yesterday. The results were mixed: two companies were up, one was down; profit margins were under severe pressure at all three from rising interest rates, but a larger volume of business enabled two of the three to snow an improved rate of return on their stockholders' investment.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company set an 8 per cent interest rate yesterday morning on its $1.57-billion of debentures with warrants the largest financing package in American corporate history.

Samuel J. Melville, who is under state and Federal indictments charging him with bombing office buildings here last fall, was transferred to the Tombs on Saturday because he had tried to saw his way out of his cell at the Federal House of Detention, according to law-enforcement sources.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (Reuters) Net purchases of common stock by four leading institutional investor groups rose 20 per cent last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission estimated today.
James J. Woody drummed his fingers on the tablecloth and said: "I feel my calling card has come. I think I can pull this deal off."
Prices on the London stock market closed sharply higher yesterday amid general optimism that the new national budget would be favorable to securities investment. The budget will be announced today.

NEW HAVEN, April 13 Burke Marshall, who headed the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division in the tumultuous years from 1961 to 1965, has been appointed deputy dean of the Yale University Law School, a spokesman said today.
ALBANY, April 13 In its rush to end its annual session this week, the Assembly nearly passed a bill last night that opponents said would have reinstituted child labor in New York State.
MOSCOW, April 13 Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, told the Soviet people today that "new methods and new solutions" were needed to solve the country's economic problems.

HOUSTON, Tuseday, April 14 The mission control room looked calm and professional, but tense. The voices were clipped and serious as mission controllers on earth tried to help three men in space cope with a grave emergency.

BUFFALO, April 13 (AP) Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the literary critic who was convicted last week of a narcotics violation, was named today as a winner of a John Simon Gugg heim Mmorial Foundation Fellowship.

The Internationl Commercial Exchange, said to be the first market for currency contract futures, is scheduled to open on April 23 at 2 Broadway, it was announced yesterday by Murray Borowitz, exchange president.

More than 200 students continued to occupy the main administration building of Fordham University yesterday in an orderly demonstration resulting from the school's decision to deny tenure to a popular professor of English.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 13 (AP) A 22-year-old Vietnam War veteran has issued a printed statement modifying his story that 33 Vietnamese men, women and children were killed in a 1967 action in South Vietnam.

The City Planning Commission formally revived a controversial proposal yesterday to rezone parts of lower Third Avenue for luxury housing, but it added a requirement that developers either reserve 15 per cent of their new apartments for low-income families now living in the area or contribute to a fund to build public housing nearby.

Franz Schoenberner, an author who was the last preNazi editor of Simplicissimus, the German satirical magazine, died Saturday at the Teaneck (N.J.) Nursing Home. He was 77 years old and lived until recently at 82 Irving Place.

ALBANY, April 13 Governor Rockefeller plans to name two prominent Republicans within the next few days to fill vacancies on the Port of New York Authority's 12-member board of commissioners.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Senator Edmund S. Muskie appealed today for prompt action on his bill to create a system of Federal insurance against financial losses to customers and others from the failure of brokerage firms.

DETROIT, April 13 Newcar dealers reported today 198,084 sales of United Statestype cars in early April, down 14 per cent from 229,383 deliveries a year ago.

NEWARK, Ohio Representative Robert Taft Jr. spent an hour last week touring the Fiberglas plant in this ecntral Ohio city. He peered into the huge machines that spew out insulating material like pink cotton candy and learned how the manufacturing process works.

The Rutgers second freshman crew was scheduled to race Northeastern and Yale last Saturday on the latter's course at Derby, Conn. But a budget shortage forced Northeastern to cancel its trip and Yale had four oarsmen available rather than eight.

With dramatic swiftness last night, a major emergency befell the astronauts of Apollo 13. The electrical system difficulties and the loss of oxygen created the most serious situation ever experienced in any American space flight to date. The original plans for this expedition had to be abandoned and, instead, there was improvised an unprecedented set of measures aimed at saving the lives of the astronauts and returning them safely to earth.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., April 13 The engagement of Miss Alexandra Morrill Harris, a sophomore at Vassar College, to Alexander William Fraser Jr., a sophomore at New York University, has been announced by Mr, and Mrs. Paul Stewart Harris, parents of the future bride. Her finance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fraser of Wilmington. Del.

The Board of Higher Education amended its bylaws last night to permit the faculty and student body of each college in the City University system to share in establishing regulations and rules of conduct.

A plan to create 11 new districts to permit more representation for blacks and Puerto Ricans in the City Council was overwhelmingly approved by the Council's Committee on State Legislation yesterday.

The parallel sensibilities of the dramatist Samuel Beckett and the choreographer Anna Sokolow were successfully joined last night at the Edison Theater in a production of Mr. Beckett's "Act Without Words No. 1." Miss Sokolow, who for many years has detailed the entropic rundown of the human race in pure dance terms, directed the playwright's pictorial vignettes of frustration with a sure hand.

CROCUSES, robins, cattail shoots moving up out of their slim green fuses, mounds of earth on the lawn brought up by worms on warm, wet evenings, are all signs that summer is near. Fishermen and those who attend to their desires are also awakening.

THE English sculptor Henry Moore is one of the few great living artists alas, one of the very few. As is always the case with artists whose careers have been long, productive, uneven and overpublicized, we have sometimes taken his greatness for granted. Indeed, there have been times when even Mr. Moore seemed to be taking it for granted.

The long-expected shakeup of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting took place yesterday at a meeting of the organization's board. Its results could signal a subtle change in direction for the group, which has served with Thomas P.F. Hoving as chairman, as a gadfly of commercial television.

Screen rights to "The Dick," a novel by Bruce Jay Friedman which will be published in August by Alfred A. Knopf, have been acquired by Brodsky-Gould Productions, headed by Jack Brodsky and Elliott Gould. They will film it next year in association with 20th Century-Fox. CULEBRA, P.R., April 14 For more than 60 years this tiny island 22 miles east of Puerto Rico has been bombarded by the United States Navy with hardly a grumble from its peaceable residents.

The danger in New Left bombing is not confined to the very great damage political fanatics can inflict on persons and property. The necessity for providing safeguards to the community against such terrorist acts often prompts governmental countermeasures that are themselves a threat to liberty.

JERUSALEM, April 14 Israeli Government officials have asserted that Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, misled them in his reported offer to meet with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, raising false hopes here and abroad.
The stock market continued its losing ways yesterday a with only a slight afternoon recovery taking some of the sting out of an earlier broad decline.

The April platinum futures contract went off the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday in a blaze of glory. With a total of 67 sales, prices of the contract closed at $172.50, compared with $170.10 the day before.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 14 (AP) Henry Belin du Pont, a former vice president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and a great-great-grandson of the company's founder, Eleuthere Irenee du Pont de Nemours, died last night at his home in Greenville, a suburb. He was 71 years old and had suffered a stroke last October.

Ned Harkness of Cornell, who coached three Eastern college teams to National Collegiate hockey championships, is expected to sign a contract as coach of the Detroit Red Wings today. The Canadian born Harkness, who is a citizen of the United States, went to Detroit last night for final meetings with Sid Abel, general manager and coach of the National Hockey League club.

STOCKHOLM, April 14 (AP) The new United States Ambassador, Jerome H. Holland, said today that he was greeted by shouts of "Nigger! Nigger!" by Swedish antiwar demonstrators as he entered the royal palace to present his credentials to King Gustaf VI Adolf.

A group of faculty members at Hunter College issued a statement yesterday opposing a proposal for equal student-faculty representation on governing bodies. The plan was approved Saturday by a committee negotiating a new plan for governing the school.

NORTHRIDGE, Calif., April 14 (UPI) Bill Henry, Washington political columnist for The Los Angeles Times for 30 years, and a television and radio commentator for many years, died at a hospital here yesterday. He was 79 years old and had suffered from heart trouble.
HOUSTON, April 14 In the cold void of space, a crucial problem for the Apollo 13 astronauts is that of keeping cool.
BRADENTON, Fla., April 14 (UPI) The Manatee County school system egan operation today under a court-ordered desegregation plan delayed for eight days by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr.
THE American Broadcasting Company News De partment took the measure of rival television networks in reporting late Monday night and early yesterday morning the trials of Apollo 13.

WASHINGTON, April 14 President Nixon's welfare reform program cleared another Congressional barrier today as the House Rules Committee voted to send the measure to the floor and prohibit any changes in it there.

BALTIMORE, April 14 The Medical and Chirurgical Faculty, Maryland's equivalent of a medical society, is preparing to establish guidelines that would restrict legal abortions to the first 20 weeks of a woman's pregnancy.
WASHINGTON, April 14 The United States formally protested to Canada today against a move to establish jurisdictior over international waters in the Arctic Ocean.
RALEIGH, N.C.(AP) A Duke University professor says that "nations which control the stork must also guard themselves against nations that do not" control their populations.

About 600 members of a social workersunion pressed their demand for a pay increase yesterday by staging na noisy, three-hour demonstration outside the offices of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropics, 130 East 59th Street.
Prices on the London stock market closed slightly higher yesterday, although profit taking caused scattered losses.
STONY BROOK, L.I., April 14 The student government at the State University Center here has drawn up guidelines for a bail fund for resident students arrested on campus starting next year.
JERSEY CITY, April 14 Dr. Hugh M. White, who practiced medicine in Jersey Ctiy for 53 years, died yesterday in a nursing home here. He was 89 years old and lived here at 271 Palisade Avenue.

If an open Davis Cup is not approved this year, the United States will push for a "super tennis series" between the challenge round champion and a team of contract professionals, Alastair B. Martin said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 The Senate Interior Committee virtually completed action today on a bill that if approved by the Senate and House and signed by the president, would finally resolve the 86-year-old issue of the claims of indigenous Alaskans.

VO-DO-DE-OH-DO!! With many shrill giggles of seeming despair, that archetypal pastiche musical, "The Boy Friend," returned to Broadway last night at the Ambassador Theater. With a gentility so strained that it is all but ruptured, this Sandy Wilson imitation of a 1920's musical comedy takes demureness to new depths and cuteness to fresh camps. Vo-do-de-oh-do!!
LONDON, April 14 In what he termed a "cautious" budget, Chancellor of the Exchequer Roy Jenkins cut takes today by $528-million a year and eased credit restraints.
BOSTON, April 14 A Federal judge ordered a temporary delay today in publication of the transcript of the Mary Jo Kopechne inquest, pending a decision on a suit brought by the inquest stenographers.
Willie Shoemaker will fly here from California to ride Silent Screen in Saturday's Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, the colt's trainer disclosed yesterday.

Together with the viewing of the first robin, the northward migration of the baseball clubs, and Cherry Blossom Week in Washington, there is an annual American spring rite known as income tax day. It is customary to celebrate the day with hearty jokes and pitiful moans.
Columbia University started legal action yesterday against six student demonstrators who allegedly committed "acts of vandalism" on the campus last week following a speech hailing the Black Panthers.
The Tandy Corporation has bought the business and certain assets of the Allied Radio Corporation, a subsidiary of LTV Ling Altec, Inc., for about $30million, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, April 14 Cambodia's new regime has quietly invited American and French banks to establish facilities in Pnompenh, informed banking sources said today.

One of the least foreseen ceremonies of the 20th Century, the raising of a "world champions" flag by the New York Mets, took place at Shea Stadium yesterday. The rain that began just before the festivities for the opening home game did nothing to dispel the joy of the occasion for the Mets and their supporters among a crowd of 41,679.
PITTSBURGH, April 14 Dr. W. George Crouch, a University of Pittsburgh professor of English, died yesterday in Presbyterian-University Hospital. He was 67 years old. He had been ill since December.
The freeing of Mikis Theodorakis by Greece's military Government, has touched off a series of efforts by colleges and individuals here to bring the composer to the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 14 Notes from the Poor Economist's Almanac:
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) President Nixon announced six new nominees today to the 24-member National Science Board.

The New York Mets awakened memories of their furious summer of 1969 at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon by raising their championship flag over Shea Stadium. But for the next three hours they awakened memories of dimmer days by losing their home opening game to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-4, in 10 innings.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 14 Morris County's Daily Record suspended publication today until the current strike of pressman, printers and mailers is settled.
WASHINGTON, April 14 The House voted today to prohibit the use of Federal funds in forcing school integration.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) David Michael Mountbatten, Marquess of Milford Haven, died today after collapsing at London's Liverpool Street railway terminal. He was 50 years old.

YONKERS, April 14 Post positions for Friday night's $20,000 final of the Ed Sullivan Pacing Series at Yonkers Raceway were decided today on the basis of average earnings by a standardbred in the series. The higher the average, the farther out the starting slot. Each assignment was automatic, except when two or more pacers had identical averages.
TOKYO, April 14 (Reuters) Japan today reported a record balance-of-payments surplus for the last year, with hopes of maintaining the trend for another year.
ALBANY, April 14 The state Assembly voted final legislative approval today for the creation of a $750-million state mortgage agency to revive the sagging homebuilding industry.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) The Nixon Administration indicated today that it would soon let doctors switch heroin addicts to regular doses of methadone, a cheap and relatively harmless heroin substitute.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 14 The annual stockholders' meeting of the United Aircraft Corporation here was marked by tight security surveillance in anticipation of trouble from war protestors and by stockholders' concern over the Apollo 13 astronauts.
Dr. Reuben Turner, a pediatrician, died of a heart attack Saturday at the White Plains Center for Nursing Care. He was 66 years old and lived at 9 Ridgeland Road, Yonkers.

SANA, Yemen, April 14 Fighting is reported to have ended in Yemen following the settlement of a dispute between this country and the neighboring kingdom of Saudi Arabia about royalist resistance to the republican Government here.

VIENNA, April 14 United States and Soviet disarmament negotiators arrived here today for the second round of armslimitation talks.
THE number of ways in which a team contest can be organized is almost as great as the number of bidding systems that have been devised in the history of the game.
Interest rates climbed fairly sharply yesterday as the capital markets shifted their gaze away from the Bell System's big new debenture offering and found other issues comparatively less attractive.
Business inventories in February reversed the previous month's trend, rising $870-million over January, the Commerce Departent reported yesterday in Washington.
NEW HAVEN, April 14 Two national Black Panther party leaders, David Hilliard and Emory Douglas, were jailed for six months for contempt after a courtroom scuffle with deputy sheriffs here today.
HOUSTON, April 14 So low is the Apollo 13 spacecraft on water to cool its electronic equipment that the three astronauts will have to coast home without their inertial "sense of direction."

A two-part benefit will be held on April 27 for the benefit of Kips Bay Boys' Club. Proceeds will aid the club's program for boys at its new clubhouse at 1930 Randall Avenue in the southeast Bronx and at a summer camp in Carmel, N.Y.
ALBANY, April 14 Governor Rockefeller plans to announce the appointment this week of William K. Jones, a 39-year-old Columbia University law professor, to the state Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) President Nixon signed today legislation granting a 6 per cent across-the-board increase to all civilian salaried employes of the Federal Government, including postal workers.

STRASBOURG, France, April 15 Fifteen Western European Governments asserted jointly today that the Greek military junta engaged in "torture and other ill treatment" of its political prisoners. The Governments also made public a 40,000-word report detailing alleged misdeeds by the authorities in Athens.
Columbia University marked the 91st birthday yesterday of Melville Cane, lawyerpoet, by establishing the Cane Collection 3,000 items documenting his twin careers over 70 years.
ONE of the world's greatest players, Jean Besse of Switzerland, paid a brief business visit to New York last weekend and found time to play bridge in a private game at the home of Edgar Kaplan.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 A one-act drama about life in a prison played a one-day stand here today in a prison.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., April 15 About 4,400 workers went on strike today for higher wages at two of the three big nuclear plants in Oak Ridge, where total employment is more than 13,000.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) Louis B. Lundborg, the head of the world's largest private bank said today that the Vietnam war was a "tragic mistake" that had distorted the United States economy.
WALNUT CREEK, Calif., April 15 (AP) James P. Howe, a retired Associated Press foreign correspondent, died yesterday of a gunshot wound, authorities said. He was 91 years old.

The major stock exchanges and the other self-regulatory bodies of the securities industry have created a task force to establish a new program of protection for inves tors in case of brokerage-house failures.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., April 15 John Edgerley, who retired as executive vice president of the Bloomfield Savings Bank in 1966, died of a heart attack here yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived at 144 Parkview Drive.

IN "The Persians," Aeschyius wrote about a contemporary event, the defeat of the Persians by the Greeks at Salamis in 472 B.C. He wrote from the point of view of the Persians, and although it is clear from history, and from the play, that the Persians were the aggressors, the play is sympathetic not to their cause, but to them as human beings.

WASHINGTON, April 15-- Nine possible defense budgets ranging from $59-billion to $88-billion were offered today as potential altternatives to the $71.8-billion defense budget recently requested by the Nixon Administration.
On the last day for filing 1969 Federal income tax returns, more than 2,500 people went to the Internal Revenue Service offices at 120 Church Street to get assistance in preparing their returns.

Seven months after the police cleared squatters from the site of the proposed state office building in Harlem, construction crews are about to begin laying concrete for the 22-story structure's foundation.

ALBANY, April 15 The Court of Appeals ruled today that three Democratic Assemblymen seeking to have the 1969 state budget declared unconstitutional lacked standing as legislators and as taxpayers "to challenge in the judicial branch the validity of appropriation bills submitted by the Governor."
The city is pulling dollars out of the air under a new program with far-reaching possibilities the leasing and transfer to private developers of air rights over city-owned buildings.
The Monsanto Company reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings declined by 8 per cent from a year earlier but that sales improved by 6 per cent.
HOUSTON, April 15 The Apollo 13 flight director's voice had a distinct edge to it.
While Luman Harris's starting pitchers don't expect much rest in the immediate future, opposing pitchers wonder if they can expect any rest from Harris's hitters.

Mrs. DeWitt Wallace, cochairman and co-founder of The Reader's Digest, became the first woman to receive the Golden Door Award of the American Council for Nationalities Service at a dinner last night at the Pierre Hotel.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 15 (AP) The St. Louis Blues return to the Metropolitan Sports Center here tomorrow night with ideas of polishing off the Minnesota North Stars and winning their National Hockey League Stanley Cup, quarter-final series.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 15 (AP) A crewman injured in an accident aboard a crippled Soviet trawler said today that another crewman had been killed in the same mishap.

KANSAS CITY, April 15 (AP) The Kansas City Chiefs announced today that 1971 season ticket sales had reached the 70,000 mark and that no additional orders could be confirmed for the first year in their new stadium.

Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson withdrew yesterday as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor because contributions to his campaign stopped coming in the day that Arthur J. Goldberg became a candidate.

Full-time faculty members at Hunter College voted yesterday not to dissolve the current governing body at the college and replace it with a college senate consisting of 50 per cent student and 50 per cent faculty representatives.

NEW ORLEANS, April 15 (AP) Lee Trevino and Billy Casper, the only two players to win two tournaments on the circuit this year, head an unexpectedly strong field for the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tournament starting tomorrow.

In this diet-conscious age the overly rich tone poems of Richard Strauss are less common concert fare than they used to be. But last night the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra went whole hog in its last appearance of the season in Carnegie Hall and served up an all-Strauss program, including two tone poems. These were fortunately separated by the more spare Four Last Songs.
Thomas J. Kelly, chief designer of the lunar lander, heard about the trouble on the Apollo 13 mission through a call that awakened him early Tuesday morning at his home in Winchester, Mass.

WASHINGTON, April 15 One of the top Nixon Administration economic officials said today that "the worst part of the slowing of economic activity appears to be behind us" and that economy is apparently "at the threshhold of moving upward once again."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15 South Vietnamese troops, operating with a token force of Cambodians, destroyed a North Vietnamese base camp inside Cambodia yesterday in the first major combined operation reported in the war, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 The Federal Government took steps today to halt the use of the controversial herbicide 2,4,5-T as a weed-killer around homes and ordered the suspension of its use as a defoliant in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 15 In Judge Blackmun, it is said, President Nixon has found the "strict constructionist" of the Constitution for which he had been searching. The new nominee looks like a man who can be confirmed, moreover, whether or not he is whatever a "strict constructionist" is.

STRASBOURG, France, April 15 Following, as made public today by the Council of Europe, are excerpts from a report by the European Commission on Human Rights on the situation under the military Government in Greece. The first section is testimony by Mrs. Anastasia Tsirka, who was arrested in connection with pamphlets deemed suspicious. The second section consists of comment by the commission.

VIENNA, April 15 The baroque doors of the Belvedere Palace creaked open this morning and a half-dozen workmen trudged quickly inside. The workmen peered for a moment at the white stone cherubs flanking the marble steps and then, with solemn delicacy, taped the American and Russian flags on the stairway.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 "Tranquility is not the order of the day," Dr. Frank Stantion, president, told the annual meet ing here today of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.

RUMSON, N.J., April 15 William L. Onderdonk, a former vice president of Appleton Cox, IInc., marine underwriters in New York City, died Tuesday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch. He was 75 years old and lived at 9 North Cherry Lane.

ALBANY, April 15 Members of the New York State Legislature are fond of calling themselves members of the "greatest deliberate body in the world," but the picture emerging this week is of a process of legislation by exhaustion.

WASHINGTON, April 15 A majority of Americans appear ready to restrict basic freedoms guaranteed by the Bill of Rights, according to a poll by the Columbia Broadcasting System, the results of which were broadcast last night.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 15 Ralph DeVita, a suspended Union County District Court judge, was found guilty here today of obstructing justice but not guilty of bribery.

ALBANY, April 15 A 37year quest by a professor who lost his job at City College in New York City for conducting a hunger strike against Fascism ended successfully here today as the Legislature ordered that he receive a pension.

The 25th season of the Caramoor Festival at Katonah, N.Y., will open on June 20 with a performance of Mozart's "Idomeneo." The opera will be staged by Tito Capobianco and conducted by Julius Rudel and will have a cast headed by George Shirley, Maralin Niska, John Stewart and Bianca Sauler. The work will be given in the Venetian Theater at Caramoor and will be repeated there on June 26.

Students boycotted classes at Fordham University yesterday in a demonstration demanding tneure for a popular professor and greater student participation in academic policies.

City narcotics detectives found 220 pounds of pure heroin in a Chelsea apartment yesterday in what was described as one of the largest seizures of illegal drugs in the city's history.
A new daily newspaper with emphasis on coverage of local news will be published here starting in six to ten weeks, according to James A. Smith, publisher.
BURLINGAE, alif., April 15 (AP) Charles McMurtry, and Associated Press correspondent, writer and editor for 35 years, died last night of cancer. He was 66 years old.
Moody's Investors Service, Inc., the oldest and largest securities-rating agency, announced yesterday that it planned to charge for rating new tax-exempt bond issues starting May 15.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 16 (AP) The United States command reported today that 25 Americans were killed and 54 wounded yesterday, one of the year's highest one-day casualty tolls. Vietcong gunners also fired rockets into Saigon for the second time in three nights.

GLEN COVE, L.I. April 15 The 53-year-old Lincoln Settlement House will benefit from the proceeds of the fourth annual dinner dance to be held at the Nassau Country Club here on Saturday. Ben Ludlow and his orchestra will play for dancing.

Jim Ard of the University of Cincinnati, one of the most sought after players by basketball's professional clubs this season, has signed a four-year $400,000 contract to play with the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, April 15 The Brookings Institution, in the first project of its kind, published today a detailed analysis of the "national priorities" choices and options disclosed in President Nixon's first budget.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 15 Increases in above-ground stocks of oil and a restudy of the producing ability of Texas wells led the Texas Railroad Commission today to reduce the May allowable production rate from 68 to 64.5 per cent of the wells' ability to produce.

WASHINGTON, March 15 The Senate passed today a bill to outlaw the issuance of unsolicited credit cards. In doing so, it brushed aside objections of the Nixon Administration and Federal banking authorities.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 15 (UPI) United States authorities released today the master of a Soviet tanker that was found to have polluted the Gulf of Alaska.

BUENOS AIRES, April 15 This city, which has drawn to itself more than a third of Argentina's population, is in danger of strangling for lack of housing.
NEW HAVEN, April 15 Tom Fagan and Jay Rauth scored two goals apiece today to lead Yale's lacrosse team to its fourth successive victory with a 6-3 decision over Hofstra.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 15 Foreign Minister Yem Sambaur informed chiefs of diplomatic missions today of the Cambodian Government's universal appeal for arms assistance against Vietnamese Communist invasion.

MONTE CARLO, April 16 (AP) Barry Phillips-Moore, a lesser ranked Australian, eliminated two seeded players today in the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament. Andres Gimeno of Spain was the lone surviving contract professional.

WASHINGTON, April 15 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided to aim for a resumption of "modest" growth in money and bank credit as early as its meeting of Jan. 15, it was disclosed today.

The debenture offering being made to shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has raised questions among investors. To help clarify them, Robert J. Cole of The New York Times has interviewed Wall Street financial leaders. Excerpts from these interviews follow:

Robert Klager smiled proudly yesterday as Nate Bowman, the New York Knicks' reserve center, pinned a button to his uniform shirt before the start of practice at the Lexington School for the Deaf. The blue and white button read, "The Lexington Sticks Together School Spirit."

LOS ANGELES, April 15 The Times Mirror Company, which owns The Los Angeles Times, announced today that it would purchase a controlling interest in Newsday, the prosperous Long Island paper published in Garden City.
WASHINGTON, April 15 A number of Soviet crewmen aboard a nuclear submarine believed to have been lost off Spain over the weekend have been rescued by Soviet surface ships, a Pentagon source

Mayor Lindsay took issue yesterday with Vice President Agnew's views if broadcasting's role as a molder of public opinion. The Mayor urged radio and television to lead, to "point the way, not wait to report that someone else has found it."

AMMAN, Jordan, April 15 Nearly 1,000 students, led by uniformed Palestinian commandos, set fire today to the United States Information Center here and another mob stormed into the United States Embassy compound.
WATERTOWN, Conn. April 15 Bartow Lewis Heminway, president of the Heminway Corporation of Waterbury, a printing and Paper box manufacturing company, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 15 (AP) The Laotian Communists have rejected Premier Souvanna Phouma's proposals to negotiate an end to the Laotian conflict, diplomatic sources here said today.

BIDDEFORD, Me., April 15 Stephen Muskie, son of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, and Mrs. Muskie, and Miss Alexis Droggitis, a fellow student at the University of Maine, will be married on June 21. An outdoor ceremony is planned at the Muskie summer home in Kennebunk Beach.

WASHINGTON, April 15 The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford, touched off an angry floor debate tonight by suggesting that Justice William O. Douglas might have had ties with gambling and underworld figures.
WASHINGTON, April 15 The Nixon Administration's welfare reform bill narrowly survived a preliminary test on the House floor today but is still expected to win final approval tomorrow.
The stock market lumbered along in search of a gain yesterday but ended with another loss.
Six youths were arrested yesterday following another disturbance at trouble-plagued George Washington High School in which union officials said eight members of the teaching staff were injured.

WSHINGTON, April 15 Next year's basic Federal income tax form, the Form 1040, may eliminate one of the features that people have complained about the most this year: The fact that the instructions for various parts of the return are on the backs of pages that have to be filed with the return.
ATLANTA, April 15 (AP) The Atlanta Hawks, facing a tough assignment, today received news that made it even tougher.
The London stock market opened firm yesterday following the announcement of the British budget on Tuesday, but profit taking brought prices lower at the close.

George Thomas, a former fashion designer and, since 1960, business manager for David Barrett, the interior designer, died yesterday at his home, 15 West 55th Street, after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

BONN, April 15 Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that he had the "understanding, support and trust" of the United States Government in his continuing efforts to improve relations with the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.

The fight between the Madison Square Garden Corporation and Transnation Development Corporation for control of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., appears to be reaching a solution. Yesterday, Madison Square Garden indicated that it is not opposed to selling its 37.5 per cent holding in the race-track to Transnation, holder of 26 per cent of the Roosevelt common stock.
ESCONDIDO, Calif. (AP) The city, surrendering to a frog pond and children power, has scrapped plans for part of a storm-drain system.
More than 200 policemen moved onto the Columbia University campus last night after about the same number of radical students and their supporters went on a windowsmashing, paint-hurling foray.
CLEVELAND, April 15 Guarded by several hundred helmeted police on foot and on horseback, the American Telephone and Telegraph company held its 85th annual meeting in Public Auditorium here today.

Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber has brought off an admirable coup in persuading Premier Papadopoulos to free Mikis Theodorakis and to permit the ailing Greek composer to go to France for medical treatment.
PARIS Stanley Hayward, 164 pounds, Philadelphia, and Pascal Di Benedetto, 165, France, drew, 10 rounds.
LE TRETEAU DE PARIS'S second program of French contemporary drama at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater opened last night with "Lettre Morte" and "Architruc" by Robert Pinget.
A car that looks like an aquarium on wheels is expected to be introduced next week in a department store here.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) Disputing contentions that its debts exceed its assets, the management of Ling-TemcoVought, Inc., told a House subcommittee today, that it could retire its obligations at under 50 cents on the dollar and hoped to do so by selling off subsidiaries.
The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, which in February lost a much wanted suitor, found itself yesterday with what it considered an unwanted one.
BOSTON, April 15 If it were the middle of July, only the manager and a few diligent observers might realize the Yankees are in a slump.
THE wildlife swap begun a few years ago, in which West Virginia agreed to accept 25 New Hampshire fishers in exchange for 25 turkeys, is nearly completed.

SAINT-GERVAIS, France, Thursday, April 16 Sixty-eight persons nearly all of them children were missing today after an avalanche engulfed three buildings of a tuberculosis sanitarium near this French Alpine center, the police said.
WASHINGTON, April 15 Fifty-five members of the House joined today in sponsoring a bill to require the "open" dating of packaged foods sold by supermarkets and other retailers.
Linda Evans, one of the 12 members of the Weathermen wanted in Chicago on Federal antiriot charges, was arrested here yesterday morning by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON Vera Simons's balloons are not the three-for-a-quarter type. Hers are on exhibit here in the "Explorations" show produced by Gyorgy Kepes, director of the Center for Advanced Visual Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The exhibit, which continues through May 10 at the Smithsonian's National Collection of Fine Arts, is sponsored by the International Art Program.
The sorry truth about the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) that resume today in Vienna is that hopes for halting the nuclear missile race ride for the moment with the Soviet delegation.
"It'll be interesting to see how I do in this job. I've certainly been prepared for it," said Dick Munro, since December publisher of Sports Illustrated.
BAKING challah and onion bread is a Friday morn- ing ritual for Mrs. Solomon Feffer, except during the eight days of Passover. Then, all forms of chametz, or leavened foods, are forbidden.

HOUSTON, April 15 When the 15-ton rocket that gave Apollo 13 its final push toward the moon last Saturday crashed into the moon last night, the Ocean of Storms trembled for three hours and 20 minutes.

PARIS, April 5 The French Cabinet decided today to press ahead in its planning targets over the neat five years with a relatively high rate of economic growth even though this might bring new troubles for the franc.
North American Rockwell which figured prominently in the production of the Apollo 13 spaceship, reported yesterday lower profits for the threemonth and six-month periods ended March 31.
The Congress of Racial Equality and a coalition of black activists and organizations announced yesterday their endorsement of black candidates for State Senate and Assembly seats from Harlem.
GENEVA, April 15 The West refused today to permit East Germany to be "officially invited" to participate in the current session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

ONCE upon a time Redwood High School, in a suburb of San Francisco, had a rule for its athletes. This was the rule: "Hair cannot fall below or over shirt collars and must not fall over ears. Sideburns must not be longer than the mid-ear level."

Karl G. Linderoth, a, vice president of Bruce Payne Associates, Inc., New York management consultants, died in an automobile accident in Copenhagen Friday. He was 42 years old and lived at 200 Eleven O'Clock Road. Fairfield, Conn.

Census workers, particularly blacks and Puerto Ricans, are urgently needed in all parts of New York City, John C. Cullinane, regional director for the New York Area, Bureau of the Census, reported yesterday.

Thin women should be urged to gain wieght before they become pregnant in order to increase their chances of having a healthy baby, an obstetrician recommended here yesterday. His recommendation was based on a study of 87,858 births.
Politics and sports, kissing cousins in New York for a long time, blended last night at the Vanderbilt Athletic Club in the Grand Central Terminal Building.
KHANHBINH, South Vietnam, April 14 There is no mistaking the border here.

WASHINGTON, April 15 The State Department called today for an international conference to establish rules governing the passage of ships and the protection of natural resources in Arctic waters beyond national jurisdictions.

Teamster strikes in several cities forced more layoffs yesterday in industries suffering from a shortage of raw materials and parts. Many major manufacturers feared thatmassive layoffs would occurr if the trucking dispute continued into next week, the Associated Press reported.

A "product safety tax" system, designed to compensate accident victims when product safety is a factor, was proposed yesterday to an audience of 100 businessmen by New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant.

WASHINGTON, April 15 The State Department called today for an international conference to establish rules governing the passage of ships and the protection of natural resources in Arctic waters beyond national jurisdictions.

Teamster strikes in several cities forced more layoffs yesterday in industries suffering from a shortage of raw materials and parts. Many major manufacturers feared thatmassive layoffs would occurr if the trucking dispute continued into next week, the Associated Press reported.

A "product safety tax" system, designed to compensate accident victims when product safety is a factor, was proposed yesterday to an audience of 100 businessmen by New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant.
DARIEN, Conn., April 15 Hugo Austin Leander, a New York industrialist, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 5 Old Parish Road here.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) Joseph J. Sisco, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, has decided not to visit Jordan on his present tour of the area because of the violent anti-American demonstrations yesterday in Amman, the State Department announced today.

NEAK, Luong, Cambodia, April 16 A ranking security official in Pnompenh said he was shocked by news that hundreds of bodies had been seen floating in the Mekong River and that he had ordered an immediate investigation. He said that no responsible official had ordered a mass execution.
Negotiators for the printers and newspapers in the city were reported still far apart yesterday on the wage issue as contract talks continued.

WASHINGTON, April 16 President Nixon's plan for a radical revision of the nation's welfare system was approved by the House today, 243 to 155. It was a major legislative victory for the Administration.
"EXPERTS say the sport of offshore racing is hurt ing because a horsepower race makes it too expensive for all but a few wealthy boatowners.
Declines outnumbered advances by almost four-to-one yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the list continued to weaken in quiet trad ing.

WASHINGTON, April 16 President Nixon unveiled today a broad compromise plan to reform the postal system, provide more pay and bargaining rights for postal workers and raise additional revenues to narrow the postal deficit.
Postal Reform. President Nixon submitted a broad postal reform measure to Congress and asked that the cost of a first-class letter be increased from 6 to 8 cents.

HOUSTON, April 16 SNAP 27, a nuclear generator with 8.6 pounds of radioactive plutonium in it, will fall into the Pacific Ocean about 200 miles northeast of New Zealand about noon tomorrow, an Atomic Energy Commission official said today.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, April 15 (AP) British Columbia became the first province in Canada to recognize "teenage adults," as legislation lowering the legal age from 21 years to 19 went into effect Wednesday.
The city announced yesterday that it had asked municipal agencies not to use cars except in emergencies during the nationwide antipollution demonstrations on Earth Day, next Wednesday.
