SHORT HILLS, N.J., April 16 Joseph Thomas Foley, president and owner of the Home Oil Company in Passaic, died yesterday in his home after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 12 Quaker Road.

The 1967 antitrust conviction of three drug companies on charges of controlling the production and distribution of $1.7million worth of antibiotics was reversed yesterday in a 2-1 decision by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here.

HOUSTON, Friday, April 17 The Apollo 13 spaceship, damaged but on course, sped toward the earth early today as its three astronauts braced themselves for the complicated and exacting climax to their aborted moon-landing mission.

Dr. Chester J. Cavallito has been named executive vice president of Ayerst Laboratories, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, effective July 1. He is now a professor of medicinal chemistry at the University of North Carolina School of Pharmacy.
WASHINGTON, April 16 A coalition of 52 Democrats and 52 Republicans called today for creation of a special House committee to consider possible impeachment of Justice William O. Douglas.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 15 The week-long strike of most Minneapolis teachers continued today, with negotiations broken off between the school board and the city's Federation of Teachers.

The deadlock between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry continued yesterday in major cities, but some dissident drivers ended small walkouts and strike-related layoffs eased in some areas.

The controversial plan for a $350-million project across First Avenue from the United Nations, including glasswrapped plazas and four towers as tall as the United Nations headquarters building, was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

Turned down in an effort to intervene in the settlement of a Federal lawsuit charging automobile makers with conspiracy to suppress development of pollution controls, the city filed its own suit yesterday.
Two anesthesiologists warned yesterday that excessive use of pain-killing and anesthetic drugs during labor and delivery may endanger the well-being and perhaps even the lives of some babies.

A 15-year-old girl who only a month ago apologetically told her aunt that she had starting smoking cigarettes has died of hepatitis complications that a medical examiner says were apparently caused by her taking heroin with an unclean needle.

The "year after" has not been brimming for the Mets so far. Nobody has hit a home run yet. No pitcher has completed a game. The gremlins of 1969 have been late arriving. And yesterday the Mets made four errors and lost their second straight game to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-4.
LIMA, Peru, April 16 (Reuters) The Peruvian Govern ment decreed today that it would take over the sale and refining of copper and all other minerals in the country it 18 months.

Beverly Griffith, former director of public relations and assistant vice president of Eastern Airlines, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 77 West 55th Street.
PARIS, April 16 The French National Assembly voted today to give mothers as much say as fathers over the upbringing of children.
WASHINGTON, April 16 Administration and Congressional sources disclosed today that President Nixon had decided that the United States should press for a comprehensive limitation on strategic weapons.
POINT PLEASANT, N.J., April 16 Fred A. Kalil, a retired textile manufacturer, died Monday at Point Pleasant Hospital after a short illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Spring Lake Gardens.

A three-alarm fire ripped through the main campus building at Kingsborough Community College late last nght, destroying a major wng of the building, which houses the student cafeteria and the director of students' offices.
The Pacific Intermountain Express Company, one of the nation's largest common Carriers, has agreed to hold merger discussions with the International Utilities Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
BAY SHORE, L.I., April 16 The Rev. Dr. Gregory Mabry, chaplain of the House of the Holy Nativity here, died yesterday at Bay Shore Hospital. He was 79 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 The United States Secretary of the Interior, Walter J. Nickel, said here today that he would withhold permission to construct a section of Interstate 95 until steps were taken to preserve a wildlife refuge in the area.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 16 (AP) Nico Charisse, the ballet master who trained such film stars as Ava Gardner, Ann Miller, Shirley MacLaine and Cyd Charisse, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

BUDAPEST, April 14 Some Soviet and other East European sources believe that a struggle in the Moscow leadership culminated early this month in a victory for the Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and possibly in plans to oust some of his associates from key positions.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) James J. Ling defended today both his acquisition of the Okonite Company from the Kennecott Copper Corporation in 1965, and his dealings With an insider of Kennecott whom he later made chief executive of Okonite.

LONDON, April 16 A Soviet Jewish woman, who had tried repeatedly to obtain permission to join her father in Israel, was reported today to have been sentenced to two and a half years in prison on charges of having slandered the Soviet Union and insulted the authorities.
WELDON, N.C., April 16 (UPI) A Navy jet collided in flight today with an Air Force jet, killing six airmen and scattering flaming wreckage into a residential area. No one on the ground was injured.
WASHINGTON, April 16 A House judiciary subcommittee completed public hearings on anti-obscenity legislation today with little indication of the scope of new laws, if any, that it would recommend.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Despite United States restrictions on arms shipments to the Greek junta, the Defense Department is reported to have secretly supplied this year nearly twice as much military aid to Greece as authorized by Congress.
Forced to change the tone of his philosophical discussions with umpires, Earl Weaver might have discovered a revolutionary approach to manager-umpire relations last night.
ANGLERS caught more than 40 tons of muskelunge in Chautauqua and Cattaraugus counties in 1969, the State Conservation Department reports.
The New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that charges by an official of the United Federatoin of Teachers against parents at Goerge Washington High School were "Lies."

There seemed to be a considerable amount of disagreement yesterday among advertising men who have fought the political fight on the merits of the legislation that would limit broadcast advertising by candidates for Federal office. The Senate passed the bill Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Hamer H. Budge, the Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress today that there is an "urgent need" for creation of an insurance to protect investors from losses when brokerage firms go bankrupt.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The wife of a Navy submarine commander testified at a courtmartial hearing today that she had distrubuted an antiwar newsletter because she felt the war in Vietnam was a "terrible mistake" for the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The nation's total output declined in the first quarter of this year but monthly figures for March indicated that the slowdown in the economy may be ending, Government reports showed today.

PARAMUS, N.J., April 16 Morris Zelkowitz, an associate partner with the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings Merrill, 400 Park Avenue, New York, died today of a heart attack in Hackensack Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived here at 2l0 Harwood Place.
DALLAS, April 16 The building from which Lee Harvey Oswald shot and killed President John F. Kennedy was sold tonight at public auction for $650,000.
The conviction last year of Carmine (the Snake) Persico on his fifth trial on charges of hijacking a truckful of linen was upheld by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 16 In a rare display of unity, the nation's Governors, Mayors, state legislators and county officials announced today that they would push in Congress for approval this year of President Nixon's revenue sharing proposal.
CHICAGO, April 16 The country's Eastern railroads were taken to task here today by an international container operator for inefficiency in container handling.

HIGH POINT, N.C. For the first time, modern furniture has moved into the forefront at the Southern Furniture Market, long the bastion of traditional. If manufacturers have guessed right, the trend toward Mediterranean styling, dominant for the last 10 years, may be on the wane.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 16 The Cambodian Minister of Public Works said here today that his country would end state control over all sectors of production and would encourage private enterprise.

The bassoon is an admirably useful ensemble instrument that seems to go well with almost any combination of tone colors, but the mildness that can make it so agreeable in company keeps it from stirring up much interest in solo assignments. Thus, the bassoon recital given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Leonard Hindell, of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, was an uncommon event.
In 1962, Isaac Bashevis Singer wrote a short story called "The Son," which told of his meeting with his son, whom he had not seen in 20 years.

Tatoi, a newcomer to Aqueduct, found the Big A strip to his liking yesterday. The 3-yearold colt owned by Orme Wilson Jr. won the feature event on the card, a seven-furlong sprint, against four rivals. The feat was not easy, though, for the margin was a mere nose over the Birchfield Farm's Sailstone. This pair waged a thrilling duel in the stretch, with Sailstone just falling short, after an awkward start.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 16 The operators of one of the first antiwar G.I. coffeehouses went on trial today on charges of operating a public nuisance. State Circuit Judge E. Harry Agnew ruled that the common law violation could carry a sentence up to 10 years in prison.

In an attempt to block the proposed merger of the National Basketball Association with the American Basketball Association, the players of the N.B.A. filed an antitrust suit yesterday in Federal Court here, challenging both the merger and the reserve-clause system that ties a player to one team within a league.

MILWAUKEE, April 16 A note of sadness accompanied the otherwise confident New York Knicks today on their flight here from New York to meet the Milwaukee Bucks tomorrow night in the third game of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division championship playoff series.
The Bank America Corporation reported yesterday that first-quarter net income rose 15.6 per cent to $36.92-million, or $1.07 a share, from $31.94million, or 93 cents, in the 1969 period.

WASHINGTON, April 16 A group of black educators who met with Commissioner of Education James E. Allen Jr. questioned today President Nixon's commitment to higher education for the nation's black youth.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Dr. Floyd A. McClure, a botanist at the Smithsonian Institution who was considered one of the world's leading authorities on bamboo, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 72 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam April 16 The United States combat death toll rose again last week to 141, the highest since last September, the United States command announced today.

THE basic inadequacies of television network news coverage, which is essentially a recital of bulletins with a smidgen of commentary, was illustrated afresh last night in perhaps the best program of its kind, "Washington Week in Review." The program was seen over the facilities of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and Channel 13.
A rash of troubles, of varying degree and for assorted issues, affected seven colleges in the city yesterday, but the disruptions and attempted dislocations involved little violence.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 17 (AP) South Vietnam has offered to repatriate all Vietnamese nationals living in Cambodia, Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam said today.

THE New York interclub championship, contested each winter by representatives of the leading social clubs here, resulted predictably in a victory for the Regency Whist Club. The winning team included Constantin Platsis, Thomas McCarthy, Fred Dossenbach and John Kachmar, with Wingate Bixby and Walter Hochschild alternating.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 16 (AP) The world's largest private shipyard, its proposed minority employment program turned down by the Labor Department, has postponed indeefinitely Saturday's scheduled keel-laying ceremonies for the $510-million nuclear powered aircraft carries Dwight D. Eisenhower.

STOCKHOLM, April 16 Ingmar Bergman's staging of Strindberg's "A Dream Play" is the sensation of the Stockholm spring season. Composed as "A Chamber Play," it is being performed at the smaller of the Dramatic Theater's two playhouses and is completely sold out for the remainder of its initial run. News of its extraordinary quality has spread quickly. It will soon be seen elsewhere in Europe.

Millions of dollars worth of appliance advertising assignments are being shifted around Chicago by the Sunbeam Appliance Company. J. Walter Thompson's office there is getting a pile of "personal care" products that will be moved in from Perrin Associates and Foote, Cone Belding. FC in turn will be getting several assignments that will also be shifted out of Perrin.
MOSCOW, April 15 (AP) Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, toured the construction site of an Italian-designed auto plant today 500 miles southeast of Moscow.
JERSEY CITY, April 16 Edward J. Hall, director of the New Jersey State, Employment Service, died Monday at Jersey City Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived here at 117 Kensington Avenue.

ESSEX, Conn., April 16 Lawrence G. Washburn, a Washburn, a former vice president of the SuCrest Corporation in New York City, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Simons Island, Ga. He was 77 years old. Mr. and Mrs. Washburn were on the way to their home at 62 North Maine Street here, after spending the winter on Pompano Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) A special House panel investigating the alleged Songmy massacre subpoened today six Army officers and enlisted men, including Capt. Ernest L. Medina, saying the Army had refused to let them testify voluntarily.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 16 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., became the only United States women's survivor as Rosemary Casals and Julie Heldman bowed today in the quarterfinals of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament.

Bill D. Moyers, the publisher of Newsday, refused yesterday to comment on the sale of the controlling interest in the Long Island daily to the Times Mirror Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times, or on his own plans.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 16 (Reuters) The novel "Myra Breckinridge" by Gore Vidal is "filthy, bawdy, lewd and disgusting," a Sydney judge said today in upholding a Customs Department ban on the book.

Well-to-do New Yorkers in 5,000 apartment houses may wake up next Tuesday to find themselves without some of the people whose services are essential to their comfort; men who run their elevators, carry their garbage downstairs, sweep their hallways, fix their leaky faucets, guard their buildings

HOUSTON, April 16 In spite of the stress of more than five days in space, most of it under emergency conditions, the Apollo 13 astronauts seem cool, calm and efficient as they approach the flight's last decisive point the re-entry tomorrow.
The three national television networks plan to broadcast live the Apollo 13 splashdown, expected at about 1 P.M. today.

Robert L. McCorckle, who retired a year ago as display administrator for Bamberger's department store in Newark and its New Jersey branches, died Wednesday of a heart attack at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 67 years old and lived at 160 East 65th Street.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) The Chicago Cubs, acting to curb rowdyism at Wrigley Field, announced plans today to install a 42-inch screen shelf bordering the bleachers and to stop the sale of standing room in the bleachers.

AVON, Conn., April 16 Mrs. Christine Geer Cottrell was married this afternoon to Dr. A. John Elliot, orthopedic surgeon in Westerly, R.I., in the Avon Congregational Church by the Rev. Theodore C. Schoonmaker.

New York City sold $165,445,000 of bonds at a net interest cost of almost 6.52 per cent, down from 7.31 per cent in a similar sale in January. This was the first drop in borrowing costs for New York City in a year.

ALBANY, April 16 (AP) Leaders of the Iroquois Confederacy appealed to New York officials today to return to them religious and political wampum belts in custody of the state under a 72-yearold agreement whose validity the Indians are challenging.
MOSCOW April 16 (UPI) Soviet astronauts today sent the Apollo 13 crew their best wishes for a safe return to earth.

William F. Kenney, a scout for and sponsor of college and high school athletes, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital, after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 953 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 16 (AP) The St. Louis Blues, powered by Red Berenson and Ab McDonald, moved into the semifinals of the Stanley Cup playoffs with a 4-2 victory tonight over the Minnesota North Stars.

ABOARD U.S.S. IWO JIMA, at Sea, April 16 (AP) Lieut. (j.g.) James Coolbaugh sailed from Pearl Harbor April 4 with only one quick job to do on a three-week cruise. And now he's out of that.
LONDON, April 16 The Rev. Ian Paisley, the Protestant militant, won a by-election today to fill a seat in Northern Ireland's Parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Judge Harry A. Blackmun, President Nixon's latest Supreme Court nominee, is expected to be questioned closely on ethical matters by the Senate Judiciary Committee as a result of the disclosure that he has participated in three cases involving companies in which he owned stock.
WILTON, Conn., April 16 Mrs. Margaret L. Martin, the wife of Raymond Martin, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. She was 68 years old, and lived here for 35 years.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 More than a few skeptics who had scoffed at the touring series from which a definitive world champion harness racing driver would emerge, found considerable merit in the idea tonight.
The sign hanging from the rafters said, "We Will Bury You," but it was the Rangers, not the Boston Bruins, who got buried last night at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The head of the Federal Aviation Administration repeated today the Government's determination to discharge the leaders of the recent slowdonw by Federal air traffic controllers but said that they might be given a chance to resign first.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 16 Juan Bosch, a man of letters as well as a political leader, is a student of the Bible, and his essays include what amounts to an apology for Judas Iscariot.

ALBANY, April 16 The Court of Appeals today ruled that Mrs. Alice Crimmins, a Queens housewife convicted of killing her 4-year-old daughter, was entitled to a new trial because three jurors visited the scene of the alleged crime.

BOSTON, April 16 (AP) A Federal judge issued guidelines today designed to help a Massachusetts court decide how to release the transcript of the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne, killed in Senator Edward M. Kennedy's car accident last July.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16 Tear gas still hung in the air near Harvard Yard late today after a night of rioting led by the November Action Coalition, an offshoot of Students for a Democratic Society.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended April 11, was reported considerably below the corresponding week of last year, following work stoppages throughout. Freight traffic on United States railroads in the same period registered increased tonnage.

Major producers of stainless steel disclosed yesterday that they had reduced scheduled prices last week or earlier for a few product lines, mainly to meet discounting, market softness and official cuts by some smaller companies.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday reorganized the Model Cities program here to provide "the tools and leverage needed to allow Model Cities to move ahead at full speed with complete community participation."

A pale young fireman in a wheelchair, who was seriously injured in December while responding to a false alarm, was carried down the steps of Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday morning and given a hero's welcome by his colleagues and a fourth-grade class that seems to have adopted him.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The United States has received a specific request from Cambodia for arms and military supplies, but not American troops, to fight North Vietnamese and Vietcong invaders, State Department officials said today.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (Reuters) Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that any cuts made by President Nixon in United States troop strength in Europe would be relatively small and would not weaken the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

NEW ORLEANS, April 16 (AP) Bobby Mitchell, a drawling Virginian, fired an early, 7-under-par 65 today, then sat back and watched it stand up for the first-round lead in the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tournament.

Mrs. Isadore Berger of Forest Hills, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rodley Joy Berger, to Ronald Matthew Polon. He is the son of Matthew Polon, president of the R.K.O.-Stanley Warner Theaters, and Mrs. Polon of Woodmere, L.I.A wedding in the summer is planned.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The Federal Aviation Administration had its medical officers, including a staff psychiatrist, investigate the tactics and motives of F. Lee Bailey, the Boston lawyer who directed the air traffic controllers' threeweek "sick-out" that ended this week.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16 Haverford College announced today that it would not give the state the names of Pennsylvania students receiving state aid who are involved in campus disorders.

ALBBANY, April 16 The State Senate today voted final legislative approval of a proposed constitutional amendment that would end the ban against state aid to parochial schools but permit court challenges by taxpayers.

ALBANY, April 16 Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the state take over commuter service on the Harlem and Hudson divisions of the Penn Central and asked the Legislature to approve a $65-million, bondfinanced modernization program for the lines.

Lou Carnesecca smiled as he looked up from his desk yesterday in the office of the New York Nets at Hempstead, L.I. Things were looking up for the American Basketball Association. A call from the A.B.A. commissioner's office had brought the news that two and possibly three games of the league's championship series would be televised nationally by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 16 (AP) Roger Hagberg, 31year-old reserve fulllback and tight end for the Oakland Raiders, was killed last night when his car crashed into a highway guard rail and hurtled across the road, throwing him into the path of another car.

The Southern California Edison Company's first-quarter revenues and earnings ran ahead of 1969 levels but costs "in virtually all aspects of operation continued to reflect the adverse impact of inflation," T.M. McDaniel, president, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Los Angeles.

LISBON, April 16 The Portuguese Government announced today that it would try 10 left-wing political activists, including a candidate for parliament in last October's election, on charges of having links with the anti-Portuguese guerrilla movement in Africa.

A SURPRISINGLY large number of musicians and critics are split about Lorin Maazel. Some consider him the most talented of the younger conductors a man with an amazing memory, tremendous control, innate musicianship and a great deal of power. Others consider him a cold fish, an "I.B.M. conductor," a precisionist without soul.
CHARLIE EDDY had that Clyde Beatty look about him yesterday as he reflected on the stock market as a menagerie containing many depressed values.

WASHINGTON, April 16 A House Committee subcommittee, in a move that represented a tremendous victory for the antiregulation forces in the mutual fund industry, decided today to substitute legislation that the industry has little or no objection to for a stricter measure that passed the Senate.

Wilmot Brookings Mitchell 2d, a partner in the law firm of Hall, McNicol, Marett Hamilton, 41 East 42d Street, died Wednesday of cancer at Memorial Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived at 116 East 63d Street.
When a bearded man stepped through Gate 34 at La Guardia Airport Wednesday night to board a Miami-bound Eastern Airlines plane, a red light flashed on an electronic device called a Friskem.
WASHINGTON, April 16 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today a new program of one-year advances to savings and loan associations at a subsidized interest rate
PRINCETON, N.J., April 16 John O'Hara, the novelist, was buried here today after a funeral service in the Princeton University Chapel. Mr. O'Hara had lived here since 1953.

RICHMOND, April 15 6:47 P.M. "Hokay, hokay, the Monster of the Payement is on its way," roars Barker Keith as he swings the wheel of his barn-red International Harvester tandem tractor out into the heavy traffic of Kings Highway in Bridgeport, Conn. Grinding into third

On behalf of the United States delegation, I want to thank you, Foreign Minister Waldheim, for your gracious words of welcome. May I also take this opportunity to convey my delegations' appreciation to you and to the Austrian Government for the cooperation shown in providing the site and arrangements for this second phase of the strategic arms limitation talks.

NEW HAVEN, April 16 (AP) James Anthony (Rip) Collins star first baseman of the St. Louis Cardinals during the 1930's, died here yesterday. His age was 65. He is survived by his widow, Joanne, three sons, a daughter and a brother.

VIENNA, April 16 Negotiators for the Soviet Union and the United States opened the second round of the strategic arms limitation talks at a formal ceremony here today and immediately decided to get down to business at two working sessions tomorrow and Monday.

If all goes well in these last hours of Apollo 13's fantastic flight, the most perilous journey human beings have ever undertaken will end safely in the Pacific today. The space ship crippled in mid-course, then desperately struggling to reach a safe harbor before disaster strikes, is a familiar theme in science fiction but now it has become reality.
David Berger, a vice president of ABC Records, Inc., a subsidiary of the American Broadcasting Company, died at his home in Forest Hills Wednesday. He was 54 years old.

In nominating Judge Harry A. Blackmun to the Supreme Court, President Nixon appears finally to have met the exacting standards of excellence that the Senate has rightly demanded for one of the nation's most responsible and respected lifetime offices.
Like the Latin mass and fish on Friday, the regular visit to the confession box may be on its way to obsolescence in the Roman Catholic Church.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) The Massachusetts House passed a bill today to allow voluntary prayers in public schools. The roll call vote that sent it to the Senate was 207-17.
WASHINGTON, April 16 Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio was sitting last week in a model kitchen in Bryan, Ohio, discussing his campaign for the Senate with a group of supporters.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The House Armed Services Committee voted today to authorize funds requested by the Administration to add a third site to the Safeguard antiballistic missile system and to go ahead with preliminary work on five more sites.

PLATEAU D'ASSY, France, April 16 Seventy-two persons were declared dead today after thousands of tons of mud crashed onto the boys' wing of a children's tuberculosis sanitarium here in the heart of the French Alps.

Evidence of Government-inspired mass murder of Vietnamese civilians living in Cambodia should provoke second thoughts in Washington about the stability as well as the morality of the regime that recently displaced Prince Sihanouk in Pnompenh.

With oil futures leading the way, activity in the soybean complex on the Chicago Board of Trade was hectic yesterday. Soybean oil futures hit new highs for the season an all options. while the aMy contract advanced nearly the limit. Soybean meal and soybeans futures also closed higher.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16 Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet Union's chief delegate to the United Nations, said today that the situation in Southeast Asia "is not a matter for the United Nations," but one for a new Geneva Conference.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 16 William J. Baxter, an economist and former president of the Baxter International Economic Research Bureau, died today at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 2 High Ridge Road, Larchrnont, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Apollo 13's main recovery ship, the helicopter carrier Iwo Jima, is being positioned to rescue the astronauts by a oncesecret Navy navigation system that has almost pinpoint accuracy.
PABLO CASALS wasn't around very long Wednesday at the benefit concert and gala in his honor, but he seemed to be having a good time.

United Press International awarded a $1-million contract yesterday to Data Dimensions, Inc., for the development and implementation of a highly sophisticated automated system of gathering, editing and distributing news.
As they have for every National Hockey League season in the last 30 years the Rangers were once again denied last night a chance of attaining hockey's ultimate prize: the Stanley Cup.
The Federal Reserve System pushed its policy of "modest" monetary growth in the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.

UTICA, April 16 A As their campaign trails crossed time and again, Howard J. Samuels carried the fight today to Arthur J. Goldberg, the man ehviews as his "opposition" for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

ALBANY, April 16 Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders said today they had agreed on a package of new local taxes and revenue-sharing measures including offtrack betting and a numbers-type of state lottery that would yield New York City more than $400-million.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 16 (AP) Retired Vice Adm. Richard L. Cruzen, who commanded pioneering cruises in both Arctic and Aantarctic waters during a 35-year Navy career, died yesterday at the age of 72.

PARIS The second session of Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) which just started in Vienna is unlikely to produce dramatic results. The talks come at an unfortunate moment since nobody could have foreseen when their date was fixed that the Soviet Government would then be engaged in internal political contortions.

The chairman of the Barnard College French Department, Dr. LeRoy C. Breunig, has been named dean of the Barnard faculty. The appointment was approved Wednesday night at a meeting of the college's board of trustees.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 (AP) Fotomat Corporation, filed a $321.5-million action against the Eastman Kodak Company in the Federal District Court here yesterday, charging conspiracy to violate antitrust laws.

The Metropolitan Opera had planned to include Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" in its current season but had to abandon it when its schedule was truncated by last fall's labor dispute. However, in order to keep it in the repertory of the company's spring tour, which begins next Monday, it put on one performance last night, and it will be brought back for the Met's two-week gala at Lincoln Center in June.
Major companies in four di verse industries issued similar bad news yesterday; sharply lower, profits for the quarter ended March 31.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The American Civil Liberties Union complained to the Federal Government today that the new application for permission to picket near the White House was almost impossible to fill out.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 16 Arthur J. Goldberg charged today that the Rockefeller administration was suffering from hardening of the arteries.
Fifty travelers waited unhappily at the taxi stand of the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy International Airport at 9 P.M. the other night.

Time Inc., the world's largest publishing company, reported yesterday that it had made a recovery in the first quarter of the year. Operating earnings for the period were $1,083,000, equal to 15 cents a share, in contrast to an operating loss of $300,000 in the initial three months of 1969.

MOSCOW, April 16 Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, flew to Lenin's birthplace today and made his third nationally televised speech in four days. He asserted that, although the road might be hard, Communism would eventually triumph around the world.

The Board of Estimate approved major expansions of urban renewal housing plans in Brooklyn yesterday. It added 425 units in the Fulton Park project of the general Brooklyn Model Cities area and 1,362 in the Coney Island neighborhood development area.
STRASBOURG, France, April 15 The United States Government and the major American automobile manufacturers plan to share with foreign manufacturers the fruits of their research on automotive safety.

The gloom gathered a little deeper on Wall Street yesterday as stock prices took another beating in a broad-based retreat that took its toll of blue-chip and glamour issues and a lot of stocks in between.

President Nixon's nomination of Judge Blackmun to the Supreme Court offers a promising opportunity to end the unseemly political bickering over the Court appointment and to restore public confidence in the independent judiciary and the Presidency. House Republican Leader Gerald R. Ford's attack on Justice William O. Douglas points in just the opposite direction.

The tentative agreement Mayor Lindsay has won in Albany for a state revenue-sharing program that will provide more than a quarter-billion dollars in extra aid to New York and other hard-pressed cities represents the longest step this state has taken in many years toward a sounder balance of fiscal responsibility.

The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company announced yesterday that it would lend money at a preferred interest rate as an inducement to, "get something going" on the problem of environmental pollution.
LONDON, April 16 At the Old Vic one night last week, Maggie Smith was playing Mrs. Sullen, the unsatisfied wife in Farquhar's "The Beaux' Stratagem."

The Legislative Conference of City University, the collective bargaining agent for 5,500 tenured faculty members, yesterday announced its affiliation with the National Education Association and the New York Teachers Association.

Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio filed a $6.3-million libel suit against Time Inc., in Federal District Court here yesterday, disputing an article, "The Governor and the Mobster," that was published in Life magazine last May 2.

BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP) Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Melville, a former priest and nun, surrendered today to a United States marshal to begin serving prison terms for participating in the burning of draft board records in suburban Catonsville.
Theodore W. Kheel, the lawyer and labor mediator, renewed yesterday his attack on the Port of New York Author ity, saying it "has taken a copout on mass transportation."
WASHINGTON, April 16 The fierce winds and driving rains of early April have suddenly subsided here, and the capital of the United States is ablaze with flowering trees.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 16 Juan Bosch, leader of the Dominican leftist opposition, returned from three years of exile today and received a tumultuous welcome despite police efforts to restrain his supporters.
WASHINGTON, April 16. Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress on postal reform and pay increases for postal employes:

MILWAUKEE, April 17 On the strength of a magnificent all-round performance by Lew Alcindor, who scored 33 points, grabbed 31 rebounds and exceded on defense, the Milwaukee Bucks made an early lead stand up and defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 101-96, tonight.
BUDAPEST, April 17 (UPI) Pete Veres, former head of the Hungarian Writers Association and ex-defense minister, died yesterday at the age of 74, according to the M.T.I. news agency.

State Democratic Chairman John J. Burns, who is backing Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor, has removed himself from the state committee's payroll "to remove any question about the legality of my full support of ... candidates designated by the New York State Democratic Committee."

CANTON, Ohio Ask most of the political professionals in Ohio whether United States Representative Donald E. Lukens has a chance, and they will list the reasons why he ought to lose not enough money, too young, too much of a loner. But then they will tell you that he may win, anyway.
Two Brooklyn men were convicted of murder last night in the 1968 shooting of a policeman outside an East Side discotheque.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) Judge Julius J. Hoffman of Federal District Court granted today a Government request to continue until June the riot conspiracy charges against Bobby G. Seale, Black Panther party chairman.
ABOARD U.S.S. IWO JIMA, at Sea, April 17 The three Apollo 13 astronauts splashed down gently today in the Pacific, ending a four-day fight for survival.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) Hundreds of Washington newsmen paid memorial tribute today to Merriman Smith, chief White House correspondent for United Press International, who died last Monday at the age of 57.

HOUSTON, April 17 Snap 27, a nuclear generator aboard the lunar module jettisoned by the Apollo 13 crew before re-entry today, apparently fell into 2,700 fathoms of water in the Pacific Ocean northeast of New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, April 17 The State Department said today that United States deliveries of military equipment to Greece had been "generally consistent with our militaryassistance-program policy of suspended shipment of major end items."
WASHINGTON, April 17 The White House condemned today the slayings of Vietnamese civilians in Cambodia as "abhorrent."

As four Soviet ships moved into the South Pacific to fulfill an offer by their Government to help in the recovery of the Apollo 13 astronauts, President Nixon sent a message to Premier Kosygin expressing his "deep gratitude" for the offer but that the ships were not needed.
American Airlines will formally open a passenger lounge for Boeing 747 passengers at Kennedy International Airport tomorrow as it starts its 747 flights between New York and San Francisco.

An 18-year-old Bronx youth charged with having set off bombs in Federal office buildings here last fall was sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for a psychiatric examination after the Government said his acts might have been affected by his use of drugs.
Prices closed narrowly mixed on the London stock exchange yesterday as trading turned sluggish.

Miss. Akiko Kobayashi of Tokyo and Dr. John Z. Bowers of New York, president of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation here, were married yesterday morning in a civil ceremony in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I, April 17 Ernest W. Pittman, president in the nineteen-thirties and forties of Interchemical Corporation (now Inmont Corporation) died Wednesday at his home at Terbell Lane. He was 80 years old and also lived in Georgetown, Washington.
BOSTON, April 17 (AP) The Kopechne papers were ordered impounded indefinitely in a ruling issued today by Judge Wilfred J. Paquet in Suffolk Superior Court.
PURCHASE, N.Y., April 13 When a family moves from a city apartment to a country home, it has to acquire a whole new set of skills that go with owning a home.

The Magnavox Company's first-quarter net profit fell to less than half of its earnings in the same period last year. Profits for the quarter were $5,340,000, or 33 cents a share, compared with $11,151,000, or 67 cents a share, in the same period of 1969, a drop of 52.1 per cent. Sales were down 20.4 per cent to $117,150,000 from $147,265,000 the year before.
The family of 15-year-old Jimmy Santos got a better apartment yesterday, but it took a group of angry neighbors and a funeral to accomplish it.

MILWAUKEE, April 17 Professional basketball play ers fight three instruments used by management to control their lives and restrict competition the college draft, the reserve clause and forced trades. This week, the owners seemed ready to take up a fourth instrument, the merger of the rival leagues, the older, established, televised National Basketball Association and the new, aggressive, possibly richer American Basketball Association.

CLEVELAND, April 17 Henry C. Osborn Jr., former president of the Glascote Products Company of Euclid, Ohio, and son of the founder of the Addressograph and Multigraph Corporation, died today after a long illness at his home at 2319 Ardleigh Drive, Cleveland Heights. He was 59 years old.

If the real Maria Sabina of Mexico is as extraordinary a performer as Maria Soledad Romero, the Puerto Rican actress who portrayed her in the premiere of "Maria Sabina" at Carnegie Hall last night, it is not surprising that she has been the object of so much popular and scholarly attention over the last several years.

Nearly 16,000 telephone installers and repairmen walked off their jobs in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday afternoon in a dispute with the New York Telephone Company over security during work assignments in highcrime areas of the city.

The circus clowns were putting on makeup a few feet away yesterday and the Rangers' dressing room was deserted. The uniforms hung on a metal rod in the middle of the room. The skates lay on benches, under the nameplates.

At a time when increasing numbers of nations are inviting Americans to visit their lands without visas and without scrutiny of their teachings and writings the State Department is using its visa power to deny entry to the United States on political grounds. A few weeks ago Dr. Ernest E. Mandel, a Marxist economist from Belgium, was prevented from speaking here after a number of university scholars had invited him.
THE BOYS IN THE BAND" has just en tered its third year at Theater Four on West 55th Street, and the damndest thing has happened to it. It has become a period piece.

National Basketball Association player representatives succeeded yesterday in halting merger negotiations between the N.B.A. and the American Basketball Association. They obtained a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court staying the merger discussions.
The Control Data Corporation announced yesterday the creation of a corporate office to share top management responsibility in the company.

WASHINGTON, April 17 The American Bar Association's committee that rates prospective judicial nominees will decide tomorrow whether to pass on the qualifications of Judge Harry A. Blaekmun to sit on the Supreme Court.

Strict new regulations are being drafted by the city to reduce further the sulphur in fuel oil because officials say a public-health danger exists despite restrictions that have cut more than half the sulphur from fuel burned here.
SAN DIEGO, April 17 (AP) Houston Ridge, defensive end for the San Diego Chargers, sued the team and professional football today for $1.25-million because of a hip injury.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 17 (Reuters) A military spokesman said today that the Vietcong had more than doubled their area of control in Cambodia in the last two weeks.
The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad will consider forming a holding company to diversify outside the transportation industry.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 17 (AP) Kathy Whitworth, Sandra Haynie, Judy Kimball and Gloria Ehret fired three-underpar 69's today to tie for the first-round lead in the $16,500 fifth annual Raleigh women's invitation tournament.
ALBANY, April 17 The State Legislature approved state aid of $28-million for nonpublic schools today, with proponents hailing it as a major, but small step, toward saving the troubled private system.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 17 (AP) Larry Kristoff, a former Southern Illinois wrestling star, scored a pin in only 22 seconds today and maintained an unblemished "black mark" record in the National Amateur Athletic Union free-style championships.

Edward SwayducK, president of Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America, said yesterday that the dividends from this country's moon shots had "produced unprecedented technological windfalls reaching into every corner of our society and industry."

MILWAKEE, April 17 It was no surprise to anyone in the Milwaukee Arena to see Lew Alcindor play one of the greatest games of his short professional career tonight in leading the Bucks to what the Milwaukee players considered a "must" victory over the New York Knicks.
IT was lunchtime when the little boy wandered into the office of the school guidance counselor. He greeted her solemnly and then made straight for a shelt of toys.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 17 Santa Barbara County deputy sheriffs, reinforced by riot control squads from police agencies in neighboring counties, stood prepared today to quell expected new youth demonstrations in the community of Isla Vista, bordering the University of California's Santa Barbara campus.

LONDON, April 17 (UPI) Evonne Goolagong, an 18-yearold Australian, reached the final of the Cumberland hard court tennis championship today by beating Marilyn Aschner, Holliswood, Queens, 3-6, 11-9, 6-2.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Selective Service System has told its local boards not to draft anyone with a lottery number higher than 145 in May, a headquarters spokesman says.
WASHINGTON, April 17 Dennis Gabor, who is known as the father of holography, or three-dimensional lensless photography, was granted a patent this week...
Landlords and apartment house employes broke off negotiations yesterday after the owners rejected a union proposal that would have postponed a strike in 5,000 buildings for 30 days.

WASHINGTON, April 17 The United States agreed today to recall its Ambassador from Jordan, as requested by the Jordanian Government, but the State Department expressed hope that this incident would not impair "the close and cordial relations" with the Arab country.
NEWARK, April 17 (AP) The on-again, off-again, television report by the National Broadcasting Company on Newark appears to be on again.

An invoice arrived yeserday at the Houston office of North American Rockwell, the company that makes the Apollo command and service modules. It was from the Grumman Aerospace Corporation, builder of the lunar module, the moon-landing craft that turned unexpectedly into a "lifeboat" on the Apollo 13 flight.

WASHINGTON, April 17 The White House said today that the United States was interested in exploring with the Soviet Union the possibility of convening an international conference to resolve the conflicts in Indochina.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) President Nixon appointed today five members of the board of directors of the reorganized Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May).
THERE were two big attractions in the ballroom of 1 Beekman Place the other day: Colorful patchwork fashions, and Mrs. John D. (Jay) Rockefeller 4th. Both are from West Virginia.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 17 Ruth B. Manser of Woodland Avenue, who retired in 1957 as an associate professor of education at New York University, died yesterday, at a nursing home in Whippany. She was 78 years old.
The revenue package to help balance next year's city budget that was worked out by state and city officials is divided into four main categories. They are:
THE Hector Guimard exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art will remind collectors of the variations in the quality of art nouveau objects by showing them the best.
WASHINGTON, April 17 The possibility of legislated import quotas on textiles moved a step closer today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 President Nixon dropped all other duties today to follow the Apollo 13 astronauts during their final moments of descent. He applauded when they splashed down and lit up a triumphant cigar when they boarded the aircraft carrier Iwo Jima.

TAKEO, Cambodia, April 17 About 100 Vietnamese civilians, including perhaps 30 children, were shot to death by Cambodian soldiers last night in a grade school where they were under detention, survivors said today at the scene of the slayings.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) Jim Maloney, Cincinnati Reds' pitcher, underwent surgery today for a ruptured Achilles tendon in his left ankle, an injury suffered in last night's game against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, April 17 Robert W. Haack, as president of the New York Stock Exchange, proposed today a system of insurance against brokerage firm failures that would involve the Federal Government only as a lender of last resort in the case of widespead bankruptcies.
The New York Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday, 6-0, and crossed two frontiers somebody finally pitched a complete game and somebody finally hit a home run.
MOSCOW, April 17 The Soviet Union today reported a significant improvement in its economy for the first three months of 1970.

A HAUNTINGLY effective and heartrending adap tation of the novel "They," by Marya Mannes, essayist, critic and writer, was shown last night on the National Educational Television Playhouse over Channel 13. The drama, on which Miss Mannes and Harding LeMay collaborated, was an ode to the values of those beyond 50 years of age and their appreciation that freedom and discipline must go together, that in their time too they wanted truth, peace and beauty.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 Cambodia's new chief delegate here said today that he did not want to believe Cambodian soldiers had slain hundreds of innocent Vietnamese civilians.

ATLANTA, April 17 (UPI) Nine major airlines have called off their $100,000 war on fog at the Atlanta airport because of a lack of fog and because when the fog appeared, it was so thick the antifogging plane could not get off the ground.

WASHINGTON, April 17 Johnny Cash came from the country to the capital tonight to perform at the White House. He had his audience mostly people from Tennessee, where he makes his home, and Arkansas, his birth state tapping their feet and swaying in their seats.

After a record trading volume of 19,779 contracts on Thursday, soybean oil futures attracted somewhat less attention yesterday. Prices drifted lower for the day although some deliveries made new lifeof-contract highs.

LONDON, April 17 The prospects for peace in troubled Northern Ireland appeared to have been further dimmed today after the election of the controversial Rev. Ian Paisley to Ulster's provincial parliament.

The fans were unhappy, and James J. Woody, the beaten fighter, was most unhappy when Referee Johnny Colan stopped his heavyweight fight with unbeaten George Foreman at 37 seconds of the third round last night in the Felt Forum.

ALBANY, April 17 Republican legislative leaders said today that they had enough votes to pass a $400-million package of tax and revenue measures for New York City that is designed to help close a budget gap estimated by Mayor Lindsay at $630-million.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) President Nixon willdeliver his television-andradio report on Vietnam Monday evening from his home in San Clemente, Calif.
ACROSS the street is Central Park clothed in its seasonal garb. On weekends, if the weather's right, the strollers are an animated film strip, and colorful balloons bob in the chestnutscented air.
DACCA, Pakistan It is a striking thing about this Moslem city, the capital of East Pakistan, that few women are to be seen on the streets.

After eighty-nine years, the State Legislature has aroused itself and approved a major recodification of criminal procedures in New York. It is not exactly a model code; too many conflicting views had to be reconciled. But it makes important changes in the archaic language and in the confusing sections of the old law. The opportunity now exists to improve the administration of justice at all levels from the arrest to the appeal stage.

PLATEAU D'ASSY, France April 17 Two minor landslides last night forced rescuers to step up efforts to recover the bodies of the 72 victims of the avalanche that destroyed the boys' wing of a children's tuberculosis sanitarium here. The bodies of 28 boys and eight members of the sanitarium staff have been recovered so far.

LOS ANGELES, April 17 (AP) Richard Neutra, acclaimed as one of the world's most influential modern architects, died last night apparently of a heart attack at Wuppertal, Germany, his family said today. His age was 78. He was on a tour of Neutra architectural projects in Europe.
CHICAGO, April 17 America's longshore industry was advised here today to take a leaf from European waterfront labor-management practices and adopt permanent management-labor councils.

Witold Woyda, the diminutive Polish star, culminated a day of brilliant campaigning last night by defeating Roland Losert of Austria in the final foil match of the Martini Rossi international fencing tournament at the New York Athletic Club.

NEW ORLEANS, April 17 (AP) George Archer, the lanky golfer from Gilroy, Calif. who hasn't won in more than a year, bolted into the lead today after two rounds of the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open with a sparkling five-under-par 67. His total for 36 holes was 133, giving him a two-stroke lead over Howie Johnson of Palm Springs, Calif.

Laverne L. Hammer has been elected president of Collier-Macmillan International. He succeeds Leo P. Mabel, who has been named vice president in charge of international publishing sales for Crowell Collier Macmillan, Inc., the parent organization.
The election of Gilbert H. Jones as chairman of the board of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation was announced yesterday. He also has been elected chairman of the company's executive committee.
TOKYO, April 17 (AP) Australia's Davis Cup tennis team met surprisingly stubborn resistance today from Japan before winning the first two matches of their Asian Zone Section A final.

The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company announced yesterday that it would lend money at a preferred interest rate as an inducement to "get something going" on the problem of environmental pollution.
NEWARK, April 17 Alexander Bernardik, who had practiced law in New York for 55 years, died at the Newark Beth Isarel Medical Center yesterday of cancer. He was 80 years old.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 17 President Suharto announced today sweeping changes in Indonesia's foreign exchange rates. Speaking before members of Parliament, he said that the new system of a "general foreign exchange rate" would hopefully simplify the complicated bureaucratic problems previously experienced under Indonesia's multiple rate system for foreign trade.
THE recent death of Albert Rose, the English expert, deprived the world of international bridge of one of its most engaging personalities.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that prices of fabricated panels for mobile homes and recreational vehicles have been raised by about 2.5 per cent with orders placed April 14 and on all shipments made after May 14.
The Wood Memorial, the New York racing fans' preview of the Triple Crown, will have its 46th running today, at Aqueduct.

The weather was clear, the track fast, but the only meet record that was set was in a field event as the two-day 16th annual Queens Iona Relays opened yesterday with a schoolboy program at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 17 One of the most intensely fought election campaigns in 22 years is drawing to a close with new manifestations of bitterness between the governing Nationalist party and an extreme right-wing splinter group.
John F. Budd, a maritime publisher and a specialist in international trade, died Thursday of cancer in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old and lived at 247 Stratford Road, Brooklyn.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17 (AP) The New York Nets, with Levern Tart scoring 46 points, held off a Kentucky rally tonight and defeated the Colonels, 122-118, in overtime.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) Under Secretary of the Treasury Charls E. Walker said today that the country was "well on the road to wageprice stability with strongly encouraging signs of having avoided the opposite danger of high unemployment and recession."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17 The mass killings of Vietnamese in Cambodia in recent days have stirred deep anger among the people here and have confronted the Government with a difficult political problem.

MOSCOW, April 19 Tens of thousands of Soviet citizens waited for hours to see the embalmed body of Lenin, others darted into shops in search of vodka, still others fought for wholesale flowers they would sell at high prices.
RYE N.Y., April 19 Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club, who headed the draw, won the Rye invitation open squash tennis championship today for the third straight year.

WASHINGTON, April 19 Mrs. Marion Henley of Chicago got a phone call the other day from a woman who saw her on a local television show. The caller said: "I heard you talking about whatever that thing was you were talking about. I called to tell you I didn't receive whatever it was you were talkine about."

Santa Fe Industries, Inc. (the corporate parent of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway) and Husky Oil, Ltd., have agreed to study the feasibility of affiliating the interests of the two companies, they announced over the weekend.
Passover, which commemorates the liberation of the ancient Israelites from bondage in Egypt, begins at sundown today with the traditional Seder the ceremonial feast.
Bond underwriters, fearful for several reasons that prices of fixed-income securities will register further declines, can be expected to bid cautiously for new offerings this week.

AKRON, Ohio, April 19 Miss Susan R. Pearl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl D. Pearl, was married at her parents' home here today to Richard I. Grausman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Roland I. Grausman of New York. Rabbi Morton Applebaum performed the ceremony.
BEIRUE, Lebanon, April 19 Two Jordanian Army officers known to be on good terms with Palestinian guerillas were appointed to key posts in Cabinet and military changes announced in Amman tonight.

In one of the biggest surprises since the international martini Rossi fencing jamboree was introduced at the New York Athletic Club 10 years ago, Rolando Rigoli, an agile competitor from Italy, won the saber championship last night.

BUENOS AIRES, April 19 The administration of the $6billion Inter-American Development Bank is bracing for a major revolt of its member countries when its governors open their 10th annual meeting tomorrow across the River Plate at Punta del Este, Uruguay.

HOUSTON, April 19 The Apollo 13 astronauts were welcomed home tonight with a message from President Nixon reiterating his "strong, firm support" of the nation's manned space program despite the aborted moon mission.
WASHINGTON, April 19 After nearly a year of trying to mobilize Americans against the war in Vietnam, the Vietnam Moratorium Committee announced today that it was disbanding.

MONTERREY, Calif., April 19 Parnelli Jones of Torrance, Calif., driving a year-old Ford Mustang and handicapped by an injured left eye, won the first Trans-American championship race of the season today at Laguna Seca Raceway.
Net revenues of the New York Stock Exchange plummeted 61 per cent to $803,300 from $2,059,000 in the first quarter of this year, Robert W. Haack, president, reported over the weekend.

The appointment of Leonard S. Silk to the editorial board of The New York Times was announced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page. Mr. Silk has been a senior fellow of the Brookings Institution in Washington for the last year.

A potential threat of antitrust actions "hangs over hundreds of newspaper publishers," an American Newspaper Publishers Association committee said yesterday, on the eve of the association's 84th annual convention here.

CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) Boston's high-scoring center, Phil Esposito, beat his younger brother, Tony, the Chicago Black Hawks' goalie, for three goals today to lead the Bruins to a 6-3 victory in the opener of their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series. Tony was the winner of the Vezina Trophy during the regular National Hockey League season for his record 15 shutouts.

ALBANY, Monday, April 20 The Assembly, in less than a half-hour debate, passed four new tax bills that are part of a $400-million revenue package designed to cover two-thirds of New York City's prospective $630-million budget gap.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 19 There is a 5foot-3-inch-tall woman here who has been termed "the flea in the ear" of the Government of Prime Minister John Vorster.
Around 5000 B.C., scientists have estimated, there were fewer people on the face of the globe than there are now in New York City.

AUBURN, N.Y., April 19 (AP) Assemblyman George M. Michaels, who last week cast what proved to be the swaying vote for approval of the abortion reform bill in the Legislature, was denied today the endorsement by his party for re-election.
WASHINGTON, April 19 Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin, a tall man with an amiable smile, will learn this week how many friends he has on the House Agriculture Committee.
Central Synagogue, which claims the distinction of being the nation's second oldest synagogue in continuous use, found a cornerstone yesterday that it had "lost" in the last century.

A three-alarm fire, alleged to have been deliberately set, heavily damaged a row of six attached three-story frame apartment buildings in the Bronx last night, making 75 persons homeless and slightly injuring two firemen.

CLEVELAND, April 19 Most of them came here in their black habits the veils set a little farther back on their heads now, the hemline a few inches below the knee but many wore neat suits or dresses in bright pink, green or yellow.

The pressures for an early debate among the three Democratic candidates for Governor mounted yesterday with the announcement by the New Democratic Coalition that it would meet next Sunday to consider endorsing one of them.

"Applause" and Lauren Bacall, its star, walked off with top honors as best musical and best actress in a musical last night at the 24th annual presentations of the Antoinette Perry Awards at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

Carlton Harrison along with 2,400 other randomly chosen pupils here answered his telephone the other day and got ready for one of a series of automated arithmetic drills that have improved by 20 per cent some pupils' ability to add, subtract, multiply and divide.

The National Distillers Product Company is assigning its Old Crow bourbon to Ogilvy Mather. And so ends a search that started on Feb. 2 when the distiller first announced it would be shifting the $4-million account out of Lennen Newell.

Inspired, if not embarrassed, by the emergence of Bud Harrelson as an extra-base slugger, the New York Mets eventually rewarded the largest April audience, except for opening days, in Shea Stadium history yesterday by splitting a dou-ble-header with the Philadelphia Phillies.
CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) One person in each million vaccinated for the first time against smallpox dies of the injection, the Journal of the American Medical Association said in its current edition.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 19 Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, a former military dictator now heading a populist movement, claimed victory tonight in the election for president.
NEW ORLEANS, April 19 The stars were as bright as lanterns but there was no moon.

NEW ORLEANS, April 19 (AP) Bob Charles, a left-handed player from New Zealand, stormed out of the pack with a final round of 67 today and tied Miller Barber and Howie Johnson at 278 for the $25,000 first prize in the Greater New Orleans open golf tournament. The deadlock will be resolved in a sudden-death playoff tomorrow.

The City's Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday that contractors at many construction sites were not obeying the new regulations requiring the contain ment of asbestos dust and that it would order work halted on projects that did not comply.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 19 (UPI) Ruben Olivares of Mexico, who retained his bantamweight championship with a over Shucho Castillo, also of Mexico, last night, wants to make his third title defense after a "short rest."

NEW DELHI In the homes of New Delhi, Mrs. Chand Balbir Singh was explaining, cooking goes on for 12 hours a day, seven days a week. And Mrs. Singh is something of an exception in her community. Although she has two maids and one cook, she does most of the cooking for her family.

Rocco Bruzzese, the Rocky of the Rocky Lee Chu-Cho Bianco Italian restaurant at 987 Second Avenue, at 52d Street, died last Tuesday of cancer at the White Plains Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived at 26 Cayuga Road in Scarsdale.
ALBANY, Monday, April 20 The Legislature voted final approval last night of $65-million worth of programs designed to fight the increasing problem of drug addiction among youths.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 19 President Nixon returned to the mainland tonight after a whirlwind trip to Honolulu where he honored the Apollo 13 astronauts. He will address the nation tomorrow night on Vietnam.
George Washington High School will remain closed again today to preclude a renewed outbreak of violence, the Board of Education announced last night.
Months of planning by dozens of organizations and hundreds of people will culminate Wednesday in Earth Day, the largest demonstration ever organized to protest the degradation of the environment.
Apartment house owners made a new contract offer yesterday to their service employes, in an effort to avert a strike threatened for midnight tonight in 5,000 buildings.

Miss Jo Ann Theresa Mirto, daughter of Assemblyman and Mrs. Peter Gasper Mirto of Brooklyn and Stony Brook, L.I., was married in Brooklyn yesterday to Lieut. Allen Henry Karlebach, U.S. A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Karlebach of Bergenfield, N.J. Msgr. Raphael Testagrossa performed the ceremony in St. Joseph Patron Roman Catholic Church.

Rules of the road for auto drivers come from all sources such as the Government, auto clubs the car makers and Ralph Nader, but practical approaches to buying a car still remain more of a game than anything else.

MILWAUKEE, April 19 Doctor Cazzie Russell explained his operating procedure today after giving the Knicks the injection they needed to overcome the Bucks in what might be regarded as the critical game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Division championship series.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 19 (UPI) The Indiana Pacers outlasted the Carolina Cougars, 103 98, today and took a twogame lead in their American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoffs.

A WOMAN who's bored just staring at the tiles when she's taking a bath, might try bathtub gym. The cosmetics companies, shifting their interest temporarily from faces to bodies, seem to think that cleanliness is not the end-all of bathing.
PARIS, April 19 Greek and French politics have become inextricably mixed in the person and activities of JeanJacques Servan-Schreiber, the journalist turned politician.

The United States has rejected with unseemly sharpness Canada's bid to extend her control over the Northwest Passage in order to prevent pollution of her Arctic territories. That rejection is sure to exacerbate relations with Canada while failing to advance the cause of more enlightened international regulation of the seas.
Eight of the last 10 unmanned Soviet rockets fired toward the moon have been aborted, according to a report in the curren issue of Newsweek magazine.
All three major networks said last night that they would televise President Nixon's address to the nation live at 9 o'clock tonight.

MILWAUKEE, April 19 The New York Knickerbockers survived a furious third-period assault by the Milwaukee Bucks to gain a 117-105 victory and a 3-1 lead in their National Basketball Association Eastern playoff series today.
PARIS, April 19 Henri Massis, a defender of the cause of the intellectual Catholic and nationalist right in France and a member of the Academie Francaise, died here on Friday. He was 84 years old.

The nation's total output, corrected for price increases, declined by 0.4 per cent in the first quarter. Since it had already declined by 0.1 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1969, the United States is currently in its fifth postwar recession provided that a recession can be defined as two consecutive quarterly declines in real gross national product.

WASHINGTON, April 19 The United States, it was disclosed today, secretly stationed air observers in northern Laos in 1966 to help guide the bombing of Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese forces by Royal Laotian and American planes.
TOKYO, April 19 (AP) Australia clinched the Eastern Zone, Section A, Davis Cup final today by taking a doubles match from Japan for an insurmountable 3-0 lead in the three-offive-match series.
To Clare McMahon, a secretary who is almost 5feet-11-inches tall, the store means slacks that are long enough. For Gail Shapiro, another secretary, it means shoes size 12.

John Rodriguez, 13 years old, was admitted to Jacobl Hospital in the Bronx for severe electrical burns last week. Dr. Lewis M. Fraad, chief of the pediatrics department, said the boy had been "fried to a crisp." He died the next day.
BUFFALO, April 19 (UPI) Representative Richard D. McCarthy formally re-entered the race for the Democratic party's nomination for the United States Senate tonight.

ROCHESTER, Minn., April 19 Judge Harry A. Blackmun said today that if he became a member of the Supreme Court, he would not expect to agree on all issues with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, his longtime friend and legal associate.

HUGH HEFNER, who became a millionaire with his Playboy Magazine and chain of bunny clubs, appears on television as something of an aging anti-feminist. In his Saturday night hour over WOR-TV it is not just that he interminably chews a pipe stem, which means those slippers for the weary cannot be too far be-...

JERUSALEM, April 19 Israeli Army authorities reported today that an Egyptian jet was downed and two others were hit by Hawk missiles in an attack yesterday against Israeli positions on the Suez Canal.

MOSCOW, April 19 Nicolae Ceausescu, President of Rumania and head of that nation's Communist party, today indicated that while his country sought continued good relations with the Soviet Union it would not lend it military support in case of war with Communist China.
OSAKA, Japan, April 19 (AP) Seiichi Ueno, co-owner of Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest national newspapers, died at his home in Ashiya near here tonight of a heart ailment. He was 87 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 19 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

INUVIK, Northwest Territories, Canada The search for oil in the Canadian Arctic has become so frenzied that this bustling town of 3,000 persons will set up a bypass route to keep next summer's expected torrent of truck traffic from blanketing the main street in dust.

An experiment in teaching black studies that will give pupils a chance to compare some of the standard history textbooks with what they have learned will be introduced tomorrow in the social studies program at Intermediate School 201 in Harlem.
ROCKLAND LAKE, N.Y., April 19 A forest fire burning between the south end of Rockland Lake State Park and Hook Mountain has destroyed 1,000 acres of trees.

CHAUDOC, South Vietnam, April 11 Hundreds of South Vietnamese troops supported by armored vehicles and artillery fire returned here last night from an extensive twoday operation in Cambodia, according to witnesses and knowledgable military sources.

STRASBOURG, France, April 16 Air pollution and vibrations caused by supersonic planes have helped to bring "a dramatic acceleration in damage to the stonework" of Strasbourg Cathedral and its famous spire, French authorities have found.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 19 Theodore Yudain, editor of The Stamford Advocate, died at Greenwich Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 22 Valleywood Road, Cos Cob.

COINCIDENTALLY, the Eagle that landed on the moon last summer was not the first pioneer flying craft to bear that name. It must have been coincidence, for had the men of NASA remembered Eagle's ancestor, they would surely have chosen another name.

WASHINGTON, April 19 A group of more than 20 economists, most of them academics but some from business, has been asked to help decide exactly what should be studied by the new Commission on Financial Institutions.
OWERRI, Nigeria, April 8 The conquered nation that was Biafra is struggling to its feet with some success.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 The nation's 100 Methodist bishops today called the war in Vietnam a "fiasca impossible to justify" and urged the immediate acceleration of troop withdrawals along with stepped-up peace talks in Paris.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Hanoi has called on Communist forces to kill American soldiers in South Vietnam at a rate "far beyond the 100-aweek level, which the United States ruling clique has considered bearable."

Students strikes, demonstrations and canceled classes cut attendance at several colleges and universities here yesterday as a City Councilman called for an investigation of recent campus disruptions in the city.
The Goodyear Tire Rubber Company and the B. F. Goodrich Company may soon be locked in a fight for control of a Dutch tire manufacturer with sales of about $70-million yearly.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 20 A special military court trying 21 university students on charges of treason and violating security unexpectedly granted a defense appeal today and adjourned the proceedings pending a ruling by the South Vietnamese Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the trial. The military tribunal also released ten of the defendants pending the Supreme Court decision.
CHICAGO, April 20 Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, charged today that hunger in the United States "is as bad or worse as in some of the most backward naitons in the world."
In the late nineteen-thirties a Rollins College crew came north from Florida to row Manhattan on the Harlem River and the event caused a sensation here because the Rollins coxswain was a girl.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, said that Mr. Carswell was "taking his case to the people."
ATLANTIC CITY, April 20 Walter P. Reuther, the president of the United Auto Workers, warned today "we have got to stop violence in America before it destroys our society."

Harry W. Golding, president of the Golding Bros. Division of W. R. Grace Co., died Sunday in a Boston hospital after a short illness. He was 73 years old and had moved recently from 160 Central Park West to Palm Beach, Fla.

A listing stock market was brought back almost to an even keel yesterday, thanks to an afternoon rally led by the glamour issues.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The Subversive Activities Control Board was left with virtually no function to perform today after the Supreme Court refused to review a lower court ruling that barred the board from declaring individuals to be members of the Communist party.
PARIS, April 20 The Vietcong today turned down the French proposal for a new, international conference on Indochina.
Steel production rose 1.6 per cent last week, compared to output in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

HIGH salaries have made business tycoons out of modern athletes and the cares of the world weigh them down. Life is so serious that they have little time for levity. But it was not thus in earlier days. The wage scale of the performers was so miniscule in comparison to today that the athletes proceeded to make sports a fun thing. They didn't make much money but they sure had a lot of laughs.
MOSCOW, April 20 Henry Ford 2d said today that the Soviet Union had asked the Ford Motor Company to help build a large truck manufacturing complex.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 20 Hector Garcia Godoy Caceres, a pres-I idential candidate Who offered a moderate opposition alternative to the re-election of President Joaquin Balaguer, died of a heart attack today in the midst of the campaign period here.

The Columbia Broadcasting System won top Peabody honors in drama for children with its production of "J.T.", Jane Wagner's account of a Harlem black lad who rose above his depressing environment to achieve a puposeful point of view in life.
Dr. Norman Vincent Peale will be honored at a banquet sponsored by the American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry next Monday for his contribution to mental health.
Four large city parks will be closed to automobile traffic tomorrow from sunrise to sunset, the city announced yesterday as planners put the final touches on preparations for they first Earth Day.

WASHINGTON, April 20 A June wedding is planned here by Miss Theodora Wilner, a student at the University of Pennsylvania, and Paul Charles Wohlmuth, an assistant professor in the law department at the University's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 20 Santa Barbara County Sheriff James W. Webster reported today that a Santa Barbara city police officer had been relieved from duty after acknowledging he accidentally discharged his rifle in Isla Vista at the time a 22-year-old student was fatally wounded early Saturday morning.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 20 The two leading candidates in Colombia's presidential elections both claimed victory today while the followers of one, Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, marched into the streets in demonstrations protesting alleged electoral fraud.

ALBANY, April 20 The Legislature passed today with only minor modification a $400million package of tax and revenue measures designed to help close New York City's projected $630-million budget gap for the next fiscal year.
John (Boog) Powell, a Floridian by birth and of sunny disposition by nature, proved to be extremely disagreeable to the Boston Red Sox yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Gen. David M. Shoup, the former Commandant of the Marine Corps, appeared as a defense witness today in the courtmartial of Seaman Roger Lee Priest, but his testimony was restricted by the military judge.
