WASHINGTON, April 20 The Social Security Administration has scrapped a plan to require the immediate removal of flammable carpeting from nursing homes certified as extended care facilities under the Medicare program.

A follower of form at Aqueduct yesterday could hardly have been blamed for observing that "it was a great day fo ducks." The rain was pelting the Queens County landscap and puddles at the Big A were fetlock deep in many cases.
LOS ANGELES, April 20 The Los Angeles Lakers appear 100 per cent ready to make their perennial bid for the National Basketball Association championship.

A strike by 25,000 apartment-house workers, set for midnight last night, was averted yesterday when landlords and union leaders agreed on a 30-day interim contract that provides for a wage increase of $13 a week.

LONDON, April 20 Thomas Butler, one of Scotland Yard's top detectives, who carried out a relentless five-year quest to put the perpetrators of Britain's great train robbery behind bars, died today of lung cancer at Westminster Hospital. He was 57 years old.
Prices slumped on the London stock market yesterday amid generally depressed conditions that sent the main indexes to new lows for the year. Trading was sluggish.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 20 Tom Marvel, an author, journalist and authority on wines, died of a heart attack last Monday while on assignment in Fresno, Calif. He was 68 years old and lived on North Avenue.
One of the nation's leading housing economists warned yesterday that "premature credit ease" could backfire and produce less money for housing rather than more.

J. Richard Ringgold, vice president for sales of the American Flange Manufacturing Company, Inc., died at Doctors Hospital yesterday of cancer. He was 57 years old and lived at Feeks Lane, Locust Valley, L.I.

HOUSTON, April 20--The investigation of the oxygen tank explosion that imperiled the lives of the Apollo 13 astronauts was focused today on the analysis of data radioed from the spacecraft immediately before and during the accident a week ago.

Perfection was the only appropriate word for the way the New York Knickerbockers played basketball last night. They crushed the Milwaukee Bucks, 132-96, with so dazzling a display of shooting, passing, moving, sniping and team cohesion that their style overshadowed the significance of a historic victor.

TELEVISION'S commercial and noncommercial net works offered instant commentaries after President Nixon's speech last night. The main reaction appeared to be uncertainty over exactly what strategy the President was pursuing in his campaign of Vietnamization.

Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warned yesterday that the United States might have to take "major offsetting actions" if a Soviet build-up of strategic nuclear weapons continued. The United States, he said, has waited until "we are literally at the edge of prudent risk."

AMMAN, Jordan, April 20 (Reuters) The Soviet press attache here was quoted as having said at a news conference today that his country supported the overthrow of the State of Israel. He denied having said so.
PARIS, April 20 Henri Matisse posthumously made a lot of people happy here today: those invited to the preview of a grand exhibition of his work. The show will open to the public on Wednesday.

Thousands of colleges, schools and communities across the country were getting ready yesterday for an unprecedented event: tomorrow's Earth Day--an interlude of national contemplation of problems and man's deteriorating environment.

NEW ORLEANS, April 20 (UPI) Miller Barber watched Bob Charles and Howie Johnson miss 40 and 17 foot birdie putts, then calmly sank a 12footer for a birdie on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff today and took down first prize in the Greater New Orleans open.

LONDON, April 20 William Owen, a Labor party member of Parliament until two weeks ago, admitted that he had given Czechoslovak diplomats information and received money in return, a British court was told today.

Moriatsu Minato, a leading Japanese economist, said yesterday that Japan should try to reduce current trade frictions with the United States and speed removal of her own barriers to imports and foreign investment.
PENN VALLEY, Pa., April 20 Miss Nancy Diane Rifkin, a student at Temple University in Philadelphia, and Alan J. Bresson, who attends Juniata College in Huntington, plan to be married in June.

ST. LOUIS; April 20 (AP) Coach Red Kelly has served notice that his Pittsburgh Penguins don't intend to be intimidated when they renew their Stanley Cup series tomorrow night against the St. Louis Blues here.

ALBANY, April 20 The State Senate passed a bill today that would permit Sanfor D. Garelik to collect his $25,000 annual police retirement pension in addition to his $45,000 salary as President of New York's City Council.

If Benjamin Franklin were to come back to the postal service he set up nearly two centuries ago, he would find many of its practices for delivering the mail little changed. The reorganization plan recommended by President Nixon, on which the House Post Office Committee begins hearings today, promises to bring the system into the automation age.
DETROIT, April 20 The Chrysler Corporation reported today a loss of $29.4-million in the first three months of 1970, making it the corporation's worst first quarter in its history.
JERUSALEM, April 20 Israeli soldiers on duty in tanks along the Suez Canal were able to join this year in the traditional seder meal opening the Passover holiday.

The final round of the National Basketball Association playoffs will begin at Madison Square Garden Friday night at 7:30, with the New York Knicks facing the Los Angeles Lakers. Tickets for this game, already sold, are marked "Game No. 8."

Two British journalists have unraveled much of the mystery of the apparent suicide of Donald Crowhurst, the 36-yearold electronics engineer who set sail from the English resort town of Teignmouth in October of 1968 to emulate Sir Francis Chichester in a voyage alone around the world.

The city's apartment house owners and the union representing their service employes have shown a commendable recognition of the public interest in agreeing to a thirty-day truce in their dispute over a new wage contract. Their action thrusts upon Mayor Lindsay and the City Council an urgent obligation to act before the new strike deadline on long-overdue reform of the rent control law, the principal obstacle to a full-scale labor agreement.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Max M. Kampelman, the chairman of the Board of WETATV, denied today that he had exerted pressure to oust an editor at the station because his wife had become press secretary for Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the Attorney General.
A suspended New York City housing patrolman who has refused to shave off his beard received his dismissal notice in the mail on Friday, his wife said yesterday.
Only one of eight diversified chemical producers made less money in the first quarter this year than in the initial three months of 1969, according to their reports issued yesterday.
CAIRO, April 20 A timetable for the economic integration of the United Arab Republic, the Sudan and Libya has been agreed upon, officials of the three countries announced here today.

Look magazine is getting out of the numbers race, cutting its circulation and advertising rates and is looking for a future with high readership in major metropolitan areas.

In an optimistic economic forecast, Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz said yesterday that he expected a lessening in consumer price increases and improved labor productivity to bring an upswing in the economy "by mid-year and beyond."

LONDON, April 20 A grim portrait of the plight of Soviet political prisoners who are forced into psychiatric hospitals was published today by Amnesty International, a respected British-based private organization.
AKRON, OHIO, April 20 (UPI) The United Rubber Workers Union called a nationwide strike tonight at 15 Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plants, involving about 23,000 employes.

PARIS There is something almost religious about today's international tributes to Lenin sponsored by the Soviet Communist leadership. Special pilgrimages to Moscow have been arranged by party functionaries from all around the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 The National Federation of Priests' Councils announced Monday that it had called off a meeting scheduled for May 3 to discuss the situation of 19 Washington priests disciplined by Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle in 1968 in a dispute over the papal encyclical banning artifical con traception.
MILWAUKEE, April 21 (UPI) Oscar Robertson of the Cincinnati Royals was traded today to the Milwaukee Bucks, where he'll join another basketball superstar Lew Alcindor in the line-up.
LUXEMBOURG, Wednesday, April 21, (UPI) Common Market ministers agreed this morning on free trade in wine, thus clearing the way for starting talks on British membership next summer.

CAIRO, April 21-Egyptian fighter-bombers struck again today at Israeli military positions in the Sinai Peninsula, underlining indications here of a new sense of confidence and readiness for battle on the part of the Egyptian Air Force.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 21 Juan Bosch, former president and a pivotal figure in the civil war here in 1965, said in a nationally broadcast speech today that he had returned here to "help solve the political crisis with the least harm to the Dominican people."

HOUSTON, April 21 The commander of the Apollo 13 spacecraft that almost did not get back from the moon said tonight that, if the space agency asked, he was willing to make another attempt at a lunar landing.

WASHINGTON, April 21 Representative Jonathan B. Bingham said today that it was "impossible to get fair consideration of a balanced transportation program" in the House of Representatives and announced that he would boycott the new House hearings on the Federal highway program.
GENEVA, April 21 Investors Overseas Services Management, Ltd., reported yesterday that the net cash flow produced by sales of its mutual funds had slowed in the first quarter of the year.

STEVEN AXELROD, a college sophomore who looks as calculating as a choirboy, insists he had no intention of fomenting revolution in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. But the "orange juice incident" he precipitated taught the girls of Skidmore College a lesson in political action. It also indicated to doubting parents, trustees and administrators what the effect of coeducation on a traditionally female college is likely to be.

After a dramatic series of orderly discussions, Fordham University; students ended their week-long strike yesterday in the hope that a student-faculty council would be established to give them a significant voice in policy decisions on the Bronx campus.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 21, (AP) Holly Stacy, the medalist, and Barbara McIntire, last year's winner, were among the favorites today who advanced as play began in the Northand-South women's amateur golf tournament.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 21 President Carlos Lleras Restrepo decreed a state of siege and martial law tonight in Co lombia.

WASHINGTON, April 21 Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today that the Nixon Administration was committed to a policy of prohibiting further deterioration of the country's water supplies.

"It was a normal Bob Gibson game," said Billy Williams, the Chicago Cubs' outfielder from Whistler, Ala. "He was throwing good in the first inning and all the way to the seventh. Then he made a couple of bad pitches and walked Don Kessinger, Glenn Beckert hit one and he grooved one to me."
LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) L.K. Shapiro, one of the founders of Western Harness Racing, Inc., died today after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

Five pianists from high schools in New York and the metropolitan area will compete for more than $2,000 in cash scholarship awards in the finals of the WQXR Young Artists Competition on Saturday, May 2.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 The 11 million member United Methodist Church was asked today to give blacks not less than $10million a year for higher education and not less than $5.5million to "undergird the concept of self-determination."

WASHINGTON, April 21 The first reactions here to President Nixon's latest report on Vietnam focused on his obvious effort to balance the political pressure for more troop withdrawals against the military's request for a show of strength on the battlefield in the next few months. The President...
Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown. Especially when the track comes up muddy.
The American Stock Exchange is studying the feasibility of establishing a West Coast branch operation to facilitate serving investors in the Western states.
The Justice Department has stepped up its pressure to bring the New York Stock Exchange under the purview of the Federal antitrust laws.

WASHINGTON, April 21 The House Commerce subcommittee that is considering legislation covering the mutual fund industry swung back sharply today toward the more restrictive measure passed by the Senate last year.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 21 Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., a Democrat, appealed for a return to office today on the ground that the nation needs "a Democratic Congress that will not rubber-stamp token withdrawals while the war spills over into Laos and Cambodia."

OF ALL the boutiques that Bloomingdale's, has had and it has had plenty probably the most successful has been micmac of St. Tropez, which took up residence on the third floor a couple of years ago. One reason is that the designer for it, Tan Giudicelli (half Italian, half Vietnamese),...

OSAKA, Japan To say that things are quiet at Expo '70 as the big fair enters its second month would not be entirely accurate, since the noise and the crowds are as great as ever. But Expo has settled down to routine operation for its increasing millions of visitors and the sealing provides an opportunity for a less distracted look at the place.
SYRACUSE, April 21 The 10 black athletes on the Syracuse University football team continued a boycott of spring practice today as Coach Ben Schwartzwalder directed the first workout since Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 21, (AP) President Nixon said today that it would not be good for either the country or its schools if either public or private school systems had a monopoly over the education of the nation's children.
The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries, reported yesterday new highs in earnings for March, the first quarter and the 12 months ended March 31.

CAPE NEDDICK, Me., April 21 Robert Laurent, a sculptor, who figured in the development of an American sculptural art that balanced nature and abstraction, died at his home here yesterday. He was 79 years old.
Samuel G. May, vice president of Samuel H. Moss, Inc., manufacturers of rubber stamps, died of a heart attack Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 420 East 51st Street.

An agent of the Internal Revenue Service has been spending hours in the screening room of National Educational Television at 10 Columbus Circle to determine whether any of the group's noncommercial TV programs in 1969 advocated legislation that might involve tax-exempt problems.
Wunderman, Ricotta Kline very big in direct response advertising has just been named the agency for the Peak-of-the-Month Club. The ad budget is expected to be approximately $4-million.

The International Business Machines Corporation, the computer industry giant, announced yesterday its longanticipated entry into the office copier field. The Xerox Corporation, the behemoth of the copying industry, immediately filed a patent-infringement suit against I.B.M.
WASHINGTON, April 21 Representative William C. Cramer said today that G. Harold Carswell's entry into the Forida Republican Senate primary had not changed his own intention of remaining in the race.
WASHINGTON, April 21 The Food and Drug Administration issued tonight an urgent warning that as many as 80,000 frozen pizzas may be contaminated with lethal germs that cause botulism.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a preliminary study of the feasibility of charging tolls on the city's four East River bridges into Manhattan.

CHICAGO, April 21, (UPI) Phil Esposito stole the, puck and beat his brother Tony for an unassisted goal tonight to wrap up the scoring for the Boston Bruins in a 4-1 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks. The victory gave the Bruins a 2-0 edge in their four-of-seven Stanley Cup semifinal hockey playoff series.
ISLA VISTA, Calif., April 21 Kevin Moran was buried today as this college community started to unwind from five days of tension and to probe the circumstances surrounding his death.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that corporations and their stockholders may not write off as business expenses some of the costs of reorganization, including some incurred in corporate merger proceedings.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 21 Louis P. Anziano president of the Anziano Building Company, died of a heart attack Saturday at a hospital in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 67 years old and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla., and at 10 Carteret Place.
For the first time in its 118th-year history, the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York will have women on its board of directors.

The Pacific Vegetable Oil Corporation announced yester day that it planned to make a cash offer for the assets of the Drew Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary of the Slick Corporation. Drew Chemical had slaes of more than $70-million in the last fiscal year.

The Long Island Railroad, already changed into the finest commuter rail line in the country, according to Governor Rockefeller, made another change this week: It ceased being the Long Island Rail Road.

Yale University's president declared last night that "the malaise, the disenchantment with life" and its prospects, is greater now than a year ago among most American students" on college and university campuses.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) A supplier of M-16 rifles remains far behind schedule two years after the army cited ability to meet an accelerated delivery timetable as justification for paying the supplier premium prices for the rapidfiring weapons.
ROME April 21 (AP) Topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King and Julie Heldman gave the United States a pair of opening victories in the Italian open tennis championships today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 The announcer who peers over a man-sized razor blade with nicks in its edge and sneeringly proclaims "Corrosion" is facing a forced change in his television message.

First-quarter net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) was reported yesterday at $325-million, or $1.50 a share on 223.6 million shares, matching the year-earlier record of $325-million, or $1.51 a share, on 215 million shares.
TRENTON, April 21 The state is investigating the possible misuse of funds by they retiring chief of staff of the New Jersey Department of Defense, according to State Senator James H. Wallwork.
ALBANY, April 21 Following are the major actions taken by the Legislature during the regular 1970 session that ended last night:
A new service for air travelers to San Juan, P.R., that guarantees baggage delivery direct to hotels has been announced by Pan American World Airways.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 21 Nationalist China, whose very right to exist is questioned by much of the world community, manages to live on, even to prosper, despite the tortuous uncertainties of its international position and nagging discontent within its body politic.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, founded in 1913 to generate more national advertising dollars for the nation's papers, is in the midst of a major effort to hold onto newspaper's biggest source of revenue retail advertising.

WASHINGTON, April 21 The national organization that is sponsoring Earth Day plans to stay together after nationwide environmental demonstrations scheduled for this week. It will adopt a new name and begin emphasizing direct political action.
The New Yorker, which has been suffering advertising page losses, is going to a different agency Lord, Geller, Federico and Partners.
WASHINGTON, April 21 Three-month and six-month mortgage purchase commitment prices rose again at this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association disclosed yesterday.
Parents were temporarly enjoined yesterday from setting up a grievance table at George Washington High School in Washington Heights.
MANILA, April 21 (Reuters) All 33 persons aboard a twin-engined passenger plane were killed when it crashed today about 75 miles north of Manila.
The 30th annual George Foster Peabody Awards for "distinguished and meritorious public service" in radio and television were presented yesterday at a luncheon at the Pierre Hotel.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 21 The Governors of Oregon and Washington sought an injunction today in United States District Court to delay the proposed shipment of nerve gas from Okinawa to the Umatilla Army Depot in eastern Oregon.

The City Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday that 12 persons had died from acute reactions to heroin or from direct complications from heroin addiction from Friday to yesterday. One was a teen-ager.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday in light trading after selling pressure erased an early advance.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) In a White House ceremony today, Vice President Agnew presented the Medal of Honor to wives and parents of 13 Marines and two sailors who were killed while winning the nation's highest decoration in Vietnam.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 21 The engagement of Miss Carlyle Berdan Bodman to James Calvin Hughes Jr. has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Luther Bodman Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Hughes of Winston-Salem.

CONCORD, N.H., April 21 The New Hampshire House of Representatives today approved four-year terms for the state's Governors, thus virtually assuring that the proposed constitutional amendment will be voted on by the people.

UNION, N.J., April 21 Gustave G. Kein Jr., attorney for Union Township since 1946 and a Republican leader here for many years, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a brief illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 504 Twin Oaks Road.
WASHINGTON, April 21 Prof. James Samuel Coleman is so busy these days that the little things in life sometimes slip by unnoticed.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 The man who wasn't there testified for about two hours as the first witness today in Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's $12.5-million libel action against Look Magazine.
WASHINGTON, April 21 Attorney General John N. Mitchell is looking for a new press secretary.
BOSTON, April 21, (AP) Victor O. Jones, former executive editor of The Boston Globe, died today in Massachusetts General Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
The typographical union increased its economic pressure on The New York Times yesterday by lengthening the daily chapel, or (union), meetings that stop composing room operations.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 21, (UPI) The United Auto Workers called today for an environmental bill of rights for Americans and said that pollution control would be made an issue in the union's contract talks this year with the nation's auto makers.

Criminal informations against seven corporations, including the Long Island Lighting Company and Mobil Oil for alleged violation of Federal antipollution laws were filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

FEW players are on record as having successfully de- fended a major regional team championship. This rare feat was performed at the Florida Regionals last week by Hal Fein of Eastchester, N.Y., Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Dan Morse of Houston. They headed a field of 132 teams in the Swiss team championship, played in Miami Beach. William August of Springfield, Mass., who did not compete last year, was the fourth player.

AKRON, Ohio, April 21 Because of the strike called last night by 23,000 members of the United Rubber Workers Union, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today that it was "reluctantly discontinuing" the Akron Goodyears basketball team in an effort to reduce anticipated financial losses.
A top level task force was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to hurry into shape the details of the city's new offtrack betting plan.

WASHINGTON, April 21 The "Campaign to make G.M. Responsible" charged today that the General Motors Corporation had spent more than $500,000 to defeat proposals to put representatives of consumers and conservation interests on its board of directors and to make other changes in its operations.
"Personal freedom," President Nixon observed in his Economic Report last winter, "will be increased when there is more economy in Government and less Government in the economy.
Television and radio will observe Earth Day today with special broadcasts devoted to various aspects of pollution and their effects on the ecological balance of the country.

There is a bitter-sweet message in President Nixon's announcement that United States forces in Vietnam will be reduced by 150,000 during the coming year, the same withdrawal rate as in recent months. By next spring almost half the American troops will be out. But about half will still be there, 284,000 of them, more than two years after Mr. Nixon's assumption of office with a pledge and an undisclosed "plan" to end the war.
Neil Simon, Broadway's prime provider of humor, is turning serious. He has written a new play, "It Only Hurts When I Laugh," which is essentially tragic in content.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 21, (UPI) All Ahead held off the favored Imbibe in the early going and drew away from the field in the stretch today to win the $12,000 allowance purse at Garden State. The 4-year-old filly was a badly beaten eighth in her last start.
AKRON, Ohio, April 21 A classified ad in The Akron Beacon Journal gave a clueto the hard times ahead: "For sale, Buick Riviera, Goodrich worker who may have to strike."

ATHENS, April 21 Greek political prisoners marked the military-backed Government's third anniversary in power today by staging a hunger strike, maintaining silence and wearing black armbands for 24 hours.

WASHINGTON, April 21 Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo of Nationalist China was reported today to have warned Secretary of State William P. Rogers that the Nixon Administration's gestures to improve relations with Communist China were not in the interests of peace in Asia.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- A House subcommittee unanimously approved today a bill designed to reduce air pollution by providing national quality standards and strict enforcement procedures for the foulers of the atmosphere.
A group of about 20 students made an unsuccessful attempt to disrupt the annual meeting of the Union Carbide Corporation here yesterday in the Hunter College Auditorium.

A group of 75 students swept through the kitchen of New York University's Washington Square Faculty Club yesterday as a protest in support of striking library and cafeteria workers continued.
While Dumbo's away, Porky will play. And the more Porky plays, the better it is in the Wonderful World of the Detroit Tigers.
Like the city dwellers, more and more residents of the suburbs are turning to ingenious stratagems and new devices to protect their furs, jewelry, silverware and television sets from theft.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Justice Department, in the first action of its kind in 20 years, filed an antitrust suit today charging the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and two major Japanese companies with illegally conspiring not to sell certain products in each other's countries.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Claims that G. Harrold Carswell had advance approval from the White House and the Republican National Committee for his Senate bid from Florida were advanced and denied here today.
ALBANY April 22--Governor Rockefeller forwarded to the State Senate for confirmation oday the names of four new members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

PARIS, April 22--Eight months after the devaluation of the franc, the French Government announced today it has repaid all its short-term debts to central banks and is be ginning to relax its austerity program.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 22-- When Puerto Ricans voted in 1967 by 60 to 39 per cent for commonwealth status rather than American statehood, with only one per cent choosing independence, the issue seemed pretty well settled.

Sources within the city's Housing and Development Administration said yesterday that the agency had begun an investigation designed to entrap those who have been leaking confidential studies--such as the Rand report--to the press.

FOUR people in an empty park, six musicians in a green bandstand. The new musical "Park," which opened last night at the John Golden Theater, takes simplicity in Broadway musicals to new lengths. Given its world premiere by Baltimore's Resident Theater, it makes an unpretentious yet somewhat thin New York evening.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 --The Blue Grass Stakes, generally accepted as a criterion for the Kentucky Derby over the last several years, will offer an even greater influence on the 3-year-old championship field tomorrow, when it has its 46th running.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 --Victor Olgyay, an architectural pioneer at integrating buildings into their environments, died at his home here today after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and an associate professor of architecture and urban planning at Princeton University.
Detectives pressed their investigations yesterday into two gangland shootings that were discovered within a 16-hourperiod here on Tuesday.

SELECTION by committees and organizing bodies is a feature of the bridge scene in Europe, but it hardly exists here because of the feeling that selection is "undemocratic." As a result, good players on the opposite side of the Atlantic have more opportunities than those here to play in events of high standard from which the less experienced players are excluded.

PARIS--If you see a young man swinging a knap sack full of pots and pans and cutlery along the banks of the Seine, it may well be an American named William Rice en route to a cooking session in the home of a friend or friends.

A survey of 60,447 university and college faculty members has disclosed that while most profess liberal views on national and international affairs they are becoming more conservative on academic issues.

YOU can't be a tourist in the novels of Janet Frame. The act of apprehen sion makes you an accomplice. The landscape is static, a world of art, frozen images, memories like cameras pointed at each other, dreams like cooled lava that once upon a time erupted from a volcanic imagination.

LONDON, April 22 (UPI)-- The United States Lawn Tennis Association was fined $2,500 today by the International Lawn Tennis Federation for rule violations at recent tournaments in Boston and Philadelphia.
A locksmith in the Bronx tells a story about a woman with seven locks on her door who had an eighth one installed because her apartment was broken into so often.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, April 23--The Yankees and the Senators almost completed a baseball game in two hours last night but that would have been ridiculous. Instead they played four hours and 40 minutes, 18 innings in all, before the home team scored a 2-1 victory.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's largest producer of cigarettes, turned in record sales and earnings in the first quarter this year, with all areas of its diversified operations contributing to the gains.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The House Commerce subcommittee reached agreement today on legislation increasing the Government's authority to regulate the charges imposed on investors by mutual funds. But the agreement was only tentative and subject to reversal at the subcommittee's next meeting on Tuesday.
The stock market continued its sharp plunge yesterday with the bears outpointing the bulls for the 15th consecutive session.

The John W. Brown, the former World War II Liberty ship that has served as a floating classroom for thousands of maritime-minded city high school students for more than 20 years, is headed for retirement.
WASHINGTON, April 22 A Federal district judge dismissed a suit today that would have kept the Army from collecting, storing and circulating information on the political activities of civilians.

Shortly after the Bolshevik seizure of power in 1917, Lenin, in an open letter to American workers, acclaimed the "revolutionary tradition" of the United States and urged worker to help the Soviet cause.

ST. LOUIS, April 22--Health and welfare agencies supported by the United Methodist Church serve an almost all-white, middle-class clientele, according to a report distributed here today to delegates attending the church's five-day general conference.
Two bills awaiting Governor Rockefeller's signature and a third measure just introduced by the State Insurance Department are expected to have a wide impact. for consumers.
NOW that Wall Street has had time to eval uate the gargantuan American Telephone and Telegraph financing, the ifs, ands and buts are flying.

After 17 years, the New York Knickerbockers have another shot at the National Basketball Association championship, and some things are remarkably familiar. The opposing team is, again, the Lakers--although now it represents Los Angeles instead of Minneapolis.
Meetings between negotiators for the city's four major newspapers and the typographical union continued yesterday, but no progress toward a contract settlement was reported.
New-car sales in the United States in the April 11-20 period fell 10.5 per cent, the major automobile makers reported yesterday.
LONDON, April 22--A dramatic turn in the public-opinion polls today gave Prime Minister Wilson and the Labor party hope of victory at an early general election.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)--President Nixon proposed today a reorganization of the Federal Government's disaster relief operations, including loans to help local governments make up property tax losses.

The bond market took a turn for the worse yesterday, despite some surface indications that it might be beginning to recover. Specialists said that a dramatic change in psychology had apparently become widespread in the last week or so, indicating that more declines lay ahead.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- President Nixon tonight awarded to seven journalists, including Arthur Krock of The New York Times, the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award.
ALBANY, April 21 (AP)--An appellate court has ruled that a newspaper editor cannot collect unemployment compensation because he quit his job in a disagreement with his publisher over an editorial.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 22--An atmosphere of heightening national emergency is overtaking Cambodia.

A strong defense, bolstered by Bobby Orr, and a sharpshooting offense, paced by Phil Esposito, have given the Boston Bruins an unexpected 2-0 lead over Chicago in their East Division final of the Stanley Cup playoffs.
WEST HEMPSTEAD L.I, April 22--The New York Nets should have taken a lesson tonight from the Whiz Kids, a group of basketball tricksters who staged a half-time show at the Island Garden.

WASHINGTON, April 22--The United States flew a planeload of weapons, including mortars and machine guns, to Trinidad today at the urgent request of the black Govern ment there, which is seeking to put down a mutiny inspired by black-power elements.

LONDON, April 22--Six heavy cruisers and a helicopter cruiser led a Soviet fleet today in a large exercise across an area of the North Atlantic traditionally associated with naval control of the coast of Western Europe.
It just may be that Mutual Transit Sales might have struck on the secret formula needed to bolster sagging transit advertising sales.

The story of a strange odyssey through the sky, in which almost everything seemed to go wrong, was unfolded yesterday at a National Transportation Safety Board hearing near Kennedy International Airport.
Living costs for New York area consumers rose 0.7 per cent in March, the regional director of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, Herbert Bienstock, announced yesterday.
Earth Day, the first mass consideration of the globe's environmental problems, preempted the attention and energies of millions of Americans, young and old, across the country yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the passage of an antinarcotics bill backed by the Nixon Administration would "severely impede our efforts" to control the illegal use of drugs.

DURING the recent 10board quadruple round chess match between the Soviet Union and players from the rest of the world, Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., a seven-time United States champion, was paired on Board 6 with a former world champion, Vasily Smyslov.
Announcing a symposium to be held next Thursday and Friday and called "Is Law Dead?" the head of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York said yesterday that it isn't.
H. Ross Perot, the executive who has been workking privately for the return of American war prisoners from North Vietnam, suffered a sharp paper loss yesterday in the over-the counter market.

The Lindsay administration's study of possible tolls on East River bridges drew a protest from Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday, who said such charges would be "an undue burden upon the motorist."

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 22--Thirty-one professional golfers, whose total winnings in 1969 exceeded $2.4million, are here for a special tournament. It is the Tournament of Champions, an event limited to those who have won one or more events on the circuit during the last 12 months.

PROGRESS report: Two year ago The Times carried a story about how Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Levy of Mansfield Center, Conn., purchased a bearded collie in England under the impression that they were getting an Old English sheepdog. Instead of being annoyed ...
Earthlings concerned about their Mother Earth heard the bad news yesterday, and were heartened by wishes for a speedy recovery.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 22--Peru's revolutionary military regime today urged Latin America to adopt a new political orientation that would abandon capitalism and at the same time prevent Communism from spreading through the region.

MUNICH, West Germany, April 23 (Reuters)--Paul Schmidt, Hitler's chief interpreter who was also press spokesman for the Foreign Office of the Third Reich, died yesterday at the age of 71, it was reported here today.

Earth Day is over and the country's most elegant pedestrian mall--Fifth Avenue--is again just another noisy, congested, exhaust-poisoned traffic artery, like all the other streets in this noisy, congested, exhaustpoisoned pollution capital of the world.
