MOSCOW, April 22--The 100th anniversary of Lenin's birth was officially commemorated today with pomp, speeches and a pledge by Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin that the Soviet Union would guard the peace and aid the struggle against imperialism.

TORONTO, April 22--Reporting to its shareholders on Earth Day, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced increased first-quarter earnings today and outlined efforts to reduce air pollution from its principal complex of mines and mills, at Sudbury, Ont.

When some 500 of New York's political, social and community leaders get together for a $100-a-person dinner dance, there is usually an excuse; and if there's one thing next Tuesday's party at the Plaza doesn't lack it's excuses.
Many of the orders of small investors will be switched directly from brokerage houses to the floor of the American Stock Exchange via computer starting early next month, the Amex announced yesterday.

The public temper on the major issues of the time--from the war in Vietnam to racial integration--has cooled in the last year, a geographical sampling of newspaper editors and publishers meeting here indicated yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 22 (Reuters)--White South Africans voted heavily today in a general election that could force the Government of Premier John Vorster further to the right.

ST. JOHN'S UNIVERSITY has been celebrating its centenary with a series of concerts, among other things. Last night in Philharmonic Hall, St. John's presented the sixth and last of its series, sponsoring the Houston Symphony Orchestra under Hans ...

LONDON, April 22 (AP)-- Mary Quant, the British designer who introduced the miniskirt in the middle1960's and as recently as Jan. 11, 1968, insisted that "the miniskirt has built itself into a fashion classic that will never be replaced," officially abandoned the style today.
Eddie Belmonte, the Puerto Rican who has been running away with the jockeys' standings race at Aqueduct, continues to outdistance the field.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Conservatives were for it. Liberals were for it. Democrats, Republicans and independents were for it. So were the ins, the outs, the Executive and legislative branches of Government.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 22 --As the Colombian Army en forced calm in the country today, leaders of the movement trying to return Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, the former dictator, to power, insisted that they were ready to provoke civil war in the general's cause.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 22 (AP)--Hollis Stacy of Savannah, Ga., won two matches today and gained the semifinals of the Women's North and South amateur golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Nixon Administration has agreed to supply several thousand rifles to the beleaguered Government of Cambodia, Administration officials disclosed today. The weapons would be automatic rifles of Soviet design captured from Communist forces in South Vietnam.

The travel brochures write glowingly of TrinidadTobago as a tropical paradise, two islands with exquisite beaches, lovely palm trees and the throbbing rhythms of steel bands accompanying masters of calypso song. Potential investors are wooed with literature stressing the racial amity in the heterogeneous population, the political stability under Prime Minister Eric Williams's strong but moderate government, and the abundant labor supply.

BALTIMORE, April 22--The arson and riot trial of H. Rap Brown, the black power militant, was postponed today at least until Monday. A threejudge panel will hear then a defense plea to have the case moved from state to Federal jurisdiction.
Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets to a 2-1 victory over the San Diego Padres yesterday and pitched himself into the baseball records by striking out 19 batters--10 in a row.

The Standard Prudential Corporation announced yesterday it is holding conversations regarding the possible acquisition of the Levin-Townsend Computer Corporation, a financially ailing computer-leasing company.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)--Treasury Department officials encouraged American businessmen to circumvent the Federal Reserve Board's tightmoney policy in 1967 by borrowing Eurodollars abroad, Congress was told today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22-- A faculty study committee issued a report today approving the University of California's continued participation in nuclear weapons research, but only if closer administrative controls are imposed.

Representatives of pararofessional school employes belonging to the United Federation of Teachers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to recommend a strike if the Board of Education did not make a "meaningful" contract offer.
MOSCOW, April 22--Soviet officials today disclosed major personnel changes in the news and information field.
Four companies announced yesterday the election of new presidents.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Logans have a permissive child. They are the envy of all parents in the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Denis Allen Hayes, the national coordinator of Earth Day, remembers the world he grew up in as "pristinely beautiful"--a world of dense forests, rushing streams and lonely foothills rolling away into the Cascades range of Washington state.
The Conjunto Brasileiro Roberto de Regina staged what could have been just a vaudeville act, but with this group, it turned into a strong concert last night at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Department of Agriculture ordered three food manufacturing plants in the Minneapolis area today to halt distribution of products containing mushrooms suspected of being infected with deadly botulism toxin.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica-- Eight large birds, the pilot said they were parrots, rose from the jungle beneath us, and we altered course to avoid coming close to them.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 --The United States public is in no mood, according to the Gallup Poll, to be lenient with persons who commit three types of crimes that are products of modern-day America: terror bombings, hijacking and inciting riots.
The Art Directors Club honored its own again yesterday in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel where some 1,100 creative types watched 20 medals being awarded to someone else.

TEL AVIV, April 22 (AP)--A terrorist hand grenade wounded three American tourists and a dozen other persons today in the main square of Nablus in Israeli-occupied Jordan, the Israeli military command reported.

To thousands of middleaged and elderly Londoners, an event in Covent Garden in 1946 may still symbolize the end of the austerity of World War II. For on Feb. 20 of that year the royal family headed an invitation audience that filled the 2,200 ...
IN Russ Meyer's "Cherry, Harry Raquel," a rugged band of Southwestern pot smugglers and their girls come to no good end and have a terrific time getting there. At the last, when all the ...

WASHINGTON, April 22-- President Nixon has assured a leading critic of multiple-warhead nuclear weapons that the Administration is not developing the capability of striking at shielded Soviet mssiles.
KANSAS CITY, Mo.--No one agrees more than the American farmer that the cost of food is outrageous.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., April 22 (UPI)--Stanley Benham, the bobsled ace who represented the United States in more international competitions than any other American, died today at a hospital in Miami, after suffering a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

PARIS, April 22--Pierre Dux, a veteran actor who headed the police force of the authoritarian junta in the movie "Z," was named today to head France's most prestigious theatrical institution, the Comedie Francaise.

The Board of Eductaion announced last night that, "in the interest of restoring a positive educational climate" to embattled George Washington High School, a student-grievance table staffed by parents would be set up in the school.

Daniel Patrick Moynihan, counselor to President Nixon, declared yesterday that the national welfare reform approved by the House "reflects what we are now able to do" in funds likely to be available over the next five years.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Consumer prices rose strongly again in March but there were signs that the pace of inflation was slowing, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The executive committee of station WETA-TV approved today the dismissal of William Woestendiek, the news editor who was ousted last week after his wife took a job as press secretary to the wife of Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

From the standpoint of a Penn Central Railroad passenger, a worm's-eye view if ever there was one, it begins to seem that the vaunted Metroliner is going into a decline in record time even for the railroad industry.
Representatives of the New York City Ballet's orchestra met with management yesterday in a hastily called meeting as the musicians' strike against the company went into its second day.

In the last-minute push for adjournment, the Legislature gave final approval this week to a bill exempting newsmen from contempt proceedings for "failing to disclose any news or the source of any such news."
SAN FRANCISCO, April 22-- "It costs a lot less to become a monsignor or a Bishop these days," said Kevin Quinn. "The trend is definitely toward simplicity."
Huge, light-hearted throngs ambled down autoless streets here yesterday as the city heeded Earth Day's call for a regeneration of a polluted environment by celebrating an exuberant rite of spring.

NEW HAVEN, April 22-- Picket lines were set up around most undergraduate classroom buildings at Yale University this morning as students began a strike in support of Black Panthers who are awaiting trial here on charges of murder and kidnapping.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 22-- Some 250 stockholders of the General Electric Company assembled here today for their annual meeting amid implied threats of bombings and disruptive activities of the young militants.
The Penn Central Company's financial position worsened in the first quarter of this year.

NEW HAVEN, April 22-- The main prosecution witness in the forthcoming murder trial of Bobby G. Seale, national chairman of the Black Panther party, testified at a bail hearing today that the Panther leader ordered the slaying last May.
One of every 20 cars in New York City will be stolen this year, according to officials who have tried without much success to curb the rising number of automobile thefts.

Roland A. Wank, head architect of the Tennessee Valley Authority from 1933 to 1944, who designed towns, public housing projects and many important buildings, died Wednesday of cancer in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 35 Highview Avenue. New Rochelle, N.Y.

PARIS The great American troop withdrawal from foreign parts appears irreversible, unless wholly unexpected crises come, and affects both East and West. Over a hundred thousand soldiers have already left Vietnam and President Nixon promises to take away another 150,000 within a year.

Basketball's world series, the final round of the National Basketball Association playoffs, begins tonight at Madison Square Garden with the New York Knickerbockers facing the Los Angeles Lakers in the first contest of a four-out-of-seven game series.

During its curtailed 85th season, which ended Saturday, the Metropolitan Opera played to an estimated 90 to 92 per cent of capacity. Its neighbor at Lincoln Center, the New York City Opera, which closed its 51st season on Sunday, played to an estimated total of 95 to 97 per cent of capacity. Although these are not final figures, officials of both companies feel certain that they are close to the corrrct ones.
The negotiations for the Zero Manufacturing Company to acquire the Rossmoor Corporation, a privately held company in Laguna Hills, Calif., have been terminated, both companies announced yesterday.
DETROIT, April 23 The first attempt in the nation by stock salesmen to organize brokerage firms failed here today.
BUENOS AIRES, April 23 A general strike call supported by all six warring factions of Argentina's organized labor movement brought industry throughout the country nearly ...

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) A Navy court found Seaman Roger Lee Priest not guilty of the most serious accusations against him tonight but found him guilty on two counts of promoting disloyalty and disaffection among servicemen.

American space plans for a "grand tour" of outer planets call for two space craft to be spun off the gravitational field of Jupiter as a booster, Dr. Wernher von Braun told the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The cost of buying a home continued its steady push upward in March despite some recent pauses in other interestrate increases and a promising improvement in available loan money, the Government reported today.
Stock and bond prices fell sharply on the London stock market yesterday as bearish influences increased. Key market averages dipped to new lows for the year for the second consecutive day.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 23 The members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies have voted overwhelmingly to allow advertising agencies to own media as well as supplier companies.

The New York money market was sharply tighter this week, banking data published yesterday showed. But even so, it appeared that the Federal Reserve System had not modified its basic policy of encouraging "modest" monetary expansion despite increasing concern within the central bank over the position of the Federal budget.

WASHINGTON, April 23 In his latest report on the war in Vietnam, President Nixon said: "A fair political solution should reflect the existing relationship of political forces within South Vietnam. We recognize the complexity of shaping machinery that would fairly apportion political power in South Vietnam. We're flexible. We have offered nothing on a take it or leave it basis."

FORT BENNING, Ga., April 23 (AP) A military judge today set a new trial date of Aug. 24 for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who is charged with murdering 102 Vietnamese civilians at Songmy in 1968.
A four-day music festival sponsored by the Harlem Jazz Music Center began last night and will continue through the weekend as one of the musical events marking April Is Jazz month.
Three major aerospace companies reported sharp declines yesterday in first-quarter profits. A fourth, meanwhile, reported a strong drop in profits for the second quarter.

Thirty black students at Wagner College on Staten Island held the dean of the college captive in his office for more than seven and a half hours yesterday to press their demands for an increased blackand-Puerto-Rican-studies program.
HOUSTON, April 23 (AP) TOPSEEDED Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and unseeded Nikola Spear of Yugoslavia advanced to the semifinals of the $25,000 River Oaks invitation tennis tournament today.

A system that stores the energy of a moving subway train as it helps bring the train to a halt, then uses the stored energy to help the train start up again may be tested on the city's subway system as a way of reducing electric bills.
WASHINGTON, April 23 United States international monetary reserve assets declined $320-million in March, largely because of a reduction in foreign currency holdings, the Treasury reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown injected some of his philosophy of political public relations today into the trial of Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's $12.5million libel complaint against Look magazine.

The Air Force Yesterday rejected a request from the General Dynamics Corporation for about $40-million more in progress payments for F-111 planes completed since an accident grounded the fleet in December.

Twenty-five members of the Yale track team have withdrawn from the Penn Relays today and tomorrow at Franklin Field in Philadelphia. Among the group are five blacks, including Kwaku Ohene-Frempong, a high hurdler and the team captain, and Don Martin, a sprinter.

DARIEN, Conn., April 23 John Patridge Howland, president of West Point-Pepperell, Inc., the textile concern, and Mrs. Howland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Briggs Howland, to Peter Norris Pund, son of Mr. and Mrs. H.R. Pund.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Following is the impact of President Nixon's draft proposals on the monthly pay of military men with less than two years service:
The 40th annual luncheon in aid of the eight charitable organizations that benefit from sales at the Lots for Little Thrift Shop, will be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria on May 5.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 230 Informed Cambodian sources reported today that their country had received a shipment of weapons for its underequipped army, which has been striving to check advances by Vietnamese Communist troops.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had voted to keep the exchange open on Friday, May 29, the day before Memorial Day, but to close on Friday, July 3, the day before Independence Day.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 23 (AP) Bobby Knoop's homer and a two-run throwing error by the Minnesota relief pitcher, Ron Perranoski, brought the Chicago White Sox a 7-5 victory today, ending a Twins' winning streak at four games.

WASHINGTON, April 23 Calling the Nixon Administration's welfare reform bill "only a beginning," Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today raising Federal benefits to the poor and requiring the states to contribute, too.

Governor Rockefeller is backing Herman Badillo, former Borough President of the Bronx and a Democrat, as the Republican nominee for United States Representative from the 21st District, political sources said yesterday.

GENEVA, April 23 Dr. Marcolino G. Candau of Brazil, Director General of the World Health Organization, today deplored man's failure to match his progress in medicine with an improvement in the quality of his environment.
BOSTON, April 23 (UPI) John Bucyk scored two powerplay goals tonight while leading the Boston Bruins to a 5-2 victory and a 3-0 Stanley Cup playoff series lead over the Chicago Black Hawks.
CAIRO, April 23 Egyptian fighter-bombers carried out a midnight raid last night against Israeli military positions about 60 miles east of the Suez Canal, Cairo's military spokesman reported today.
The Greyhound Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to reconsider a restrictive order issued against the company early this month.

MONEY, believe it or not, doesn't make it any more at least not as a sales incentive. The old green stuff that used to turn on boat dealers and their salesmen now leaves them with a yawn and a "so what else is new?" The reason is simple: Like too much of a good...

The family trudged like refugees, yesterday through the chill rain up Columbus Avenue, the man with a vacuum cleaner over his shoulder, the gaunt woman cradling a year-old daughter wrapped in faded scarves, a small boy, walking along by her side.
ANDORRA, April 23 (AP) The men who govern this tiny principality decreed today that women had the right to vote.

PEKING, April 23 Communist China strongly attacked Moscow's economic policies today with an article declaring that the Soviet economy had been brought to the brink of ruin by Nikita S. Khrushchev and Leonid I. Brezhnev.
The idea that there may be only three days left to see the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater again before its possible dissolution owing to lack of just plain money is incredible.
"Dillinger Is Dead" ("Dillinger e Morto"), an Italian film drama, will have its first local showing at 8 P.M. tomorrow at a special screening at the Museum of Modern Art.

The Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington said yesterday that he would not withdraw as the Liberal party's candidate for Governor in favor of Arthur J. Goldberg unless the party received evidence that the Democratic designee was "really independent from the old-line Democratic machine."

DURING one early season game Joe Mullaney, the handsome young freshman coach of the Los Angeles Lak ers, surveyed his troops and snickered. Yet the situation wasn't even funny. It was ridiculous to the point of being ludicrous.

Long Island Figure Skating Club members took the top four places of the 6-to 9-year-old division of the special juvenile girls' event of the Middle Atlantic States championship yesterday at Sky Rink, 33d Street and 10th Avenue.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 Dust Commander kicked mud into the eyes of eight rivals in the $32,975 Blue Grass Stakes today at Keeneland.

THE doors at B. Altman Co. had barely swung open yesterday when the women came swarming up to the fifth floor. Teen-agers, Moms, Great-great-grandmothers. They were all there for what was billed as a "Sew-In." There was no sewing on their part, however.

YONKERS, April 23 There are 79 Smiths listed as licensed drivers in the United States Trotting Association directory and the accomplishments of Argo Port, a 7-year-old gelding, are making Samuel E. Smith of Westbury, L.I., one of the most famous of the Smiths.

The slowdown in the nation's economy in the first quarter of 1970 did not have much impact on the paper industry but some downtrends are beginning to appear, William R. Adams, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 23 Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended April 18, still affected by work stoppages throughout the country was considerably below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Freight traffic on United States railroads during the same period registered an increase.

The London Philharmonic Orchestra, making its New York debut, gave the first of three concerts in Carnegie Hall last night as part of the hall's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras. A comparatively young ensemble, founded in 1932 by the late Sir Thomas Beecham, it has bernard Haitink as its current conductor, who also heads the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam.

MANILA, April 23 (Reuter) An explosion that ripped off the tail section of a Philippine Air Lines plane in midair, killing all 36 persons aboard, could have been the work of a passenger intent on suicide, civil aviation investigators said here today.
OUTSPOKEN Howard Butcher 3rd was as bullish as a cowcatcher on Penn Central stock in January when the stock was selling at 29 just a couple of points below its 1969-1970 low.

A spokesman for the Roman Products Corporation of South Hackensack, N.J., said yesterday that his company "uses no mushrooms whatsoever in any of its frozen pizza products" and was not to be confused with the Roman Inn Pizza Company of Eau Claire, Wis.
NEWARK, April 23 (AP) A judge ruled today that a state statute enacted Dec. 1 authorizing a passenger head tax at Newark Airport was unconstitutional.
PARISMINA, Costa Rica In the dark recesses of an ever-narrowing lagoon that reached back into the jungle, the blazing tropical sun could no longer reach us and night shadows came early.

The marriage of Mrs. Ruth Starr Tatar, a lawyer with the office of the Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, to Bennet H. Korn, a communications consultant and former president of Metromedia's television division, took place here yesterday.

PARIS, April 23 Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief negotiator at the peace talks here, is expected to return to Hanoi in a few days, and the Vietcong delegation hinted today that its leader, Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, might also leave Paris.
The economic slowdown took its toll on corporate profits in this year's first quarter, with the sharpest decline in several years.

NEW HAVEN, April 23 The undergraduate faculty of Yale University tonight rejected a proposal by black professors to cancel all classes next week in sympathy with a student strike supporting the Black Panthers who are aawaiting trial here, a university spokesman said.
TEL AVIV, April 23 (Reuters) A 72-year-old Briton has been arrested here on suspicion of saving spied for the United Arab Republic, it was disclosed today.

BONN, April 23 West Germany's merger carousel took another spin today as the Government announced the amalgamation of the Salzgitter steel works and Ilseder Hute, another steel plant, into the country's third-largest steel concern.
MADISON, Wis., April 23 William T. Evjue, founder, publisher and editor of The Capital Times, died here early today. He was 87 years old.
A parent group that has been demanding a grievance table for students at George Washington High School, yesterday rejected a plan for such a table announced on Wednesday by the Board of Education.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 23 (AP) Hollis Stacy's putting carried her to a 2-and-1 victory over Connie Day today, and into the final of the North and South amateur golf tournament against Mrs. Paul Dye, winner by the same score over the defending champion Barbara McIntire.

A group of directors of the City University's SEEK program yesterday challenged an Assemblyman's report that an $18-million package had been negotiated in Albany for the program's 1970-71 fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, April 23 The Defense Department said today that a Soviet missilecarrying submarine was patrolling in the Atlantic.
TALLAHASSEE, April 23 (AP) Jack McGowan, Harold Henning and Terry Dill carded five-under par 67's, today and shared the first-round lead in the $50,000 Tallahassee open.

In one of the largest quarterly losses ever reported by an airline, Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it had a loss of $39,770,000 in the first quarter of 1970, compared with a loss of $14,911,000 in the same period last year.
Pressure on The New York Times mounted yesterday as meetings continued between negotiators for the typographical union and the city's four major newspapers.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 23 A potent, studious, often raucous and sometimes violent black-power movement has come to the English-speaking Caribbean, and nowhere more visibly than here.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market took another pounding yesterday in comparatively quiet trading.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries achieved new highs in first quarter sales and earnings, according to the company's quarterly report released yesterday afternoon. Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president, placed worldwide sales and revenues at $1,324,464,000, or 13 per cent higher than the $1,169,470,000 reported a year earlier.
SAANG, Cambodia, April 23 (AP) Pvt. Kong Deth hugged his AK-47 rifle and pressed close to the sunbaked earth. He was afraid.

Thtee eligibles for the $50,000 added Carter Handicap which will be contested at Aqueduct a week from tomorrow, and a noneligible for that fixture, who had won five of his six 1970 starts, were among the six principals yesterday in the Big A's featured Sailor Handicap.
PITTSBURGH, April 23 (AP) Bill Mazeroski's bases-loaded double keyed a five-run Pittsburgh surge in the seventh inning and the Pirates held on to defeat the Atlanta Braves, 8-6, tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Four former chief Presidential science advisers joined today in sharp criticism of present Government policy in supporting science.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 (UPI) Cambodia agreed today to admit a South Vietnamese Red Cross delegation this weekend to start the repatriation of 600,000 Vietnamese.

The stock market has absorbed a merciless pounding so far this spring and pessimism is rampant on Wall Street. Securities prices keep falling day after day, with little regard for news developments or the lack of them.

Mayor Lindsay said last night that the presiding justices of the two Appellate Divisions of the State Supreme Court were investigating reports that some Criminal Court judges in the city were working on a part-time basis.
TRENTON, April 23 Nelson G. Gross, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, reported today that his and his wife's net worth was $802,191.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 21 A young Texas politician named Ben Barnes will make speeches during the next six months in Alaska, Illinois, Ohio, Colorado, New York and half a dozen other states.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 23 The Government of Trinidad and Tobago pressed its negotiations today with a holdout faction of black-power advocates in the armed forces who mutinied on Tuesday. At the same time, the police continued to round up anti-Government activists.

LEWISBURG, Pa., April 23 (AP) Thomas F. Johnson, former Democratic Representative from Maryland, reported today to a deputy United States marshal, who took hom to the Federal penitentiary to start serving a six-month sentence.
Hesitancy on the part of dealers because of the imminence of the Government's report on stocks caused grain and soybean butures to turn generally weak yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 23 (AP) Walter P. Reuther was re-elected president of the United Auto Workers today, swamping his first opponent in 21 years and setting the stage for handpicking his successor four years from now.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 The 11million-member United Methodist Church became today the first Protestant denomination to transmit formally to its constituency a plan of union that would merge nine churches into a single denomination of some 25-million members.
There were some obvious and not-so-obvious results of the city's first Earth Day.

JERUSALEM, April 23 Two Israeli civilians touring the occupied Golan heights were killed today and five others were wounded when infiltrators from Syria ambushed their cars on a main road less than a mile from the 1967 cease-fire line.
For followers of oil industry fortunes, the news was mixed yesterday.
Governor Rockefeller won the support yesterday of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York in his bid for a fourth term.
LONDON, April 23 Dame Adeline Genee a celebrated dancer who helped to found modern Birtish ballet, died today at Esher, Surrey, at the age of 92.

LONDON, April 23 (AP) A report of four doctors conducting research for the British Government says new, lowdosage oral contraceptives should reduce deaths among women using the pill by onehalf and cut the thrombosis rate by 25 per cent.

Shifting rapidly to a target of opportunity following his nomination and rejection for the Supreme Court, Judge G. Harrold Carswell has resigned from the United States Court of Appeals to run for the Senate. He has, of course, every right to leave the bench, if he wishes, and seek a seat alongside the majority of Senators who spurned him for the high court.

Miss Cynthia Alley plans to be married in July to Woodbury H. Andrews, a cum laude graduate of Princeton University, of which his fiancee's ancestor, Jonathan Dickinson, was the first president. The university was known then as the College of New Jersey.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 23 George C. Wallace, who ran for President knowing he would not win, entered this state's Democratic gubernatorial primary believing he could not lose. Now, 10 days before the election, there are indications that he has changed his mind.
NEW HAVEN, April 23 Don Martin, one of 25 Yale athletes who withdrew from the Penn Relays, said today, "The rest of the track season is in doubt for me."
The stock market plunged through the 760 support level in the opening half-hour yesterday and kept moving downward to close at 750.59.
ENUGU, Nigeria, April 8 Lawrence Chibiko, a 29-yearold Ibo with a fierce pride but no money, is camping out in a bullet-scarred office building here, waiting to get his old job back.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Treasure bill rates advanced at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
Bowing to heavy pressure from New Jersey Congressmen, Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that it had cancelled plans to end Newark-to-Washington flights on its air shuttle service.

In the sort of mob scene that establishes an event's status, angers fans and warms the heart of any promoter's accountant, the New York Knickerbockers sold out their remaining playoff tickets yesterday before the hour that had been officially set for the beginning of the sale.
DURBAN, South Africa, April 23 The Nationalist party of Premier John Vorster has been returned to power with a reduced but still overwhelming majority in Parliament.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church ended a three-day meeting today by narrowly defeating a motion to open portions of future sessions to the press and other observers.
WASHINGTON, April 23 A Congressional joint subcommittee recommended today that the House and Senate give the Navy money to start building its third nuclear aircraft carrier.

WASHINGTON, April 23 The plan to replace the Electoral College with direct popular election of the President won the grudging approval of the Senate Judiciary Committee today and moved toward a final floor vote.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Kristensen of Jyderup, Denmark, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Hanne Agnete Kristensen, a stewardess with American Airlines, to John Douglas Maxwell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Maxwell is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell of Glen Head, L.I.

GENEVA, April 23 The United States and the Soviet Union today submitted to the Geneva Disarmament Conference a revised draft treaty for the banning of nuclear weapons on the ocean floor under which countries not possessing those weapons would be accorded special treatment.
The three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor, in their debate last night, attacked Governor Rockefeller far more vigorously than they criticized each other.
The bond market took it on the chin again yesterday, although there were few declines as severe as were recorded on Wednesday.

MADRID, April 24 Four Spanish opposition figures today expressed to Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany their "concern that Spain could become a part of Europe without first achieving moderate liberal reforms."
The Penn Central said yesterday that a representation dispute between two unions over railroad police at its "piggy-back" freight yards had had some effect on vans being trucked in.
BOGOTA, April 22 On a cold afternoon 11 years ago, the Colombian Senate censured a retired lieutenant general as unfit "because of his misconduct in the presidency of the republic."

The board of governors of the National Basketball Association realigned yesterday the league's 17 teams for next season at the Hotel Roosevelt. The league owners had previously realigned the association's two divisions into four sections at a meeting in Chicago on March 16.

A 26-year-old grocery clerk from the Bronx was arrested last night after he allegedly beat his two stepchildren a 6year-old girl and her 4-year-old brother so severely that they were hospitalized in serious condition with welts and bruises.

Dr. Thomas F. Goreau, an authority on coral reef ecology, died Wednesday at St. Vincent'S Hospital of complications following surgery for cancer. He was 46 years old and lived in Discovery Bay, Jamaica, where he was resident director of a marine laboratory, sponsored jointly by the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., and the University of the West Indies.

WASHINGTON, April 23 A bitter controversy between members of the House and Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel intensified today over the Interior Department's alleged "inconsistency" and "inaction" in enforcing new Federal safety standards for coal miners.
The Earth Day theme of environmental concern continued to resound yesterday on campuses, in legislative halls, and among conservation groups across the country.
WASHINGTON, April 23 President Nixon is struggling with a decision on further military aid to Cambodia in terms that at least some of his advisers portray as fateful.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company estimated yesterday that the United States balance of payments was in heavy deficit during the first quarter, representing a sharp deteriora tion from the large surplus posted in the final three months of 1969.
A plan to convert movie houses into offtrack betting parlors was proposed to Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 (AP) Enemy gunners in Laos and South Vietnam shot down 12 American aircraft in a two-day period this week, the United States command said today.
RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 23 Gary Player of South Africa led the field with a 68 as foreign golfers dominated the opening round of the $150,000 Tournament of Champions today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 President Nixon abolished today, by Executive order, occupational draft deferments and deferments for fathers.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Bills were introduced in both the Senate and the House today to exempt the last Mississippi River steamboat that carries overnight passengers from Federal fire regulations.

Mrs. Marian Thomas Hammond, wife of Dr. E. Cuyler Hammond, vice president for epidemiology and statistics of the American Cancer Society, died yesterday at her home. She was 47 years old and lived at 164 East 72d Street.

TRENTON, April 23 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark lost his bid today to have all references to him removed from a grand jury presentment that censured the city for its tolerance of widespread gambling.

President Nixon's announced plan to withdraw 150,000 more troops from Vietnam inevitably raises hopes that the United States is now decisively shifting its national priorities and will soon have the resources needed to tackle domestic social problems that have long been starved for funds by the war.

BONN, April 23 Chancellor Willy Brandt has written to the Polish Communist leader, Wladslaw Gomulka, to underline the West German Government's earnestness in seeking normal relations with Poland, it was disclosed today.

ATHENS, April 23 An unfinished manuscript on Byzantine music, written on paper napkins by the Greek composer, Mikis Theodorakis, was found this week at the prison camp where he had spent six months before his unexpected release 10 days ago.

VIENNA, April 23 The United States and the Soviet Union continued to outline their positions on the limitation of strategic arms today as their chief delegates met for an hour and 40 minutes at the Soviet Embassy.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Despite unexpected strength from opponents of the space program, the House supported today a proposal to give the space agency more money than President Nixon requested.
An eviction order was signed yesterday against the University of the Streets, the Lower East Side training school and day-care center, for failure to pay $5,000 in back rent.

THE Juilliard Theater was inaugurated last night with a performance of Igor Stravinsky's "The Rake's Progress," and now Lincoln Center stands complete. This little theater, seating about 1,000, but possessed of every stage facility known to current technology, is a little jewel the handsomest and most tasteful of all of the Lincoln Center auditoriums.
An organizer of the New York branch of the Black Panther party was convicted yesterday of having shot to death a stranger on an East Bronx street last year in a case of mistaken identity.
MOSCOW, April 23 The Soviet Union today made public the names of its 10-man delegation that will take part in a public discussion with American public figures next week in New York.
Suddenly and surprisingly, more street phones are starting to work.
WASHINGTON, April 23 The management of the Senators had every excuse for calling off tonight's game this afternoon, when it was raining like mad.
President Nixon has taken substantial new steps toward making the draft more equitable with his order ending some deferments and with his request to Congress to put an end to others.

There were tunes of glory in Great Britain last week when the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Roy Jenkins, stood in the well of the House of Commons, bearing his budget in the same battered red dispatch case once carried by Gladstone.

The recently ousted president of the Levin-Townsend Computer Corporation filed a $750-million antitrust suit against that company and the International Business Machines Corporation in Federal Court here yesterday.
ONLY one partnership from the New York area will be among the American representatives in the World Pair Championship in Stockholm in June.

In the nineteen-sixties, movie actresses were semihippies, like Mia Farrow. In the fifties and forties, they were girls-next-door, smiling wholesomely out of the faces of June Allyson and Doris Day. But in the movies' golden era, the thirties and twenties, they were Stars. And in the firmament that included great vamps such as Theda Bara, Nita Naldi and Gloria Swanson, there was no starrier star than Pola Negri.

As New York State's first Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, Henry L. Diamond is in the enviable position of being a public official riding a cresting wave of public enthusiasm for his specialty.
WASHINGTON, April 23 The Justice Department announced today its intention to file suit to block the planned acquisition of the American Credit Corporation by the Wachovia Corporation.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the formation of a special five-man committee to review the city's procedures for investigating police corruption.

Unless the laity of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn increase their contributions to the parishes and the schools there may be no parochial elementary schools in Brooklyn and Queens within five years, according to the Center for Urban Redevelopment in Education.
COLLEGE, Alaska, April 23 The Secretary of the Interior, Walter J. Hickel, said last night that he would issue a right-of-way permit for construction of an 800-mile oil pipeline across Alaska.
Normalization of United States relations with Communist China could bring a gradual, though modest, growth of trade, according to a study made public here yesterday.

Mrs. Irene Miles Downes, widow of Olin Downes, The New York Times's music critic for more than 30 years, died of cancer Wednesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 81 years old and lived at 205 West 57th Street.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 23 For 20 years Gian Carlo Menotti has been harboring the idea of "The Leper." At first he planned this work on the theme of minorities as an opera, but two years ago he decided to write it as a play because it was becoming "too intellectual and philosophical."

NEW HAVEN, April 23 The 73-year-old Sheriff of New Haven County was questioned for four and a half hours today on the selection of the grand jury that returned a murder indictment against Bobby G. Seale, national chairman of the Black Panther party.
Attacks on teachers by students and others have increased substantially during the current school year, according to figures compiled by the Board of Education.
Those students and faculty members at Yale who are trying to stop a murder trial by calling a strike against the university have plunged campus activism into new depths of irrationality.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that the nation's schools faced a financial crisis and urged that Federal aid for education be increased.

BOSTON, April 23 Senator Edward M. Kennedy asked the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court today to order released for public examination the original transcript and report of the Mary Jo Kopechne inquest.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that reports of police corruption in this morning's issue of The New York Times "are extremely serious and go to the heart of the effective

WASHINGTON, April 24 Scholars at major American universities fear that the study of some foreign languages and of the history and culture of critical areas will be permanently damaged if Congress approves the Nixon Administration's cuts in the education budget.

LONDON, April 24 British controversy over the use of tear gas in Northern Ireland was heightened today by the release of a document reportedly prepared by a United States Army research team detailing the damaging effects of the widely used riot-control agent known as CS.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 24 The Cambodian military acknowledged today that the shipment of arms received yesterday consisted of Soviet-designed and Chinesemanufactured AK-47 automatic rifles and ammunition that had been captured from Communist forces in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 24 Max M. Kampelman has withdrawn as moderator of "Washington Week In Review," a television feature appearing on educational stations around the country.
PORT OF SPAIN, April 24 (Reuters) Prime Minister Eric Williams ordered all foreign naval vessels today to leave Trinidad's territorial waters.

PARIS, April 24 The French Army assigned 750 soldiers to the Paris garbage detail at dawn today, replacing 3,800 striking sanitation men. By nightfall, the city streets were filthier than when they had started.
NEW HAVEN, April 24 (AP) Organizers of a May 1 rally in support of the Panthers were said today they would do their best to keep order.

Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, disclosed yesterday that his agency had no funds available to build its planned high-speed rail link to Kennedy International Airport from Manhattan and Queens.

The near-disaster of Apollo 13 has shown that lunar landings are risky as well as expensive. Still I think it can be argued that carefully planned scientific exploration of the moon justifies the outlay. Unfortunately, this is not happening.
BATHURST, Gambia, April 24 (Agence France-Presse) Gambia, Africa's smallest country, became a republic within the British Commonwealth just before midnight last night.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 24 The men whose ideas shape the philosophy of the black-power movement in the English-speaking regions of the Caribbean represent a wide range of radical thought but they are all together on one point: that white power must become a thing of the past in their countries.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 A seven-furlong race called the Stepping Stone Purse will be the main attraction at Churchill Downs tomorrow. The reason for the eminence of a race of only $6,500 value is that it will include in its line-up two of the leading candidates for the Kentucky Derby a week from tomorrow.
BOZEMAN, Mont. As it does in cities large and small across the nation, Chet Huntley's television image arrives in Bozeman in the evenings.
The despicable attempt at assassination of Chiang Ching-kuo was a criminal perversion of a cause which, on its merits, deserves a wider hearing in the United States.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their latest reports on changes in shareownings by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:
PINEHURST, N.C., April 24 (AP) Hollis Stacy won the first two holes and went on to defeat Mrs. Paul Dye, 6 and 4, in the final of the North and South women's amateur tournament.
HATIEN, South Vietnam, April 19 Le Tan Son, a Vietnamese refugee from Cambodia, decided it was time to flee when, he said, he saw two Vietnamese monks and a nun stabbed to death on a Pnompenh street.

YONKERS, April 24 A swollen front left leg, apparently the result of having bumped against his stall at Stanley Dancer's Egyptian Acres Farm at New Egypt, N.J., will keep Lucky Creed of Australia out of the qualifying mile he was scheduled to pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow morning.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 24 Twenty-two persons were arrested at 1 A.M. today by a 50-man sheriff's squad as they tried to flee from a Stanford University building captured by protesters yesterday.

PARIS, April 24 It was the end of a cold spring day in Paris as the monetary authorities of the richest nations dashed from the spacious galleries of the Chateau de la Muette into their warmed-up official cars.

WHITE PLAINS, April 24 The scenic Bronx River Parkway-the world's oldest and Westchester County's most dangerous parkway is getting some safety improvements in a county effort to lower the high accident rate.
HONOLULU April 24 (AP) Student demonstrators seized a second R.O.T.C. building on the University of Hawaii campus late today.
HONG KONG, April 25 (Reuters) Communist China opposed today any reconvening of the Geneva conference and accused the Soviet Union of betraying the peoples of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 24 Frank Beard equaled one record and narrowly missed another as he scored a 64 today in the second round of the $150,000 Tournament of Champions. Golfdom's leading money-winner in 1969 with earnings of $175,223,93, the Louisville, Ky., slugger had nine birdies in a round that tied for the lowest tally put together in this 18-year-old event for the game's elite.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 24 The city manager of New Rochelle has dismissed Police Commissioner Edward F. Carey, effective midnight tonight.

LONDON, April 24 Late in 1956, after the Conservative Government's disaster at Suez, an American correspondent newly arrived in Britain was talking with Aneurin Bevan, the great left-wing Labor politician. How would Labor do in an election today, he asked.

ROME, April 24 The small group of Sardinian anarchists involved in a stone-throwing melee with policemen guarding Pope Paul VI today are the modern representatives of an intellectual and political tradition that goes back to 1876 in Italy.
Dianna Donghi, a member of the Weatherman fection of Students for a Democratic Society, was arrested in Foley Square yesterday on a charge of unlawful use of dangerous weapons.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Representative William M. Colmer, chairman of the House Rules Committee sidetracked today for 60 days a bipartisan resolution calling for a study of impeachment proceedings against Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas.

JERUSALEM, April 24 Israeli defense officials have announced that "for military purposes" they intend to close off a 750-acre site in the town of Hebron, in the occupied area on the West bank of the Jordan. This type of action has previously been used to prepare for Jewish settlement in occupied Arab areas.
The city's newspaper dispute appeared yesterday to be approaching a critical phase.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 The severe impact of inflation on the steel industry was emphasized here today by Allison R. Maxwell Jr., chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Art: Holograms in Their Infancy I WISH I could wax more enthusiastic, as they say, about the esthetic potential of holography which, as every preschooler seems to know, is the making of threedimensional photographs by laser beam. But while "N Dimensional Space," a show of holograms by artists at the Finch College Museum of Art/Contemporary Wing, is earnest and enlightening, it doesn't go far toward con vincing me.

TRIPOLI, Libya, April 4 "About the most exciting thing to do at night now is to go down to Al Istiqlal Street and look at the thermometer, barometer and hygrometer in the meteorological case," a sunburned American oil driller remarked as he sipped a Pepsi-Cola in the "bar" of
WASHINGTON, April 24 Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader who was a defendant in the Chicago Seven trial was turned away from the White House today when he tried to attend a tea given by Tricia Nixon.
PARIS, April 24 France will turn down a request from the Cambodian Government for arms to fight North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces, according to informed diplomatic sources here.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 24 (UPI) Angered by a trustee's crackdown on disruptive campus elements, two student leaders of Pennsylvania State University proposed today a protest "strike" by all of the university's more than 48,000 students.
THOSE letters from irate small investors continue to turn up in the mail.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., April 24 Three teen-aged boys were injured today during a wild melee involving about 80 Negro and white students at Hightstown Regional High School. Chains, baseball bats, and lengths of pipe were used as weapons.

Officials of the Aluminum Company of America said yesterday in Pittsburgh that Alcoa might build a smelter in the Ryukyu Islands and had told the Government of the Ryukyus that if the project went ahead a Japanese concern might be invited to participate as a joint owner of the smelter.

ROME, April 24 (AP) Two American women, Mrs. Billie Jean King and Julie Heldman, seeded No. 1 and No. 2, respectively, in the women's singles of the Italian international tennis championships, earned berths in the semifinals today, but in men's competition top-seeded Lew Hoad of Australia was ousted by Alexander Metreveli of the Soviet Union.

SEATTLE, April 24 (AP) A bomb mailed in Seattle to the White House was detected and deactivated in Washington, officials said tonight. Another bomb, mailed to Selective Service headquarters, was also intercepted, they said.

While the session of the New York State Legislature which just ended was one of the most productive in recent years, it nonetheless left some important unfinished business. Four major areas were neglected: labor law, the courts, reapportionment and legislative procedural reform.

PARIS They used to say that when a good Ameri can dies, his soul goes to Paris and they still say that when a good gourmet dies his soul goes to the Place Madeleine, specifically to the corner that quarters the house of Fauchon.

Slang, one theory holds, is sometimes created so that those who understand it can discuss subjects they want to keep secret. Whether this is true for the police is not known, but there are many police slang words that deal with corruption.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Ships of Haiti's coast guard sporadically shelled her capital, Port-au-Prince, this afternoon in apparent rebellion against the regime of President Francois Duvalier, American and Haitian sources reported.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of "better than a 50 per cent interest" in Emprases Incorporadas C.A. of Maracaibo, Venezuela, a refrigerator maker.
The London stock market closed slightly firmer yesterday following two days of sharp losses.
Mrs. Poldi Goetz-Wittels, a former editor of the Western Publishing Company, Inc., in New York, died of a heart attack at her home at 155 East 93d Street on Thursday. She was 72 years old.
The new-issue market did practically no business at all this week as 14 companies postponed their public offerings because of depressed market conditions.

ANYONE willing to follow the maze of Greenwich Village streets to 283 West 11th Street, just off Bleecker Street, and make her way into "The Tickle Tree," a new basement shop specializing in decorative, hand-crafted furniture, is bound to feel a little like "Alice in Wonderland."
WASHINGTON, April 24 A patented system per mits communication by a handicapped person who is unable to write or to operate a conventional typewriter
LOS ANGELES, April 24 The New York Mets made their first appearance on the West Coast as the defending champions tonight with Jerry Koosman pitching against Alan Foster of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
An explosion rocked an Army and Air Force recruiting office on the second floor of a Harlem office building late yesterday afternoon, but four sergeants and a woman enlistee escaped injury.
People who go to bed tonight without setting their alarm clocks ahead one hour may be late getting to church or the golf course tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. told Congress today that the Apollo 13 astronauts had felt close to death but that they had still wanted to get their crippled spacecraft as near to earth as possible, even if they perished.

DELANO, Calif., April 24 A spokesman for the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee announced today that supporters of Cesar Chavez, the farm union organizer, had scheduled a three-day march on the nation's capitol for May 1 through 3.
Weekend performances by the New York City Ballet have been canceled as a result of the five-day-old strike by the company's orchestra.

The shocking attempt on the life of Chiang Chingkuo, Deputy Premier of the Republic of China, as he entered the Plaza Hotel yesterday is a source of shame and embarrassment to the people of this city and merits the strongest possible condemnation. Fortunately, the shot was deflected by an alert police Officer and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's son and possible heir was unharmed.

A survey of medical records over 16 years has indicated that ulcers may be becoming an increasingly common childhood disease, particularly among teen-aged boys in the upper socio-economic groups, a Buffalo researcher has reported.

THE big guns of Paris ready-made fashion, like Sonia Rykiel and Jean Cacharel, stayed home. The leading American merchants and manufacturers had already been in Paris last week buying or snooping and cribbing taxdeductible ideas at the influential pret-a-porter showings.
A routine search of a man suspected of loitering in a Harlem apartment-house lobby turned up a bomb made from a length of lead pipe, according to the police at the West 126th Street station.
A leading consultant to the banking industry warned yesterday that Congress might well enact legislation this year that would severely restrict the scope of banking operations.

Despite higher sales and operating revenues, earnings of the Atlantic Richfield Company declined 9 per cent in the first quarter of 1970 from the yearearlier level. This reflected rising operating costs and lower product prices, the concern's report disclosed yesterday.

ROME, April 24 President Nixon's leading adviser on the Middle East said here today, at the end of a stormy trip through the area, that the chances for peace between Arabs and Israelis had not improved.
THE average bridge player is well above average in inteligence, and the average bridge expert is even higher on the I.Q. scale.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market continued to Weaken yesterday although the number of declines and the price drops were not so large as in the previous two sessions.

The first of 344 Japanesecherry trees, their pale pink petals just beginning to appear on slim green branches, were planted along the river edge of the Henry Hudson Parkway yesterday as a gift from the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation.

Water. The President signed an executive order that broadened the jurisdiction of the New England River Basins Commission to cover Long Island and Long Island Sound. Also he requested that a representative from the Atomic Energy Commission be added to the agency.

NEEDHAM, Mass., April 24 Miss Margaret Louise Bryant of New York and Arnold Everett Amstutz of Cambridge, founder and board chairman of Decision Technology, plan to be married June 27 at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston.

Narcotics dealers, gamblers and businessmen make illicit payments of millions of dollars a year to the policemen of New York, according to policemen, law-enforcement experts and New Yorkers who make such payments themselves.
Interest shifted on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday from soybean oil and soybean meal to those three basics wheat, corn, and soybeans.

MOSCOW, April 24 The Soviet Union broke its monthlong silence on events in Cambodia tonight with a bitter attack on the United States and a warning that attempts to widen "imperialist aggression" in South Asia "may have most serious consequences."

The New York Yankees will entertain 5,000 disadvantaged youngsters, 140 college sports editors and numerous women at the Stadium this afternoon, when they meet the Oakland Athletics in the first Ladies Day game of the season.
WASHINGTON, April 24 Attorneys for Seaman Roger Lee Priest protested today that the sailor should not have been taken into custody despite his conviction by a military court late last night.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 24 High military sources reported today that there was a greatly increasing number of local attacks by the enemy throughout the frontier regions occupied by the Vietnamese Communists. They expressed concern that the enemy might be preparing an offensive designed to divide Cambodia in two.

Milton N. Grass, a historian of the hosiery industry, who retired in 1962 as president of Stylecraft Sales Corporation here, hosiery wholesalers, died Sunday of a heart ailment in Stamford, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived at Skyview Lane in New Canaan, Conn.
In its efforts to pacify strife-torn George Washington High School, the Board of Education is aiming primarily and properly at safeguarding the right of students to an uninterrupted education.
Aetna Life and Casualty reported yesterday that net earnings in the first quarter rose to $19.7-million, or 74 cent a share, from the year-earlier $9.4-million, or 35 cents a share.

After having taken a 20point lead in the first 17 minutes and a 15-point lead midway through the third quarter, the New York Knickerbockers had to come from behind in the final period to beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 124-112, before another hysterical gathering of 19,500 at Madison Square Garden last night.
CHICAGO (AP) Vincent DiCola nearly lost a full head of hair after a hearing in divorce court.
CAGLIARI, Sardinia, April 24 Pope Paul VI made a triumphal visit to this craggy Mediterranean island today. He was the first reigning pontiff to set foot on its impoverished shores.

PENNS GROVE, N.J., April 24 (AP) Fighting broke out between black and white students at Penns Grove Regional High School today, forcing the closing of the 900-student school. Several youths suffered minor injuries.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 In the southwest corner of the cavernous Convention Hall here, the fat man and his friends politicked furiously but in vain all week against the candidate of the Reuther caucus.

A Taiwanese fired a pistol at Chiang Kai-shek's son and heir apparent, Chiang Ching-kuo, in a revolving door at the Plaza Hotel here yesterday, but missed when a detective grabbed his wrist just before the gun went off.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 24 (UPI) Jack McGowan and Bobby Greenwood, a tour rookie, shared of the 36-hole lead in the Tallahassee open golf tournament today with six-under-par 138's.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Hospitals can fight rising prices by improving the utilization of hospital facilities and adopting programs of preventive or prospective medicine, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

Classes at Grover Cleveland High School were dismissed shortly before noon yesterday after a small fire flared in the crowded cafeteria and hundreds of unruly youths headed toward the school from another neighborhood.

ST. LOUIS, April 24 The United Methodist Church committed itself today to give $2million in 1971 and $2-million more in 1972 to its Commission on Religion and Race to be used "in the service of minority peoples."
The 747 flew over Wall Street yesterday, but unfortunately for the bulls it was the DowJones industrial average and not the big jetliner.

PARIS, April 24 "Beginning to End," an anthology of the works of Samuel Beckett, edited and performed as a one-man show by the Irish character comedian Jack McGowran, had its world premiere at the Theatre Edouard VII last night.
A new gallery for the exhibition of glass, ancient and modern, will be opened today at the Toledo Museum of Art, which from its beginning in 1901 has had important sponsorship by glass magnates.

The Parents Association of the West Side Montessori School will sponsor a street fair on 99th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway next Saturday. Proceeds of sales and admissions to entertainments for children will benefit the scholarship fund of the school at 225 West 99th Street.

WHITE PLAINS, April 24 Harry Archer, a partner in the law firm of Archer, Leonard Archer, died yesterday at the United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 64 years old and lived at 20 Old Mamaroneck Road.

Cheri Eisenberg, a high school sophomore from Woodmere, L.I., was sitting cross-legged, tranquilly holding a long-stemmed yellow lily. She was sitting on the sidewak, easing herself into a mood of euphoria suitable to the movie "Woodstock," which she would see after a wait in line of an hour and a half.
The Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday it would increase wholesale prices of its ground and freeze-dried coffee effective Monday.
Mrs. Helen Thomas Follett, a writer of travel books, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived at 404 West 116th Street.

Classes were suspended at Hunter College yesterday afternoon following student disruptions in which more than 60 helmeted policemen were called in to clear the building at Lexington Avenue and 69th Street.
Frank Howard made it out of Robert F. Kennedy Stadium twice last night once with his bat and once with his temper.

The Metropolitan Opera has announced details of the added four-week season of nonsubscription performances that will begin June 1. The series will make up for some of the performances lost during the labor dispute that shortened the regular 1969-70 season by 15 weeks.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 (AP) Wage demands of the United Auto Workers on the auto industry this year will be well in excess of 8 per cent a year, Walter P. Reuther said today.
A 17-year old suspect was arrested late yesterday afternoon in the fatal stabbings of an elderly couple and their 25year old daughter-in-law in the Rosebank section of Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, April 24 The United States Bureau of Mines was under a Federal Court order today restraining its inspectors from enforcing some controversial sections of new coal mine safety regulations that have stirred confusion and anger in the coal fields.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 24 (AP) Final figures from Wednesday's general election showed today that the ruling Nationalist party lost.

Kalman Feher, a tennis coach at the Vanderbilt International Racquet Club here and former member of the Hungarian Davis Cup team, died of a heart attack Thursday at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Jamica, Queens.
WARSAW, April 24 (Reuters) Polish and West German delegations completed tonight their third round of talks on improving relations and agreed to meet again early in June in Bonn.

THE saddest aspect of the present Royal Ballet season at the Metropolitan Opera House-indeed, perhaps, the only sad aspect is that it marks the last time we will see Sir Frederick Ashton at the head of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 With raindrops falling on his head, Tony Colon outsmarted and outfought Joe Savage of Roselle (N.J.) Catholic to give Power Memorial the championship today in the schoolboy distance medley at the Penn Relays.
WASHINGTON, April 24 For what is believed to be the first time in American political history, a Roman Catholic priest is running for the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, April 24 The Justice Department formally filed suit today to prevent the merger of the American Credit Corporation into the Wachovia Corporation.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aprils 24 One roundhouse swing with a bottle of champagne by Mrs. Robert W. McCullough of Riverside, Conn., and her words, "I christen thee Valiant," launched a new America's Cup defense candidate today.
WHEN Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla was the dictator of Colombia 15 years ago, the people told a joke about a visit he made to a struggling rancher.
Walter Berchtold is not exactly what one pictures as the president and managing director of an international airline, but then Swissair, which he heads, is not exactly a typical airline.

FORT LEE, N.J., April 24 J. Cameron Day, a trade peridical editor, died today in Englewood Hospital, after having been struck by an automobile here last night. He was 59 years old and lived at 233 McElroy Avenue.
A 29-year-old Brooklyn man was killed by a policeman early this morning after he allegedly wounded another policeman with the latter's own gun.

NEW HAVEN, April 24 About 200 Yale students, freshly shorn and attired in clean jeans, ventured into parts of this city today to explain their concern over the impending murder trial of Bobby G. Seale, chairman of the Black Panther Party.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Vice President Agnew said tonight that the rate of increase in street crime had been reduced sharply since the Nixon Administration took office, and he gave the credit to Attorney General John N. Mitchell.
The new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 19th-Century America, can help collectors expand their knowledge of the distinctive urban art and design of the period.

Jerry Grote, who had been complaining of chills for several days, was examined in the clubhouse before the game by Dr. Robert Woods, the Dodgers' physician. He was found to have a temperature of 103 degrees and was sent to St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica where Bill Singer of the Dodgers has been under treatment for hepatitis.

NEW HAVEN, April 24 Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, declared last night that he was "skeptical of the ability of black revolutionaries to achieve a fair trial anywhere in the United States."

GREENWICH, Conn., April 24 John J. Sullivan, a senior partner in the law firm of Hirschberg, Pettengill Strong, died after a heart attack last night at Greenwich Hospital. He lived at 31 Anderson Road, Milbrook, and was 51 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) A new report on hunger in America will be released Monday, timed to coincide with Congressional consideration of welfare reform, and the food stamp and school lunch programs.

GEORGETOWN, Conn., April 24 Richard Gillmore Knott, a consultant of Goldmann Sachs Co., investment bankers, and the publisher and editor of The Louisville (Ky.) Post and Herald from 1919 to 1929, died today of a heart ailment at his home here. His age was 77.

A sketch of a picture frame by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis, drawn when she was the wife of President John F. Kennedy, was withdrawn from an auction sale Thursday night by order of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

Prof. Eugene J. Keefe, a faculty member of the Fordham University School of Law for 42 years, died Wednesday in Physician Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens, after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Jackson Heights.

BOSTON, April 24 (AP) State Attorney General Robert H. Quinn called today for the "full and speedy disclosure and publication of the report and transcripts of the report and transcripts of evidence" of the Mary JJo Kopechne inquest.

Fear that the Internal Revenue Service is being converted into an agency of political repression can only be increased by the disclosure that tax agents have been exhaustively scrutinizing programs produced by National Educational Television.
MILWAUKEE, April 24 As Wisconsin observed Arbor Day today, Milwaukee County discovered that one of its choicest woods had been demolished by a "misled" logger.
BERLIN, April 24 (AP) Rudolf Hess today received the first visit from members of his family inside West Berlin's Spandau Prison, where he has been held since 1946.
Miss Barbara Jo Oppenheim and Geoffrey Case Berresford, teachers at the Collegiate School, will be married here June 12.

Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel, the Federal official who has the broadest responsibilities for preserving the American environment, introduced an ominously sour note into the Earth Day observance (which otherwise the Nixon Administration largely ignored), when he announced his intention to grant a permit for the controversial 800-mile oil pipeline across Alaska.

GLASSBORO, N.J., April 24 Dr. Julian Carter Aldrich, an emeritus professor of education of New York University and an author, died here Wednesday of a stroke. He was 69 years old and lived in Mansion Park Apartments 70.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 24 Vice President Agnew made his first venture into the South tonight since the Senate rejected the nomination on April 8 of Judge G. Harrold Carswell of Florida to the Supreme Court.
MOSCOW, April 24 Leonid I. Brezhnev ended his threehour speech on Lenin the other day with the slogan, "Lenin lived, Lenin lives and Lenin will live!"

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) President Nixon traveled by limousine today to Camp David, his mountain retreat in Maryland. The camp was submerged in clouds and fog and the customary helicopter trip was ruled out.

Thirty-one years after its founding, The Kenyon Review, the literary quarterly that gave early exposure to such writers as Boris Pasternak and Robert Penn Warren, has suspended publication and will not resume unless a sponsor is found.
Elliott Burch materialized out of the rain and fog of Aqueduct at precisely 8:25 yesterday morning and fixed his cool brown eyes on the assistant racing secretary.

Arthur J. Voute, a former vice president of the Emigrant Savings Bank, died at St. Vincent's Hospital Thursday after a brief illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 5420 Netherland Avenue on the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
HOUSTON, April 24 (UPI) Clark Graebner of New York and Manuel Santana of Spain moved into the semifinals of the $25,000 River Oaks tennis tournament today.

MOSCOW, April 24 The Soviet Union today formally opened its election campaign for the Supreme Soviet with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, President Nikolai V. Podgorny and Leonid L. Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist party, heading the list of those nominated for automatic election to the Soviet version of a national legislature.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 24 The acting police commissioner for Trinidad and Tobago declared today that the black-power disorders that shook this tropical island for the last three days were now under control.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., April 24 (UPI) Herb Shriner, the homespun humorist who starred on television in the 1950's, was killed with his wife in a car wreck that apparently was caused by a mechanical failure, the police said today.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 Senator Charles E. Goodell said yesterday that he planned to introduce legislation to prevent President Nixon from using any military personnel in Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Commercial banks, life insurance companies and trustees of pension funds have pledged to increase by $2-billion their investments in residential mortgages this year, the White House announced today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 24 A march on the administration building at Ohio State University today by some 400 dissidents was described as "peaceful" by a school official.
FIGHTING REPORTED NEAR ALLIED CAMP SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24 (AP) New fighting was reported today near the beleaguered allied camp at Dakseang near the Laotian border.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 24 (AP) The Indiana Pacers broke a 104-104 tie with six straight foul shots tonight and downed the Carolina Cougars, 110-106, to complete a four-game sweep of their American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoff.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration advised physicians today to prescribe oral contraceptives with the lowest content of estrogen, a hormone.

WASHINGTON, April 24 The United States and the Soviet Union publicly disagreed today over the character of the current fighting in Cambodia, although the two Governments were reported to be maintaining private contacts on the possibility of a broad Indochina peace conference.

WASHINGTON, April 24 Mr. and Mrs. John S. Hayes of Washington and Ponte Verdra, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hayes's daughter, Miss Ellen Laurie Klein, to Stephen David Klein. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Klein Jr. of Chicago.

A GREAT actress in a great performance this is Madeleine Renaud in Samuel Beckett's "Oh, Les Beaux Jours." The French production, directed by Roger Blin and featuring Olivier Hussenot as Willie, opened last night at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater as Le Treteau de Paris's third program, to run through May 3.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters will submit its controversial contract to its members within a week, Frank Fitzsimmons, the union's general vice president, said here today.

Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenue-based specialty store chain, and Harrods, London's prestige department store, have agreed to reciprocal credit arrangements for each other's customers, starting May 15. The plan is the first one between major stores in different countries.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 Villanova began the 76th annual Penn Relays today the way it opened the preceding four meets, by running to a comfortable victory in the distance medley relay at Franklin Field.

WASHINGTON, April 24 A Senator investigator contended today that contract "guarantees' on performance of the F-111 attack plane were unenforceable and that defens officials never had any intention of making the manufacturer comply strictly with requirements.

EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 25--Miss Arlene B. Rome and Dr. Peter Hoyos Ten Eyck were married here this morning. Chaplain Frank Hall of the Veterans Administration Hospital performed the interdenominational ceremony at the home of the bride's father, David Rome.

The question came from the father of two boys of grammar-school age as we sat at a picnic table in a crowded camper-trailer park near Sylva, 10 miles from the Cherokee entrance to Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

TO THE EDITOR: DICK CAVETT'S contribution to civilized talk on the late night shows has been widely noted. Recently Stokely Carmichael was Cavett's guest and I assume that, to the extent word got around, there were many people watching who would be susceptible to Carmichael's arguments. He proved to be a beguiling figure. His manner was almost bland. What he said was not, however, nor could it have been expected that it would be.

ORANJESTAD, Aruba, N.W.I.--We first "found" Aruba years ago, and loved the native Dutch ambiance and the line-up of canopied Venezuelan boats on which cargoes of mangoes, papayas and bananas were sold. Day after day, cloudless and hot, spent on miles of soft beaches.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)--President Nixon has ended a two-and-a-half year freeze on Presidential pardons and sentence commutations carried over from the previous Administration.

The Government got its first convictions yesterday in its attack on a truck hijacking ring in the metropolitan area allegedly dominated by the Mafia.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) --The Senate Judiciary Committee has been notified that Judge Harry A. Blackmun's colleagues on the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit enthusiastically support his nomination to the Supreme Court.

CAIRO, April 26 Two detachments of Egyptian commandos crossed the Suez Canal this afternoon and ambushed Israeli patrols, Cairo's military spokesman reported.
