New orders for machine tools an important indicator of how businessmen view the future were almost unchanged in March from those of the preceding month.

MOSCOW, April 26 Tens of thousands of Russians observed Easter today by strolling through cemeteries, where they ate picnic lunches, chatted as they placed the traditional hard-boiled eggs and cakes on graves, and enjoyed the warmth of Moscow's sunniest day of the spring.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 26 (AP) Luis Tiant, triggering a four-run Minnesota sixth inning today with a double and stolen base, stopped Detroit, 6-0, with a three-hitter.
LOS ANGELES, April 26 The New York Mets had a new worry today hepatitis, the liver ailment that already had appeared among the St. Louis Cardinals and Los Angeles Dodgers players.

ROME, April 26 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., using a brilliant assortment of drop shots and passing drives, defeated Julie Heldman of New York, 6-1, 6-3, today for the women's singles title of the Italian international tennis championships.

The Eastman Kodak Company realized an 8 per cent increase in first-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 5 per cent with both setting record levels for the period, according to the report released today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 26 The engagement of Miss Rosamond Hoyt Heroy to Lieut. Thomas Hayes Miller, U.S.N., who is with the Bureau of Naval Personnel in Washington and is a White House social aide, has been annouced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William Ward Heroy of Lloyd Harbor. Lieutenant Miller is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Maxwell Miller of Elizabethtown, Ky.

ONE cool night last November, Bob Cousy leaned against a wall in Madison Square Garden and said: "The Knicks are good, they have drive and power. But the kids today aren't as hungry as we were. The Knicks have something to prove, but after they've won, will they be fat cats?"

LONDON How familiar it all seems as the generals and the jingoes begin their pressure for American intervention in Cambodia. The situation, we read, gives us a great chance to win the Vietnam war if only we expand it. We must send arms and encourage the South Vietnamese Army to cross the border. The opportunity to clean out the Communist sanctuary is almost too good to be true. Etcetera.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Upwards of 100 Alaskan businessmen, bankers, politicians, lawyers and publishers, headed by Gov. Keith Miller, are descending on the capital this wek for two days of intensive lobbying on the trans-Alaska pipeline.

The hope of starting a college of optometry here in the fall of 1971 as part of the State University was voiced yesterday by Dr. Alden N. Haffner, executive director of the Optometric Center of New York.
NEWELL, W. Va., April 26 Joseph M. Wells, board chairman of the Homer Laughlin China Company, and a former United States senior golf champion, died Friday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

THE recent 10-board, quadruple-round match be tween masters from the Soviet Union and the rest of the world 40 games in all at Belgrade, Yugoslavia, was fiercely contested down to the final move on board No. 10.
KINGSTON, N.Y., April 26 Jay LaFevre of New Paltz, a former Republican Representative, died at the Kingston Hospital today. He was 76 years old.
LONDON, April 26 Woman with shopping bag (handing fare to conductor on bus on Fulham Road): "I should say it's about time. I've waited 25 minutes, mind you!"

An investigation into the crash of a Pilgrim Airplanes plane in Long Island Sound Feb. 10 with the loss of five persons may result in recommendations for tighter safety regulations on "air-taxis," a member of the National Transportation Safety Board said last week.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The Federal Communications Commission, making its first national survey of telephone service, has compiled voluminous new evidence that the New York City phone system is the worst in the country and getting worse.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) Sandy Alomar's eighth-inning double drove in Aurelio Rodriguez with an unearned run that decided the game today as the California Angels defeated the Washington Senators, 3-2.
MOUNT DESERT ISLAND, Me., April 26 Mrs. Clara Fargo Thomas, a painter and muralist, died today of cancer at her home, Fortune Rock. She was 79 years old.

After giving away baseball caps in their first promotional day of the season, the New York Yankees stuck a feather in their own caps yesterday by defeating the Oakland Athletics, 8-3, and climbing out of last place in the American League's Eastern Division.

ALBANY, April 26 (AP) Governor Rockefeller's office announced today that the Governor had signed three bills whose over-all effect will be to help New Yorkers whose property is condemned for public projects.
In the lambent air, on a neglected lane squeezed between the Belt Parkway and Gravesend Bay, Antonio Turco labored patiently yesterday to reclaim a corner of the city for spring.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 26 Dutch Bomb, an inexperienced 4-year-old bay gelding owned by the Hollandia Farms of St. James, L.I., captured the preliminary jumper championship in a jumpoff tonight at the 48th Boulder Brook horse show.

NEW HAVEN, April 26 The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., the chaplain of Yale University, said today that, if a riot developed during next weekend's pro-Black Panther rally here, his church would be open as a place for "disengagement."
The German-Hungarians defeated the New York Ukrainians, 3-2, in a German-American Soccer League game yesterday at Metropolitan Oval, Queens, and took a 2-point lead in the South Group standing.

Contrary to what it may have looked like on television yesterday, Horace Clarke and Bobby Murcer of the Yankees were not taking their signals from the stands in the eighth inning of the game against Oakland.
WASHINGTON, April 26 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange are arguing over how to measure whether a brokerage firm is insolvent and ought to be put out of business.
The Soviet Union's position as the world's second largest aluminum producer has been significantly strengthened with the inauguration of an unusual raw material source in Siberia.

YURIKO'S customary choreographic voice is quiet understatement, but occasionally she allows herself a more vigorous approach. On Saturday evening at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, she enclosed the middle section of her program with two repertory works that showed her in a spritely and charming mood.
The fundamental decision that confronts President Nixon in Cambodia is not whether to send further arms aid at this time but whether to pursue a military mirage.

A neighborhood in Fresno, Calif., held its breath as a cat sat on the crossarm of a utility pole. The Fresno Bee reports. The Fire Department said the pole was out of its jurisdiction, and so did the telephone company. The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it had to take care of its human customers before it could get to the cat.
George Wisniewski of the United Athletic Association won the 5,000-meter Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Association development run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

The executive board of the United Federation of Teachers voted unanimously last night to authorize a strike by the union's paraprofessional members if a "meaningful" contract offer was not made by the city school system.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 27 (Reuters) The Taipei City Council, in an expression of indignation, voted today to seek the extradition of two Taiwanese being held in New York after an attempt to assassinate Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo.

Paul D. Townsend, a well known marketing man, will be joining The New York Times as director of sales and marketing. He will be in charge of the newspaper's advertising and circulation sales, and its promotion.
WASHINGTON, April 27 In a four-page letter to House leaders, President Nixon reaffirmed today his opposition to an amendment to the voting rights bill that would give 18year-olds the right to vote.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday that beginning at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow four-fifths of the 25,000 patrolmen on the force would call in sick and refuse to report for duty.

WESTBURY, N.Y., April 27 The engagement of Miss Barbara H. Krech to Ronald C. Smeder, son of Rear Adm. Orvan R. Smeder, U.S.C.G., Assistant Chief of Staff for Ocean Sciences at Coast Guard Headquarters in Washington, and Mrs. Smeder of Chevy Chase, Md., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. William G. Krech.

One of the compensations for the underpaid position of choreographer is that you can shape your personal concerns into a public performance. Last night at the Gramercy Arts Theater on "Events: Part I" four choreographers presented seven dances of an introspective nature.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2 The New York Times again has been rated the best news paper in the country, according to a 1970 survey of newspape publishers made public by Edward L. Bernays, public relations consultant here.
MOSCOW, April 27 The Soviet Union announced a comprehensive legislative program today to conserve water and curb increasing pollution.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The formation of a study group to make detailed inquiries into corporations' performance in such areas as defense production and the environment was announced today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27 (AP) The United States command reported today the loss of an AC-130 gunship over southern Laos. Six crewmen were killed, four are missing and one was rescued, spokesmen here said.
Commercial broadcasting's first regularly scheduled allblack television news program will begin next month on WNEW-TV, Channel 5, here.

WASHINGTON The new production of Prokofiev's "Cinderella," seen here over the weekend at the Lisner Auditorium, is very possibly the most ambitious project to date of Washington's National Ballet. The company already has "Giselle," "La Sylphide" and "Coppelia," in its repertory, but this was the first time it had dared produce a completely new choreographic version of a full-evening ballet.
LONDON, April 27 On an April morning in 1965, a young Spanish shepherd found two bodies partly covered with earth and stones in a eucalyptus grove near a village beside the Portuguese border.

WASHINGTON The Agency for International Development is lending $23-million to Guatemala to finance part of a joint five-year Alliance for Progress rural development program. The program is designed to improve the economic well-being and social welfare of the small farmer of the Guatemalan highlands.
BOSTON, April 27 Release to the public Wednesday was ordered today for the transcript and judge's report in the Mary Jo Kopechne inquest.
BRAVE, Pa. (AP) Mrs. Rose Harker attempted to retrieve a lamb that had fallen into Dunkard Creek on her farm near this Greene County community in southwestern Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Dora Brahms, the interior designer whose touch had helped transform the Oval Room in the White House and Lyndhurst, the old Jay Gould mansion at Tarrytown, died last night of cancer in her apartment at 419 East 57th Street. She was 73 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 Martin Goldman, the managing editor of Look magazine, insisted today that he believed "absolutely" in the truth of an article which he cleared for publication that linked Mayor Joseph Alioto with Mafia hoodlums.

It began when a desk clerk handed Roy Chernock the keys to his hotel room, and the numbers read 711. Since Chernock spends most of his time dissecting statistics as a track coach, he knew it would not be any ordinary weekend in Philadelphia.

PARISMINA, Costa Rica Driven by unseasonable rain and flood waters from fishing for tarpon in the Parismina River, Al Ristori and I soon developed compromise excursions. Rising at 5 each morning, we ate a substantial breakfast in the tarpon lodge at Parismina operated by Carlos M. Barrantes of San Josh, and were on the water by 6 or shortly thereafter.
DALLAS, April 27 LingTemco-Vought, Inc., had a $6.5million operating loss in the first quarter, James J. Ling, chairman, told the annual meeting here today.

Since "Jibaro" is a familiar word for a native Puerto Rican, particularly a countryman, this translates loosely into what some deride as "hillbilly statehood" but what Mr. Ferre...
The last-minute victory, the heroic substitute, the drive that faltered these were the ingredients that contributed to the tightening of division lacrosse races last week.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 27 Sonny Dove pushed his 6-foot-8-inch frame around in the New York Nets' workout today at the Island Garden. He dominated the offensive and defensive boards and his jump shot was working well from both corners and from the key.
Nine-year-old Tito Ayala, of Nutley, N.J., has been named a grand award winner in the American Automobile Association's 26th national school traffic safety poster contest.

LONDON, April 27 They move in battered trailers, camping for a week or two in the muddy fields on the fringes of London. The men collect scrap metal. The women wash clothes and fry food outdoors while swarms of children play with the skinny dogs that follow each caravan.

The printers' union announced early today that it was lengthening its work-stopping chapel, or union, meetings at The New York Times in an effort to bring pressure on the four major papers here to increase their wage offer in stalemated contract talks.

Federico Mompou, the Catalan composer and pianist, performed in a program of his works Sunday night to help inaugurate the Lucrezia BoriAuditorium, a small recital hall in the Spanish Institute, at 684 Park Avenue.

A six-month investigation of an alleged 80-member ring of Latin-American pickpockets yielded its first jail term yesterday, when state Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin gave Chita Cruz, a 32-year-old Chilean, a sentence of seven and a half months.

An executive of a company that supplies private port security guards charged yesterday that the bistate Waterfront Commission and its investigator had "systematically and routinely undermined the osition of the port guard" in New York.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 27 President Francois Duvalier's armed militiamen staged a colorful demonstration of support for their chief today, celebrating the end of a mutiny in this country's small coast guard.
A SEXTET of young experts headed by Jeff Rubens remains the only unbeaten team in the New York Double Knockout Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy.
Clinton E. Frank, New York, is three years old now and doing well, thank you.
PARIS, April 27 Afternearly four years of negotiations, Indonesia and Western creditor countries have agreed upon a formula for repayment of her debts over the next 30 years.

LOS ANGELES, April 27 The annual stockholders meeting of the Union Oil Company here today was marked more by what did not happen than what did.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Senate passed a bill today that would increase disability compensation payments to two million veterans and their dependents by about $230million a year.

GLADSTONE, N.J., April 27 The United States Equestrian Team will compete in six major European horse shows starting with Wiesbaden, Germany, May 16 through 18, Bert de Nemethy, the coach, announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Presidential adviser, scolded tthe United States Chamber of Commerce today for its "shrill opposition" to the Nixon Administration's welfare reform legislation.

LONDON Very young children learn aggressive behavior from short periods of observing behavior by adults, whether actually or on film, according to scientific studies at the Stanford University School of Medicine.
PONTLAC, Mich. (AP) John Ponushis, an avid golfer, was ordered at gunpoint to drop his club.

LONDON, April 27 The British Government faces difficult financial decisions on two projects crucial to the future of the British aircraft industry the British Aircraft Corporation's proposed wide-body airliner, the B.A.C. 3-11, and the advanced jet engine of Rolls-Royce, Ltd.

NEW HAVEN, April 27 Students at the Yale University Law School voted today against suspending classes while the campus is engulfed in debate about the Black Panther trial here. In a second vote, however, the students approved giving professors and students a choice of whether to continue academic work now.

Harding F. Bancroft, executive vice president of The New York Times, said yesterday he believed that "any incursion against freedom of the press" would lead to ever larger incursions until eventually "the concept of freedom of the press is irrevocably damaged or lost."

Between a quarter and half a million dollars worth of jewelry will be auctioned off at bargain prices on Monday when the Association for the Help of Retarded Children holds a benefit sale at Cartier, Inc.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell to their lowest level in more than two years yesterday as the list continued to decline in slow trading.

Thieves broke into the office of Dr. George Roberts, a physician, at 79 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, during the weekend, and stole a painting by Norman Rockwell, done for a Saturday Evening Post cover in the nineteen-twenties.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The United States surplus of export over imports, which had risen steeply in February, fell back in March, the commerce department reported today.

Thirteen persons, including two faculty members, were arrested at Hunter College yesterday during a day of hit-andrun disturbances by bands of dissident students. The arrests followed the announcement earlier by Mrs. Jacqueline G. Wexler, president of the college, that seven students had been suspended for the rest of the spring term and that she would no longer tolerate "violence, force and bully tactics."

A Complaint filed two years ago on behalf of two members of the Black Panther party who were among those beaten in the Brooklyn Criminal Courts Building by a group of whites that included off-duty and outof-uniform policemen has been dismissed as "unsubstantiated."
Tony Curtis's conviction for marijuana possession in London yesterday has prompted immediate cancellation of his antismoking spots for the American Cancer Society by national and local television.

AS far as the fashion establishment is concerned, there is no hemline hassle. The mini, a definition that includes anything above the knee, is out; the midi, an equally elastic definition that descends from the knee to the ankle, is in.
THE little guy who has suffered as much as any body in the current bear market is perhaps more disenchanted than ever before with Wall Street.
An off-duty patrolman was beaten and slashed with knives and a machete by three men in Brooklyn early yesterday but managed to wound two suspects.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. April 27 Miss Angie Brooks of Liberia, president of the 24th General Assembly, was married today to Isaac Randolph, an educator. She kept a long-standing promise to "let her friends at United Nations know" right away.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, President Nixon's science adviser, said today that cuts in Federal funds for research might turn the United States into a second-class nation in some scientific fields.
Penn Central services were delayed yesterday by three derailments.

MILWAUKEE, April 27 Gov. Warren P. Knowles said today that Capt. James A. Lovell Jr., the astronaut, had decided not to run for the United States Senate against Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin yesterday rejected a call for a state investigation of charges of police corruption after presiding at the first meeting of a special committee appointed by Mayor Lindsay to investigate the allegations.

MOSCOW, April 27 The Soviet Union expressed opposition today to the convening of any international conference to eal with the crisis in Cambodia.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 (AP) Joe Decker, a rookie, scattered six hits before Hank Aguirre and Phil Regan relieved him in the ninth inning tonight as the Chicago Cubs ran their winning streak to 11 games with a 1-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
WASHINGTON, April 27 In this radio commercial being used in the termite belt this spring two termites are overheard discussing the dumbness of the man whose floor they are eating.

ATLANTA, April 27 The International Business Machines Corporation is feeling some effects of the economic slowdown, Thomas J. Watson Jr., Chairman, told 1,100 stockholders at the annual meeting in the Regency Hyatt House here today.

WASHINGTTON, April 27 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would hold public hearings shortly to determine whether the National Association of Securities Dealers is exceeding its authority in refusing to let its members join with nonmembers in distributions of securities.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Four Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee have asked for more detailed disclosure of the financial affairs of Judge Harry A. Blackmun, President Nixon's latest Supreme Court nominee.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Senate passed and sent to President Nixon today a bill extending the Interior Department's power to review federally licensed construction projects affecting the Hudson River.
SEATTLE, April 27 A crowd of antiwar demonstrators attempted today to disrupt the annual meeting of the Boeing Comnany here.

Operating on the theory that if life really begins at 40 that perhaps it ought to start with a new format, Mike Sorrentino, the jockey from Baldwin Harbor, L.I., has quietly announced his retirement.

The Correspondents Fund which holds title to the 11-story building at 54 West 40th Street that houses the Overseas Press Club, served an exiction petition on both the club and 35 of its tenants yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 27 (UPI) An anonymous note wrapped around an arrow and dropped in a newspaper's mail slot today said that Louisiana's Capitol was dynamited last night in retaliation for the killing of three Negroes by the police.

CHICAGO, April 27 Three reporters were subpoenaed here today to appear as witnesses for the prosecution in the Federal trial of 15 persons charged with destroying Selective Service records in Chicago last May.

MOSCOW, April 27 A history teacher in Gorki, a Volga River city, and three students have been reported sentenced to confinement in a labor camp for distributing a pamphlet against alleged Stalinist trends in Soviet life.

CHICAGO, April 27 The directors of Commonwealth Edison faced a new group of stockholders today pollution fighters who had bought stock so they could attend the annual shareholders' meeting and demand a faster clean-up by Chicago's No. 1 air polluter.

The Los Angeles Lakers evened the score in the National Basketball Association playoffs last night by beating the New York Knickerbockers, 105-103, in the second game of the four-of-seven final round at Madison Square Garden.

PARIS Although Paris has scores of fine restaurants (and please don't labor the point that the finest French restaurants are in the provinces), a few of the most interesting are not necessarily French.
LA TRINITE SUR MER, France, April 27 (Reuters) France's first challenger for the America's Cup, The France, underwent first sea trials today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) A Navy court repprimanded and ordered a bad conduct discharge today for Seaman Apprentice Roger Lee Priest, who has been convicted of "promoting disloyalty and disaffection" through his antiwar newsletter, Om.

MIAMI, April 27 (UPI) Three Government sales of mortgage-backed securities last week brought to $25.5-million the total sales volume under the new program to aid residential financing, an official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development Said today.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 27 (AP) Sam McDowell worked out of several jams and hurled the Cleveland Indians to a 5-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

The Southern Pacific Company, the holding company that controls the Southern Pacific Railroad, announced yesterday that its net income in the first quarter dropped in comparison with the corresponding period last year.

Stock prices cracked sharply yesterday as the DowJones industrial average, smashing through a "support" zone as though it were tissue paper, plunged 12.14 points to 735.15. This marked the lowest closing level for the market's most closely watched indicator since the Friday afternoon of President Kennedy's assassination on Nov. 22, 1963. The Kennedy death had brought on near-panic selling, with the Dow on that fateful day tumbling 21.16 points to 711.49.
Additional closed hearings into the possible "purchase" of state judgeships are expected next month, according to staff members of the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) Assistant Attorrney General Jerris Leonard indicated today that the Government would soon propose that new public housing projects be built in the suburbs rather than in the slums.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Justice William O. Douglas disqualified himself today from participating in rulings on obscenity appeals involving the film "I Am Curious (Yellow)" and a libel suit against Look magazine.
ROME, April 27 (UPI) Ilie Nastase of Rumania became the first East European to win the Italian tennis championship today when he beat Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia in the final, 6-3, 1-6, 6-3, 8-6.

Michael Keating, WCBS-TV's on-air editorial spokesman, has been named director of news for the Columbia Broadcasting System-owned station, it was announced yesterday by Alan P. Sloan, its vice president and general manager.
Robert M. Morgenthau resigned his $42,500-a-year post as a Deputy Mayor yesterday and Mayor Lindsay, parceling out the duties elsewhere, quickly abolished the post.
A doctor reported yesterday finding that some disorders of the nervous system, thought to be congenital, may be caused by viral infections in the mother during pregnancy.
Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, minister of the Marble Collegiate Church, author and lecturer, was honored last night by more than 1,500 persons for his efforts in the field of mental health.

LONDON (UPI) When burglars invaded the home of Miss Jennie Arnold, 98 years old, she said she did not mind a bit.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 Gypsy Rose Lee, the strip tease artist, actress and author, died of cancer last night at U.C.L.A. Medical Center. She was 56 years old.

Profits of the New York Telephone Company for the first quarter of 1970 fell to $41,484,000, or 34 cents a share, from $49,362,000, equal to 47 cents a share, in the like period last year, the Bell System affiliate announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 Dr. Norman Topping, president of the University of Southern California for the last 12 years, has announced his retirement.

A sub-contractor at the building under construction at 888 Seventh Avenue near 56th Street was served yesterday with a show cause order obtained by the city's Department of Air Resources to stop the spraying of asbestos as an insulating material.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 27 Dr. Aaron Hardy Ulm, a former New York urologist and lawyer, died of a heart attack while on vacation here Saturday night. He was 57 years old.
MIAMI, April 27 Cuba announced today that all members of an exile guerrilla group that landed in Eastern Cuba on April 17 had been either killed or captured.

The United States Government granted political asylum yesterday to a 25-year-old Latvian waitress who took an overdose of barbiturates 18 days ago to get off a Soviet trawler sailing 100 miles off New York.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 (UPI) Jacques Plante will be back in the St. Louis goat tomorrow night when the Blues play the Pittsburgh Penguins in the fifth game of their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff.
Prices on the London stock market resumed a downward trend yesterday as renewed selling reversed initial gains. Key market indexes closed at lows for the year.
After an intensive search, Mayor Lindsay has asked Dr. Peter Rogatz to head the quasiindependent corporation that will assume control of the city's 18 public hospitals on July 1.

TRENTON, April 27 Warning that drug abuse in New Jersey had reached "crisis proportions" and was "out of control," Gov. William T. Cahill urged the Legislature today to lessen the criminal penalties and in some cases do away with them altogether for the simple possession of a small quantity of marijuana.

WASHINGTON, April 27 President Nixon has moved to assume personal command of the fight to expand the Safeguard missile defense system by issuing a stern warning to Republican Congressional leaders that the United States is in danger of becoming militarily inferior to the Soviet Union.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 27 Mr. and Mrs. Julius Manger Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Bell Manger, to John Harrison Bertles, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bertles of Greenwich and Tuckerstown, Bermuda.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 27 (AP) A strike by printers pressmen and mailers against The Daily Record of Morris County has ended and the paper will resume publication tomorrow after two weeks' suspension.

The police raided a basement club at 517 West 134th Street last night and seized more than 40 homemade bombs. Nineteen teen-agers, who, the police said, were making the bombs in productionline fashion for use in a gang war, were taken into custody.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The New York Stock Exchange, within the last two weeks, has renewed its request to the Federal Reserve Board for a reduction in stock-margin requirements. The board has not responded to the latest approach.
VIENNA, April 27 American and Soviet disarmament negotiators met for an hour and a quarter here today, their fourth working session since the strategic arms limitation talks resumed 10 days ago.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Nixon Administration encountered nearly unanimous bipartisan opposition in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to the extension of military aid to Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Treasury bill rates advanced sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

Colombia's dilemma after the surprisingly powerful Presidential bid of General Rojas Pinilla last week is a familiar one for developing countries. President Lleras Restrepo's administration, which has laid the necessary foundations for sound economic development and social reform, has been a model in the Alliance for Progress.

Governor Rockefeller's misbegotten scheme for building a six-lane expressway along the Hudson River north of Tarrytown has received another rebuff in a ruling of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit that has implications for conservation far beyond the shores of the Hudson.
The musicians' strike against the New York City Ballet, now in its eighth day, was characterized yesterday as "hopeless" by I. Philip Sipser, lawyer for the orchestra's bargaining committee.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the constitutionality of the District of Columbia's antiabortion statute, which is similar to the abortion laws in effect in most states.

Consolidated earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in the first quarter fell to $85.6-million or $1.24 a share, from the year-earlier $94-million, or $1.33 a share on fewer shares, the company reported yesterday from Chicago.

Claude Savard pianist, and Suzanne Shulman, flutist, two young performers from Canada, made their New York debuts last night in a concert presented by Carnegie Hall-Jeunesses Musicales at Carnegie Recital Hall.
