A State Supreme Court jury here recommended life sentences yesterday afternoon for two men whom they had earlier found guilty of murdering a policeman. The jury had been given the choice of recommending life imprisonment or the death penalty.

WHITEVILLE, N.C. The burgundy Oldsmobile bumps along the back highways of the Carolinas, trailing a cloud of dust and passing paint-flecked roadside signs nailed to the trees along the tobacco fields.
Sam Puro, president of the Purofied Down Products Corporation of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home, 42 Hawthorne Lane, Great Neck, L.I. He was 58 years old.
Michelle Jackson sidestepped an overflowing garbage can and raced down the block after the lean, blond young man. "Hey, Larry, hey, Larry!" she called. "Hey, Larry!"

WASHINGTON, April 27 James E. Allen Jr., United States Commissioner of Education, took a stand today for desegregation that appeared to go substantially beyond that of President Nixon and his Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
TEL AVIV, April 27 (Reuters) Israelitennis players called on the Lawn Tennis Association today to go through with the Davis Cup match against Rhodesia.

LOS ANGELES, April 27 (UPI) Florabel Muir, a reporter and columnist for The New York Daily News, who covered both Hollywood celebrities and New York gangsters during her career, died of a heart attack today. She was 80 years old.
The Board of Education has told Ocean Hill-Brownsville school officials to adhere to legal procedures in taking any action against teachers in the Brooklyn demonstration district.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 Hepatitis shots were ruled out at least temporarily for the New York Mets today after the team received encouraging word on the condition of Jerry Grote.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 27 TThree operators of the U.F.O Coffee Housse, one of the firs antiwar coffee houses that catered to G.I's, were found guilty here today of operating and maintaining a public nuisance.

COLETTE, the French writer who created such de lectable girls as Claudine and Gigi and Mitsou, and who was responsible for the casting of the then unknown Audrey Hepburn in the role of Gigi for the stage (the movie came much later), also produced a girl of her own.
Reports That grain output in Europe may not come up to early estimates sparked buying of wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) Ed Brinkman's tworun single tied the game and John O'Donoghue's throwing error let in the deciding run in the 10th inning tonight as the Washington Senators rallied for a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

MOSCOW, April 27 (UPI) The Soviet Union announced today that it sucessfully placed eight unmanned satellites into orbit around the earth with a single rocket booster on Saturday, and that all were reported functioning "normally."
MOSCOW (UPI) The country girls who went to Fergana to work in the silk weaving mill found the advantages of their high wages outweighed by terror on the streets, a Soviet newspaper reportd.

John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, said at the annual meeting yesterday that the company expected profits during the remainder of the year to be "considerably better" than in the first quarter, when earnings fell from 53 cents to 27 cents a share.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 27 South Vietnam officially called on the Cambodians today to preserve the lives and property of the Vietnamese minority and was told that Cambodia would take steps "to stop all acts that are contrary to the principles of justice and humanity."

WASHINGTON, April 27 The manager of WETA-TV, Washington's educational television station, told a House communications subcommittee today that he had had three brief telephone conversations with Ford Foundation officials before he decided to discharge William Woestendiek, a news editor.
Favorable results have been reported from Stockholm for a method, developed by the Cabot Corporation of Boston, of burning oil spills at sea.

Several years ago George Furth wrote a straight play, or rather eleven mini-plays, about marriage, and Kim Stanley was going to play all the wives. Astoundingly altered, the Furth work is now the new Harold PrinceStephen Sondheim hit musical, "Company," starring Dean Jones as the best friend in all those marriages.

Earl Caldwell, a reporter for The New York Times, and Don Hogan Charles, a Times photographer, are among the eight journalists named to receive the 1970 Russwurm Awards, presented each year by the New York Urban League.
All five floors of Wildenstein's art gallery will be open the night of May 6 as the New York Infirmary sponsors a benefit there.

The commercial paper market surged to a record for the third consecutive month during March, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. But the figures showed that the rate of climb was markedly lower than has been characteristic recently.

JOHN KORTY'S "riverrun" is an ode to the simple life as it is lived by Sarah and Dan, two Berkeley dropouts who have elected to return to the soil on an immensely photogenic sheep ranch two hours outside San Francisco.

DETROIT, April 27 The nation's two largest automobile makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, announced today that their profits slumped sharply in the first three months of this year.

The city's uniformed patrolmen are threatening to hold up the city at midnight tonight with a so-called "job action" overwhelmingly voted by members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. This unconscionable pressure tactic on the part of supposed guardians of the law stems from an admittedly complicated contract dispute; it is particularly inexcusable...
PNONPENH, April 27 (AP) A United States air Force C-130 arrived today and unloaded ases that American officials said contained communications equipment for the United states Embassy.

THERE have been so many dazzling moments for the Knicks throughout this season that their bemused fol lowers can see only to the end of the current rainbow. Hopefully, it will be the first basketball championship ever won by the New Yorkers in their long and not always glorious history. They can supply a fitting climax to a spectacular year by polishing off the Los Angeles Lakers in the final playoff series now in progress.
The freeze quietly imposed or city jobs in February affects every agency except the Sanitation Department, a spokes man for Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.
James Elson, a television producer and director, died of cancer Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 45 years old and lived at 137 East 66th Street.
BOSTON, April 27 (AP) Reggie Smith completed a perfect day at bat today by leading off the eighth inning with a home run, lifting the Boston Red Sox to a 4-3 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

LIBERTY CORNER, N.J., April 27 Five healthy and remarkably composed quintuplets, wrapped in blankets and strapped into car seats, came home today by ambulance under police escort with their parents, Mr. and Mrs. William G. Kienast.

WASHINGTON, April 27 A team of physicists at the University of California in Berkeley reported today the synthesis of a new element and proposed that it be named hahnium in honor of Otto Hahn, the late German physicist.
Lawyers for 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places protested yesterday against the use against them of dynamite seized at the home of a Brooklyn woman not indicted with them.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 27 Monticello Raceway will open its 13th season of harness racing Thursday night with win, place, show, daily double and perfecta betting in various denominations. An innovation will be the same availability of $3 doubles and perfectas, which will replace the more conventional $2 tickets.

WASHINGTON, April 27 William T. Pecora, director of the Geological Survey, told about 120 prominent Alaskans today that his agency was in "unanimous agreement" that it was unsafe to bury a hot-oil pipeline in the permafrost for 90 to 95 per cent of the 800 miles from the Arctic North Slope to Valdez.

BERLIN, April 27 Faced with serious economic troubles and a farming crisis, East Germany called on all able-bodied men and women throughout the country over the weekend to put in extra work in day and night shifts.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 27 (UPI) The leader in Colombia's presidential election, Misael Pastrana Borrero, set up study groups today to draft a general plan for the country for the next four years.

BALTIMORE, April 27 A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit rejected today a plea by attorneys for H. Rap Brown that the black militant's long-delayed trial in a Maryland court be removed to the jurisdiction of the Federal court here.
Donato Paduano of Montreal, will fight Marcel Cerdan Jr. in Madison Square Garden on May 11, says the only worry he has in meeting the undefeated Frenchman is "eating too much."

ARISTOPHANES' "Ecclesiazusae" probably was the world's first play about women's liberation. First performed in Athens in 392 B.C., it reopened last night under the title "The Republic" at the Free Store Theater, the scene of the great "Che" bust.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 George Lewis, the California Derby winner, will compete in the Derby Trial tomorrow. And he will be favored against 10 rivals. For a time it was doubtful that the colt, owned by Alan Magerman, would start, because of a cough, but this morning his trainer, Buster Millerick, reported that the cough had gone and that his horse was ready.
Short-term interest rates shot up yesterday to their highest levels since mid-February amid a resurgence of the belief that inflation will not be halted.
Prices on most foreign stock markets turned sharply downward yesterday in reaction to the previous day's slide on Wall Street.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 28 (AP) Frank Reaume, a 22year-old substitute school teacher, from Ypsilanti, Mich., eased Dr. Ed Updegraff of Tucson, Ariz., out of the North and South amateur golf tournament today, with a 1-up second-round victory.

WASHINGTON, April 28 House liberals who oppose various portions of the military budget suffered a setback today when the Rules Committee turned down their request for increased time to debate the defense authorization bill.

WASHINGTON, April 28 Two specialists in missile strategy argued today that the projected deployment of new missile systems would seriously reduce changes of an agreement with the Soviet Union to curb the arms race.
Spencer Haywood, the Denver rookie who led the American Basketball Association in scoring and rebounding this season, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 28 Three operators of an antiwar coffeehouse that catered to soldiers were each sentenced to six years in prison today after their conviction yesterday on charges of operating a public nuisance.

ELLICOTT CITY, Md., April 28 Judge James Macgill today ordered the trial of H. Rap Brown resumed here at 10 A.M. next Monday, and aides in the Howard County Circuit Court said the black militant leader must be present then or forfeit $10,000 bail bond.
SHARON, Conn., April 28 Carman J. Cage, a retired operations supervisor for the Western Union Telegraph Company in New York, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.
A leading Soviet scientist said here yesterday that the time was fovorable for the Soviet Union and the United States to negotiate an agreement for cooperation in space exploration.
Rod McKuen was ata Philharmonic Hall last night his long, Tangy frame slumped over a high stool, singing in a hoarse, worn voice, croaking out his poems.

IF Machiavelli were alive today and engaged in auto racing politics, he would have to paint a rookie stripe on his bumper. He'd be dazzled by the Borgia-Medici machinations in the routine councils of the Autmomobile competition Committee for the United States, let alone something ...

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 28 Vice President Agnew said here today that the Nixon Administration would stay out of what is shaping up as an explosive Republican primary battle for a Senate seat from Florida.
TAKE your pick," said Red Holzman, his voice flat and his face an unemotional mask. "It could have been good defense by them or bad shooting by us."

WASHINGTON, April 28 About twice each week, food manufacturers in the United States order products off the market for safety reasons, sometimes because of deadly contamination, Government reports indicate.

Three persons, only one of them a student at the school, were arrested at Hunter College yesterday as school administrators continued a hard line taken on Monday by Hunter's president, Mrs. Jacqueline G. Wexler.

HONG KONG, April 28 (reuters) North Vietnam made public today the names of 129 Vietnamese and Chinese who were allegedly massacred in Prasault, in a Svayrieng Province, April 9 by Cambodian troops on Government orders.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The State Department said today that anti-American demonstrations in Stockholm yesterday were "insulting and uncalled for" and a spokesman indicated that some diplomatic action might be taken.

WASHINGTON, April 28 Keith Miller, the Republican Governor of Alaska, announced here today that he had decided to ask the Alaskan Legislature to appropriate the money to build a 390-mile gravel road from the Yukon River to Prudhoe Bay on the Arctic North Slope.

TEL AVIV, April 28 Two Sukhoi-7 fighter-bombers were reported shot down today by Israeli interceptors when the Egyptian Air Force launched synchronized low-flying attacks on Israeli forces in the occupied Sinai Peninsula.

BFRLIN, April 28 The East German Government increased tolls on West Berlin's highway and canal access routes about 30 per cent today on the day of a four-power conference on improving the situation of the city.

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (UPI) Frank St. Marseille scored three goals and Jacques Plante shut out the Pittsburgh Penquins tonight as the St. Louis Blues scored a 5-0 victory in the Stanley Cup semifinal series.

NEW EGYPT, N.J., April 28 Looking overweight, Lucky Creed, a 6-year-old Australian stallion, nevertheless proved he was in top shape by pacing a mile here today in 2 minutes 1 4-5 seconds, an incredible time for a workout.

MONTREAL, April 28 In January, 1968, three months after he had quit the Liberal party and before he had founded the separatist Quebec party, Rene Levesque contemplated a modest timetable for political success.

SOME lived in hospitals where, even if anyone cared, no one had the time to help them with their appearance. Others simply felt they weren't worth bothering about. One was so sure she was ugly that, when asked to look in a mirror, she burst into tears.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The Patricia and the Julie, Presidential yachts named after President Nixon's two daughters, were decommissioned today while Tricia, Mr. Nixon's elder daughter, watched.
HOLLYWOOD, April 28 (AP) Ed Begley, the character actor who won an Academy Award for his portrayal of a Southern political boss in "Sweet Bird of Youth," died tonight. He was 69 years old.

BOSTON, April 28 (UPI) A Harvard microbiologist who won the 1970 Eli Lilly award for being the first to isolate a pure gene said tonight that he was turning the $1,000 honorarium over to the Black Panther party.
In line with prices received at the Government's auction in Washington, silver futures prices on the Commodity Exchange here, dropped yesterday.
TRIESTE, Italy, April 27 The Italians, Austrians and Yugoslavs who live within a 250-mile are west, north and east of this Adriatic seaport are among the friendliest neighbors in Europe.

The Norfolk Western Rail way reported yesterday that its consolidated net, income in the first quarter had dropped sharply to $9.5-million, or 88 cents a share, from $22-million, or $2.03 a share, in the similar period last year.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The Columbia Broadcasting System said today that its forthcoming television interview with former President Johnson had had material cut out, at Mr. Johnson's request, on the ground of national security.
Dozens of palm trees will help transform the Pierre ballroom into a "South Seas Island paradise" Tuesday when about 600 persons gather for the 17th annual Feather Ball.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday postponed for 72 hours until 12:01 A.M. Saturday a threatened work stoppage by 20,000 of the city's 25,000 patrolmen.

TRENTON, April 28 A controversial New Jersey law authorizing the busing of parochial and private school students at public expense was declared unconstitutional today by State Superior Court Judge Joseph A. Stamler.
At 3 P.M. yesterday, as the stock market plunged to its lowest level in nearly six and a half years, a retired Bronx plumber named Silvio Volpe sat in a brokerage board room and gave his assesment:

WASHINGTON, April 28 Brig. Gen. George Arthur Lincoln, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lincoln of Washington and Evergreen, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce LeFevre Lincoln, to Keith Arthur Conrey. He is the son of Prof. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Conrey of Ann Arbor, Mich.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that draft calls this year may be reduced to as low as 150,000 men about 100,000 under original plans because of troop withdrawals from Vietnam. This is the lowest estimate yet made.
WASHINGTON, April 28 A Democratic party reform commission warned today in its final report that the only alternative to broader citizen participation in politics was "the antipolitics of the street."
The two Taiwanese suspects in the attempted slaying of Chiang Kai-shek's son last Friday were ordered held in high bail yesterday by Criminal Court Judge Dennis Edwards Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 28 An Army lawyer warned today that public disclosure of evidence in a two-year-old murder case connecting the United States Special Forces, the Green Berets, to a Cambodian sect once dedicated to the overthrow of Prince Norodom Sihanouk would threaten American security.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 John Emmet Donnelly Jr., an architectural sculptor, died yesterday at Princeton Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at Fair Acres in Freehold.

Charging the Transit Authority and its Police department with racial discrimination, an organization representing 900 black transit policemen yesterday threatened mass sick calls by its members if the authority failed to negotiate the issue.

A detective testified yesterday that a "fully loaded" .38caliber revolver, several kinds of ammunition, two books about explosives and homemade bombs, and five bottles of liquid, three with names of chemicals on them and two unlabeled, were seized at the apartment of one of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places.

Texaco, Inc., held an oldfashioned annual meeting yesterday where the only people with long hairs were women and the protesters were stockholders who wanted to know why the dividend had not been raised.

PETER LEVENTRITT'S team, including Sam Stayman, Stan Turecki, Sol Rubinow, Jacqui Mitchell and Dorothy Hayden, won its semifinal match Monday night in the New York Double Knockout Championship. They will oppose Jeff Ruben's unbeaten squad in the final and if Leventritt wins this, a playoff will be required to decide the title.

WASHINGTON, April 28 When President Nixon refused Israel's request for more Phantom fighter bombers recently, he did so in the hope that the Soviet Union would also limit its military aid to the Arab states and thus help bring stability to the Middle East. That, however, is not the way things are going.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28 Members of at least one of the groups planning to join the May 1 Black Panther demonstration in New Haven have been purchasing guns in Boston-area stores in recent weeks, despite their public disavowals of any violent intention.
PARIS, April 27 Opponents of the French Government have been criticizing France's continuing military intervention in Chad, the central African state that they sometimes call "France's Vietnam."

Senator Charles E. Goodell told a group of older persons yesterday at a tea opening Senior Citizens Month that all the expenditures authorized by Congress under the Older Americans Act from its inception in 1965 would finance the war in Vietnam for less than two days.

In this period of labor-management turbulence, any note of rationality on the collective bargaining front is cheering. That is especially true when it takes the form of long-term agreements reached five months before the deadline in an industry whose labor relations were once notorious for violence and discord.

CHRUI CHANGWAR, Cambodia, April 28 The mayor of Pnompenh crossed the Tonle Sap River today to this village to show an official of the South Vietnamese Foreign Ministry how Cambodia treats members of her Vietnamese minority.

WASHINGTON, April 28 Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas notified a House investigation panel today that he had retained Simon H. Rifkind, a New York lawyer and former Federal judge, to represent him on possible impeachment charges.

Robert L. Kaufman has been appointed president and general partner of the Mollie Parnis Boutique division, a new branch of Parnis-Livingston, Inc., of which Miss Parnis is president. He formerly was vice president of Jerry Silverman, Inc., a wholesale dress firm.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange took another beating yesterday in stepped-up volume.

John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said yesterday that a New York Times editorial suggesting that the sanitationmen were engaging in a work slowdown was "a filthy liefilthier than the streets of New York."
IT is reasonable to doubt whether Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill's "Mahagonny" is a musical at all. But if it is a musical, it leaves every other musical in town looking sick, green and trivial.
BEVERLY, Mass, April 28 Frederick J. Bradlee, former financial consultant to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, died today of an aortal aneurism. He was 77 years old.

Interest rates on several, types of fixed-income securities Federal agency notes, tax-exempt notes and bonds and corporate bonds moved upward yesterday as the credit markets sought to get their bearings.

MADRID, Spain, April 28 (Reuters) Lieut. Gen. Carlos Asensio Cabanillas, one of the Spanish Army officers involved with Generalissimo Francisco Franco from the start of the Spanish Civil War, died here last night at the age of 73.
"It was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair, We had everything before us, we had nothing before us . . ." Charles Dickens, "A Tale of Two Cities."

WASHINGTON, April 28 Judge Harry A. Blackmun received a strong endorsement today from the American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary, on the eve of the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearings on his Supreme Court nomination.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 28 Young militants turned the annual meeting of Honeywell, Inc., today into an unruly shouting match that lasted only 14 minutes. At that point, James H. Binger, chairman, who had been frustrated in his attempt to conduct the meeting, declared it adjourned.

JERUSALEM, April 28 The Coptic patriarchate lodged a complaint in the Israeli Suprem High Court today demanding that the Ethiopian Orthodox patriarchate return the keys to a passage in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

An "Emergency Citizens' Task Force" of Alaskans, headed by Governor Keith Miller, has been in Washington this week pressing for immediate permits to get on with the proposed oil pipeline from the North Slope. The eagerness of these citizens, especially contractors who have invested time, money and equipment, is understandable. But in no way does their plight release Secretary of the Interior Hickel from the obligation to act with extreme caution.
Darrell Dess, a guard, was retired by the New York Giants yesterday. The club said it was making room for some promising youngsters for next year.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 Lance Brisson, one of the authors of the Look magazine article that linked Mayor Joseph L. Alioto with Mafia hoodlums, refused today to identify sources of information.
A 33-year-old policeman mugged early Monday morning while checking a tire on his auto in a Brooklyn service station was reported in critical condition yesterday in Kings County Hospital.

Her hands quivering and her voice shaking, a tall, blond woman charged yesterday that she had been dismissed last November by the Allstate Insurance Company because it discriminated against women employes.

WASHINGTON, April 28 President Nixon, responding to pressure from the academic community, has increased his request for funds for university study programs in the language, history and culture of countries that are outside Western Europe but nevertheless crucial to modern American diplomacy.

NEW HAVEN, April 28 National Guard units have been ordered to stand by here Friday for deployment in the event of disorder at the massive rally being organized in support of eight Black Panthers facing murder and kidnapping trials.
DETROIT, April 28 General Motors said today that its new entry into the subcompact car field would be named the Vega 2300.
George Harrison of the Beatles said yesterday that as far as he is concerned there is every prospect that the singing group would get together again eventually.

Civil liberties are held in contempt by extremists of tight and left alike. Convinced of their own righteousness, the dogmatists at both ends of the political spectrum characteristically believe in freedom for themselves but rarely for those who reject their ideological discipline. This narrowly restrictive view of freedom is normally accompanied by a self-indulgent approach to violence as an appropriate terror weapon against the ideological enemy.
MOSCOW, April 28 Anastas I. Mikoyan, a leading official for more than 40 years, has published some details concerning the power struggle between Stalin and Trotsky in the first years of Soviet rule.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28 (AP) The United States command announced today the loss of five aircraft in which 15 Americans died and six were injured, and an accidental bombing by American planes that killed 10 South Vietnamese militiamen and wounded 20 others.
The Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater, usually found in Tulsa, Okla., Baalbek, Lebanon or Paris, is now on 55th Street, where it opened the City Center's "American Dance Season" last night.
Mrs. Albert D. Lasker has been elected president of the United Cerebral Palsy Research and Education Foundation, the organization's executive committee announced yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 28 (UPI) Ilmari Kianto, writer, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 96 years old, and lived in Suomussalmi, in northeastern Finland.
WELL, this lost weekend in Los Angeles the Dodgers scored three runs in three games and still took two from the Mets. Cleon Jones, Tommie Agee and Joe Foy were benched.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The House Armed Services Committee says it does not want any more Pentagon research funds going to colleges and universities where lecturers are heckled and "other forms of disruption" take place.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 28 Miss Hope Glendon Harron, a magna cum laude graduate of Lawrence University, and David K. Glidden, who was graduated summa cum laude from Lawrence plan to be married this November.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla. Apr. 38 (AP) Altitude chamber tests of the two spacecrafts for the Apollo 14 moon mission have been delayed about a month pending an investigation of the flight of Apollo 13.
The New York Stock Exchange was faced yesterday with a complaint by an Orthodox Jew that the exchange had refused to permit him to wear a yarmulke at work.
Joseph Monserrat, the president of the Board of Education, said last night that he was hopeful that a strike by paraprofessional school employes, threatened for next month, could be averted.

TOKYO, April 28 Radical students with helmets and bamboo poles took to the streets here tonight in an annual rite known as Okinawa Day. But the level of violence was much lower than last year, when the students briefly occupied a major railroad station as well as an important downtown intersection.
A big (and therefore, one would think, impersonal, conglomerate is going to offer its TV commercial tune to people who want to get something off their chests.

NAGOYA, April 28 (AP) Haruo Yasuda of Japan, playing in a drizzle, shattered the course record with an eightunder-par 62 today to extend his lead to eight strokes after three days of play in the $52,777 Chunichi Crowns golf tournament.

An 11-month controversy over the management of a South Bronx antipoverty program that led to a virtual halt in its activities and created racial friction throughout the area, has been settle, community leaders said yesterday.

Robert L. Koerner, assistant professor of business law at Fordham University, was found dead in his home, 60 west 190th Street, the Bronx, Saturday. He had been on medical leave for the last year, and apparently died of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The House Banking Committee approved today legislation for an increase of almost $2-billion in contributions by the United States to the capital of international financial institutions.

A group of top Wall Street officials will meet with several Cabinet members and leading economic officials of the Administration in Washington this morning to discuss the current problems of Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The House Commerce subcommittee gave final approval today to the mutual fund bill and, in the process, took out virtually every provision it had inserted earlier that would have given the Government any authority to restrict the charges that fund managers impose on investors.
PITTSBURGH, April 28 (UPI) Demonstrators staged a noisy protest at the Gulf Oil Corporation annual meeting today and then joined a march of 200 persons on various downtown corporate headquarters.
PARIS, April 28 The ninth Earl of Hardwicke was married quietly here yesterday to Mrs. Enid Boulting, the former wife of the British movie producer, Roy Boulting.

Although Tony Perez would have to get 15 hits in his next 15 times at bat to catch Fritz Peterson in batting, the Cincinnati third baseman holds a comfortable lead over the Yankee slugger in home runs.
The stock market tried to get out of a hole yesterday but ended up in a deeper one.

BOSTON, April 28 (AP) Judge Bailey Aldrich refused today to issue a Federal injunction to prevent the Massachusetts Superior Court from making public the transcript of the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne.
Frank Borman, the astronaut, will leave the space program on July 1 to become a vice president of Eastern Air Lines, the carrier's management announced yesterday before the annual meeting in Houston.

CAIRO, April 28 Egyptian fighter-bombers, continuing a wave of offensive actions, struck Israeli targets today along the Suez Canal and southward along the Gulf of Suez, Cairo's military spokesman reported. All the planes returned safely from the raids, he said.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 One year after he was sentenced to die for the murder of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Sirhan Bishara Sirhan sits on death row in San Quentin, waiting for the long legal maneuverings that will decide his fate.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday characterized as "unfair" and "McCarthyism all over" a series of articles printed in The New York Times dealing with police corruption in the city that reportedly involves millions of dollars a year in graft.
For its Magazine Advertising Workshop yesterday, the Magazine Publishers Association quite naturally invited representatives of some of their favorite companies.

DENVER, April 28 (A6) The Denver Rockets turned back the Washington Caps, 143-119, tonight and won the American Basketball Association's Western Division semifinal series four games to three. The Rockets will meet the Los Angeles Stars in the division finals.
Owners of the Woolworth Building, fighting a plan to designate the 60-story structure as a landmark, attacked the city's landmark law yesterday as onerous and discriminatory.
There are so many books coming out on the New York Mets' rise to baseball's world championship in 1969 that not even the Mets have any idea of how many there are.
Revised norms for mixed marriages issued by the Roman Catholic Church yesterday eliminate the requirement that the non-Catholic partner promise orally to raise offspring in the Catholic faith.

WASHINGTON, April 28 There is growing evidence that Soviet pilots are now participating in the defense of central Egypt against penetration raids by the Israeli Air Force. But no direct clashes have been reported so far.

PARIS "Does television by its very presence at an event help to create an explosive atmosphere of excitement and disorder?" This question, posed in the current London Encounter by the highly regarded British television commentator, Robin Day, undoubtedly lies at the source of many contemporary political headaches.

TRENTON, April 28 (UPI) The resignation of Judge Ralph DeVita of Union County District Court, who was found guilty April 15 of obstructing justice was accepted today by Gov. William T. Cahill and Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 (UPI) Tony Roche, the world's second-rainking player, was knocked out of the men's singles in the British hardcourt (clay) championship today. The Australian said that a persistent shoulder injury could sideline him for a year.

PARIS, April 28 Europe's stock markets tumbled today in response to the fall in Wall Street, higher short-term interest rates, rumors that mutual funds were dumping their assets and general pessimism over immediate economic prospects.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season yesterday with interclub team matches over 50 courses in the district.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 28 (AP) The United States Civil Rights Commission urged Congress yesterday to pass laws aimed at halting what it called "widespread patterns of police misconduct" against MexicanAmericans in the Southwest.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28 In South Vietnam, where the Government forbids antiwar demonstrations, limits freedom of speech and censors books before publication, artists have unusual freedom in protesting against the war and the influence of foreigners in their country.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The Department of Transportation said today that a survey showed that victims of serious traffic crashes and their dependents recovered in 1967 only an average of one-fifth of their losses from automobile insurance companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 Time has not treated the San Francisco Giants kindly. They toured Japan this spring and lost six of nine games. They paid $750,000 for synthetic grass in their park and baseballs began bouncing over the fences. And Willie Mays will be 39 next week.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers disclosed today a new analysis indicating a moderation of inflation this year even if, as he expects, the economy rises "for the remainder of the year."
Two men described as among the highest-ranking Mafia leaders on the East Coast were indicted by a grand jury here yesterday.

TALK TO the average investor and he'll tell you that his broker is lousy; that the broker steers him into situations fraught with risk and then forgets to tell the customer when the situations go sour.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 28 Richard Remsen, a retired partner in the New York City law firm of Remsen Millham Bowdish Spellman, died today at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. He was 80 years old and lived at 64 Second Street.

LONDON, April 28 The Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum expressed skepticism today over the authenticity of the so-called "Boston Raphael," a tiny portrait that has prompted debate in European art circles.

WASHINGTON, April 23 The Nixon Aministration and key Senate Democrats have agreed on compromise legislation that would aid rail passenger service in heavily traveled intercity "corridors," James A. Beggs, the Under Secretary of Transportation, disclosed tonight.

The election of George S. Trimble Jr. as president, chief executive officer and a director of the Bunker-Ramo Corporation, succeeding Milton E. Mohr, was announced MacIntyre, chairman. All other officers were reelected.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 28 The Eastman Kodak Company, which has a licensing agreement with the Polaroid Corporation to make and sell color film for Polaroid cameras in five or six years, told about 700 shareholders at its annual meeting here today that Kodak was also working on a Polaroid-type film of its own invention.

LOUISVILLE, April 28 Admiral's Shield added confusion to the 3-year-old picture today by winning the $16,500 Derby Trial. The one-mile event, designed as a proving ground for the Kentucky Derby, had some important entrants for that famous 1 -mile event in its line-up of 10 starters, but Admiral's Shield was not one of them.

While a rock concert on the Mall attracted all the attention and the publicity, something considerably more significant was taking place in jam-packed Central Park Sunday under the warm and brilliant sunshine of a lovely spring afternoon.

TRENTON, April 28 (AP) The Republican State Committee elected John E. Dimon, the Burlington County leader, as state party chairman today to succeed Nelson G. Gross, who resigned to run for the United States Senate.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 28 The removal of 15 military and police commanders accused of using violence in support of President Joaquin Balaguer's re-election campaign was recommended today by a nonpartisan electoral control commission.

The three largest steel companies in the nation reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter had dropped about 30 per cent, despite sales and other revenues that were higher in all cases than those of the 1969 period.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 28 (AP) Villanova and the University of Massachusetts were penalized today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for rules infractions.
WASHINGTON, April 28 Democratic leaders in Congress continued to press today for lowering the voting age to 18 as part of a broad voting rights bill, despite opposition from President Nixon.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) James McCormack, chairman and chief executive of the Communications Satellite Corporation, announced today he is retiring from those offices at the annual shareholders' meeting on May 12.
Jerome Deutsch, executive vice president of the Realty Equities Corporation, has been convicted of a violation of the kickback provision of the Investment Company Act of 1940.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 28 Church leaders of most of Rhodesia's Christian denominations agreed today to defy new laws that would prevent people of one race from worshiping on land allocated to another race.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., April 28 William Livingston Freeborn, former president of Freeborn Co., insurance brokers in New York City, died yesterday at Northern Dutchess Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Tivoli, N.Y.
The Frick Collection, that sumptuous mansion of masterpieces on Fifth Avenue, quietly turned 50 this week. And in the Frick tradition, it is modest about the occasion.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission today terminated special rates on telegraph and telephotograph lines leased by news organizations. The order ending seven years of proceedings, is effective in 50 days.

Charlie (Devil) Green, who serves as a bouncer in an East Village nightclub, is a quick man with his fists in or out of the ring. Last night in the Felt Forum before 1,500 fans, Green fired two right-hand punches at Ray Anderson and the 10-round fight ended in the first round.
PARIS, April 28 French scientists announced a world premiere today in the implantation in a human patient of a heart pacemaker powered by nuclear energy.
DETROIT, April 28 Curfews were ordered in two Detroit suburbs after racial violence erupted last night and edged into Detroit today.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., April 28 Theodore K. Hess, supervising accountant for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in New York, died Sunday at Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield. He was 61 years old and lived at 7 Indian Run.
A 200,000-word novel by Ernest Hemingway, considered by scholars to be the most significant of his unpublished manuscripts, will be issued this fall by Charles Scribner's Sons.

Higher local and state taxes and general wage increases effected in January reduced first-quarter earnings of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to $26,492,287, or 68 cents a share, from $29,599,654, or 79 cents a share, in the first three months of last year.

DARIEN, Conn., April 28 Charles Welles Buek, president of the United States Trust Company of New York, and Mrs. Buek have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Pinckney Buek, to James Harry Beggs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry George Beggs. Both families are of Darien.

WOMEN who want to buy just plain clothes next fall will probably be able to find some, but that's not what designers are counting on. The forward-thinkers want to sell "a fashion experience" a life style, not just the cut of a sleeve or a longer skirt.

United States Senator Charles E. Goodell, Republican of Jamestown who is seeking re-election, called for doubling the $61-million budget of the city's Department of Corrections yesterday after witnessing overcrowding at the Tombs prison.
The typographical union increased its economic pressure on The New York Times yesterday by lengthening its workstopping meetings to 15 hours a day.

The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will add two new series of concerts to its schedule in its 1970-71 season at Alice Tully Hall. One will be presented Sundays at 5 P.M., and the other Tuesdays at 7 P.M. Each series will comprise six concerts, as will the Friday series at 8:30 P.M. and the Saturday series at 9 P.M.

When Gen. Emilio Gerrastazu Medici was named President of Brazil last October he said he hoped by the end of his term to "leave democracy definitely installed in our country," along with the bases for economic and social development.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 Wilt Chamberlain is alive, and standing under the basket, just as he always has been. That's what the New York Knickerbockers discovered in New York last night before they and the Los Angeles Lakers flew here today, in separate charter planes, with the National Basketball Association's final playoff series tied at 1-1.

LONDON, April 28 (Reuters) Nijinsky, rated one of the best colts to race in Europe in the last decade, is heavily favored to win the one-mile 2,000 Guineas at Newmarket tomorrow in the first classic of the British racing season. The race has a value of $100,152, with the winner getting $67,910.
"My horse is supposed to be able to run all day," said Mike Venezia, flipping a card onto the table during a between-race interlude yesterday in the jockey room at Aqueduct.
At 1:28 P.M. yesterday, all the telephones in the office of the president of Hunter College began to ring.
ELIABETH, N.J., April 28 The selection of a jury began today for the trial of Bobby Lee Williams a key figure in the Plainfield riots of July, 1967, that resulted in the murder of a policeman.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 28 (AP) The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported today that first-quarter earnings fell to $21.8-million from $33-million in the first quater of 1969.

E. McL. Tittmann, chairman of the American Smelting and Refining Company, told the (annual meeting here yesterday that increased production and prices for metals had pushed earnings in the first quarter to the highest level for any quarter in Asarco's history.

HONG KONG, April 28 Communist China today hailed the weekend meeting between Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian Head of State, and top Communist officials from North and South Vietnam and Laos, and expressed support for a joint declaration adopted by the delegates.
Ron Woods is one game ahead of Roger Maris, but Fritz Peterson is still far behind Babe Ruth.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 28 The 3-point basket, at which the Kentucky Colonels excel, sent the American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal series into a seventh game tonight.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 29 A rebellion by Christian churches in Rhodesia against the country's new Land Tenure Act was taken a step further today when the Roman Catholic Bishops presented an ultimatum to the Government.
A police stake-out using an armored truck believed to carry a $200,000 gem shipment resulted yesterday in a shootout near Kennedy International Airport and the arrest of four alleged hijackers.

AUGUSTA, Me., April 18 Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis has announced a two-year water pollution abatement program that will cost $60-million and "take care of more than a third of the municipal water pollution in Maine."
LOS ANGELES, April 29 (AP) The police said today that they had broken up a plot to assassinate Superior Court Judge Alfred Gitelson, who recently ordered the Los Angeles school system to desegregate.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) Democrats accused the Nixon Administration today of "distorted priorities" that they said had short-changed education, health care, the fight against crime and other programs.

PARIS, April 29 The composer Mikos Theodorakis called today for the formation of a broad "national council of resistance" among Greeks to over-throw the military dictatorship in Athens, which he described as a creature of "American imperialism."
WASHINGTON, April 9 By the end of this century, man's activities may have a controlling influence on the world's climate, a scientist predicted today.

THE known United States population of Pharaoh hounds more than doubled last January when a litter of seven, bred by Mrs. Ruth Taft Hobbs of Bummet Brook Farm, Shrewsbury, Mass., was whelped. The litter was the first of the breed in this country.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 29 The conviction that ability, not luck, is the key to success is held by an overwhelming proportion of citizens of both races and at all levels of American society, the Gallup Poll reported today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Thursday, April 30 Seven persons were injured, one of them seriously, by shotgun pellets, as student rioting disrupted the Ohio State University campus yesterday. Gov. James A. Rhodes ordered 1,500 National Guardsmen onto the campus.

BOSTON, April 29 One of a group of men strolling across the Boston Common in the spring sunshine at noon today was heard to declare: "There's no reason to get panicky but there's an awful lot to be depressed about."
Two men were arrested yesterday after one allegedly struck a stewardess and the other had walked about naked during an Eastern Airlines flight from San Juan, P. R., to Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON, April 29 President Nixon's welfare reform bill was caught in a crossfire of criticism from liberals and conservatives today as the Senate began consideration of the controversial income main tenance plan.
WHY would an actress who can put on a complicated stage make-up in 10 minutes flat want to attend a class in using rouge or eyeshadow?
Mrs. Alice Draper Carter, who gave four decades to public service, died Wednesday at her home here. She was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 29 The Senate Judiciary Committee completed its hearings today on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Harry A. Blackmun in a friendly, one-day session that produced no opposition to his confirmation.

The Junior League's volunteer of the year will be announced Tuesday when league members and their guests gather at the Waldorf-Astoria for the fourth annual Medallion Ball, which takes its name from the gold medallion that will be presented to the six volunteer candidates.

Dr. Alfred J. Spiro, assistant professor of neurology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, will be the guest of honor at the annual luncheon of the Gotham Chapter of the National Foundation for Genetics and Neuromuscular Diseases on May 2. The luncheon will be held in the Colonnades Room of the Essex House, Central Park South.

LOS ANGELES, April 29 Ed Begley, the versatile character actor who won an Academy Award in 1963 for his portrayal of a malevolent redneck political boss in "Sweet Bird of Youth," died last night, apparently of a heart attack. The 69-year-old actor collapsed at a party in the Hollywood home of Jay Bernstein, his publicity man.

Two conflicting accounts of the work of an undercover policeman who infiltrated the Black Panther party were presented to a State Supreme Court jury here yesterday at the opening of the trial of three former Panthers charged with conspiring to murder and rob.
The New York State Division of Human Rights charged a theatrical craft union yesterday with willfully restricting the admission of Negroes and Puerto Ricans.
HONG KONG, April 29 Peking delivered one of its strongest attacks on the Japanese Government today and subjected Premier Eisaku Sato to personal vilification.
The city firemen served notice yesterday that if policemen received the $1,200 annual raise they were demanding, the firefighters would expect an equal increase.

In another week or so, people who earn $20,000 to $25,000 a year will have some money to "burn." They may have forgotten that this is about the time when they complete this year's required withholding for Social Security, which totals $374.40.
MOSCOW, April 29 (Reuters) North Vietnam's Communist party leader, Le Duan, flew to Peking today after a 10-day visit to Moscow, Japanese diplomatic sources reported.

JUNEAU, Alaska, April 29 Twice in the last five years, the United States has exploded nuclear devices far below the desolate surface of Amchitka, a barren spot of tundra in the Aleutian Islands. Each time, concerned residents of the islands, Alaska conservationists and even foreign scientists have protested, with little success.

The engagement of Miss Mary Robinson Lambert to William von Raab, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick von Raab of Roslyn, L. I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Adrian Lambert of New York and Old Black Point, Conn.

Saigon, South Vietnam, April 29 In a surprising victory for more than 32,000 striking students in the city, the South Vietnamese Supreme Court ruled tonight that the 1962 Government decree that established a special military tribunal was unconstitutional.

Avon Products, Inc., the cosmetics manufacturer and distributor, is adding costume jewelry and a permanent-coloring product to its line sold door to door, Fred G. Fusel, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 The Administration's decision to support a South Vietnamese military operation in Cambodia set off moves by leading Senators in both parties today to cut off funds for American military operation in Cambodia.

LONDON, Behind a tiny butcher shop in Driffield, Yorkshire, stands an archeological museum known by few people, but which draws scholars from as far away as the Soviet Union, China and the United States.
MIAMI (AP) A 12-year-old boy fished a box of dynamite out of a canal behind his parents apartment here.

The reports that Soviet pilots are flying operational missions in defense of Egypt signify an ominous escalation toward the Big Power confrontation that is inevitable if the drift toward another Middle Eastern war is not soon reversed.

WASHINGTON, April 29 "All right, all right, gentlemen! Enough of this futile weighing of alternatives. I need hard answers. If we go in with nothing more than military equipment, what explanation can I give the American people?"

MANCHESTER England, April 29 Beneath the shimmering lights of the Old Trafford stadium, nearly 64,000 balloon-carrying, horntooting fans watched the 11man Chelsea soccer team thrust and weave relentlessly over a hard sand field and triumph over Leeds United, 2-1, in overtime tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) The Labor Department reported today tentative figures showing the first decline in the wholesale price index in nearly two years.

SAINT JOHN, New Brunswick, April 29 (UPI) The Americans who debarked here yesterday on their way home after having worked for two months as volunteers cutting sugar cane in Cuba sang Cuban songs and praised the Government of Fidel Castro.
DETROIT, April 29 Violence broke out today at two junior high schools in Detroit.
A homemade pipe bomb was found early yesterday in front of the West 123d Street police station in Harlem.
JERUSALEM, April 29 (Reuters) Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Israeli Government on its assertion that Soviet pilots are flying in the United Arab Republic:
WASHINGTON, April 29 As so often before in the Indochina war, an American President has chosen to expand the conflict in the hope of ending it more quickly.
WASHINGTON, April 29 American scientists reported today the development of the world's most powerful continuous-beam laser whose output energy could, theoretically, drive a sports car.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 Mayor Lindsay told 2,000 cheering university students tonight that he had "unending admiration" for those who refused to serve in Vietnam and were willing to take the consequences.

The transportation industry was urged yesterday by a leading Congressional business expert to tackle mounting losses From theft and pilferage with new ideas and new answers "lest the theft problem overwhelms us."

WASHINGTON, April 29 Leaders of major organizations in the securities industry met today with the top economic policymakers of the Nixon Administration and each side reassured the other that things were under control.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 29 An all-white jury was chosen today for the trial of Bobby Lee williams, a 24-year-old Negro who is accused of assaulting Patrolman John V. Gleason Jr. with intent to kill during the July, 1967, riots in Plainfield.

LONDON, April 29 Floating rates, often debated as a panacea for troubles in the foreign exchange markets, came to the international bond market today in a hefty and unusual $425-million financial deal for the Italian state electricity authority.
Stricter controls on two environmental health hazards air pollution and noise were proposed yesterday by state and city officials.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) A former adviser to President Nixon predicted today the nation might be seeing "the end of the American economy as we have known it."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 The New York Mets had a tworun lead with two innings to go today, and they had even treated themselves to the rare pleasure of manhandling Juan Marichal. But they came to a no good end when the San Francisco Giants scored three runs in the eighth inning to take the game, 8-6.
"What a difference a day makes," could well have been the tune Eddie Belmonte, the talented jockey, was chanting at Aqueduct yesterday.
Jerome Kahn, vice president and a director of B. Altman Co., died yesterday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 64 years old and lived at 220 Madison Avenue and at Pound Ridge, N.Y.
President Nixon, who was elected on a pledge to bring peace in Vietnam, has instead escalated the war into Cambodia in a rash move that has the gravest implications for the United States.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 29 A, series of charges and countercharges between Cornell University and Vice President Agnew's office was touched off today by an erroneous reference to Cornell in a speech by Mr. Agnew last night.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad disclosed yesterday that Joseph D. Shane, a Los Angeles businessman and investor, had notified the railroad that he intends to seek representation on the carrier's board at the May 12 annual meeting. Mr. Shane is the owner of a block of Milwaukee Road preferred shares.

Another Manhattan judgeship battle took shape yesterday as the New Democratic Coalition backed Criminal Court Judge Amos S. Basel for the Surrogate's Court seat held by S. Samuel DiFalco, a candidate for re-election.
Mayor John V. Lindsay expressed concern yesterday that the Nixon Administration would expand the Vietnam war into Cambodia.
LONDON, April 29 The wife and mother of Yuri Galanskov, the jailed Soviet poet, have reported that he is in "grave condition" and receiving inadequate medical attention.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Hart Schaffner Marx, the clothing company, agreed today to dispose of 30 of its retail men's clothing stores in settlement of an antitrust suit that was brought by the Justice Department a year and a half ago.

Robert K. Ruskin, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday that his office was investigating the alleged "misappropriation" of city funds used in training and educating the hard-core unemployed.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange staged a sharp technical rally yesterday after the market had declined because of the news about Cambodia. The Dow-Jones industrial average rose 13.06 points to 737.39, with most of its gain coming in the final hour.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters) The Federal Reserve Board said today that both the official settlements and liquidity-based United States balance-of-payments positions were registering large deficits in the early months of 1978.

With a view to neutralizing the North Vietnamese Communists' scheme of using the Cambodian territory as operation bases to infiltrate, shell and attack in the territory of the RVN [Re- public of Vietnam] the ARVN [Army of the Republic of Vietnam] have launched an operation on April 29, 1970, to destroy the enemy's bases along the border in the Parrot's Beak, southwest of Tayninh.

The Standard Oil Company of California yesterday firstquarter earnings of $103,642,000, or $1.22 a share, down From the year-earlier $113,579,000, or $1.34 a share. Revenues pose 9 per cent to a new high of $1,211,000,000 from $1,114, 000.

The Third Street Music School Settlement is 75 years old, and last night it celebrated this milestone with a concert in Alice Tully Hall that showed what it has done and is still doing. The oldest institution of its kind in this country, the school has been a model for almost 50 settlement music schools in the United States and Canada.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (AP) The United States command refused today to permit American correspondents to accompany American support units in the new Cambodian operation. Officers that that it was an operation directed by the South Vietnamese but that the South Vietnamese were making no press arrangements either.
The stock market, speeding along a roller-coaster course, finally produced a strong technical rally yesterday. The DowJones industrial average swept up 13.06 points to finish at 737.39.
The American Stock Exchange scored its biggest advance in more than a month yesterday as the list rallied the last two hours of trading in the heaviest volume of the year.

Bournemouth, England, April 29 (UPI) Evonne Goolagong, the 18-year-old Australian aborigine girl, scored her biggest etnnis triumph today by beating Rosemary Casals of San Francisco 6-2, 6-3, in the third round of the $36,000 British hard-court open championship.
WASHINGTON, April 29 The Defense Department has begun including casualties from Laos as well as Vietnam in its daily list of those killed and wounded in the fighting in Southeast Asia.
The delegate assembly of the United Federation of Teachers voted 432 to 139 yesterday afternoon to support a strike of paraprofessional school employees against the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, April 30, (AP) The United States lifted reStrictions today on 222 items for export to almost all Communist countries.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 29 Historic pageantry and a demonstration by Australian aborigines against their treatment at the hands of whites marked the 200th anniversary today of Capt. James Cook's landing at Botany Bay.

The Federal District Court here issued a permanent injunction yesterday barring the Madison Square Garden Corporation and Goldman, Sachs Co. from violating securities laws in connection with the Garden's attempt to acquire additional stock of Roosevelt Raceway.
BOSTON, April 29 The judge at the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne reported that he could not accept as the truth key elements of Senator Edward M. Kennedy's sworn testimony at the hearing.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 30 South Vietnamese forces supported by United States warplanes and artillery and accompanied by United States advisers. swept across the border into Cambodia yesterday in a big operation against North Vietnamese and Vietcong sanctuaries inside Cambodia.
ONE flounders in these thousands pages. Aldous Huxley was not in the same league with Yeats and D. H. Lawrence as a letter-writer (nor as a poet, nor as a novelist).

James M. Lane has been promoted to executive Investment department, Chase Manhattan Bank. He vice president and executive officer of the Fiduciary succeeds Francis G. Ross, executive vice president, who continues its executive officer of the bank's trust department.
WASHINGTON, April 29 The Secretary of Agriculture, Clifford M. Hardin, was petitioned today to act immediately in banning all forms of the controversial herbicde 2,4,5-T.
HANS Randolph Reinisch was raised in the Nether lands where the litele Duch boy was supposed to have put a finger in the dike and thus prevented a trickle of water from becoming a deluge.

DUNELLEN, N. J., April 29 Donald C. Nelson, vice president of the Ziegler Chemical Mineral Company, Piscataway, died yesterday at the Somerset Valley Nursing home, Bridge water. He was 59 years old and lived at 523 Fourth Street.

LONDON, April 29 Prices on the London Stock Exchange took another beating today. But the drop of 5.2 in the Financial Times industrial index was more modest than yesterday's startling 10.1-pint plunge. The index has fallen nearly 30 points since the weekend to 360.8.

About two-thirds of the teaching staff at Public School 200, Seventh Avenue and 150th Street, stayed away from classes yesterday to protest the transfer of two teachers who were allegedly involved in slapping incidents.
A student boycott began yesterday on most of the 17 campuses of the City University of New York to protest the proposed increase in fees at the university.

PARISMINA, Costa Rica A tropical rainstorm drummed on the metal roof of Carlos M. Barrantes's tarpon fishing lodge, and soon after the first drops fell a creature with a fog-horn voice that had been holding forth at the edge of the jungle a few yards away fell silent.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 The Kentucky Colonels and New York Nets played the final game of their American Basketball Association playoff series here tonight, but hardly anybody noticed.
Redevelopment of an area described as the "gateway to Harlem" was speeded to approval yesterday in the City Planning Commission after two hours of testimony by several speakers in favor.

DALLAS, April 29 A shortened golf course awaits Gary Player, Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and their colleagues for the $100,000 Byron Nelsan Classic that begins here tomorrow. The Preston Trail Golf Club course was subjected to tornado winds and ran last weekend and the effects are still in evidence.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Senator Edward M. Kennedy rejected as "not justified" today a Massachusetts judge's report that the Senator may have driven negligently and contributed to the death of Mary Jo Kopechne at Chappaquiddick Island last July.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission provisionally accepted today the first settlement of "truth-in-lending" charges against the Chrysler Corporation under the law that took effect last July 1.

WASHINGTON, April 29 The Treasury announced today a three-part financing operation to refund $16.6-billion of maturing securities $4.9-billion of them held by the public and $11.7-billion by Government agencies and to raise some cash besides.
Imports of knitted outerwear sweaters, shirts, dresses, playsuits and trousers have reached record proportions and now are approaching close to half of domestic consumption.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Most of the 24 academic and business economists who are consultants to the new Presidential Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation believe that the top priority issues for the commission are finding ways of channeling more money into mortgages and finding ways of getting rid of mandatory interest ceilings.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Reflecting the growing sense of alarm here over the Middle East, President Nixon today ordered an "immediate and full" evaluation of reports that the Soviet Union had assumed a substantially larger role in the defense of The United Arab Republic.
Col. Frank Borman, the astronaut, suggested here yesterday that the United States and the Soviet Union agree to an exchange of space engineers as a first step to cooperation in space exploration.

SECOND thoughts are proverbially best, and so sometimes are second casts. Last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Royal Balleet offered an almost completely new set of principals in its fresh presentation of Frederick Ashton's classic.

WASHINGTON, April 29 A series of rocket and balloon observations has confirmed that an as yet unexplained infrared radiation impinges on the earth's upper atmosphere, apparently from all parts of the sky.

A fashion show, including the work of such designers as Beene, Blass, Brooks, Cardin, de la Renta, Galanos, Halley, Lanvin and Norell, will be the feature of next Wednesday's Crystal Ball at the Plaza.

Overcoming the day's preoccupation with the news from Cambodia and the Middle East and a token demonstration on behalf of Soviet Jews, panels of prominent Americans and Russians struggled here all day yesterday to find new opportunities for a peaceful dialogue.

A number of large new construction contracts placed in March sustained the level of building contracting in the United States at a high level, the F. W. Dodge Division of McGraw-Hill, Inc., reported yesterday.

THE American Contract Bridge League announced yesterday that its next executive secretary would be Richard Goldberg of Stamford, Conn. He has been assistant to the last two holders of the league's chief administrative position Alvin Landy, who died in 1968, and Easley Blackwood, who is to retire early next year.

They chairman of Mayor Lindsay's committee on police corruption said yesterday that he did not believe the committee's performance would be hampered by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary's characterization of the New York Times survey of corruption as "unfair."

WASHINGTON, April 29 A split has developed within the Administration over whether Alaska should be encouraged to take the right-of-way for a 390-mile road from the Yukon River to the Arctic North Slope and proceed with its constrution.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) The Apollo 11 astronauts, the first men to land on the moon, received the National Geographic Society's award today for the most outstanding contribution to United States aerospace progress in 1969.

TEMPE, Ariz., April 29 Joseph S. Parker, a writer and a director in the fields of radio, motion pictures and television until his retirement five years ago, died yesterday of a heart, attack in his home here. He was 57 years old.

The consent decree regarding the disposition of 30 stores by Hart, Schaffner Marx is expected to have important ramifications on dual distribution in the apparel industry. Under dual distribution, a manufacturer sells both to independent retailers and to company-owned stores.
Stock exchange received approval from the securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to go back on normal trading hours next Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) President Nixon's program to renew the United States Merchant Marine with a program to build 300 ships was approved today with some modifications by the House Merchant Marine Committee.

Contract talks between the typographical union and the four major newspapers in the city continued yesterday, but neither side reported any progress in narrowing differences on the critical money issue.

WNBC-TV, Channel 4, and WCBS-TV, Channel 2, won two Emmys each last evening from the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences for local programs broadcast last year. WABC-TV, Channel 7, received one Emmy. The awards were made at Sardi's Restaurant on west 44th Street.
LUBBOCK, Tex. (UPI) One oof the last of a hardy breed, a professional trapper, has related and recorded many of his memories for the Southwest Collection at Texas Tech University.

STOCKHOLM, April 29 (AP) The Swedish Government said today that demonstrators against the new United States, Jerome H. Holland, were scoundrels who damage Sweden's reputation. But the Government reiterated its opposition to American policy in Vietnam.

The Justice Department filed an appeal in Denver yesterday to reverse one of several Federal court decisions that have blocked Government efforts to discipline air traffic controllers who participated in the recent sick-call slowdown.
Jerome A. Ambro, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, said yesterday that he would reject any support offered to him "merely because I am white."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (Reuters) The African Christian churches of South Africa, in which faith often owes as much to tribal lore as to the Bible, are seeking a firmer basis for their beliefs.

NEWMARKET, England, April 29 (UPI) Favored Nijinksy, owned by the American millionaire Charles Engelhard scored an easy victory today in the 2,000 Guineas, the first classic of the English racing season.

The 20th annual Animal Kingdom Ball has been arranged for May 7 at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof. The event, being held during Be Kind to Animals Week, will benefit the adoption care program of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 The Kentucky Colonels, after trailing by 48-46 at half-time, outscored the New York Nets, 20-8, in the opening minutes of the third quarter tonight and defeated the Nets, 112-101. The victory gave Kentucky the semifinal series in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division, 4 games to 3.
John Cumberland isn't just struggling for a job in the major leagues. He is battling to afford a new wardrobe for his wife.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters) Charles L. Schultze, a former Director of the Bureau of the Budget estimated today that the war in Vietnam would cost the United States $12billion to $13-billion in the 1971 fiscal year, which begins July 1.

WASHINGTON, April 29 The executive committee of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters held a closed meeting today to plan strategy against challenges to its leadership by the nation's organized truck drivers.

NEWARK, April 29 The New Jersey Division on Civil Rights announced today that it was formulating a state regulation that would require the landlords of apartment houses with 25 or more units to file annual lists designating the race of their tenants.
SARASOTA, Fla. (AP) It took a court order, but Alice has come home.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 29 Edmond William Tipping, one of Australia's best-known journalists, died in Melbourne today after a long illness. His age was 54.
Faced by a circulation and advertising rate cut by his archrival Look, Lee Heffner, Life's ad director, has dispatched a pep talk to his team that is worthy of Notre Dame's late Knute Rockne.

Anyone attending the seventh annual art sale of the Child Study Association of America the evening of May 5 hits the "Jackpot," as the association likes call the benefit at its headquarters at 9 East 89th Street. Every guest leaves with a painting, a graphic, or a sculpture valued at a minimum of $200, according to the association.

BOSTON, April 29 Followlowing are excerpts from the testimony of Senator Edward M. Kennedy at the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne on the night of July 18-19, 1969, at Chappaquiddick Island, Martha's Vineyard, Mass.:

State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican and Conservative candidate for Mayor last year, gave his endorsement yesterday to James L. Buckley, the Conservative party's designee for United States Senator.

Fred Schoenberg, principal of Stuyvesant High School from 1944 to 1953 and an associate superintendent of schools at his retirement, died here Tuesday after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 230 Riverside Drive.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 29 For nearly three decades, James E. Folsom has been many things to many people Lincolnesque hero, Machiavellian plotter, shining savior, scheming scoundrel, salty sinner and senile saint.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 29 (Reuters) Indonesia has invited North Vietnam and 19 other Asian and Pacific countries to a conference on Cambodia to be held next month.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 29 (AP) Dale Morey, 51 years old; Bill Campbell, 46, and Bill Hyndman, 53, thwarted the younger set's bid to take over the North and South Amateur golf tournament today. They won two matches each and moved into the quarterfinals.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 The South Vietnamese military command took the unusual step of suspending military operations around the besieged allied camp at Dakseang today. The action came after a clandestine Vietcong radio station had said that wounded South Vietnamese prisoners would be released it the fighting stopped temporarily.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 29 (Agence France-Presse) North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troops, in a sudden attack have captured most of Attopeu, a town 30 miles from the Cambodian border in the southern tip of Laos, a military spokesman said today.
NEW HAVEN, April 29 Yale students closed ranks today behind their embattled president, Kingman Brewster Jr., whose ouster has been proposed by Vice President Agnew.
QUEBEC, April 29 Robert Bourassa, an ardent Federalist, led the Liberals to a sweeping victory in the Quebec parliamentary elections today.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 29 The smell of fresh paint is certain to be overcome by the smell of fresh money, when Monticello Raceway's 13th annual opening "Lucky 13" is this year's slogan at the Sullivan county harness racing track begins here tomorrow night. Leon Greenberg, the president of the raceway, predicted today that 10,000 or more fans would turn out and wager $500,000 or more on this earliest Kickoff in the local oval's history.

The proposed Gateway National Recreation Area would make available to fifteen million people a series of magnificent beaches and ocean-front parks. While we do not necessarily endorse all details of the proposal, it is a noble concept; but, as a recent story in this newspaper indicated, it has made disappointingly little progress since it was first announced almost a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 29 The United States announced today that it was providing combat advisers, tactical air support, medical evacuation teams and some supplies to South Vietnamese troops attacking Communist bases in Cambodia.

LOS ANGELES, April 29 The New York Knickerbockers, making up a 14-point deficit at half-time and deprived of victory in regulation time by Jerry West's 55-foot shot in the final second, went one up on the Los Angeles Lakers tonight by winning in overtime, 111-108, in the third game of the National Basketball Association's final-round playoffs.
City hospital officials pledged every effort yesterday to perform medically sound abortions on all New York City women who requested the operation after the new reform law became effective on July 1.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) Nathaniel J. Farmer, a brother of James Farmer, assistant secretary of the Department of Helath, Education and Welfare, died yesterday of cancer. He was 42 years old.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 The number seems to hold at 17 for the Kentucky Derby and if that many should start on Saturday, it would be the richest of all 96 runnings of fine race. There have been fields larger than 17, but that was before the race had an addedmoney value of $125,000.

The New Court Securities Corporation, an investment concern here sponsored by the Rothschild and Pierson banking interests of Europe, announced yesterday the formation of a venture capital fund to which institutional investors have subscribed $51.5-million.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would "firmly support the Board of Education warning that there must be full compliance with legal requirements and personnel regulations in Ocean Hill-Brownsville or anywhere else in the school system."
They had another fight in Boston last night, and Derek Sanderson wasn't even involved.
In active trading, silver futures weakened yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange and continued the sharp downward trend established the day before.

The International Business Machines Corporation introduced yesterday a group of computer programs designed to help brokerage houses solve back-office paperwork problems.
The managements or Saxon Industries, Inc., and the Standard Packaging Corporation announced yesterday they had reached an agreement in principle for Saxon to acquire Standard Packaging.

NEW HAVEN, April 29 Yale University will open its gates this May Day weekend to an expected throng assembled for a three-day demonstration against alleged Government repression of the Black Panthers and specifically to protest the impending murder trial here of Bobby Seale, the Panthers' national chairman.
Bond prices advanced yesterday, bouncing up after their steep decline that lasted more than two weeks.
LONDON, April 29 Ernst L. Freud, a son of Sigmund Freud, died here on April 7. Mr. Freud, an architect, was 78 years old.
