ROME, April 29 Experts on canon law and ecumenists of various faiths said today that the Roman Catholic regulations on mixed marriage made public in Washington yesterday were conciliatory in form but rather conservative in substance.

KOMPONG CHAM, Cambodia, April 29 Authoritative official sources here reported today that the important rubber plantation town of Memot, east of this provincial and military region capital, fell to the North Vietnamese and Vietcong invaders yesterday after three days of encirclement.

A new plan for control of Roosevelt Raceway was announced late yesterday by George Morton Levy, president. The Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Transnational Development Corporation, which collectively own about 63 per cent of the stock of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., would put their joint holdings into a "paper" corporation that would then seek to gain control of the racetrack and its properties.
"We're involved" is the umbrella theme that the United States Steel Corporation's new agency, Compton, will use to pull the giant company back into television after an absence of six years.
WASHINGTON, April 30 In sometimes emotional debate, the House rejected today efforts to cut funds for the Safeguard antimissile system.

WASHINGTON, April 30 Students at American University here are planning to go on a one-day strike tomorrow protesting the Administration's actions on Cambodia, the trial of Black Panthers in New Haven, an a recent speech by Vice President Agnew.

The Giants traded Henry Davis and John Fuqua, two of their lesser players, to the Pittsburgh Stealers yesterday for Dick Shiner, a reserve quarterback who has also play for the Browns and the Redskins.

Stan Bahnsen and Roy White sometimes miss a Yankee game because of their duties in the Army reserves, but they were in Yankee Stadium last night.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The Senate Finance Committee was startled to learn today that President Nixon's new welfare program would involve less total assistance, in some cases, for poor people who worked than for those who did not.

BONN, April 30 The West German Cabinet today approved a bill for the establishment of a public foundation to help mentally and physically handicapped children, including victims of thaliodomide, the tranquilizer sold here and abroad 10 years ago.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 30 Mrs. Doris Howell Buckles, a flower show judge, died today at Stamford Hospital after a long illness. She was 62 years old and lived on West Lane. She was the wife of Robert A. Buckles, a patent lawyer.

JERUSALEM, April 30 Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that the use of Soviet pilots in the United Arab Republic was "an almost revolutionary change" in the military situation and called for quick international assistance to Israel to compensate for it.
The city was granted a preliminary injunction yesterday against a threatened police work stoppage in a salary dispute, but the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Asso

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 30 (UPI) United States hopes for the women's singles title in the $36,000 Rothmans British hard-court tennis championships were dashed today when Mrs. Billie Jean King and Julie Heldman were eliminated in the quarterfinals.

Activities. The President conferred in the morning with Henry A. Kissinger, his assistant for national security affairs. In the evening, about one hour before his televised address on Cambodia, the President met with his Cabinet and bipartisan Congressional leaders.
TOKYO, April 30 Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange suffered their sharpest single-day decline in history today in a trading session described by observers as "panicky."

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The American Bankers Association said today it had set a goal of lending $1-billion for minority businesses over the next five years and committed itself to "an aggressive policy of equal opportunity employment."
BOSTON, April 30 Most politicians declined to comment publicly today on the potential impact of the Mary Jo Kopechne inquest findings on Senator Edward M. Kennedy's political career in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, April 30--President Nixon made no attempt in his speech tonight to expound a legal justification for his move into Cambodia, other than to refer to his duties as Commander in Chief under the Constitution and the need to protect the lives of American soldiers.

BALTIMORE, April 30--Ten persons identified as Black Panthers or their sympathizers were arrested today in a series of raids by 150 policemen in connection with the slaying last year of a 20-year-old Baltimore resident reputed to be a Panther.

BOSTON, Aprii 30 Joseph F. Gargan, a cousin of Edward M. Kennedy's who was with him immediately after his July accident on Chappaquiddick Island, told three of Mary Jo Kopechne's friends that night that she had returned to Martha's Vineyard alone in the Senator'a Oldsmobile, according to the friends' testimony at the inquest into Miss Kopechne's death.

HONG KONG, April 30 A major role for Communist China in last weekend's conference of Cambodian, Laotian and Vietnamese Communist and procommunist leaders was disclosed in official reports reaching here today from Peking and Hanoi.

Stanley Nehmer, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce, spelled out yesterday what the textile quota bill would do in cutting back imports. Mr. Nehmer was active in the yearlong discussions with textileexporting countries that failed to produce a voluntary agreement.

A massive, detailed study of the economics of the city's housing a study on which the Lindsay administration plans to base its revisions of rent control has concluded that higher rents are "necessary but not sufficient" to stem the flood of decayed and abandoned apartments here.
NEW HAVEN, April 30 "The Bulldog and the Panther have got to move together."

Sixty-five hitherto unknown letters to Sir Philip Sidney, the dashing Elizabethan poet and soldier, from leading European statesmen and scholars, were disclosed last night in the stately Renaissance splendor of the Pierpont Morgan Library.

The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday voted "Borstal Boy" the best play of the 1969-70 season, "The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the Moon Marigolds" as the best American play and "Company" as the best musical.
LONDON, April 30 The Government announced today that male sterilization operations could be performed free and with comparative ease under the National Health Service.

Citing his observations of marijuana users who participated in research studies or who were treated as patients in a hospital, a physician has reported that distinct types of adverse reactions, such as "panic," occur among some smokers of this drug.

NEWMARKET, England, April 30 (UPI) Lester Piggott, the jockey, won his first 1,000 Guineas race today when he rode the co-favorite, Humble Duty, to a seven-length victory in the $74,376 classic for 3year-old fillies.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 Nolan Ryan, who pitched a one-hitter and a two-hitter in his previous starts, pitched a three-hitter today as the New York Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 4-1.

Inclement weather in many growing areas resulted in increased soybeans and corn futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat futures rose early in the session but the advance dissipated under profit taking and stop-loss selling.

WASHINGTON, April 30 Five black members of the House of Representatives and eight more members from the New York City area endorsed in separate statements today a drive to elect representatives of the public to the board of the General Motors Corporation.
NYACK, N. Y., April 30 Edgar Van Slyke of South Nyack, a zoologist, died last night at Nyack Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

TRENTON, April 30 Gov. William T. Cahill warned the powerful, old-line Hudson County Democratic organization today that he would send in a special deputy state attorney general as county Prosecufor if the organization insisted on blocking his nominee for the post.

PARIS France's Fifth Republic has reason to regard the arrival of May with special querulousness since it was ushered in by the events of May, 1958, which destroyed its predecessor and brought back de Gaulle, while the general himself was ushered out by the events of May, 1968, featuring student uprisings and massive strikes. He resigned only a year later but his real political revolution was bracketed by the decade separating two uproarious Mays.
The Union Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that its net income in the first quarter declined to $13,500,000, or 64 cents a share, from $15,200,000, at 72 cents, in the year-ago period.
WASHINGTON, April 30 Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. seemed today to rule out any prospect that he would enter politics in the next few years.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The White House Press Secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said tonight that the telephone response to the President's address on Cambodia seemed to be running 6 to 1 in the President's favor.

When the demonstration in support of the Black Panther trial in New Haven gathers on the Town Green there today, somewhere in the throng probably close to the center of action will be the short, squat, bald figure of Jean Genet.

Richard M. Clurman, chairman of the board of the City Center of Music and Drama, has called upon striking members of the New York City Ballet orchestra to drop their demand for a reduced work week the central issue in the labor dispute and to convert this demand into money terms.
CLEVELAND, April 30 National Guardsmen patrolled the interstate highways around this industrial city today as a wildcat teamsters strike moved into its 30th day.

The Tobacco Institute disclosed at a news conference here yesterday that the American Cancer Society had twice denied its request for an independent scientific review of a study in which the society said cigarette smoking produced cancer in dogs.
WASHINGTON, April 30 Manufacturers' inventories rose by less than $100-million in March, the smallest increase since the slowdown in the economy began, the Commerce Department reported today.

If American business has in mind retrenchment in the face of recessive trends, it does not include the cutting of investment for new plants and equipment, McGraw-Hill Publications pointed out yesterday.
Hall Johnson, 82-years-old violinist, composer and arranger died of burns received in a fire at his Harlem apartment last night, fire officials reported.
About 40 Puerto Rican students barricaded the president of Brooklyn College inside his office yesterday afternoon and demanded that the number of Puerto Ricans at the school be increased.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., showed little improvement in operating results in the first quarter from the preceding three months, although the month of March made some progress with a reduced loss from that month last year, according to the preliminary unaudited statement issued yesterday.

Reaffirming his faith in the economy, President Nixon this week sought to rally the stock market, which has fallen to its lowest level since President Kennedy's assassination. "Frankly," said Mr. Nixon, "if I had any money, I would be buying stocks right now."

LOS ANGELES, April 30 Right now, the New York Knickerbockers have the upperhand in their struggle with the Los Angeles Lakers for the National Basketball Association championship strategically, physically,tactically and mentally as the result of last night's 111-108 overtime victory.

A liquor store owner thwarted a holdup yesterday when he drew his revolver and fired five shots, three of them hitting the gunman who was attempting to rob his store. The wounded suspect, although in serious condition, is expected to live.
The entire slate of independent candidates won control of the financially beset Overseas Press Club last night.

During Rico Carty's torrid September hitting streak that helped Atlanta win the National League's Western Division title last season, someone noticed a rabbit's foot sticking out of Carty's pocket and asked if the foot was for luck.
ROME, April 30 The Vatican's leading ecumenist, Jan Cardinal Willebrands, called today for interfaith talks on mixed marriages.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I, April 30--A crackdown on motorists who fail to deposit the required 10-cent toll in the exact-change baskets on the Southern State Parkway has resulted in the arrest of about 150 persons by the Long Island State Parkway Police since Tuesday.

William E. Madden, chairman of the board of Charles W. Williams Co., Inc., 6 Stanwix Street, Brooklyn, makers of paper for boxes, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 609 East 37th Street, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old.

Dr. Roberto Arias and Dame Margot Fonteyn have announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Rosita Arias, to George B. Hanily, a former Marine captain, who is with the treasury department of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here. The wedding is set for May 29.

The season's final Evenings for New Music program, given last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, offered five works that seemed admirably structured for the composers' purposes but seldom convinced this listener that the purposes were worthwhile.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 30 Miss Sarah Catherine Nimitz, granddaughter of the late Fleet Adm. Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet during World War II and Chief of Naval Operations from 1945 to 1947, plans to be married on June 13 to F. Curtis Smith, a classmate at St. Lawrence University.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 30 (AP) Bill Hyndman and Dale Morey, former winners, Gary Cowan of Kitchener, Ontario, and John Birmingham of Pittsburgh scored quarterfinal victories today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

GREENWOOD, Va., April 30 Gordon Mountjoy Buck, a retired lawyer who had represented the Southern Pacific Company and the Pacific Oil Company, died Sunday at his estate in Greenwood. He was 94 years old.

'Five New York City Congressmen demanded yesterday that Mayor Lindsay remove Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary from the special committee investigating charges that policemen in the city receive millions of dollars a year in graft.

PLAYERS representing the Metropolitan Life Insur ance Company dominated the competitions of the Metropolitan Commercial Bridge League during the past season. Although their team was narrowly defeated by I.B.M. in the 12-a-side contest that runs through the season, they captured titles in both the competitions that wound up the season.
Two men were arrested Wednesday after one allegedly struck a stewardess and the other had walked about naked during an Eastern Airlines flight from San Juan, P. R., to Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) Charles H. Rogovin, a Democrat who is resigning his Justice Department job over policy and personal differences, nonetheless gave Attorney General John N. Mitchell yesterday high praise for the Government's crackdown on organized crime.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration is investigating charges that agency officials have manipulated laboratory results for years to avoid weakening or contradicting established Government policies on food additives and pesticide safety.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 An interim report issued today by a Harvard University committee recommended that students be authorized "to sit on boards and committees that consider student disciplinary cases."

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) The St. Louis Blues advanced to the Stanley Cup final tonight with a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins. The winning goal was scored by Larry Keenan, who shoved a loose puck into the net with 5:45 to play.

Francis I. du Pont Co., one of the nation's largest stock brokerage firms, issued yesterday a quarterly statement of its financial condition that reported the firm's total capital funds as of March 31 were $62,594,000. It said the amount was the third highest among general brokerage firms.

Mrs. Julia Fuentes, who is 40 years old and just beginning her college education, is from Puerto Rico and is the sole support of her three children. She lives on the Lower East Side and was formerly on welfare.

Boyle's report on the closed inquest into the death of Miss Mary Jo Kopechne may prove to be the final legal act in the prolonged summer-island tragedy involving Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. If so, ironically, it exposes the utter inadequacy of the efforts of local law-enforcement officials to arrive at the truth.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., April 30--Mild weather and reasonably fast horses greeted about 5,802 harness racing fans as Monticello Raceway opened its 13th straight season tonight. It was the earliest start at the track and the 8:45 P.M. firstpost time was the earliest.

WASHINGTON, April 30 Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended April 25 affected by week stoppages throughout the nation, was considerably below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Freight traffic on United States railroads in the same period registered an increase.

The Radio Corporation of America proposed yesterday that the Government support the development of an antimidair-collision system invented by an R.C.A. engineer who has publicly critictized his own management on the subject and denounced an airlines' anticollision project as "totally inadequate."

CAIRO, April 30 The United Arab Republic reported today that a heavily armed battalion of its troops crossed the Suex Canal along a 15-mile front last night, attacking Israeli positions and killing or Wounding tens of defenders.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 Dawn slipped into the ancient cavalry post at Churchill Downs today with a sullen slowness. It edged through the cover of gray clouds that hovered over the barn area like an oppressive blanket. Even in early morning it was hot and sticky with temperatures heading toward 90 and with the threat of thunderstorms before nightfall. The day thus began on a depressing note.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) The Senate Judiciary Committee delayed today until Tuesday a vote on Judge Harry A. Blackmun's nomination to the Supreme Court but confirmation still appeared tob e certain.

DENVER, April 30 (AP) The Denver Rockets needed a threepoint goal at the buzzer to pull even before they blitzed the Los Angeles Stars in overtime for a 123-113 victory in the first game of the American Basketball Association Western Division final playoff tonight.

ALBANY, April 30 The Corporation Counsel for New York City today denounced the New York Telephone Company's request for a rate increase and said that the company should be penalized instead for poor service.
Prices of Government bonds and notes declined yesterday, bringing their yields more into line with the terms of the $16.6-billion refunding operation announced late Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 --An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was named in court today as the source of some of the material printed in a Look magazine article that linked Mayor Joseph L. Alioto to men identified as Mafia hoodlums.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 30 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has agreed to meet with leaders of the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches to discuss the churches' rebellion against legislation that bars interracial worship.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 30 Mindful that Yale University and its restless student body is only 40 miles away, the Olin Corporation took precautions today to insure that its annual meeting would not be disturbed by outsiders.
NEW HAVEN, April 30 The impending Black Panther trial is expected to prompt a massive gathering on the New Haven Green here tomorrow.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 (AP) C. V. Whitney's True North came on with a strong stretch drive today to win the seven-furlong $15,000 added Churchill Downs Handicap, leading Advance Party by threelengths at the finish.

Popular stock averages drifted lower yesterday after the sharp Wednesday rally spent its force. On Wall Street, with prices hovering only slightly above the lowest levels in nearly six and a half years, an atmosphere of extreme caution still prevailed.
Negotiators for the typographical union and the city's newspapers yesterday resumed their efforts to find a solution to their deadlock on the key money issue.

HANOVER, West Germany, April 30 The Soviet aviation industry has made its first appearance at Hanover's international air show with a sturdy, short-haul passenger jet that aspires to the workhorse fame of the venerable DC-3.

It didn't take Eddie Belmonte, the Puerto Rican riding star, long to renew his concentration on Saturday's Kentucky Derby, after being notified at Aqueduct yesterday that he had been held "blameless" for a questionable ride on Interwood Wednesday.

PARIS, April 30 The Saigon delegation at the Vietnam peace conference here declared today that North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces were introducing large quantities of arms and reinforcements into the Cambodian frontier area in preparation for a new offensive.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 1--The United States sent troops and B-52 bombers inside Cambodia early today in the first strike of an attempt to crush the sanctuary there of the North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 30 North Vietnamese forces took control of the embattled town of Attopeu in southern Laos early this morning.

James H. Hubert, the first executive director of the New York Urban League, died after a brief illness Wednesday at the Hillcrest General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He was 84 years old and lived at 104-65 165th Street, Jamaica.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 William J. Stephens, chairman and chief executive officer of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, told the annual meeting here today that the concern had a loss of $977,000 in the first quarter.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 30 Mrs. Isobel Victoria Cawthra Dezell of Stamford, widow of Dr. William R. Dezell, a New York surgeon, was married here today to Holgar J. Johnson. Robert Hardman performed the ceremony in the chapel at Christ Episcopal Church.

The sweeping Liberal party victory in Quebec, turning back an ominous separatist threat to Canadian unity, offers hope for stability and badly needed economic development in the French-speaking province. Louis B. Brodsky, a former city magistrate, died at Mount Sinai Hospital on Wednesday. He was 86 years old and lived at 465 Park Avenue.

Angered by Mayor Lindsay's statement that some draft resisters were heroic the sponsors of tomorrow's Loyalty Day parade threatened yesterday to bar the Mayor from the event.

The marriage of Mrs. Patricia Shephard Norris to Herbert P. Patterson, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, took place in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon. Only members of the couple's immediate families attended the ceremony, performed by the Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read, minister of the church. A reception for 300 followed at the Colony Club.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Settlement today of disciplinary cases against two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, Hertz, Warner Co. and Harris, Upham Co.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 The 96th running of the Ken tucky Derby on Saturday has attracted 18 entrants, the largest field for the 1 1/4-mile test in 19 years. The turnout was a surprise; it included at least two horses that had been considered quite unlikely starters.
THE effort to establish the striped bass as a game fish in New York State has once again failed.

BUFFALO, April 30 Dr Leslie A. Fiedlre, the author and literary critic, was sentenced today to six months in the Erie County Penitentiary for permitting marijuana to be smoked in his home here. He was released in $500 bail to await an appeal.

QUEBEC, April 30 Robert Bourassa, the 36-year-old leader of the pro-federalist Liberial party of Quebec, has won an unqualified mandate to keep the predominately Frenchspeaking province within the Canadian confederation.

WASHINGTON, April 30 President Nixon was reported tonight to have received a generally favorable reaction from Congressional leaders to his decision to send American ground combat troops into Cambodia to destroy Communist sanctuaries in that country.

The Federal Reserve continued to pursue gingerly its policy of modest credit expansion in the latest two weeks despite apparent tightness in some important indicators, banking data published yesterday showed.
JUNEAU, Alaska, April 30 (AP The Alaska Legislature voted, 41 to 17, today to override Gov. Keith Miller's veto of a liberalized abortion law.

WASHINGTON, April 30 The White House was reported today to be ready to announce the nomination of J. Richard Lucas, a 42-year-old professor of mineral engineering at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, to be the new director of the troubled and demoralized Bureau of Mines.
Mayor Lindsay endorsed former Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo yesterday for election as Representative from the 21st Congressional District.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 30
WASHINGTON People in Pine Bluff, Ark., remember Martha Elizabeth Beall as a deep-dimpled, happy-golucky, headstrong, highstrung girl who was never at a loss for words.
The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday a $7.0-million damage award against RKO General, Inc., for using insider information to buy stock.
PARIS, April 30 The Government marshaled its big majority in the National Assembly early today behind a bill reinforcing France's legal arsenal against troublemakers.
A new $5 minimum fee to the the franchised towing operators serving New York City's parkways and expressways goes into effect today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 If you're a little confused about what's going on around here these days, it may be because you haven't caught on to the new rule of politics. The new rule is that logic is out and reverse logic is in, and under this rule everybody talks and acts against his awn self-interest and in the interest of his opponent.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30 National Guardsmen and police repeatedly scattered crowds of students on the campus of Ohio State University today, firing hundreds of rounds of tear gas and pepper gas, and discharging shotguns at the youths.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced late yesterday afternoon increases in the price of flat rolled steels averaging 4.7 per cent.

BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N. J., April 30 Mrs. Gwen Kopechne declined to comment today on Judge James A. Boyle's opinion that the death of her daughter, Mary Jo, might have been due to negligent driving by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

DALLAS, April 30 Golf's so-called "Rabbits," the professionals who hop from tournament to tournament seeking a qualifying place in a circuit tournament, are jumping with indignation. They object to the name by which they are described.

OAK PARK, Ill., April 30 Irvin E. Houck, retired director and senior vice president of Marsh McLennan, Inc., insurance brokers, died yesterday at West Suburban Hospital of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.
The editorial employes of Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, have decided to ask the United Automobile Workers of America to begin an organizing campaign at the publication.
WASHINGTON, April 30 Arthur F. Burns said today the Federal Reserve Board is "determined to resist any reemergence of excess demand later this year or in 1971."

CLAREMONT, Calif., April 30 A group of Protestant theologians asserted here today that Christianity had played its part in provoking the current environmental crisis and that any solution to it would require major modification of current social and religious values.

Well, maybe not exactly today's split-level. According to the historian Vincent Scully and other authorities the great age of American home building came to an end about the time of World War I.

A list of entries for the Newport-Bermuda race contained the names of 147 yachts, a figure that was likely to change before the start on June 20 because of additions and withdrawals. The list was of entries to mid-April. The total was 20 yachts fewer than the record starting fleet of 1966. There were 151 starters in 1968, the last time the event was held.

Nathan Stern, a retired civil engineer for the Board of Education, died apparently of a massive stroke yesterday at the Flushing Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 64-10C 186th Lane, in Fresh Meadows,. Queens.

VISITORS to Bermuda from the United States and Canada are finding shopping a lot easier since the popular vacation island switched to the decimal monetary system on Feb. 6, after 360 years of pounds, shillings and pence.

WASHINGTON The invasion of Cambodia ordered by President Nixon makes it clear that he does not have and never has had a "plan to end the war." SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2 (AP) Maj. Gen. Nguyen Viet Thanh, commander of the South Vietnamese IV Corps tactical zone, which encompasses the Mekong Delta, was killed today when his helicopter and a United States helicopter gunship collided over Cambodia, official sources said.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2 The percentage of white Southern parents who would object to sending their children to schools where Negroes were enrolled has dropped from 61 per cent to 16 per cent in the last seven years, according to the Gallup Poll.

WASHINGTON Last Wednesday was to have been the day when the cloud lifted over Edward Moore Kennedy, the cloud that had shadowed both his public and personal life since the dark midnight last July when Mary Jo Kopechne drowned off Chappaquiddick Island in the car he had driven off Dike Bridge.

TWO blocks from the Dawson County Courthouse in Dawsonville, Ga., is a 30 90-foot log building known as The Moonshine Museum. Inside are four stills. They have never produced anything but curiosity in their present location, swears the museum's owner, but he's confident they could.

A DC-9 jet on a flight from New York to the Caribbean was ditched off St. Croix yesterday with 63 persons aboard. The Coast Guard reported 40 persons rescued last night, seven dead and atleast 16 others missing.
BERLIN, May 2 Twentyfive years ago this week, two Soviet sergeants hoisted the hammer and sickle above the Reichstag here.

ONCE upon a time, when children helped work the land to assist in supporting the family, every child was an economic necessity. This situation no longer exists. Neither does the need for procreation to insure survival of the race. Social scientists, in fact, are saying in louder voices and larger numbers that survival of our species now is dependent on decreasing the birth rate.

MALMO, Sweden The emphasis here in the southern tip of Sweden is on leisure. The people are sun worshipers, and after the long and dreary winters they savor the beautiful summer days and the long hours of daylight. The slightly undulating countryside, with its yellowing cornfields, is restful to the eye. Blond children on bicycles wave as you pass by, and a feeling of relaxation pervades the atmosphere.

Columbia University's president-designate, William J. McGill, said yesterday that he was "willing to die for the academic cause."

Miss Martha Katherine Marston and Dr. Sidney Robert Block were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations was performed jointly by the Rev. Charles Koerber, a Roman Catholic priest, Rabbi Samuel H. Baron and the Rev. Dr. Carl Soule, a Methodist minister who heads the center.

ARMONK, N.Y., May 3 Steve Ross of Brooklyn, who heads the draw, continued the defense of his title in the 37th annual Westchester County amateur championship tournament at Armonk Tennis Club today by defeating Reynolds Acker of Weestport, Conn., 6-2, 6-0, in the third round.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 Most politicians in Alabama have concluded that neither Gov. Albert P. Brewer nor former Gov. George C. Wallace is likely to gain a majority in the Democratic gubernatorial primary Tuesday.
Two separate public opinion polls yesterday reported conflicting results on the attitude of the American people toward sending United States troops into Cambodia.

NEW HAVEN, May 3 A force of 3,000 National Guard troops sent here to control a mass weekend rally in support of the Black Panthers began leaving the city today, and there was a general relaxation of fear as more of the students and young radicals attracted by the rally also departed.

LONDON May 3 The International Planned Parenthood Federation said here today that, after drawing together the available evidence, it had found that the risks involved in the use of oral contraception were small and its continued use throughout the world was "fully justified."
The Federal Reserve has bluntly repudiated the official Government measurement of the nation's international balance of payments.
In the unlikely event that all goes well, The New Yorker may finish reprinting "Ulysses" about 90 years from now.
MADRID, May 3 (Reuters) Manuel Santana of Spain beat Lew Hoad of Australia, 6-3, 8-10, 6-3, 6-0, in the final of the Madrid international tournament today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 (AP) Fred Lewis scored seven of Indiana's last 9 points from the free-throw line today to help the Pacers beat the Kentucky Colonels, 114-110.
PITTSBURGH, May 3 New orders for steel are coming in much faster than shipments are going out.

WASHINGTON CROSSING, N.J., May 3 The dog that to day won best in show in the second of two events that have exceeded 3,600 dogs this year was the same Lakeland that had won the first. The terrier was Ch. Special Edition, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 3 Many matters from pensions to politics have come up for discussion here at the annual convention of the New York City school supervisors, but the topic that appeared to dominate the three-day meeting was violence.

GENEVA, May 3 Changes in the top management of the embattled Investors Overseas Services financial empire are expected to result from a meeting of its board of directors. The meeting began today and will continue tomorrow.

Mayor Lindsay's special committee set up to investigate alleged police corruption was criticized yesterday by two prominent Democrtas, Howard J. Samuels and Basil A. Paterson. Both suggested that the state conduct an investigation.
Signs of a backlash against the crusade for a cleaner environment and restoration of the ecological balance are beginning to appear.
The ferocious hatred the leaders of the Soviet Union and China harbor toward each other emerges vividly from the latest exchange of polemical blasts between Moscow and Peking.

BANGALORE, India, May 31 (AP) Premjit Lall outlasted Ray Ruffels in a 66-game match today giving India a 1-0 lead over Australia in their five-match Davis Cup Eastern Zone final. The score was 6-2, 6-8, 6-3, 3-6, 14-12.
MONTREAL, May 3 Jubilation prevailed in Montreal's predominantly English-speaking financial community following the Liberal party's sweep of the Quebec elections last week.

ELKINS PARK, Pa., May 3 At Congregation Rodeph Shalom Suburban here this afternoon, Miss Susan Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Miller Harris, was married to Joel Lavenson, who is serving with the Army in Heidelberg, West Germany. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Lavenson of Pelham, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David H. Wice.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 3 Chanting an exuberant cadence, a platoon of soldiers blocked traffic for several minutes the other day as they marched down a dusty highway in rural Western Nigeria, ignoring the honking of horns.

CULVER CITY, Calif., May 3 A mantel clock used as a prop in the Greta Garbo movie "Ninotchka" was the star in the first hour of bidding at the auction today of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It went for $3,750 to a collector who refused to identify himself.

Pierre Salinger said yesterday that former President Lyndon B. Johnson had made "another unfortunate attempt to rewrite history" in his accusation that some holdover staff members had undermined his Administration in the months after President Kennedy's assassination.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 3 William E. Kelly of the host Larchmont Yacht Club, sailing Dowry, won the 7.4-mile Etchells-22 Class race today by 18 seconds and 2 boat more than 300 yards under poor sailing conditions on Long Island Sound.

Henry R. Ashton, a senior partner in the New York patent-law firm of Fish Neave, formerly Fish, Richardson Neave, died Saturday in Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 28 Ridge Croft Road, Bronxville, N.Y.

BOSTON, May 3 "Ladies, if you'll maintain your composure," said Chairlady Edie O'Leary moments before Senator Edward M. Kennedy arrived at a luncheon outing for Democratic women on the edge of Boston harbor, "the Senator will vist each table on the boat. We certainly want to give him a standing ovation, but we don't want to crush him."
The Administration proposal for extending Medicaid and Medicare lays the foundation for a complete restructuring of the economics and organization of the existing medical care system.

Coast Guard and Navy ships and helicopters searched the choppy Caribbean off St. Croix through the night last night for 22 persons missing from the Dutch Antillean Airlines DC-9 jet that ditched with 63 persons aboard on Saturday.

DALLAS, May 3 Arnold Palmer drew even with Jack Nicklaus, after 36 holes in the Byron Nelson Classic at the 6,854-yard Preston Trail Golf Club today, but one hole later, in the playoff, the Ohio star beat his older rival's star with a birdie 4.
MOSCOW, May 3 The chances for a negotiated settlement in either the Middle East or Southeast Asia the world's two most inflammatory spots seem more remote than ever to Western diplomats here.

For 40,000 Manhattan apartment dwellers, cable television is a way to see home games of the knickerbockers and the Rangers and old movies without commercials. For them, as well as for 500 others uptown in Riverdale, cable TV means interference-free reception.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 3 If the Christian churches of Rhodesia force the Government to amend the recently adopted law segregating the nation's land on racial lines, it will be a victory for a worldly Roman Catholic Bishop.
A residency requirement designed to keep New York City from becoming "the nation's abortion capital" has been introduced in the City Council.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird predicted today that Congress would extend the draft for at least two years beyond the July l, 1971, expiration date for the Selective Service Act.
WASHINGTON, May 3 Senate investigators have charged that the job training program run by the National Alliance of Businessmen with Labor Department support has fallen short of its promises.

GODAUHA, South Vietnam, May 3 The three task forces of Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri's III South Vietnamese Corps, which moved into the Parrot's Beak area of Cambodia on Wednesday, are now reported to be sweeping back in a semicircle toward the South Vietnamese border, after having reached Sveyrieng on Friday.
WASHINGTON More than five million veterans were insured during 1969 in five Government life insurance programs valued at $38-billion, according to the Veterans Administration.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 3 Enemy forces staged widespread attacks, the heaviest in a month, in South Vietnam this weekend.

KANSAS CITY, May 3 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond, top-seeded and second-ranked nationally, defeated the defending champion, Clark Graebner of New York, 7-6, 6-1, to capture the $2,500 first prize in the Glenwood Manor national invitation tourney today.
There was no applause for the speeches. During most of the three-hour ceremony all heads were bowed. The most persistant sound was that of sobbing.
WASHINGTON, May 3 President Nixon's decision to send troops into Cambodia and particularly the manner in which it was carried out has transformed and troubled the spirit of this capital.
KINGS POINT, L.I., May 3 --Mr. and Mrs. Leo Hausman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Hausman, to James Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gould of Cincinnati.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May 3 No additional legal action was taken against Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the drowning last year of Mary Jo Kopechne because the Massachusetts officials who might have acted were apparently convinced there were no witnesses and no evidence that would substantiate a new charge against him.

Samuel Dilworth-Leslie's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon came together best in Edward MacDowell's "Tragic" Sonata, No.1 in G minor, a work now gen erally left on the shelf because its ideas recall so vividly those of better composers of the 19th century. Mr. Dilworth-Leslie, with a restraint that enhanced the music, searched out and often found the MacDowell behind the imitations of Liszt, Chonin and Brahms.
YONKERS, May 3 Arthur McAndrews of the Boston Athletic Association won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Assocition Eastern regional 10,000-meter championship today at Tibbets Brook.
WASHINGTON, May 3 A high official has disclosed an "intense" difference of opinion within the Government over the future of the nation's trade and balance-of-payments policies.
An unusual group of veteran blues singers was assembled at Carnegie Hall Saturday night for a program called "B.B. King and His Friends."

THE one danger of an institutional theater, and perhaps the only argument that can occasionally be leveled against it, is a natural tendency to drift toward the complacent and the safe, rather than the adventurous and the unknown. This is a danger that New York's Shakespeare Festival has avoided with a studious flamboyance. It seems to go out of its way to shock, and yet it succeeds in shocking in style.

HOUSTON, May 3--Senator Ralph W. Yarboroough said today that he was defeated for renomination yesterday by voter apathy, war weariness and, primarily, the last-minute introduction as a campaign issue of his vote against a public school prayer proposal.
THERE is a growing group of people in town who don't have to elbow their way into subways, fight each other for cabs, or struggle to fish out the exact fare for buses.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, warned yesterday that a plan by union printers to increase their economic pressure on the paper "brings us face to face with crisis."

HOWARD ZINN, historian and professor of political science at Boston University, has never ben one to wait around for history to decide its next move. In the nineteen-forties he fought in World War II as an Air Force bombardier.
GOEMBA, Japan, May 3 (AP) Jackie Stewart of Scotland, the world champion auto racer, led all the way at an average speed of 120.2 miles an hour today and won the Japan Grand Prix by 50 seconds.

QUINCY, Ill. Jessie Hill, a brawny bear of a pitcher, lathered in the first pitch of the Quincy Cubs' 1970 season. Rick Auerbach, the Clinton Pilots' scrawny shortstop, swung and the ball soared in a high arc over the black and gold "Brockshmidt Plumbing and Heating" sign...
NEW HAVEN, May 3 Black Panthers, who have built their organization on slogans of violence, have shown themselves adept at keeping the peace.
CLEVELAND, May 3 With the most exciting Ohio Senate primary election in years up for decision Tuesday, voters find themselves with not one but two races close enough to make forecasters wary.

BRUSSELS, May 3 With national borders in the European Common Market fading away, the old-fashioned smuggler has disappeared but the dishonest exporter who knows how to manipulate the new regulations has taken his place.

WASHINGTON, May 3 seventy-five persons, including Dr. Benjamin Spock, were arrested this afternoon across the street from the White House in a peaceful outdoor prayer service to protest the war in Vietnam and the United States involvement in Cambodia.
An 18-year-old Jersey City girl was severely beaten while on her way to work at the New York Telephone Company offices at 140 West Street last night.

CHROI DANG, Cambodia, May 3 Vietnamese Communist forces were reported today to have attacked and at least partly occupied a key Mekong River crossing point in Cam bodia 35 miles southeast of Pnompenh.
VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., May 3 Richard E. Sterns, a lawyer, died in his sleep early today. He was 44 years old.
The three Democratic candidates for Governor are all taking "quickie" telephone polls this week and they are all interested in the same question: Is Arthur Goldberg in trouble?
Ninety-nine exhausting games after opening the National Basketball Association season on Oct. 14, the Knicks begin their final and decisive week of play tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Dr. Richard D. Brasfield, a cancer surgeon here, died yesterday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 935 Esplanade, Pelham, N.Y. His office was formerly at 115 East 61st Street.
Ken Kling, a former horseracing handicapper and cartoonist, died yesterday after a long illness. He lived in Great Neck, L.I., and was in his 70's.

Newsday of Garden City, L.I., the nation's largest circulation suburban newspaper, will pass into new ownership this week under a plan prepared by the prospective proprietor, The Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 3-- Liberal and moderate members of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg school board suffered a crushing defeat yesterday at the hands of a slate of candidates pledged to fight busing for racial balance in schools here.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Franklin Stewart Brown, chief of the Bureau of Power and chief engineer of the Federal Power Commission, died today of cancer. He was 60 years old.
KENT, Ohio, Monday, May 4 National Guardsmen and the police drove students into their dormitories at Kent State University ltae last night, the third night of campus unrest.

TOKYO, May 3 The Sokagakkai, Japan's fast-growing neo-Buddhist sect, publicly apologized "to the nation and the people concerned" today for the actions it took in trying to suppress a book critical of the organization:

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) The Americans for Democratic Action voted today to call for amnesty for young men who have gone abroad or to prison to escape the draft because of their opposition to the war in Vietnam.

"My Sweet Charlie," a drama about the growth of understanding between an ignorant Southern girl and a militant black Northern lawyer that starred Patty Duke and Al Freeman Jr., walked off with eight Emmy nominations from the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences the highest number for any single dramatic program.

State Senator Basil A. Paterson charged yesterday that his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor had injected the race issue into the campaign by making repeated disclaimers that he was seeking white support.

SAN DIEGO, May 3 The New York Mets split a doubleheader with the San Diego Padres today and ended their first visit to the West Coast with five victories, five defeats and a serious shortage of hitting.

PLYMOUTH, England May 3 The voyage of the Mayflower 350 years ago from the granite quays of this ancient seaport to a land of hope across the Atlantic was celebrated here this weekend with bell-ringing hoopla that would have bewildered perhaps even shocked the austere Pilgrim Fathers.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 3 More than 2,000 well-armed Cambodians serving in American-operated units in South Vietnam were flown into Pnompenh last night and Friday as reinforcements for the Cambodian Army.

ATLANTA, May 3 (UPI) Leo Durocher, the Chicago Cubs' manager, was fined $200 and suspended for one day by Chub Feeney, the National League president, today for making an obscene gesture at an umpire in last night's game with the Atlanta Braves.
Dave Romansky left the starting line for the one-mile walking race to the usual accompaniment of giggles and whistles.

A group of female editorial employes at Time Inc. charged last night that its magazines "treat women as inferior employes in publishing." Women who work for Time, Life, Fortune and Sports Illustrated magazines said legal action would he taken against the publisher.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 3 (AP) Secretary General Thant said today that the Vietnam war threatened to engulf Indochina and that he would present "some ideas" to prevent that from happening.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 3 The warm public reception given Queen Elizabeth II and other members of the royal family in a five-week tour of Australia that ended today has been interpreted here as a severe setback to any movement to make this country a republic.

At the end of the American Symphony Orchestra concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, Leopold Stokowski, who had just conducted Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, received an ovation.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 3 Tricolor Farm's Catbird, with Barney Ward in the saddle, won the open jumper stake today at the concluding session of the three-day St. Clement's horse show at Saratoga Race Track.
KAMPALA, Uganda, May 3 (AP) A British High Commission official, Brian A. Lea, was kidnapped here yesterday, British officials announced today.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska--From the severe neatness of the vast oil complex strung out at great white intervals along the frozen margin of the Arctic Ocean, one might imagine for a moment that the industry was out to enhance the stark environment--if even the bleakest scene can be enhanced by oil rigs. The superintendent of the...
Johnny Bench likes to sing ballads songs with good lyrics that say something meaningful.
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 3 Dr. McIver Woody of 552 Westminster Avenue, medical director for the Esso Standard Oil Company from 1922 to 1944, died today at the Elizabeth General Hospital. His age was 84.

This is the last of a three-part series on consumer measures passed by the Legislature this season. The first two, reviewing bills the Governor was expected to sign, appeared on April 23 and 27. This is a review of the most controversial bill on the Governor's desk today. His decision to sign or not to sign it will have a broad impact on consumers everywhere.
LONDON, May 3 A merger of Trust Houses, Britain's biggest hotel chain, and Fortes, the mass catering and restaurant concern, was announced here today.

SATUM, Cambodia, May 3 Penicillin from Britain, surgical instruments from Germany, mortar shells from the Soviet Union and rice from China were the yield of the third day of the allied sweep of the Fishhook area of Cambodia.
LADISPOLI, Italy, May 3 Italy's youngest town was joyously born today, and 100 carabinieri were on hand to protect it from irate neighbors and former fellow citizens.
ADENAU, Germany, May 3 (UPI) Kelvin Carruthers of Australia, the defending champion, won the season's first event of the world 250 C.C. motorcycling championship on the Nuerburgring track.

The philanthropic program of the Friends of the Henry Street Settlement will benefit from a Riverboat Ball at the Pierre on Friday night. The decor and entertainment in the hotel's Grand Ballroom iwll stimulate the atmosphere of a 19th-century Mississippi riverboat.
ELMIRA, N.Y. Cable television is as familiar to this city as the clang of church bells on Sunday. Of a possible 25,000 household customers, 21,000 pay $4.50 a month to be "on the cable."
TAIPEI, Taiwan Just 346 years after they became the first Westerners to establish a settlement on Taiwan, the Dutch are back in strength again.

CAIRO, May 2 (Reuters) A military spokesman said here that Egyptian heavy artillery shelled Israeli positions across the Suez Canal in a three-hour exchange today, destroying one Israeli halftrack, damaging a tank and another halftrack, and hitting artillery bases and ammunition dumps.
The last vestiges of the once-notorious waterfront shape-up are being phased out in the Port of New York as a new computer hiring system is close to becoming portwide.
Isadore Alfred Wyner, long prominent in the knitted fabrics industry, died here Saturday. He was 77 years old and lived at 290 West End Avenue.
The credit markets, which shrugged off President Nixon's Cambodia speech last Friday, face another period of heavy financing activity this week.

Merit scholarships have been awarded to more than 3,000 high school seniors, including 237 from the state with 50 from New York City, it was announced last week by Edward C. Smith, president of the National Merit Scholarship corporation.

New York State may save about $140-million a year in the first year of the projected Nixon Administration welfare reform, starting July 1, 1971, Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator, said yesterday.

"SOMEDAY it will be great to do a collection of clothes without resorting to the sewing machine," Don Simonelli mused after the showing of his fall collection last week. It's the first he has not designed for someone else and it was made on sewing machines all right.

MOSCOW, May 3 (UPI) Mrs. Pauline Zhemchuzhina Molotov, the wife of former Premier and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, died of cancer in a Moscow hospital on Friday, family sources reported today. She was 76 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan said today that the Middle East is moving toward a big-power conflict because of what he termed United States indifference and a one-sided policy favoring Israel.
WASHINGTON, May 3 The Nixon Administration today described its large bombing raid against targets in North Vietnam as only a continuation of a long-standing policy of selfdefense for American forces.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board has reimposed a weight limit on baggage checked by airline Passengers.
NEW YORK bridge players bade farewell a week ago to two Australian experts who are undertaking a world bridge tour of record-breaking duration.
HONG KONG, May 3 The North Vietnam Government implied today that United States bombings in two North Vietnamese provinces Friday and Saturday might disrupt the Paris peace negotiations on Vietnam.

During the last 15 years, United States industry has built up one of the world's largest air forces 24,000 executive planes that now outnumber the nation's airline fleet by 12 to 1, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board.
The names of Marines killed in Vietnam were read in Battery Park yesterday at a memorial service sponsored by the Marine Corps Fathers Association.
CLEVELAND, May 3(AP)--Dissident teamsters in Cleveland voted today to end their 32-day wildcat strike, and 6,000 truck drivers in the local were to go back to work tomorrow.

John W. Kiermaier resigned yesterday as president of the Edcational Broadcasting Corporation, operator of Channel 13, to seek the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives from the Fourth Congressional District of Connecticut. He makes his home in Westport, Conn.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) Dr. Roger Bannister, the first man to run the mile under four minutes, said today Mexico should never again stage a major international sporting contest.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) Johnny Bucyk, nine days short of his 35th birthday, celebrated early today by scoring three goals and leading the Boston Bruins to a 6-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues in the opening game of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup championship series.

Elizabeth of New Jersey, trailing by 1-0 at the half, came back strongly in the second period to defeat Croatia of Los Angeles, 2-1, and capture the United States Challenge Cup for the first time. The game was played at Randalls Island before more than 2,000 fans.

BOBBY FISCHER, an eighttime national chess cham pion, was outstanding in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, during the recent 10-board, fourround match between the Soviet Union and stars from the rest of the world. Fischer, on Board 2, dramatically triumphed over a former world champion, Tigran Petrosian, with two victories and two draws.

The Presiding Justices of the two Appellate Divisions here declared yesterday that conditions in the city's Criminal Court were deplorable and called for reforms with more staffing and "massive" new funding.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 A Pennsylvania crew that added audacity to ability, beat Harvard this morning by one length to retain the Adams Cup. It was the first of two meetings between the nation's strongest college crews and Penn's victory proved so convincing that the Red and Blue will be favored to beat Harvard again on Saturday in the Eastern sprint championships at Worcester, Mass.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 3 Richard S. Nye's Carina, out of the nearby Indian Harbor Yacht Club, was the winner on Long Island Sound today in the Riverside Yacht Club's annual "Tune-up" race for cruising yachts. There were 38 starters. The 48-foot aluminum sloop, new last year, covered a 15mile Division I course in 3 hours 46 minutes 56 seconds as a light northwesterly swung nearly 180 degrees during the race.

The opportunity exists to turn Floyd Bennett Field, which will close down as a Navy base, into a supplementary facility for civil aviation. There are problems of jurisdiction and still bigger problems of coordination with New York's two nearby major airports. But convenience, safety and congestion elsewhere require added facilities.

Eager to get in two games against the lowest club in the American League, the New York Yankees turned on their lights yesterday afternoon and played the Milwaukee Brewers under overcast skies through intermittent rain. Their determination paid off and they swept the double-header, 8-7 and 4-2, before 11,490 paid fans.

Merle Park, one of the Royal Ballet's top ballerinas, is so good an actress that it is almost possible to forget that her excellent dancing contributes equally to the entrancing effect of her dramatic roles. Both qualities, however, were very much in evidence Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House in Kenneth MacMillan's "Romeo and Juliet" when Miss Park and Donald MacLeary stepped into the title roles.
Calls for ending classes to allow college students to protest the widening United States involvement in Southeast Asia were echoed yesterday on campuses in many parts of the country.
One adman has decided to make a big change. Another one already has. A Connecticut-based agency is opening a New York showroom and a New York agency is opening its mouth.

CANNES, France, May 3 The 23d Cannes Film Festival opened last night. Its initial offering Marc Allegret's screen version of Raymond Radiguet's novel "Le Bal du Comte d'Orgel" took the gala premiere audience back to 1923. This was the year of the book's publication and that of its youthful author's death.
Riverside Church marked an anniversary yesterday. But the sparkle of birthdays and mortgage-burnings was lacking.
LOS ANGELES (AP) Bel Air, one of the most affluent residential sections of Los Angeles, has the lowest heart disease rate among 76 Los Angeles County areas studied by a university research team.

Three-quarters of the Legal Aid lawyers assigned to the city's Criminal Court about 75 lawyers went on strike yesterday, leaving dozens of defendants with no representation and dozens of others with hastily assigned private counsel or Legal Aid trainees.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 4 (AP) Two men fired on Israeli Embassy personnel today, killing one secretary and seriously wounding another.

Mick Moynihan scored 6 points to lead New York to a 13-8 victory over County Offaly yesterday at Gaelic Park in the Bronx before a crowd of 6,241 in the windup of their two game total-point-Gaelic football series.

An advertising man, concerned that "the country is falling apart," has formed an agency that will give a fifth of its time to organizations opposed to the war in Southeast Asia, racism, waste and poverty.
WASHINGTON, May 4 Mortgage prices held essentially steady at this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association said today.

The sharp drop in the stock market yesterday was undoubtedly a reflection of the uneasiness over the Cambodian affair and international reaction to it. The continuing downslide of the market in recent months, however, has conjured up, in the minds of some observers, the specter of "another 1929." Is there any justification for such an alarming comparison?
The head of a civil rights training organization predicted Sunday that the number of black elected officials in the nation would "more than double in the next four years."
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell to their lowest level in more than two years yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by almost five to one in slow trading.
Drew Middleton, European affairs correspondent of The New York Times, was named the newspaper's military correspondent yesterday.

DONALD BROOKS decided not to shilly-shally around. He simply made the most razzle-dazzle clothes in the most razzle-dazzle colors anybody could remember. And then he decided his own showroom wasn't big enough to show them off, so he hired a hall.
HOUSTON, May 4 (AP) The chief executive of the United States Steel Corporation said today higher steel prices are needed.
The Rent Guidelines Board has recommended to the City Council that rents in residential hotels here be permitted to rise by no more than 8 to 10 pee cent a year.

ELLICOTT, CITY, Md., May 4 The Federal Bureau of Investigation was asked today to join in a search for H. Rap Brown when the black militant leader failed to appear for the long-delayed start of his trial on Maryland charges of inciting rioting and inciting arson.

The tragic nature of the division of this country, exacerbated by escalation of the war, was underscored yesterday when four students were killed during a confrontation with National Guardsmen and police at Kent State University in Ohio.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 4 The engagement of Miss Deborah Morris Bent to Jerome Bowden Martin has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Horace Brook Bent of Bryn Mawr and Annisquam, Mass.
LOS ANGELES, May 4 The strike of Los Angeles schoolteachers has ended its third week with both sides apparently inching their way toward a settlement.

The Ford Motor Company and Thermo Electron, Inc., of Waltham, Mass., have announced the signing of a fiveyear agreement under which Ford will invest in the development of a prototype steam automobile engine.
After moving higher in morning and early afternoon trading, the London stock market slipped back to close only slightly above opening levels.

Chancellor Willy Brandt's effort to improve relations with West Germany's Communist neighbors was undertaken with the knowledge that it involved political risks as well as possible gains at home and abroad. But some unwelcome surprises are developing on the risk side, the latest being an administrative blunder that has weakened Mr. Brandt's essential coalition partner, Foreign Minister Walter Scheel.

WASHINGTON, May 4 President Nixon today deplored the deaths of four students at Kent State University and said they "should remind us all once again that when dissent turns to violence it invites tragedy."
PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska In biting, wind-driven snow, oil men of many companies here are drilling a succession of crooked wells.
DETROIT, May 4 New car sales warmed up in the final third of April, the car makers reported today, but even though they are better they aren't very good.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 5 Policemen cleared the Vietnam National National Pagoda and the Cambodian mission building during curfew hours early this morning.

GENEVA, May 4 The 23man board of Bernard Cornfeld's beleaguered mutual fund empire, Investors Overseas Services, was locked in a secret meeting for the third straight day today amid rumors that a group of European banks was being called on in a rescue operation.

The presidents of 37 colleges and universities urged President Nixon yesterday to "demonstrate unequivocally your determination" to end promptly the United States military involvement in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, May 4 The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to increase Social Security benefits by 5 per cent for some 25.5 million Americans, effective next Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, May 4 The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of a 1967 law that permits any private citizen to stop mail order companies from sending advertisements that he considers "erotically arousing or sexually provocative."

WASHINGTON, May 4 Many members of Congress, in both parties, now are reacting to President Nixon's re-escalation of the Vietnamese war with as much anger as the "doves" used to direct at Lyndon B. Johnson. One useful but limited result is already apparent.

QUEBEC, May 2 The new Premier of Quebec, whose election victory on April 29 was a defeat for the province's separatists, regards them nevertheless as "a fact of political life" that must be given due recognition.
CAIRO, May 4 (Reuters) An Egyptian military spokesman said today that air defend ers shot down an Israeli Skyhawk over the central sector of the Suez Canal.

Uneasiness over the United States involvement in Cambo-' dia and the bombing of North Vietnam, plus continuing uncertainty about the nation's business outlook, created a mood of deep pessimism on Wall Street yesterday and sent the securities markets into a tailspin.

A Federal judge signed a preliminary injunction order yesterday barring a merger of the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association.

HOMEWOOD, Ala., May 4 There are 50,000 people in this suburban city just over the mountain from Birmingham and most of them are white, middle-class folks who have never voted for George C. Wallace.

The University of Pennsylnavia's newly acquired status as the No. 1 power in intercollegiate rowing received recognition yesterday when the Red and Blue varsity was seeded No. 1 for Saturday's Eastern sprint championships on bake Quinsigamond at Worcester, Mass.

ATHENS, May 4 Eugenia Niarchos, the 44-year-old wife of Stavros Niarchos, the Greek shipping millionaire, died early today at Spetsopoula, her husband's privately owned islet 56 miles southwest of Athens.

WASHINGTON, May 4 Senator Edward M. Kennedy proposed today that a constitutional amendment, authorizing representation in Congress for the District of Columbia, be attached to the pending plan for direct election of the President.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Federal National Mortgage Association today shuffled some of its top officers in a move, A. Oakley Hunter, president of the association, said was in anticipation of completion of reorganization from a Government agency to a private corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 4 Secretary of Labor George P. Schultz told the Senate today that he had no ground for investigating or intervening in the United Mine Workers' election campaign last fall. He said that if the same circumstances were to present themselves again, he would pursue the same policy.

IN denouncing United States policy in Indochina at an unusual news conference yesterday, Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin indirectly also affirmed the division of functions that has marked the collective leadership of the Soviet Union since Nikita S. Khrushchev fell from power in 1964.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 Less than an hour after learning that their 19-year-old daughter had been shot to death by National Guardsmen at Kent State University, Arthur and Doris Krause and their 15-year-old daughter, Laurie, emerged from their home in outlying Churchill Borough this afternoon.

"We gambled and we got lucky," said Red Holzman, the coach of the miracle Knickerbockers, last night. "On another night, playing that gambling defense, we might have been killed."

Nine investors in Leeds Shoe, Inc., filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here seeking $15million in damages from Genesco, Inc., officials and former officials of Leeds, and underwriting concerns that include Goodbody Co. and Walston Co.

Seven Hunter College Students, suspended last week by Mrs. Jacqeline G. Wexler, president of the college, were reinstated last night by a judicial hearing board composed of four students and three faculty members.
Charles M. Trunz Jr., has been elected to the new post of executive vice president of the Horn and Hardart Company.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 4 With their bloody civil war nearly four months behind them, some Nigerians are beginning increasingly to think of politics, and the prospect of returning the country to civilian rule.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 4 Al Fatah reported tonight that nineteen men had been killed or wounded in a continuing battle in the northern Jordan valley.

A joint commission representing the Roman Catholic and Episcopal churches in this country issued a report yesterday declaring that as a result of recent ecumenical gains the "organic union" of the two churches now appeared to be a realistic possibility.
Long Island Railroad users faced more uncertainty this morning as a result of a union's threat yesterday to decide "on a day to day basis" whether to strike over a pension issue.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May. 4 (UPI) Hector Pilar, the jockey injured during a spill in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, will not be able to ride again for at least seven months, his physician said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 4 The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 1 today that laws that exempt church property from taxation do not violate the Constitution's prohibition against state support of religion.

MOSCOW, May 4 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin today assailed President Nixon for having sent American forces into Cambodia. He warned that the action might lead to a "further complication" in the international scene and a worsening of Soviet-American relations.

WASHINGTON, May 4 In his strongest criticism of the Nixon Administration to date, Senator Jacob K. Javits charged tonight that the threat of repression in the country was for the first time being "tolerated, if not actually condoned, at the highest level of our Federal Government."

Once again the voice of the buzz saw is heard in the woodland; the insatiable mouth of the bulldozer is chewing up the countryside.

Convenience food stores neighborhood markets that stay open long hours should doube in number by 1975, according to the president of the nation's second-largest chain, Jackson-Atlantic, Inc., United Press International reports.

ALTAMONT, N.Y., May 4 There is a hesitancy about discussing the war in vietnam in this little upstate village of 1,500 people. There is, even more, a feeling of futility in even trying to understand what is involved.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The House passed and sent to President Nixon today legislation to provide free or reduced price school lunches to all of the eight million poverty area children estimated to be eligible.

The teamsters in Cleveland ended their wildcat walkout yesterday, but drivers in sections of New England joined the ranks of striking truckers in the Midwest and California, The Associated Press reported.
TRENTON, May 4 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill signed into law today a measure creating a state mortgage finance agency. He said that he would seek an immediate court test of the statute's legality.

A collegiate touch was added to the opening of the jumping season at Aqueduct yesterday when Chris Elser, a Johns Hopkins freshman, scored aboard The Critter with a superb riding performance that at least entitled him to a Ph.D. in judging pace.

The printers union announced early this morning that it had rejected as "still insufficient" an offer by the city's major newspapers of a three-year contract that would have rasied printers' wages by 31.85 per cent by the start of the third year.
WASHINGTON, May 4 The International Monetary Fund reported today that it bought no gold from South Africa in April.

THE idea that a four-four trump fit is automatically more desirable than alternatives such as five-three or five-four has only limited validity. It is true that the four-four fit will sometimes permit an extra trick to be made because the five-card suit makes a discard or two possible in the opposite hand, but there are other considerations.
New York, which is host to the world's largest diplomatic community, merged the city's separate programs for the consular corps and United Nations delegates into a single service yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 A nationally known population expert decried today what he termed the efforts of some "angry ecologists" and "Johnnycome-lately's" to scare the nation into Cleaning up the environment and slowing American population growth.

A plan that will bring Dow Jones Co. which has been servicing mainly the business and financial fields into the daily general newspaper publishing field was announced here yesterday.
The Music From Marlboro series closed its fifth New York season last night at Tully Hall with chamber music performance as nearly perfect as these ears can imagine.

Mrs. Kathryn von Stade Perry, the daughter of Mrs. F. Skiddy von Stade of Westbury and Southampton, L.I., and the late Mr. von Stade, who was a trustee of the New York Racing Association, was married on Friday to John H. Krumpe, a vice president and controller of the association.

The completely subjective experience that basketball can be was demonstrated vividly last night as the New York Knickerbockers, after losing Willis Reed through injury, made up a 16-point deficit and defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 107100.

Bond prices dropped sharply yesterday, raising interest rates to records higher even than last December.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The amount of consumer installment credit outstanding increased by $198-million, seasonally adjusted, in March, the Federal Reserve reported today. It was the smallest advance in almost three years.

Scholars. The President announced the selection of 10 outstanding high school seniors as Australian science scholars for 1970. After being honored here early this month, they will join student delegations from Britain and Japan in Honololu and travel to Sydney, Australia, to attend an international science school. The theme of this year's school is pioneering in outer space. Classes will be held from Aug. 24 through Sept. 4.

ROME, May 4 Guests at the opening of an art show at the American Academy here tonight found all but a few exhibits covered with black cloth in a protest against United States military intervention in Cambodia.
Walter Cronkite will be honored Monday when the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation holds a benefit dinner at the Hilton as part of the A.C.L.U.'s 50th-anniversary celebration.

MOSCOW, May 4 In this capital where official events are often preceded by rumors about them, there were no advance hints today that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin would hold the first news conference by a Soviet head of government here in almost 10 years.

SOMERSET, England, May 4 (Ap) Sir Robert Thompson, a British expert on guerrilla warfare and a special adviser to President Nixon, said today that the United States had no alternative to the thrust into the Fishhook area of Cambodia.

WASHINGTON The Coast and Geodetic Survey has announced the completion of the first phase of a Federal geodetic survey of Mississippi's Gulf coast and islands off Mississippi and Alabama. Additional surveys in the area are planned for next year.

The sharp decline in stock prices is forcing banks and brokers to make an increasing number of margin calls on their customers, but forced sales of collateral to meet outstanding debts do not appear up until now at least to have been sufficiently large to have been a significant factor in the market break.

The United Fruit Company said yesterday it had received notice from the Federal Trade Commission indicating that the government agency considers the acquisition of United Fruit by the AMK Corporation as illegal.
YONKERS, May 4 (UPI) Six pacers were named today as starters for the $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway on Friday.
Investor fears over the intensified war in Indochina sent stock prices spiraling downward yesterday in the biggest single-day break since the assassination of President Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963.

New York's Secretary of State, John P. Lomenzo, accepted the designation petition of Arthur J. Goldberg as a Democratic candidate for Governor yesterday on grounds that no public record had been produced to show he did not meet the fiv-year residency requirement for the office.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today a ban on 60 pesticides for some uses on food and livestock feed crops.

FORT BELVOIR, Va. Letters from around the world have poured into the mail chute labeled "The Army Sounding Board for the Individual Soldier" here.

There will be an old fashion shootout Saturday when Cornell and Brown meet in Ithaca, N.Y., to decide the Ivy League lacrosse championship.
A warning that time is about to run out on the American merchant marine has been issued with the publication of a new book, "The U.S. Merchant Marine Today Sunrise or Sunset?"

Dr. David Wdowinski, a psychoanalyst who was a leader of the resistance fighters in the Warsaw Ghetto, collapsed and died Sunday in Tel Aviv after delivering a speech marking the 27th anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising. He was 73 years old and lived at 27 West 72d Street.

Miss Irene Hirsch and Robert F. Lucia planned to be married in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, but their plans were continually frustrated by flights that were booked full. and the long waiting-period required between the issuance of the license and the ceremony.

There was no indication that the commodities markets were affected to any great extent by the developments in the stock market yesterday. Volume continued at about the same pace it had been running lately and price movements varied in traditional patterns.

Sam Rosenthal, a large-volume dress manufacturer and a pioneer in the import of popular-priced women's knitwear from France, died yesterday after a long illness at his home, 22 Oakdale Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 60 years old.

Six East Harlem residents participated in a sit-in at Liberal party headquarters at 165 West 46th Street yesterday to protest the party's endorsement of Frank G. Rossetti for re-election to the State Assembly in the 68th Assembly District.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) Britain's monetary reserves increased by $50.4-million last month. Despite heavy repayment of foreign debts, to reach $2.76-billion, the Treasury announced today.

Mrs. Theresa Chalmers Baker, widow of Frederick Charles Baker, a former president of the American Potash and Chemical Corporation, died, apparently of a stroke, at a friend's apartment here Thursday. She was 82 years old, and lived in Stuart, Fla. She had a summer residence in Shaftsbury, Vt., Her husband, who retired in 1946 to establish a plantation at Stuart, died in 1961.
