Robert H.Finch, secretary of Health, education and Welfare, predicted yesterday that Federal expenditures for the nation's well-being will some day overtake spending for defense.
HOUSTON, May 4 (AP) Jim Bouton stopped Chicago on six hits and scored two runs tonight, pacing the Houston Astros to a 7-2 victory while extending the Cubs' losing string to four games.

DETROIT, May 4 The American automobile industry will show the results of its research on the air bag, a radical but yet untried safety system, to the car makers of the world at a conference next week.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 4 For the third annual Romantic Festival sponsored by Butler University at Clowes Hall, there have been some changes. Those changes are not in the musical approach the festival continues to present all kinds of forgotten music of the 19th century but in the forces involved.
Student sentiment in favor of shutting colleges to protest the United States role in Southeast Asia gained strength and increasing faculty support in the New York metropolitan area yesterday.

A report on the alleged Songmy massacre of Vietnamese civilians by United States soldiers won the 1970 Pulitzer prize in international reporting yesterday for Seymour Hersh, a free-lance reporter whose article was circulated through the Dispatch News Service.
If mathematical progression means anything, Nolan Ryan will pitch a four-hitter and walk eight batters tonight when the Mets meet the Los Angeles Dodgers in the opener of an eight-game home stand.

Cole Porter's sole symphonic composition a ballet score that was believed lost for more than 40 years will come to life again as a new ballet in the American Ballet Theater's new season. It will receive its premiere at the New York State Theater on July 1.
Steel production last week took the sharpest drop of 1970, mainly because of a trucking strike, industry sources indicated yesterday.
POOLE, England Colin Honey, governor of Dorchester Prison, reports that security at the prison has been tightened after a prisoner walked out through the main gate with visitors.
TWO organizations protesting the midi and advocat ing freedom in skirt lengths moved their operations onto the fashion industry's doorstep yesterday.

Time, Inc., the magazine and book publishing enterprise, denied yesterday charges that it discriminated against women employes on its editorial staff. The number of women working as editors, writers and correspondents for its magazines, it asserted, "has risen steadily over the past few years and we have every hope and expectation that this trend will be continued."

THIS year's Kentucky Derby made about as much impact on public consciousness as a soggy towel dropping to a locker-room floor. No dent. The emotional appeal was missing, except for that minority who had a few bob riding on the nose of the upset winner Dust Commander. His background had little distinction and his owner, trainer and jockey were comparative strangers.
ISLETA, N.M. (AP) For the first time in, their ancient histry, women at Isleta Indian Pueblo now can vote in pueblo elections.

Two tracks of American track and field athletes will leave this week for meets overseas.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 4 Senior United States military and civilian officials here are beginning to scale down their definitions of success for the four-day-old American-South Vietnamese sweep into the Fishhook area of Cambodia.
KENT, Ohio, May 4 Four students at Kent State University, two of them women, were shot to death this afternoon by a volley of National Guard gunfire. At least 8 other students were wounded.

Disruptive students forced the closing of Samuel J. Tilden High School in Brooklyn yesterday after they set off stench bombs in the cafeteria, overturned benches, tables and chairs and broke windows. One 16-year-old girl was arrested after she kicked and bit a policeman.

DETROIT, May 4 The American Motors Corporation plunged deeply into the red in the March quarter, reporting today a net loss or $10,067,000 or 41 a share, contrasted to a net income of $735,000, 4 cents a share, a year before.

JERUSALEM, May 4 Israeli military authorities announced today that an Israeli patrol surprised and killed 21 armed Palestinian infiltrators shortly after they crossed the Jordan River into Israeli-controlled territory last night.

HAIFA, Israel, May 4 (AP) Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said at a student rally here today that the Israeli Government "is ready to re-establish an un conditional and unlimited ceasefire even if this will enable Egypt to reorganize and put up SAM-3 missile sites."
KANSAS CITY, (AP) The Kansas City Art Institute paid $25 for one million bottle caps collected by third-grade pupils, and the caps may appear in pop art.

Four men, including two clerks in major brokerage firms, were arrested by detectives from the Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday and charged with crimes stemming from the theft last month of $575,000 worth of negotiable bonds.
ANTHONY GAUBIS, an investment adviser who had the good sense as a young lad to be bearish in early 1929 and then bullish in 1937, thinks the days of gloom and doom are about over.

President Nixon's sudden extension of the Vietnam War into Cambodia, without consent of Congress and against the advice of many members including a majority of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, brings sharply to the fore a constitutional crisis that has been long in the making.

ATLANTA, May 4 Miss Marion Knauss, an editorial writer for The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times, and Nelson Poynter, board chairman of the Times Publishing Company there, were married here early this morning at the home of the bridegroom's daughter, Mrs. George Feaver. The ceremony was. performed by the Rev. Robert Thomason, a chaplain at Emory University.
The Board of Education moved yesterday to keep disturbances from disrupting its public meetings, as they have in recent months.

CHARLES LUDLAM has apparently seen, adored, laughed at, been scared to death by and memorized every mad-doctor movie ever made. "Bluebeard," which he wrote, directed and starred in, is a distillation of that ghoulish genre, and serves successfully as both a loving paean and a lunatic parody.

ATHENS, May 4 The military-backed regime fulfilled a pledge to the French Government today by releasing Jean Sarrakis, a Greek-born Frenchman sentenced to 18 years in prison by an Athens court-martial on April 12 on charges of sedition and setting off bombs.
The decline in the stock market has affected the timetable for the start of a professional track and field tour, its organizers said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee complained today that the Nixon Administration, by sending American troops into Cambodia "without the consent or knowledge of Congress," was usurping the war-making powers of Congress.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) The Leeds United soccer club was fined $12,000 a British record today for fielding weak teams in league games at the peak of its hectic season.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 4 (AP) The Apollo 13 commander, Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. of the Navy, said today that the mission might have matured the space program in the eyes of the average American.

THE Environmental Defense Fund, Inc. a nonprofit organization of conservationists, scientists and lawyers dedicated to the protection of our environment, needs assistance in its efforts to obtain working funds through public membership.

The Sperry Rand Corporation had the highest revenues and earnings for any quarter in its history in the three months ended March 31, lifting the company's results for the year ended March 31 to records, J. Frank Forster, president, reported yesterday.

A Florida automobile thief accidentally abducted a 4-yearold girl, but released her minutes later when he apparently discovered her sleeping in the back seat. The Palm Beach Post-Times of West Palm Beach reports.

The first extensive, long-term study comparing the incidence of birth defects with parental use of LSD has concluded that the drug "must be seriously considered as a possible mutagen" an agent that produces genetic changes in cells.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Simmons Company of New York City, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of hospital furnishings, was accused by the Justice Department today of price-fixing.

ST. LOUIC, May 4 (AP) Scotty owman, coach of the St Louis Blues, said today that his stratedy to stop Bobby Orr would remain in effect for tomorrow night's second game here in the best-of-seven National Hockey League Stanley Cup title series against Boston. Coach Harry Sinden of the Bruins isn't complaining about it one bit.

WASHINGTON, May 4 Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, announced today that hearings would begin next Monday on trade legislation the first move in what could be a momentous struggle over the nation's trade policy.

WHEN the British playwright Joe Orton was murdered in 1967 at the age of 34, one of the most promising talents of our time passed from the Englishspeaking theater. Last night at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater, Orton's last play, "What the Butler Saw," had its hilariously bitter American premiere.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 4 (UPI) The Oakland induction center, which processes draftees for all of Northern California and a portion of Nevada, says more than half of the young men ordered to report fail to show up and 11 per cent of those who do show up refuse to serve.
The Monsanto Company anannounced yesterday it would raise prices by 50 cents a pound on vanillin, a flavoring agent used in soft drinks, candy and ice cream.
Political demonstrations, such as the one that resulted in the deaths of four students yesterday, are a relatively new phenomenon on Kent State University's attractive 790-acre campus.
The board of directors of the University Settlement House has reversed a decision to give the institution's annual humanitarian award to Governor Rockefeller.

VIENNA, May 5 An official of a Czechoslovak uranium plant hijacked a twinengined company plane today and forced the pilot to fly to Austria. He stabbed the pilot with a penknife, causing serious injuries.

BONN, May 5 Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany confronted Chancellor Willy Brandt today with a list of reservations about their Planned meeting two weeks hence raising doubts about its chances of success.

WASHINGTON, May 5 Army instructions on the use of "deadly force" in a riot situation are explicit such force is justified only by "extreme necessity" and when "lesser means have been exhausted or are unavailable."

BETHPAGE, L.I., May 5 (UPI) About 15,000 employes of Grumman Aerospace Corporation received a brief holiday from work today and the three Apollo 13 astronauts, who were visiting the Plant here, told them they deserved it.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 5 All of Indiana's 11 incumbent United States Representatives seven Republicans and three Democrats appeared today to be assured of places on the November ballot.

What does one do to repay the hospitality of a Moroccan princess? Should the question ever arise, one might note that the Princess in question, Lalla Nezha, and her husband, Ahmed Osman, Moroccan Ambassador to the United States, were obviously impressed with the "thank you" gesture showered on them Monday night by Mr. and Mrs. Jean Louis of Los Angeles.
Richard Chamberlain, best known as television's "Dr. Kildare," will be assisted in his nexte role by some of Britain's outstanding actors.

BOSTON, May 5 (UPI) The Treasurer of Harvard University supported General Motors today in its fight with Ralph Nader. The Harvard official said that in Nader's proposal to reorganize the G.M. board of directors was "an opening wedge in a movement to socialize the traditional American way of doing business."

The abrupt decision by the Senate Finance Committee to send back to the Nixon Administration its proposal far reforming the nation's malfunctioning welfare system must not be allowed to prevent approval of all reform at this session of the Congress. The need for reform is too great.
SAMUEL BECHETT'S "Endgame" is an apt mate for the Open Theater's own "Terminal." "Terminal" deals with death, "Endgame" with living death, or deathly living, or something deadly in between.

A French and a Latin American publisher are forming a partnership to publish a business magazine to be distributed solely in Europe. Each monthly issue will be published in separate Italian, German, English and French editions.

The City Center of Music and Drama has set up an "emergency office" to offer noninterest loans, legal assistance and strike information to all employes of the State Theater and the ballet who have been idled by the 16-day strike by the orchestra of the New York City Ballet.

The city's Commissioner of Investigation acknowledged yesterday that the city-owned Chrysler assigned to him was involved in a collision while he was driving it on a holiday outing with his family in Vermont last February.
WASHINGTON, May 5 Federal and city authorities acted swiftly today to smooth the way for an antiwar rally scheduled here this Saturday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 5 (Agence France-Presse) The pro-Communist Pathet Lao has put up posters at Saravane, a major southern Laotian town, warning that its forces would attack shortly, military sources reported here today.

YONKERS, May 5 Just as Ed Parker, the racing secretary, had promised, there will be eight starters in Friday night's $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway. It must be reported, though, that Parker, in making good his avowal to have a complete field for the 1 -mile race, did not leave himself too great a margin of safety.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Savings bond redemptions exceeded sales by $80-million last month, the 17th consecutive month of net decline, the Treasury Department said today.

Three Martinis staggered out of the gate in the feature race at Acqueduct yesterday and those in the crowd of 26,555 who had made him the favorite just about gave up hope of victory. For the race was only a five-furlong sprint for 2-yearolds and the chance of acquiring momentum in such a short race is remote.
Volkswagen car sales fell 3.5 per cent in the United States market last month, while Renault and Mercedes-Benz sales increased, the companies reported yesterday.

An independent study of Congressional ethics, released yesterday, has found that there is "significant room for improvement " It recommended that Senators and Represen tatives be required, among other things, to stop practicing law and, if they hold stock in banks, to stay off Congressional banking committees.
WASHINGTON, May 5 The head of the Naval Arctic Research Laboratory has warned an Alaskan Senator that the proposed trans-Alaska oil pipeline might break and wreak great damage to the environment.

Two students and two former students of Columbia University interrupted their trial yesterday and pleaded guilty to criminal contempt of court for violating injunctions against disruptive acts on the campus.

Registration for Fresh Air Fund vacations has started at more than 70 cooperating social agencies and hospitals here as the 93-year-old philanthropy prepares to send 18,200 deprived city youngsters on free country vacations this summer.
Foreign exchange markets remained stable and quiet here yesterday despite the recent plunge on Wall Street.

PARIS, May 5 Edward Heath, the British Conservative party leader, said in a speech here today that Britain should join the European Common Market only "on terms which are clearly and visibly beneficial in the long term."
A proposal for an amnesty period for those with parking tickets 30 days during which cut-rate payments would be accepted was passed yesterday by the City Council.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has made little progress on its contractual problems in four major Government programs, Daniel J. Haughton, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Burbank, Calif. However, he added, he is confident that the difficulties, "one way or another, will be solved."

PRAGUE, May 5 (AP) Leonid I. Breshnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, arrived today at the head of a delegation that will sign a new 20-year Soviet-Czechoslovak treaty of friendship and mutual cooperation.

AFTER more than 40 years of complacent acceptance of "standard" bidding methods, tournament players in this country are now showing signs of believing that there may after be something in the idea of playing one club as a strong forcing bid.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger charged yesterday that the new subway cars the city has ordered "are potential death traps" on the basis of a report that he said the Transit Authority had "suppressed."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, (AP) May 5 Than Ngoc Chau, a National Assembly member and foe of President Nguyen Van Thieu, was convicted unconstitutionally by a military court, South Vietnam's Supreme Court ruled today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Wednesday, May 6 George C. Wallace failed to win a majority of the votes cast in yesterday's Democratic gubernatorial primary and will meet Gov. Albert P. Brewer in a runoff election on June 2.

The RCA Corporation told about 900 stockholders yesterday that "the era of most vigorous expansion" in color television and broadcasting has passed. At the same time, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and president, predicted that by the end of the year the company should be "in a firm No. 2 position" in the computer industry.
Earl R. Bramblett has been appointed vice president of General Motors in charge of the personnel staff. He succeeds Louis G. Seaton, who is retiring after 42 years of service.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 5 Mrs. Seymour R. Robinowitz has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ronnie Robinowitz, to John Henry Jankoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Janwoff of New York and Groton-onHudson.

WASHINGTON, May 4 A study by Government economists shows that when relatively few companies dominate the market for a specific line of food products, they are able to increase their profits significantly by increasing their advertising.

ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP) Eddie Westfall and Derek Sanderson scored two goals each and Bobby Orr and Phil Esposito established Stanley Cup scoring records as the Boston Bruins routed the St. Louis Blues, 6-2, tonight in the second game of the Stanley Cup hockey finals.
Frank S. O'Hara, a former Queens realtor and appraiser, died at the Point Pleasant (N. J. Hospital Monday of an embolism. He was 80 years old and lived in Lakewood, N. J.

WASHINGTON, May 5 In this sensitive and dangerous hour it would probably be a mistake to act on the assumption that President Nixon is determined on some grand new strategy of smashing his way to victory in Indochina.
Robert P. Koenig, president and chief executive officer of the Cerro Corporation, told the annual meeting here yesterday that first-quarter earnings had fallen 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 5 The Defense Department, which announced yesterday that it had terminated large-scale air raids against three areas of North Vietnam, said today that a fourth area had also been attacked.

PRINCE GEORGE, British Columbia (Canadian Press) While flying here from Fort Nelson, British Columbia, with two passengers. Warren Enzler of Kenai, Alaska, could not reach anyone on his radio and thought he was off course.
DUBLIN, May 3 The day the money stopped, many of Ireland's 900 bank branches were crowded with worried customers.

IN the past, in times of crisis, Norodom Sihanouk has abdicated as King, resigned as Premier and has gone into political exile to convince his friends and enemies that he is needed in Pnompenh to restore order. Also in the past he has always re-emerged in control.
Piping Rock, the Long Island district champion, defeated its second team, 11 -3 yesterday and took a big lead in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub matches.
OAKLAND, Calif., May 5 The Yankees' winning streak came to an unlovely end tonight as the Oakland Athletics headed them their worst defeat of the season, 11-3.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 5 (UPI) President Nguyen Van Thieu ordered all schools in the Saigon area closed tonight because of unrest among South Vietnamese students.
YARMOUTH PORT, Mass., May 5 Dr. Loren C. Petry, a teacher at several universities, died Sunday in his home here. He was 82 years old.

Twelve members of the production staff of National Educational Television were discharged Monday, and more dismissals are reported to be planned in a long-predicted realignment of public television in New York.

The annual Sidney Hillman Foundation awards of the Amalagamated Clothing Workers of America for outstanding achievements in 1969 in mass communications have been awarded to a free-lance writer, a reporter, a television producer and a Congressman.

LOUISVILLE, May 5 (AP) The Indiana Pacers survived a third-period rally by the Kentucky Colonels tonight and gained a 111-103 victory. The triumph gave the Pacers a 3-1 advantage in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division playoff.
LONDON, May 5 (AP) Sir Tom O'Brien, head of the biggest trade union in the British entertainment industry, died today after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
ALBANY, May 5 Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill creating the State Nature and Historical Preserve Trust, his office announced today.

JERUSALEM, May 5 The Israeli Navy today gave a glimpse of its fleet of swift missile boats equipped with an Israeli-developed surface-tosurface missile, the Gabriel. A full display is expected to be seen Monday, when Israel celebrates her 22d Independence Day.
Trading in a new world sugar futures contract, known as the No. 11, was started yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange for delivery in July, 1970, and subsequent months.

THAT muffled sound in the distance is the beat of drums. It will grow louder in a few weeks. The Can-Am people are resuming where they left off last fall, when the message was "Wait till next year." The hope then was that 1970 would bring some competition for the ...

DEER PARK, L.I., May 5 Vladimir Heifetz, a pianist, conductor and composer, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack Sunday, while accompanying Sidor Belarsky in a concert here. He was 76 years old and lived at 351 West 24th Street, New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 5 There is increasing evidence that Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird had serious misgivings about the use of American troops in Cambodia. And there are many indications that President Nixon's war decisions in the last two weeks have been reached in an atmosphere of confusion as well as dissension.
"Money is very tight today, probably as tight as you and I have ever seen in our business careers," said Barton A. Cummings, an ad man who remembers back to 1925.
SNOUL, Cambodia, May 5 "This is a reconnaissance in force to find out what's in there and also, if possible, to take the town without destroying it."

An agreement for the recapitalization of the Hamilton Life Insurance Company of New York, which the State Insurance Department found to be insolvent in a review two years ago, was announced here yesterday by Richard E. Stewart, State Superintendent of Insurance.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., May 5 The president of predominantly Negro South Carolina State College, where three students were killed by the police two years ago, sent a telegram of sympathy today to the president of Kent State University.

MADRID, May 5 (Reuters) Four American Davis Cup players have engaged the former team captain, Donald Dell to manage their tennis affairs as a group. The four are Arthur Ashe, Bob Lutz, Stan Smith and Charlie Pasarell.
NEW HAVEN, May 5 Defense motions for an immediate pretrial hearing on the suppression of state's evidence in the Black Panther murder-kidnapping case were denied today.

PARIS, May 5 Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann said today that a speech made by Charles de Gaulle in Pnompenh, In 1966, when he was President, calling for the withdrawal of American forces from Indochina "contained something of an advance reply to the speech of President Nixon."
New York State Democrats, badly divided in 1968 on the war in Vietnam, united yesterday in an unusual drive to press for an end to the United States intervention in Cambodia.

Can Willis Reed play tonight for the New York Knicks against the Lakers in Los Angeles? Can the Knicks repeat, without him, the miraculous victory they scored at Madison Square Garden Monday night? Can the Lakers pull themselves together after spurning such a golden opportunity Monday?
OTTAWA, May 5 (Canadian Press) The Prices and Incomes Commission announced today that it will review increases in prices for coffee, rubber tires, fine papers and duplicating services and supplies.
JACKSON, Miss., May 5 The Roman Catholic and Episcopal Bishops of Mississippi backed today the newly announced goal of "full communion and organic union" of the Anglican and Catholic communions.
The worst bear market since the Depression clawed its way yesterday into the lowest territory since August, 1963, as stock prices kept falling along a broad front.

Dr. Paul Birdsall, a former history professor at Williams, College, and an employe of the Central Intelligence Agency, died Saturday of a heart attack at a hospital in Christiansted, in the United States Virgin Islands. He was 70 years old, and had lived in Christiansted since retiring from the C.I.A. in 1962.
A 24-year-old actor whose death marked a bizarre and tragic replay for many of his friends and colleagues will be buried today.

A plastic bottle being tested by the Pepsi-Cola Company in Las Vegas, Nev., has proven "extremely successful" and Pepsi plans to proceed with plans to produce and use it extensively next year, a spokesman said yesterday.
An alliance of 15 national organizations was created yesterday with the aim of "finding new ways and processes to reduce crime and create a fairer and more effective criminal justice system."

TRENTON, May 5 A young black minister has been awarded $500 in compensation for the "psychological trauma" he suffered when a Montclair landlord refused to rent an apartment to him because of his race.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, May 6 Gov. James A. Rhodes held a slim and inconclusive lead over Representative Robert Taft Jr. early today in Ohio's Republican Senate primary election after eight hours of a slow ballot count.

The Philadelphia Orchestra's final local program of the season last night in Philharmonic Hall was conventional enough, but gave pleasure for the beauty of the playing. Under Eugene Ormandy's direction there were, to start off, vigorous and fulltoned performances of Beethoven's "Coriolanus" Overture and First Symphony.

IN an uncomprehending daze the crowd slowly headed for the exits at Madison Square Garden Monday night after the Knick-Laker playoff game. In essence, everyone was saying, "I still can't believe it." The shell-shocked Lakers couldn't believe it, either. But the jubilant Knicks could believe it. They had made it happen.

A National Airlines clerk whose hobby is drag racing is trying to make money at jt. A reservations agent tried a temporary meat-packing job but had to give up when she got to the liver. A copilot, grounded by the strike of the Air Line Employes Association against National Airlines, is temporarily selling brushes door to door in Miami.

Tens of thousands of students in dozens of educational institutions here and in adjoining states halted their studies yesterday to show their bitterness and anguish over the invasion of Cambodia and the killing of four Kent State University students.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 5 C.W. Post College won 12 of 18 events today to score a 9361 track and field victory over Adelphi University at Hickox Field.

Arthur J. Goldberg, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, called yesterday for the re-establishment of the "democratic-Liberal coalition" in this state to achieve victory over the Republicans in November.
It has been 25 years since the liberation of Auschwatz, of Buchenwald, of Bergen-Belsen 25 years since the Nazi concentration camps imposed the final solution of death on six million Jews.
GUILDFORD, England, May 5 (AP) Three California girls advanced today to the third round of the Surrey hard-court (clay) tennis championship.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 5 While Vietnamese Communist forces pushed into within 27 miles of Pnompenh today, the Government called on its troops to hold out 10 more days.
HOUSTON, May 5 Ben Hogan plans another comeback. In 1949, after a nearfatal automobile crash, the golfing experts said he would never be able to play golf again. They were wrong.

AT a time when the world seems a sick mess, there is perhaps a special consolation to be discovered in the linear and spatial mysteries of Paul Taylor. With his dance company, Mr. Taylor opened a week's season at the New York City Center last night.

The Environmental Defense Fund, a coalition of scientists and lawyers concerned with protecting the environment, began legal action yesterday seeking immediate action by the Federal Government to eliminate automotive lead pollution from the air.

The Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday record firstquarter earnings and the election of J. Paul Austin, president, 55 years old, to the additional office of chairman to succeed Lee Talley, 68 years old, who continues as a director.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz called on the Lindsay administration yesterday to block attempts by groups of landlords in the Gramercy Park area to convert brownstones to cooperatives without first making offers to tenants of the building.

Still smarting from the Chicago shambles of '68, and still hurting from the Presidential campaign, the Democratic party is moving toward badly needed reform of its system of selecting delegates for the national convention.

Luciano Berio's original plan for last night's Composers Showcase concert at the Whitney Museum had been to stage a new, chamber version of his theater piece "This Means That." Evidently something funny happened to it on the way to the museum. Instead, Mr. Berio conducted five of his better-known older works, with the assistance of that incomparable vocal magician Cathy Berberian, seven live instrumentalists and tape recorders.
HONG KONG, May 5 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, exiled former Cambodian Chief of State, announced in Peking today the formation of a new government.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 6 United States troops opened a fourth front in eastern Cambodia today, thrusting across the border at a point 60 miles northwest of Saigon, the United States command announced.
It took the Atlanta Braves 16 minutes last night to score seven runs in the second inning, after which they went on to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 12-6.
WASHINGTON, May 5 The Federal Reserve Board reduced today the margin requirements on stock purchases from 80 to 65 per cent, effective tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 The keynote speaker of the spring Joint Computer Conference. Sam Wyly, today charged the telephone industry with slowing the nation's economic and social growth by failure to provide adequate data-transmission facilities.

The United States economy is laboring under an inflation that has had damaging effect on consumers' real income, industrial profits and public and business confidence. While the war in Vietnam has not been the sole cause of the inflation, it has certainly intensified it.
The John Fernald Company production of "The Cherry Orchard" was unable to open last night at the ANTA Theater because its scenery had not been built by unionized workers.

Frank Willis, the last of the "Durham Mob" to have his case decided, pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of conspiracy and three counts of grand larceny in the 1968 theft of almost $400,000 from the Neighborhood Youth Corps.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 Secretary General Thant made a worldwide appeal today for an international meeting to seek peace in Indochina.

LONDON, May 5 Prime Minister Wilson expressed "apprehension and anxiety" today that the American intervention in Cambodia might go beyond the limits declared by President Nixon and bring a change in his policy of troop withdrawal from Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The nation's ranking health officer said today that the medical profession was entering an era in which doctors must provide their patients with more information, allowing those patients to use their own judgment on many things related to health and medical care.
CLEARWATER, Fla. (AP) A 21-year-old coed received her watch back and had her appendix removed in the same operation.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Women attired in everything from miniskirts to midifrocks filled the Senate Caucus Room today seeking equality with men under the Constitution.
A suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court here in an attempt to compel the state to lower the voting age to 18 years.

PARIS The French Government is convinced that United States entry into Cambodia has at least for the short-term future completely changed the international situation and set back a gradual inching toward political settlements in both the Middle East and Southeast Asia.

Dr. Philip H. Abelson, editor of the journal Science co-discoverer of the element neptunium and long a spokesman for American science, has been named to succeed Dr. Caryl P. Haskins as president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

GENEVA, May 5 A classic power struggle was under way as the chieftains of Bernard Cornfeld's Investors Overseas Services split over future policy objectives and the alliances to be made with outside interests at a marathon board meeting that was continuing through tonight.
NEWTOWN, Conn., May 5 Charles H. Fetter, founder and president of American Time Products, Inc., in New York City, died Friday at Danbury Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived on Ox Hill Road.
Dr. Peter Rogatz, the physician Mayor Lindsay had hoped would run the city's public hospital system, has turned down the position. He said he had "all kinds of personal reasons."
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals obtained a temporary injunction Tuesday barring strike activity or work stoppages at its shelters in the city and on Long Island.
Declining stock prices were instrumental yesterday in causing the postponement of a number of equity financings scheduled for sale this week.
Solomon E. Kalter, a clothing manufacturer, died Monday at his home, 507 Avenue F. Brooklyn. He was 65 years old.

The head of Typographical Union No. 6 said last night that the printers and the newspapers were still "very far apart" despite a new offer of 31.85 per cent in additional wages over three years, which he rejected early yesterday.

George Guve, a housing expert who as a vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, oversaw the construction of Peter Cooper Village, Stuyvesant Town and Parkchester, died of cancer at his home in Peter Cooper Village on Monday. He was 89 years old.
The latest scene in a violent Upper West Side story was enacted yesterday when three youths pleaded guilty to misdemeanors in Youth Part of Criminal Court.
A window has been designed by the Kawneer Company of Miles, Mich., to provide ventilation even in rainstorms with winds up to 110 miles an hour, the magazine Architectural Record reports.
State Supreme Court Justice Robert V. Sabatini died at the Long Beach, L.I., Hospital Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 58 years old, and lived at 412 East 115th Street.
WASHINGTON, May 5 The Senate Judiciary Committee voted 17 to 0 today to send the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Harry A. Blackmun to the Senate floor with a recommendation that it be confirmed.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that the Supreme Court, by conscious and deliberate inaction, had dodged its duty to pass on the question of the legality or illegality of segregated schools out side the South.

KENT, Ohio, May 5 Officials of the Ohio National Guard said today they were unable to produce evidence of sniper fire at the guardsmen who killed four Kent State University students here yesterday, but they said the soldiers had fired without orders because they feared for their lives.
A New York City policeman was charged yesterday with robbing a bank Monday in Elmont, L.I.

Clark, Dodge Co., Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Irving Lundborg Co. of San Francisco. Both companies are longtime members of the New York Stock Exchange and other exchanges.

The four students, including two women, killed by M-1 bullets fired by Ohio National Guardsmen, did not die on their campus because they were known to be committing acts of violence or engaging in illegal dissent. They were victims of panic, ineptness or worse on the part of National Guard officers and soldiers with loaded weapons almost as if Kent, Ohio, were Parrot's Beak, Cambodia.
Nolan Ryan returned to the human race last night.
Just as everything looked darkest and the stock market seemed headed nowhere but further down, the Federal Reserve Board acknowledged the strident call of Wall Street and ...

Sheila Sobel is specially skilled in producing the unexpected. She does not deal in the bizzarre nor in the spectacular theatrical effect but in the unusual configurations of the human form, in rather ordinary circumstances. She examines the day to day with the eyes of a visitor from a different galaxy. Last night at at the Cubiculo she presented "Island and After," a work in two parts for six girls and two men.

WASHINGTON, May 5 More than five months after the draft lottery drawing, Dr. Curtis W. Tarr, the new director of Selective Service, said this week he still could not predict with any certainty what the cutoff number in the lottery would be this year.

Dr. Gero von Schulze Gaevernitz, a former member of the Office of Strategic Services who helped to arrange the negotiations for Germany's surrender in Italy during World War II, died of a heart attack April 6 in the Canary Islands, where he had been recuperating from an earlier heart attack. He was 68 years old.
Some 3,500 Columbia University students attended a rally on campus last night that wound up with a march along Amsterdam Avenue to join students who had occupied the South Campus of City College.
A record in inbound international air travel was set in March at Kennedy International Airport.

DETROIT, May (AP) Louis G. Seaton, dean of the automobile industry's labor negotiators, will miss this year's bargaining between General Motors and the United Auto Workers for the first time since the mid-Nineteen-thirties.
JERSEY CITY, May 5 The police here arrested a 15-yearold boy today in connection with the bludgeoning of a telephone company worker Sunday night in downtown Manhattan.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that a special five-man committee investigating corruption in the Police Department would make "some recommendations" to him within the next two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 5 President Nixon sought to subdue mounting criticism from Capitol Hill today by giving Congressional committees what was described as a "firm commitment" that American troops would be withdrawn from Cambodia in three to seven weeks.

SOUTHBURY, Conn., May 5 Sooner or later almost everyone who comes into this small Pomperaug Valley town, with its white wooden Colonial churches, winding stone walls and hillside cemeteries of leaning tombstones, describes it as "sleepy."

SEVENTH AVENUE is having quite a flirtation with Paris these days. First off, there's the loving acceptance of longer clothes. ("Tout Paris is doing it," is the standard answer to the question of "Why long?".) Then there are the bun-at-the-nape hairdos surrounded by tiny braids, after Dior, and the Victorian sleeves and waistcinching belts after Saint Laurent.

WASHINGTON, May 5 The Chevron Oil Company was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of "knowingly and willfully" failing to install safety devices that, according to some Federal experts, could have prevented the fire and subsequent oil spill last winter at several of the company's wells in the Gulf of Mexico.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 Look magazine produced a former law secretary today to testify that Mayor Joseph L. Alioto once asked her employer to represent a man named in other testimony as the head of the Mafia in San Francisco.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 5 An international corps of young volunteers to serve abroad on United Nations development projects was proposed today by Secretary General Thant.
ATHENS, May 5 Judicial authorities continued official inquiries today into the death of Eugenia Niarchos, the 44year-old wife of Stavros Niarchos, the shipowner.
Mrs. John M. Woolsey, the widow of a United States District Judge, died yesterday at her home, 131 East 66th Street. She was 95 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a bidby a Negro-owned company to operate a charter bus service between Harlem and 19 Eastern states.
Big-store sales in New York City last month continued to reflect the slow trend of recent months.

Seven Hunter College students, suspended last week by Mrs. Jacqueline G. Wexler, president of the college, were reinstated Monday night by a judicial hearing board composed of four students and three faculty members.

High interest rates halted yesterday the sale of more than $300-million of corporate and tax-exempt bonds as concern over Cambodia and inflation continued to impede normal operations in the credit markets.
The American Stock Exchange took another beating yesterday as prices sank to their lowest levels in two-and-a-half years in quiet trading.

No further price increases are planned at his time by the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the country's largest producer of domestically minded copper, according to Frank R. Milliken, the company's president.
WASHINGTON, May 5 The defeat of Senator Ralph W. Yarborough in the Texas Democratic primary last Saturday has been greeted with mixed emotions by leading members of his party here.
BANGALORE, India, May 5 (UPI) India completed a Davis Cup upset over Australia today when Premjit Lall beat Dick Crealy, 8-6, 6-2, 6-2, in the Eastern Zone final for a 3-1 victory.

BOSTON, May 5 (AP) The prize money for the seventh annual United States professional tennis championship at the Longwood Club in nearby Brookline was increased today to $50,000, or $17,000 more than last year.

TORONTO, May 5 (Canadian Press) R.C. Berkinshaw, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Canada, Ltd., from 1952 to 1959, and former chairman of the company board, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 79 years old.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 5 (UPI) Trustees of the University of South Carolina voted unanimously today to keep the university in the Atlantic Coast Conference indefinitely.
The White House has decided to rewrite the Administration's welfare reform legislation somewhat less extensively than the Senate Finance Committee suggested last week.
HOW much is a shareholder entitled to know about his company? It's hard to say. But whatever the answer to the question, it is management who provides the answer when it comes to the annual report.
KENT, Ohio, May 5 None of the four Kent State University students killed on Monday by National Guard rifle fire was a revolutionary or a hard-core radical, according to many who knew them.
College students across the country stepped up their protests, demonstrations and strikes yesterday against widening United States military involvement in Southeast Asia.

Najeeb E. Halaby, the president and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday that the troubled airline must have access to domestic air routes if it is to become profitable again.

The second floor of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club at 283 Lexington Avenue, at 37th Street, will become a gallery next week for a show and sale of 100 paintings by members of the armed services. Proceeds will go to the artists, some of whom are hospitalized.
A rally limited to blue-chip leaders helped to check a furthey decline on the London stock market yesterday. But, over-all, prices again were lower at the close.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 (AP) Dust Commander, the Kentucky Derby winner, will leave tomorrow for Baltimore, where he may become a supplemental entry for the 13-16mile Preakness.

A Federal Court judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Federal Aviation Administration could not take disciplinary action against air traffic controllers who took part in a "sick-out" that ended last month, United Press International reported.

Nearing 51, an age she will attain without tears on May 18, Dame Margot Fonteyn is dazzling ballet audiences these nights at the "Metropolitan Opera House with the youthfulness of her renverses and her sissonnes and her grands jets. Her steps look so effortless.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 Wilt Chamberlain scored 45 points and got 27 rebounds tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers reduced the National Basketball Association's championship series to a single deciding game by beating the New York Knickerbockers, whose Willis Reed was unable to play because of a leg injury.
PARIS, May 6 North Vietnam and the Vietcong today called off the 66th plenary session of the Vietnam peace talks almost at the last moment.
Striking lawyers employed by the Legal Aid Society voted yesterday to return to work this morning, Steven Bernstein, chairman of the lawyers' negotiating committee, announced las night.

An average factory production worker's pay check in the metropolitan area has gone up in dollars but has lost 3.9 per cent in buying power in the last two years, including 1.9 per cent eroded in the last year.
BOSTON, May 6 (AP) The president of the striking Boston Teachers Union was sentenced to 30 days in jail and the union was fined $4,000 today after the union was found guilty of criminal contempt.
The Federal Trade Commission issued a proposed complaint yesterday challenging the AMK Corporation's acquisition of United Fruit Company in 1969 on the ground that it violated Federal antitrust laws.
LONDON, May 6 Will Owen, a former Labor party member of Parliament, was cleared today of charges that he had given Czechoslovak diplomats secret information from Parliamentary files.

College athletes have joined the campus protests against the widening United States military involvement in Southeast Asia. Individual teams at four eastern colleges Princeton, Columbia, Williams and Dartmouth have withdrawn from competition and several events have been canceled.
ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I. "If you can really cook well," Mrs. Ralph Wilkinson said, "you can cook under any and all circumstances."

TEHERAN, Iran, May 6 After three rounds of concentrated bargaining, the consortium of Western oil companies that export most of Iran's oil appeared today to have conceded virtually the whole of the Iranian demand for payments this year of $1,155,000,000. A brief statement from the Ministry of Finance here said the two sides had reached "complete agreement." No details or figures were officially given.
WESTFIELD, N.J., May 6 Oscar Wegelin, a bibliographer and former rare book dealer, died Sunday at his home here. He was 93 years old and lived at 149 Harrison Avenue.

A sculpture that is expected to be the largest freestanding stone carving of modern times has been commissioned by the Port of New York Authority for the plaza between the two superskyscrapers of the World Trade Center, now under construction.

The Wheatley Stable's Predictable and Mrs. Lawrence W. Knapp Jr.'s Royal Singal took the honors in the Comely at Aqueduct yesterday. The sevenfurlong event for 3-year-old fillies proved a popular one with owners and trainers and had to be run in two divisions.

TEL AVIV, May 6 Heckling students drove Dr. Nahum Goldmann off a campus platform today for the second time in a week. Dr. Goldmann, President of the World Jewish Congress, left the rostrum at Bar Ilan University in Ramat Gan today without having completed the first sentence of his lecture. Last week he abruptly left an auditorium at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem because of disturbances by students.

MILAN, Italy, May 6 Perseverance and plodding stamina paid off tonight as the Fiejenoord team from Rotterdam gained a 2 to 1 victory in overtime over Glasgow Celtic and possession of the European Soccer Cup.

An assistant corporation counfor the city, warning that increased pay demands by policemen threaten "the financial stability of the city," said yesterday that the recently approved contract between the city and the police on which the pay increases are based had not been officially ratified by the city.

Oil prospecting activities on the treeless North Slope of Alaska have so decimated the grizzily bears of that region, one of the last large reservoirs of the species, that Alaskan officials have eliminated this year's spring hunting season. The season would have run from May 15 to May 31.

More than 80 colleges across the country closed their doors yesterday for periods ranging from a day to the remainder of the academic year as thousands of students joined the growing nationwide campus protest against the war in Southeast Asia.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6 The First Battalion of Commandos of the Teaching Profession came unevenly to attention and presented arms, using World War I rifles.
Tom Seaver pitched his sixth straight victory last night as the New York Mets survived the wind, the cold and the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Six New York detectives have been indicted in connection with the alleged extortion of money from persons involved in narcotics.
Most stock markets abroad closed higher yesterday in what appeared to be mainly a technical reaction to the low price levels reached in recent sharp declines.
Futures prices of wheat and soybeans dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade while the prices of other grains also closed lower.

Asserting that rent control caused housing decay, the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, Inc., proposed a plan yesterday to increase rents in most of the city's 1.3 million controlled apartments.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had informally adopted a new procedure for obtaining early warnings of possible financial distress of member concerns. A Spokesman said a firm would be considered approaching a danger area when its capital ration reached one to 12.
Prudential-Grace Lines has announced the appointment of Edmund J. Camuti as executive vice president.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 "Ie's unconstitutional," Dave Rosenberg declared. "What are we supposed to say: Come see the girls with their clothes off? Or, see the uncovered girls?"
RABAT, Morocco (UPI) The Kingdom of Morocco, independent for 15 years, has a serious and seemingly insoluble problem a high rate of unemployment.
New York University Law School became a focal point yesterday for a coordinated national effort to mobilize student and faculty protests against the expanding war in Southeast Asia.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (UPI) The former luxury liner Queen Elizabeth, a tourist attraction at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is the basis of a bankruptcy petition filed at Federal District Court here. Keres defeated Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia by two wins and two draws. Only Bobby Fischer of the United States reached a similar plus, when he defeated the former world champion, Tigran Petrosian.

The American Brands, Inc., annual meeting here yesterday, was enlivened by a variety of subjects, ranging from marijuana, cyclamates, crushed cookies, pesticides, AM and PM juices, the Sunshine Bus, and acquisitions.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 9 A teacher who created a controversy in Phoenix by inviting a homosexual to speak to her sociology students charged today that members of her profession generally "are quick to judge a person negatively, based on surface impressions."

LAKE FOREST, Ill., May 9 Miss Leslie Meacham Hailand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Garfield Hailand Jr., and Thomas Glynn Walker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker of New Vernon, N.J., plan to be married on June 13.

LAYHILL, Md. With no trolley company hereabouts to even consider hiring them, 80 Washington area "juice fans" decided to become their own employers. The mini-streetcar railway that they have established and operate here as the National Capital Trolley Museum captures and preserves many of the delights of this fast disappearing mode of transportation.

BILLINGS, Mont., May 9 United States Senator, Mike Mansfield faces only token opposition in the Montana Democratic primary election June 2, and the state's two members of the House of Representatives, also Democrats, have no opponents.

NO experience in the theater is more distressing than the shock of seeing a revered masterpiece being butchered by a bad production. After the first few moments of startled, then indignant, disbelief, you want to pick up your coat, turn defiantly up the aisle and head out into the calming air of the street, where noise, filth, garish lights and jostling crowds are balm compared with the spectacle you have just witnessed.

DUBLIN In the heady days of the Irish rebellion, Eamon De Valera and his "Warriors of Destiny" (Fianna Fail) attacked the infant Irish Free State for accepting the British partition of Ireland. But in 38 years of almost continuous political domination, Fianna Fail has adjusted to the existence of Northern Ireland as part of Great Britain. It has officially committed itself to work for reunification by polite diplomacy of indefinite duration.

Dahle, who turned the whole valley into a museum for Norwegian memorabilia.

They are the solomon's seals, the bellworts, the mandarins and clintonias with yellow or green-yellow flowers. Additional colors are provided by the pink mandarins, blue Greek valerians and Virginia bluebells.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 9 The Berkeley Faculty Senate contends that the relationship between the University of California and the two nuclear research laboratories it operates for the Government is "antithetical to the purposes of a university dedicated to free exchange of knowledge." The faculty recommended by a vote on Monday that the relationship be severed when present contracts expire in 1972.

The dramatic and chaotic events of May 28 and 29, 1962, provide a classic example of a convulsive selling climax in the stock market. May 28 was a Monday since dubbed "Blue Monday" by historians and it came following a week of heavy losses and expressions of great concern by Wall Street leaders.

PETRONIUS'S "Satyricon" was about something. There were real people in it; relationships which, though farcical, mattered because they involved genuine feelings; and there was a plot. Encolpius the drifter's love for Giton, the young bisexual whore, and his rivalry over him with the stronger Ascyltus, is a sort of homosexual Roman "Lolita," pathetic as well as ludicrous, and, above all, recognizably human.

Whenever Bill Lee's unique New York Bass Violin Choir has given a concert in recent years, its program has usually included a few excerpts from Mr. Lee's folk opera, "The Depot." LONDON To most Europeans, I guess, America now looks like the most dangerous country in the world. Since America is unquestionably the most powerful country, the transformation of America's image within the last 30 years is very frightening for Europeans. It is probably still more frightening for the great majority of the human race who are neither Europeans nor North Americans, but are Latin Americans, Asians and Africans.
