George Washington High School will remain closed today while all other schools reopen, the Board of Education announced early today.

DALLAS, May 10 (AP) Betsy Rawls survived 30-milean-hour winds that blasted across the Glen Lakes Country Club course today, carding a two-under-par 69 to win the Dallas Civitan women's open golf tournament with a 54-hole total of 214.
The faculty-student senates of Columbia and New York universities jointly confronted New York City members of Congress yesterday with calls for ending the war in Southeast Asia.
OJAI, Calif., May 10 (AP) LaFayette R. Blanchard, former chief editor of Gannett Newspapers, died today of pneumonia. He was 81 years old.
SABAE, Japan Until a few weeks ago the 26 looms of the Yoshida textile mill, a small wooden shed on a quiet street lined with blossoming cherry trees, had been busily spinning out nylon fiber.
The Soviet Union, France, Egypt, Bulgaria and Greece won first-round matches yesterday and Italy took a lead in its opening round in European zone Davis Cup play.

Two Democratic hopefuls, despairing of being chosen, charged yesterday that the special Liberal party meeting tonight to fill two vacancies on its slate was "rigged" for Arthur J. Goldberg and Senator Charles E. Goodell.

Last month the unemployment rate climbed to 4.8 per cent up from 4.4 per cent in March and 3.5 per cent at the start of the year. There is cause for serious concern both over the speed of the rise in unemployment and over its composition.

When the Mannes College of Music holds its benefit at the Institute of International Education on Friday, the appetizer will be a Grieg sonata, the dessert will be a piano quartet by Gabriel Faure and the champagne will be, well, champagne.

WARSAW, May 8 Both Polish and West German officials involved in political talks between the two countries appear to feel that Poland will achieve West German acceptance of the Oder-Neisse line as a final boundary within a year.

LOS ANGELES, May 10 (UPI) The University of Southern California has approved a plan for students to drop out of classes and protest United States policies in Indochina without being penalized academically.

The Economic Development Council of New York City, an organization of businessmen concerned with urban problems, called yesterday for major changes in rent control to ease the city's housing shortage. It said the shortage represents a serious threat to economic growth and employment.
WASHINGTON, May 10 In the aftermath of the disorganized, almost spontaneous antiwar rally here yesterday, plans were being made here and elsewhere for further acts of protest.

Good to its word, the Interpublic Group of Companies, which last month said it would be going public, has taken the first step in that direction. It has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 It is the loss of his green bicycle that hurts him the most. For the bicycle was only two years old and not every boy in his school had one as nice. But, like most children of Asia, 13-year-old Tran Minh Hoang does not complain.
ROME, May 10 (AP) Pope Paul VI said today that the information media were making modern man's life "increasingly superficial and passive."

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate majority leader, cautioned the House today that failure to approve the vote for 18-year-olds could lead to a Senate filibuster and the death of the Voting Rights Act extension.

TORONTO, May 10 On the eve of what United States draft resisters and deserters in Canada hopefully predict will be a heavy summer influx of newcomers, two new Toronto committees to assist the exiles have been formed, one has disbanded and one is fighting an eviction notice.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)) Three American news correspondents two men and a woman were reported missing today after failing to return from a trip across the Cambodian border near Svayrieng.
A cast dominated by 17 policemen staged a play in the Police Academy on Friday and Saturday nights on the theme of corruption among law enforcement officials.

"Whitewash Is the Name of the Game" is the caption of a photograph distributed by the Penn Central that shows a cleanup team at work on one of the railroad's old cars used by Harlem Division commuters to Grand Central Terminal.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 10 Ch. Wildweir Sandwich Man, a 5-year-old Yorkshire terrier owned and handled by 18-yearold Frances Cohen of Baltimore, received the best-in-show honors among 1,596 dogs yesterday at the 25th annual Lancaster Kennel Club event.

HOUSTON, May 10 Gibby Gilbert, an obscure campaigner from Hollywood, Fla., won a three-hole, sudden-death playoff from Bruce Crampton of Australia for the top prize in the $150,000 Houston Champions international golf tournament today.

Miss Helene Diane Shulman was married here yesterday afternoon to Henry Roberts Kravis. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony in the chapel of Temple Emanu-El, where he was assisted by Rabbi Norbert L. Rosenthal of Tulsa, Okla.
RENO BEACH, Ohio For 40 years, George Frank has set his nets in Lake Erie each spring and has brought in up to $50,000 worth of white bass, perch and walleye.

The Lindsay administration plans to double the amount it spends fighting narcotics addiction, although officials say they have no firm figures on how many persons will be served or how well what is now being done works.

ROME The "Portuguese" no longer represent the serious threat to the prosperity of opera theaters in Italy they once did. They still cost money, of course, the more money the farther you travel south, but not nearly enough to endanger present-day budgets.
SEVERAL weeks ago, Nathan Brandt Jr. sat down at the dinner table and said to his son: "Tony, tonight we're going to have a little discussion about drugs."
Contract negotiations between the printers' union and the city's four major newspapers remained stalemated yesterday, although the positions of the parties were reported as not far apart.
Walter Philip Reuther went to work as a bench hand at the age of 16 and rose to become a labor leader who had a major impact on the economic, social and political affairs of his time.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 10 The flag in the center of the Lehigh University campus here flew at half-staff, and a few members of the all-male student body moved quietly among the visitors gathered around Packer Chapel seeking signatures for antiwar petitions to be sent to the White House. Otherwise, the serenity of the idyllic afternoon gave no hint of the troubles that beset the nation and the world.

A number of colleges in the metropolitan area some of which have been threatened with lawsuits by students seeking to attend classes will reopen today after shutting down because of protests against the war in Southeast Asia and the deaths of four students last week at Kent State University.

WASHINGTON, May 10 A committee of antiwar armed forces reservists said today that it would sue the Defense Department in an effort to force the expulsion of nine Senators and 50 Representatives from commissioned status as Reserve or National Guard officers.

The floats sparkled, the bands blared, bagpipes skirled and youngsters danced under a blazing sun as 70,000 men, women and children marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday to mark Israel's 22d anniversary as a nation.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (UPI) The United States command announced today that 33 Americans were killed and 30 injured last week as 21 helicopters were lost in the Indochina war.

ON Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House the Royal Ballet came up with what might well be its ideal program: Frederick Ashton's "La Fille Mal Gardee" and the final act of Rudolf Nureyev's re-staging of the old Petipa ballet "Raymonda." It is an explosive but beautiful combination.
Local and long distance operators for the New York Telephone Company staged a oneday work stoppage yesterday to put pressure on the company in a wage dispute.

IN a city of unusual faces, Jane Forth stands out. Hers is a cadaverous face, a high fashion face, half Garbo, half moon child. The lips are bright red, the pale cheeks rouged. The eyebrows are shaved off until only the beginnings looking like two a postrophes remain. The dark hair is slicked back with Wesson Oil to from a tight bun at the nape of the neck.
John C. Robbins, an oil company executive and former newspaperman and writer, has been named chief executive officer of Planned Parenthood-World Population.

A new type of traffic light designed to simplify complicated intersections, where motorists are often confused by a psychedelic nightmare of signs apparently telling them simultaneously to stop, go and turn, has passed muster in Newark.

The death of Walter P. Reuther is an even more substantial loss for the nation than it is for the labor movement. A social innovator of great creativity, he was the most zealous union proponent of the concept that labor must go forward with the community and not at the expense of the community.

Assemblyman Sidney A. Lichtman of the 44th District, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, died Saturday of pancreatitis in New York Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 1094 East 18th Street, Brooklyn.

Unless Congress takes action this week to block President Nixon's proposal for streamlining the Executive Branch of the government, an effective reform will automatically go into operation this summer. The plan was developed by an advisory council, drawing on the work of earlier commissions. The need to give more form to what has become an administrative sprawl is glaringly apparent. And the recommendations themselves appear to make excellent sense.

GENEVA, May 10 (UPI) Fire bombers believed to be political enemies of the Spanish chief of state, Generalissimo Francisco Franco struck today at planes of the Iberia Air Lines of Spain in four European cities in what appeared to be a concerted attack.
PARIS, May African and Algerian squatters in several of the worst slums in the Paris region this weekend sampled foie gras and other delicacies looted from the city's swankiest food store.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The Nixon family worshiped together at Mother's Day services in the White House after Mrs. Nixon got a big box of chocolate candy from daughters Julie and Tricia.

About 10,000 fans, many of whom wore "Jewish Power" buttons to celebrate Israel's 22d anniversary, saw the Israeli national soccer team play to a 4-4 tie with the New York All-Stars yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 10 When a businessman can't find a business to go into, he invents one. And that is exactly what Robert V. Drouillard did two years ago.
PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. (AP) Charlotte County may solve its hyacinth problem by turning it into chicken feed.
Airline operations at the three airports here are down 13 per cent this spring from l969, in an unusual downturn for an industry accustomed to setting records year after year.

The Print Festival, a supper dance, will be held on Thursday in Rockefeller Center's lower plaza. The American Printed Fabrics Council has taken over both Promenade restaurants, for the evening. A tent will be set up for dancing.
First basemen Richie Allen, St. Louis; Ernie Banks, Chicago; Orlando Cepeda, Atlanta; Lee May, Cincinnati; Willie McCovey, San Francisco; Wes Parker, Los Angees.

NEW HAVEN, May 10 Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University whose ouster has been suggested by Vice President Agnew, won a vote of confidence yesterday from the university's governing body.

It will be a long time before the full impact of the invasion of Cambodia and the death of four students at Kent State University can be assessed but it is already clear that student movements will be deeply affected. The students' role in American politics may be drastically changed.
In about two-thirds of the 50 states, drug abuse laws covering the possession of marijuana have been or are in the process of being revised to ease the penalties for first offenders.

Like many of the nation's rapidly expanding state universities, Kent State University, until last Monday, was flourishing in an obscurity out of all proportion to its size. In an instant, the obscurity was ended by a volley of rifle fire that killed four students.
CHICAGO, May (AP) A fire swept through a four-story apartment building on Chicago's West Side today, killing nine persons.
The Gospel Tabernacle, for more than 80 years a place of worship at Eighth Avenue and 44th Street, has moved crosstown to new quarters on the East Side.
Peter Ustinov, who has been known to dabble also in films and the theater, made his conducting debut yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall.
With a "very heavy name to carry," Marcel Cerdan Jr. will make his American boxing debut tonight in a 10-round welterweight bout with Donato Paduano at Madison Square Garden.

Georgians whose native state is in the south of the Soviet Union will escort friends and relatives to a dinner dance on Friday in the Pierre's Cotillion Room. The party, arranged by the Georgian Association in the United States of America, will recall May 26, 1918, when Georgia enjoyed a brief independence before being made a republic of the Soviet Union.
Six home runs flew out of Shea Stadium yesterday including a grand slam by Willie McCovey as the San Francisco Giants downed the New York Mets, 11-7.

DETROIT, May 10 Walter P. Reuther, the president of the United Automobile Workers, and his wife, May, died last night in a plane crash in northern Michigan. Mr. Reuther was 62 years old, and his wife was 59.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 10 Like neighbors ambling through a progressive dinner, the Yankees moved from pitcher to pitcher today. A little appetizer here, a little entree there, finally a little dessert and-voila! satisfaction.
New York State may soon give doctors and lawyers a chance to give some serious thought to one of their favorite subjects money.

Once again the Justice Department has overruled the State Department and denied a visa to a foreign citizen under the dragnet section of the McCarranWalter Act prohibiting entry to persons with alleged subversive associations.

The head of the city's building trades unions said yesterday that telephone calls and letters received by the unions were 20 to 1 in favor of the construction workers who were involved in a confrontation with antiwar demonstrators here last Friday.
PUSAN, South Korea, April 24--Running 24 hours a day on three shifts, the big Tong Myung plywood factory in this port is a fitting symbol of South Korea's increasingly vital economy.
In his American boxing debut, Marcel Cerdan, Jr. showed himself to be a thoroughbred son of a thoroughbred father. But even a thoroughbred loses sometime.

William V. Lawson, president of the George A. Fuller Company, construction, and Mrs. Lawson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Crandall Lawson, to Kenneth Mark Lewis 3d, son of Mrs. Lewis Jr. of New York and the late Dr. Lewis, a physician. The wedding is planned for June 13.

Anticipating that a Government report that was scheduled to be released later in the day would show excellent crop prospects, traders in wheat futures sent prices down yesterday in trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11-- Final arguments were made today in Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's libel action against Look magazine, and it was expected that the jury would be instructed in law and begin its deliberations tomorrow.
Mayor Lindsay released yesterday a study asserting that every passenger ride on the Staten Island ferry is subsidized 43 cents by the city's taxpayers.

WASHINGTON, May 11-- James M. Beggs, the Under Secretary of Transportation, said today that he would ask for Government-backed loans to Start production of the supersonic transport if ordinary private financing were unavailable.

A black policeman testified yesterday that he was shot at when he approached a car in which one of 13 Black Panthers accused of conspiring to bomb public places was seated. The bullet hit a summons pouch over his hip, he said.

The New York Stock Exchange has concluded that the new commission rates proposed in a study by National Economic Research Associates involve changes that are too drastic and has decided to draw up another rate package.

WASHINGTON, May 11-- American taxpayers who keep bank accounts in foreign countries will be required to disclose that fact on their 1970 tax returns, Randolph W. Thrower, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today.

DURING the closing stages of a basketball season that lingered with distracting persistence into the month of May, Walter Alston tiptoed unobtrusively into town with his Dodgers last week and just as unobtrusively tiptoed out again. No one noticed him especially, probably because he's the kind of guy who just blends into the scenery.
Denver has numerous claims to fame, but high among them is the fact that it has two famous John Kings--both oil millionaires.

Stock prices crunched downward yesterday with the trading pace, hobbling along at a mere 6.65 million shares, the slowest since the "summer doldrums" of 1967. The DowJones industrial average fell 7.66 points to 710.07, or only a whisker above its lowest level since August, 1963.

Several thousand hard-hatted construction workers and longshoremen, demonstrating in support of the American war policy in Vietnam, roamed the financial district yesterday, chanting tirades against Mayor Lindsay.
Not even Tom Seaver, supersymbol and charismatic leader of the New York Mets, can win a game if his team doesn't score--and he can't even get a tie if he doesn't pitch a shutout.
The Budd Company announced yesterday an "understanding" has been reached covering the sale of its moneylosing railway division to the General Electric Company.
Government securities prices sagged yesterday as the Federal Reserve took no action to support the credit market, where an $18.6-billion financing program is taking place.
The Yardney Electric Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire the Whittaker Power Systems Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Whittaker Corporation of Los Angeles.

LOS ANGELES (AP)--A research psychologist, who has studied the personality traits of almost 1100 high school students here, says those most likely to "run afoul of the vehicle code" show a high level of "expediency."

WASHINGTON, May 11-- Ralph Nader, the advocate of consumers' rights, today criticized some of the largest American corporations, including General Motors, for indulging in what he called "massive lying" in their advertising in order to give major stress to areas in which they are "weakest."

NEWARK, May 11--With the field of candidates suddenly narrowed from seven to six, 85,000 Newark voters are expected to go to the polls tomorrow in the city's mayoral election. And for the first time, it is possible that the Mayor will be a black man, although he might have to face a run-off election on June 16 in the event that no candidate gets 50 per cent of the votes tomorrow.

"They say there's going to be a demonstration Tuesday at 'Wall and Nassau Streets'--and we know that's us," said a National Park Service ranger after Friday's prowar and antiwar battles in front of Federal Hall National Memorial.

The New York Athletic Club won the Whelan Cup for senior eights in the sixth annual Father Knickerbocker regatta on the Orchard Beach Lagoon yesterday. St. John's University was second after leading for the first 500 meters.

JOHANNESBURG, May 11-- South African students demonstrated peacefully throughout the country today in protest against a law that provides for the indefinite detention of political prisoners. The protests were expressed by absenteeism from lectures, placard-bearing pickets and campus meetings.
Chief Justice Warren E. Burger dedicated the United States Customs Courthouse here yesterday, praising the building's design and calling it an "inspiration" to the people who worked there.

A study by an anonymous independent researcher working under the auspices of the City Planning Commission asserts that long delays in public school construction are adding tens of millions of dollars to the eventual price tag in an inflationary economy. In an exercise of irrelevance, an official reply from the Budget Director's office questions whether the relationship between delay and cost can be so readily pinpointed.

Gleaming Sword made a powerful bid for handicap consideration in taking the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old colt, owned by Sarah Hall, staged a strong stretch rally to take the 1 1/8-mile contest by a head over Barometer, who had five lengths on Never Bow, next in the field of five.
CARTHAGE, Tenn.--Mrs. Albert Gore, wife of the Tennessee Senator, is used to giving dinner parties without knowing whether 100 or 1,000 will sit down to eat.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 11 --Robert Elmer Baker, the former president of Baker Perkins, Inc., died yesterday at his home here at 50 Popham Road. He was 85 years old.

Lead consumption this year probably will be slightly below last year's record level, Lawrason Riggs 3d, president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, said at the annual meeting at the Barbizon Plaza yesterday.
The love song of Milton Barry Sonsky continues, unaffected by social protests and the problems in page one.
TURIN, Italy, May 11 (UPI)-- Czechoslovakia advanced to the second round of the European zone Davis Cup eliminations by winning the final two singles today for a 3-2 victory over Italy.

Haliburton Fales, former senior partner of Hay, Fales Co., investment brokers at 71 Broadway, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the Miami Heart Institute. Mr. Fales, who was retired, lived in Key Biscayne, Fla., maintained an apartment in New York at 1075 Perk Avenue and had a summer residence in Branford, Conn. He was 85 years old.

Despite the public attention belatedly being given it, the nation's drug problem worsens. It involves an ever younger and broader segment of American society. The problem is particularly acute in New York City where, according to estimates, about half of the nation's hard-core addicts live.
WASHINGTON, May 11-- President Nixon's chief trade official told the House Ways and Means Committee today that the Administration opposed legislated import quotas on textiles and shoes.
Four major food retailers in Nassau County consented yesterday not to continue an alleged practice of mislabeling cuts of meat.

A survey of what is called "excessive commercialism on children's TV programs" has been filed with the Federal Communications Commission by Action for Children's Television, a Boston-based group of women who are seeking to upgrade children's network programing.

About 20 million electric power consumers served by a power pool in five states-- Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia and Delaware--and the District of Columbia were affected yesterday by a 5 per cent voltage reduction effected "as a precautionary measure" because of hot weather.

BETWEEN ourselves, for a drama critic, or for that matter a producer, the best plays are those that are either good or bad. Then the critic can rave or rant, the damn fool critical ritual is completed, and the producer knows whether he is rich or sore. Unfortunately most plays are not clear-cut, black or white successes or disasters.

NEW DELHI, May 1--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi pleaded with angry members of Parliament today to ignore remarks of Vice President Spiro Agnew about Cambodia and the International Control Commission, of which Indira is chairman.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11 --A national antiwar fund, to which every college professor in the country is being asked to contribute at least one day's salary, was created here today.
The way the Cincinnati Reds have been hitting plus the way Bob Veale has been pitching figured to add up to an easy Cincinnati victory over Pittsburgh last night, even in new math.

YONKERS, May 11--Next Friday night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway will have to get along without Irving W. Berkemeyer's Australian-bred Adaptor. The 7year-old stallion, acquired last, season for $125,000, was declared out of the Good Time today and replayed by Abraham Schultz's Armbro Harvey.

An aging quartet of relics of teen-age rock, Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons, made its Carnegie Hall debut Sunday night before an audience that gave a cheering reception to everything the group did.

Although Dr. Pepper has been promising for a week on television and radio that it will be bringing its soft drink to the New York market on May 18, it really didn't become official until yesterday. That's when they had the press lunch.

VIENTIANE, Laos. May 11-- Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that because of the Cambodian situation he expected an intensification of the war in Laos by the North Vietnamese and their Laotian allies, the Pathet Lao. He renewed his recent appeal to the Pathet Lao for serious peace negotiations.

Felipe Herrera, president of the Inter-American Development Bank, declared yesterday that the bank would like to issue more bonds in the United States to expand lending in Latin America, but that it was unable to do so because of high interest rates.

HONG KONG, May 11--Le Duan, the head of North Vietnam's Communist party, arrived in Peking today from Moscow to pursue what was believed here to be a new effort to promote unity of action on Indochina by the Soviet Union and Communist China.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)--House members voted today to legalize kite flying in the nation's capital. They did not tamper, however, with other ancient restraints on local public behavior, including the playing of bandy and shindy or tying horses to trees.

When The New Yorker switches to its new ad agency on July 1, the move will be part of a changing promotional posture begun two years ago that was aimed at letting the advertising community know that The New Yorker is not the magazine it was 15 or even 10 years ago.

HANGAROA, Easter Island --Thee is angry talk on Easter Island these days, and mounted olicemen have posted a guard at the church on Sundays ever since islanders tried to stone the Governor several weeks ago.
TOPEKA, Kan., May 11 (UPI)--A group of Washburn University students is planning an "appreciation day" Friday to thank taxpayers for the privilege of going to college.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 11 (UPI)--Mario Andretti, winner of the Indianapolis 500mile race last year, narrowly escaped injury today in a crash that occurred at the same place as the one that forced him to use his backup car in the 1969 race.

PARIS, May 11--Xuan Thuy, the chief North Vietnamese representative at the Paris peace talks, left for Hanoi today, declaring that a settlement could not be reached until President Nixon abandoned "his policy based on a position of strength."
The Interstate Commerce Commission held a one-day hearing here yesterday on a request by the Penn Central Company to discontinue 34 east-west passenger trains.
DETROIT, May 11--Auto industry executives are beginning to worrry about the fate of their new contract negotiations without Walter P. Reuther's strong land on the United Auto Workers.

DETROIT, May 11--Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird emphasized today that American troop withdrawals from Cambodia would follow President Nixon's schedule despite complaints from officers in the field that all occupied territory might not be searched in time.
Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,618,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices for hot-and cold-rolled steel sheets and galvanized sheets by about 4.7 per cent effective June 1.
BECKLEY, W. Va., May 11-- There is a saying here that "you could take a fence post, call it a Kee and enter it in any election in the Fifth Congressional District, and it woul win."

BILL BLASS finally did it. He made the long look palatable to a lot of women who were clinging defiantly to short clothes. Women such as Mrs. William F. Buckley, who said before his fall showing of Maurice Renter clothes at the Hotel Plaza yesterday afternoon, "I look like the Prime of Miss Jean Brodie in long skirts--I'm going to wear mine very short--or stick to pants."

LUBBOCK, Tex., Tuesday, May 12 (AP)--A tornado ripped through this northwest Texas city last night, killing 19 persons, injuring hundreds and causing millions of dollars in damages, much of it among downtown office buildings.

WASHINGTON, May 11-- The House Post Office Committee unexpectedly added a major new provision tonight to the post office reform bill --a requirement that the wages paid postal workers, in the future, contain regional differentials.
WASHINGTON, May 11-- Vice President Agnew believes there is a danger that young Americans may be "carried away by mob psychology" because they see so many examples of confrontation on television.
MILWAUKEE, May 11--The Yankees scored three unearned runs in a gathering rainstorm tonight and gained a 5-5 tie with the Milwaukee Brewers in the ninth inning.
Physicians have reported 260 cases of lead poisoning in children to the New York City Health Department during the first four months of this year --more than for any other comparable period.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) --Seventeen persons ranging from military officers to lawyers and teachers were appointed today to be White House Fellows for a year as special assistants to the President's staff and Cabinet members.

The new city budget package worked out with the state means that the real-estate tax for city homeowners and landlords will rise to $5.95 for each $100 of assessed valuation for the year starting July 1, according to the Citizens Budget Commission.

A glimpse at one of the most generous, flexible and sustained musical philanthropies by an individual in America has become possible with the publication of the first report by the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music, Inc., since its founding in 1962.

Long before William F. Johntz succeeded in teaching algebra to elementary school children from poor families, he had become convinced that all children--until they come to hate mathematics in school--have "a lust for and high facility in abstract thinking."

WASHINGTON, May 11--In his televised address on the war last Nov. 3, President Nixon declared that a "precipitate" American withdrawal from South Vietnam" would inevitably allow the Communists to repeat the massacres which followed their takeover in the north fifteen years before. They then murdered more than 50,000 people and hundreds of thousands more died in slave labor camps."
A study of ways to strengthen specialist units at the New York Stock Exchange has produced a decision to abolish all two-man units by June 1.

The United Federation of College Teachers, collective bargaining agent for about 6,000 untenured faculty members of the City University, plans to set up picket lines today a three colleges and the Graduate Division in a contract dispute with the Board of Higher Education.

GENEVA, May 11--John M. King, a Denver businessman with interests in oil and mutual funds, has taken over effective voting control of Investors Overseas Services in a complex transaction aimed at restoring investor confidence in the beleaguered mutual-fund empire.

WASHINGTON, May 11-- President Nixon says he is not going to be the first President to lose a war. Before him President Johnson said the same. This is sports talk. Easy to make fun of, but not so easily disposed of because the notion of war as the ultimate game is a big piece of mental luggage in Atlantic society.

WASHINGTON, May 11--A group of military reservists who oppose American involvement in the war in Vietnam asked the United States District Court here today to cancel the reserve officer commissions of more than 100 members of Congress.
Dr. Alfred Lewis Goldberg, an assistant professor of physiology at the Harvard Medical School, and Miss Joan Marilyn Helpern, a fourth-year medical student there, plan to be married on May 24.

American industry has apparently begun a massive refunding operation in which the large amounts of short-term debt it incurred in the last year or two are being paid off with the proceeds from long-term debt and equity financings.

Bache Co., the nation's second largest brokerage house, disclosed yesterday that it plans to acquire Stein Brothers Boyce, a medium-sized regional member of the New York Stock Exchange doing business since 1853.

"I should have stayed in bed." This comment by a floor broker on the American Stock Exchange neatly summarized its activities yesterday as prices continued to decline while volume dropped to its lowest level in almost three and a half years.
AUGUST, Ga., Tuesday, May 12--Four Negroes were reported shot to death and 20 persons wounded today in racial violence marked by burning, looting and sniper fire.
The London stock market continued yesterday the firmer tone that developed last Friday, but investors remained cautious.
Both sides in the city's newspaper dispute reassessed their positions yesterday as the stalemate continued.

During the National Basketball Association playoffs the New York Knicks received a sentimental letter from Dr. Eugenia Yanagisawa and her five children, wishing the team well. Mrs. Yanagisawa, a gynecologist, is the widow of Dr. Kazuo Yanagisawa, the Knicks' physician who died Feb. 22 of a heart attack. The club displplayed the letter prominently in the dressing room.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 9--The no-strike strike has come to Smith.

IT is amazing that Antoinette Sibley had never danced Giselle for the main company of the Royal Ballet until Sunday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. She had danced a couple of performances with the Royal Ballet's smaller company during a South African tour about nine years ago and a little later made a guest appearance with Walter Gore's London Ballet, but she has yet to dance Giselle in London.
WASHINGTON, May 11--The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted 9 to 3 to ease monetary policy at its meeting last Feb. 10, it was disclosed today.

DETRIOT, May 11 (AP)-- More than 200 F.B.I. agents staged a series of raids in Detroit and Flint, Mich., today in an effort to smash what Federal officials described as a numbers operation with a daily handle of $250,000.
Many of the nation's colleges and universities reopened for classes yesterday, but students at 158 institutions were reported still on strike "indefinitely."
STOCKTON, Calif. (UPI)-- The School of Engineering of the University of the Pacific is instituting a new education program that will allow students to earn $10,000 over a three-year period.

WASHINGTON, May 11-- Over State Department objections that Congress was proposing to restrict the President's constitutional powers as Commander in Chief, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved an amendment today to cut off funds for future American military activities in Cambodia.

While Bobby Orr collected still another award yesterday, and was mobbed on the steps, of Boston's City Hall, the Rangers were trying to make deals that would enable them to do the celebrating next year.

The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday its first computer designed specifically for business applications. The new machine, called the Sigma 6, is a medium-size general-purpose computer. It will lease for $12,000 to $18,000 a month, depending on complexity.

Mrs. Dorothy Gordon, for 17 years moderator of The New York Times Youth Forums, a weekly radio and television program she created, died yesterday at her home, 350 West 57th Street. She was 81 years of age.

WASHINGTON, May 11-- President Nixon conferred today with 45 state and territorial governors to press his search for ways of improving communication with the academic community and to explain his decision on Cambodia.

BRUSSELS, May 11--The six European Common Market countries decided today to reduce the Executive Commission from the present 14 members to 9 and replace its president, Jean Rey of Belgium, by an Italian, still to be named.
SEATTLE, May 11--The King County Democratic Convention has refused to endorse Senator Henry M. Jackson for re-election to his fourth term.
Bowie Kuhn, Commissioner of Baseball, promised yesterday that he would put his weight behind ending the professional draft of college players.
WASHINGTON, MHay 11-- The Senate opened debate today on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Harry A. Blackmun.

The Administrative Judge of the city's Criminal Court said yesterday that he will ask today to be relieved of his duties because he doesn't "have any faith in any political structure helping" him reform the court.

BALTIMORE, May 11--Dust Commander and My Dad George, one-two in the Kentucky Derby, and two other candidates for Saturday's 95th running of the Preakness Stakes turned in sharp workouts today at Pimlico Race Course.
WASHINGTON, May 11-- Treasury bill rates declined sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late today.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) --The House sent to President Nixon today a bill authorizing $429-million for merchant marine activities, including the start of a 300-ship construction program.
PARIS, May 11--French Government authorities have made public wide-ranging plans to improve their country's environment--including a campaign to rid Paris streets of excessively noisy cars.
WASHINGTON, May 11-Mortgage prices declined at this week's auction of the Federal National Mortgage Associ ation for the first time since January, the association disclosed today.

A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a suit by a lawyer, Gerald B. Lefcourt, against the Legal Aid Society for dismissing him, allegedly because he criticized its handling of indigent defendants' cases.
PARIS, May 11--The wife of Mikis Theodorakis, the Greek composer, and their two children have escaped to Paris from Greece, it was announced here tonight.

JERSEY CITY, May 11--The United States Attorney's office is expected to increase the number of subpoenas served on officials of Mayor Thomas J. Whelan's administration in an inquiry into crime and alleged corruption in Hudson County, informed sources said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 11-- Student protests against the war in Southeast Asia moved from the noisy streets to the quieter confines of Congressional hearing rooms and the State Department today.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) --The Supreme Court was asked today to halt the flow of millions of dollars of Federal construction grants to church-related colleges and universities.

THOSE who recall Gretta Plattry's sure hand with sportswear may remember that when she first started in business back in '4l, her forte was hand-crocheted dresses she designed and had made by European immigrants. Now, nearly 30 years later, Miss Plattry's
SEOUL, South Korea, May 11 --The Opposition New Democratic party ended a sevenmonth boycott of the National Assembly today when its members attended the opening meeting of a special 30-day session.
A rubbish fire on the Penn Central tracks at Park Avenue and 96th Street yesterday morning snarled rail traffic in and out of Grand Central Terminal.

JERUSALEM, May 11-- Mayor Teddy Kollek elbowed his way up Salmon Street, hung with strings of lights and jammed with people celebrating Israel's 22d independence day. In this country, holidays begin the night before, and Jerusalem started celebrating at 7 o'clock last night with a long siren blast.
Dr. Gladstone Hodge, a surgeon, died, apparently of a heart attack, Saturday in his home at 1267 Carroll Street, Brooklyn. He was 55 years old.

In his unsuccessful 1962 campaign to become New York's Attorney General and the first statewide Negro officeholder, Edward R. Dudley characterized himself as an impatient man. "I'm impatient with the affairs of the world," he said. "I don't think they're moving fast
CARMEL, Calif., May 11-- If a search for a missing Polish nobleman is successful, the family circle gathering here for a June wedding of international proportions will be complete.
The Hospital for Special Surgery has arranged a theater party at the Royal Ballet's performance next Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center.

Lloyd Burns, executive vice president of the Screen Gems division of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., died in London Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 565 Park Avenue.

MILFORD, Mich., May 11-- Air bags, the major innovation to protect auto passengers from injury since the seat belt, will require many more years of laboratory testing before they, become standard equipment, representatives of two major United States automobile makers said today.
PARIS, May 11--Leo Cardinal Suenens of Belgium criticized Pope Paul VI today for having refused to submit the question of priestly celibacy to free discussion among the Roman Catholic bishops.
BACK in the exhilarating bull market days of 1967, the go-go fund could do no wrong, and investors eagerly sought out the hottest performers in their quest for overnight riches.
Two major nuclear fuel contracts were made known yesterday involving utilities in Michigan and upstate New York.
LONDON, May 11 (AP)-- South Africa, already suspended from the Davis Cup, faces a new struggle to keep her tennis stars on the world tournament circuit next year.

The election of Seymour Graubard, a lawyer in New York, as national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith was announced yesterday at the 57th annual meeting of the league at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ROME, May 11--A group of about 500 striking nurses and internes held a sitdown protest today in front of St. Peter's Basilica as a series of strikes continued to halt a number of public services in Italy.

The college crew season has another month to go and it will be a miracle if the schedule is fulfilled as planned. The concluding events are the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's regatta at Syracuse on June 11-13 and the Harvard-Yale race at New London on June 13.

The Eastern Intercollegiate Tennis and Baseball Associations, consisting of the eight Ivy League colleges, Army and Navy, decided yesterday that any team refusing to play a league engagement as a result of current student strikes and protests must forfeit that match.

In an atmosphere of rising protectionist sentiment, the House Ways and Means Committee has opened hearings on United States foreign trade policy. A showdown is rapidly approaching on whether this country will continue the efforts for a freer international trade system which began with the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act of 1934 or whether it will head toward compulsory quotas, higher tariffs and possibly an international trade war.

A Westchester woman filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday against a hospital in Mount Kisco which allegedly refused to allow a sterilization operation, even though she had requested it and her doctors were ready to perform it.

TRENTON, May 11--In another move against organized crime, the New Jersey Assembly voted today to extend the anticrime jurisdiction of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to the major jetports in the New York metropolitan area.

George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, supported Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel yesterday in his criticism of the Nixon Administration's attitude toward the nation's youth.
Bernard J. Lasker, senior partner of Lasker Stone Stern, was re-elected yesterday as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange to serve his second one-year term.

ROME, May 10--The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is considering a proposal that the Soviet Union reduce its forces in Central Europe by 30 per cent in return for a 10 per cent cut in Allied troop strength.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 11 (AP)--Six American soldiers are under restriction pending an investigation of charges of refusal to make a combat assault into Cambodia, a spokesman for the Fourth Infantry Division said today. They are obtaining legal counsel, he said.
The leaders of five Police Department organization yesterday accused Mayor Lindsay of "undermining the confidence of the public in its Police Department."
There was much shuffling of official chairs yesterday at Lincoln Center. Amyas Ames took a new seat, and he drew up new chairs for at least nine other people.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. (UPI)--Tomorrow's railroad executives will come in large measure from the ranks of women, according to Emil Jesse, a railroad official, speaking at the annual meeting of the National Association of Railway Business Women.

Most colleges and universities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut officially resumed classes yesterday after a week of protest, but attendance on a number of campuses was marginal as students continued strikes and antiwar activities.

WASHINGTON, May 11-- United States officials said today they saw no reason to regard the postponement of the opening of an American cultural exhibition in the Soviet Union as an officially inspired sign of protest against American military actions in Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)--Wholesale prices held steady in April for the first time in 18 months, the Government reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11-- Thousands of aged persons who are living alone in New York City public housing are unable to care for themselves and are existing "as if they were in a hospital or nursing home with janitorial but no medical or social services," a geriatrics specialist said today.
Johnny Hodges, a longtime alto saxophonist with Duke Ellington's band, died yesterday in Manhattan. He had collapsed in a dentist's office. He was 63 years old and lived at 170 West End Avenue.

Arthur J. Goldberg, a Democratic candidate for Governor, and Senator Charles E. Goodell, a Republican seeking election to a full term in Washington, were endorsed last night by the Liberal party's state committee.
NORTH NEWPORT, N.H.-- It was nearly 5 o'clock in the afternoon when Victor Pomiecko of Claremont, N.H., and I reached Chapin Pond, and a strong, cold wind was blowing out of the west.

Henry Crown and Nathan Cummings, the Chicago financiers who have been offered six places on the board of directors of the General Dynamics Corporation to be elected at the annual stockholders' meeting on May 27, are faced with the problem of selecting a sixth nominee to succeed the late Homer Livingston.

On Saturday morning Mercury crossed the face of the sun. In telescopic photographs the planet appeared as a dot that was small relative to several sunspots, even though Mercury was 52 million miles from the earth and the sun was 94 million miles from the earth at the time.

The consent Triborough bondholders have finally given for transfer of bridge and tunnel surpluses to the municipal subway system represents a giant step toward a truly unified concept of mass transit for the metropolitan area.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 11--Forty-seven vessels of the South Vietnamese Navy moved up the Mekong River here late this afternoon and tied up in the heart of Pnompenh.

N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken, the giant Dutch electronics and electrical equipment producer, yesterday reported first-quarter earnings of $35,280,000, up from the yearearlier $29,2440,000. Sales rose to $909.6-million from $777.6million.
NORTH NEWPORT, N.H.-- It was nearly 5 o'clock in the afternoon when Victor Pomiecko of Claremont, N.H., and I reached Chapin Pond, and a strong, cold wind was blowing out of the west.

Henry Crown and Nathan Cummings, the Chicago financiers who have been offered six places on the board of directors of the General Dynamics Corporation to be elected at the annual stockholders' meeting on May 27, are faced with the problem of selecting a sixth nominee to succeed the late Homer Livingston.

Three members of the Knicks' National Basketball Association championship squad--Don May, Bill Hosket and John Warren-- were lost to expansion teams yesterday in the draft that stocked new franchises at Buffalo, Cleveland and Portland, Ore.
MOSCOW, May 12 Bitterness marked the first official Soviet reaction tonight to the selection of Montreal as the site of the 1976 Summer Olympics.

ACCORDING to Robert Engelhardt, the man who does most of the cooking, the food "wouldn't knock a connoisseur dead" but to thousands of New Yorkers who have sampled the menu of the Oola Carts in the last month, the offerings are a happy medium between a hot dog and a hefty lunch bill.

WASHINGTON, May 12 President Nixon gave a sympathetic audience of labor leaders a fresh report today on what he called the "enormous success" of American and South Vietnamese military operations in Cambodia.

YONKERS, May 12 Australia will be without representation in Friday night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway. In the wake of yesterday's declaration of Adaptor, the $125,000 Aussie pacer who suffered a broken splint bone in last week's $50,000 Martin Tananbaum International Pace Lucky Creed of Australia was withdrawn this morning.
Electric utility customers in parts of New Jersey and Pennsylvania already plagued by precautionary voltage reductions over the last two days were put on notice yesterday that 1971 may be even worse.

Melvin Intriligator, a director of the Anchor Corporation, has been named senior vice president and will be succeeded as treasurer by Arthur White, James E. Preifer has been named treasurer of Anchor's subsidiary, Anchor National Life Insurance Company.
BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) The addition of Hickory Tree Farm's Buzashi today increased to 13 the list of starters for Saturday's $150,000-added Preakness and further padded the already record purse.

BRUSSELS, May 12 (UPI) Three Americans moved into the second round of the Belgian open tennis championships today as Cliff Richey and Marty Riessen won first-round men's singles matches and Wendy Overton gained in the women's competition.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded contracts yesterday to two aerospace industrial teams for the preliminary design of a reusable shuttle vehicle a short of space airplane to operate between the earth and earth-orbiting space stations.

The state has charged the Consolidated Edison Company with serious violations of state conservation laws in the operation of its nuclear generating plant at Indian Point and asked that the plant be closed until "suitable methods" to protect the Hudson River can be developed.
Albert Vann, president of the African-American Teachers Federation, won a directed motion of acquittal yesterday on charges arising from the Ocean HillBrownsville school dispute in 1968.

LONDON, May 12 (Reuters) Gen. Wladyslav Anders, who commanded Polish troops who fought with the Allies in World War II, died in a hospital here early today after suffering an apparent heart attack. He was 77 years old.
Prices generally eased on most foreign stock exchanges yesterday in reaction to Monday's decline on Wall Street.
Robert M. Morgenthau withdrew at 11:45 last night as a candidate for Democratic nomination for Governor.
MIAMI (AP) The prosecutor was going to introduce police witnesses, so he asked prospective jurors if they had ever been robbed or victimized.

SONS of famous fathers carry unconscionable burdens throughout their lives because they are always being compared with their more renowned sires. The greater the stature of the father the more difficult it is for the son to escape from the smothering shadow that bloodlines have imposed on him. Ty Cobb's son, for instance, didn't even try. The offspring of baseball's finest hitter became a tennis player at Yale. Sic transit gloria mundi.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) does not foresee any significant increase in the use of satellite circuits in this country this year, Joseph V. Charyk, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in l'Enfant Theater here today.
MILWAUKEE, May 12 Yankee pitchers can't complete their games and the Milwaukee ground crew can't cover the field during a thunderstorm.

MADRID Perhaps the most interesting and certainly the most gingerly diplomatic negotiations now going on in Europe are those between Spain and the Soviet Union. Contacts have existed for sixteen years, on and off, but they have recently been renewed at Moscow's initiative.
Back in January the Federal Reserve Board decided to change its tactics in fighting inflation, and the shift seemed sensible enough since the old tactics had not been much of a success.
The policemen who arrested Joan Bird, one of 13 Black Panthers accused of conspiring to bomb public places, denied repeatedly yesterday that he had beaten her the night of her arrest.

CHICAGO, May 12 Five of the seven Black Panthers who survived a shooting incident with the Chicago police last December refused today to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the incident.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 Palestinian commandos, Lebanese guns and the Syrian Air Force combined today in opposing an Israeli sweep into a guerrilla stronghold in southwestern Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that several thousand American troops had already been withdrawn from Cambodia and that more would be withdrawn this week, Mr. Laird also predicted that all ground combat in Vietnam would be taken over by South Vietnamese forces by July, 1971.
When Navy No charged into contention in the second race at Aqueduct yesterday, Camille Radice knew she had made a mistake.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 12 (AP) A C-101 cargo plane crashed on its sixth take-off during tests today, killing all four on board.

The Columbus (Ohio) Gallery of Fine Arts will benefit from a dinner at the St. Regis-Sheraton next Monday night and the preview afterward of the first exhibition in New York of the Ferdinand Howald Collection at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East 64th Street.

CANNES, France, May 12 The weather has been so cold and rainy so much of the time that movie producers, who ordinarily sport tans 12 months of the year, have turned as blue as the Carlton Hotel beach umbrellas that are going unrented.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 The Penn Central Company will have to hold its capital expenditures this year to $166-million, down from $268-million in 1969 and $334-million in 1968, stockholders were told here today at their annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, May 12 Total business inventories rose by the unusually small amount of $150-million in March, the Commerce Department reported today.
MURRY BERGTRAUM'S three children offered him some advice Monday night when they learned he was about to become president-elect of the Board of Education.

The Bangor Punta Corporation reported yesterday a sharp drop in earnings for the six months ended March 31 and a net loss for the second fiscal quarter. As a result, directors took no action on the common stock dividend for the rest of fiscal 1970.

MEMPHIS, May 12 One hundred years ago today a little band of black churchmen, tired of being treated like secondclass citizens in a predominantly white church, withdrew from the old paternalistic Methodist Episcopal Church, South.

WASHINGTON, May 12 A report on air pollution control, prepared under the direction of Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said today that Senator Edmund Muskie had provided "politically expedient platitudes" rather than "real leadership" in the field of environmental protection.

The Americas Golf Cup match has been discontinued by mutual agreement of the United States Golf Association, the Royal Canadian Golf Association, and the Mexican Golf Association. The 1970 match was to have taken place July 24 and 25 at the Broadmoor Golf Club, Colorado Springs, Colo.

Crofters, Inc., an Ohio company that has made substantial finder's fees helping major corporations raise a total of $20million from the Ohio state treasury, defended its practices yesterday as "in conformance with Ohio law."
SAN FRANSISCO, May 12 Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's $12.5million libel suit against Look magazine was in the jury's hands tonight.

BOSTON, May 12 Dr. Robert C. Wood, director of the Joint Center for Urban Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University, is expected to be elected president of the University of Massachusetts tomorrow.
Dr. Stanley F. Yolles of the National Institute of Mental Health calls drug misuse an "epidemic" sweeping the nation. It has rippled in, from the port cities across the hinterland plains.

By designating Democrat Arthur J. Goldberg and Republican Charles Goodell as its nominees for Governor and Senator, the Liberal party has given the candidacies of both a long push forward. The halfmillion or more votes the Liberals are likely to attract to their line could well determine the outcome of the two principal statewide contests this November.
MONTREAL, May 12 For Montrealers, today's announcement that this metropolis had been awarded the 1976 Summer Olympics couldn't have come at a better time.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 12 The Occidental Petroleum Corporation is close to obtaining an oil exploration concession in the United Arab Republic, Armand Hammer, chairman, said at the annual stockholders' meeting here today.

Edward R. Dudley, Administrative Judge of the city's Criminal Court, said late yesterday that he had submitted his request to be relieved of his duties and to be reassigned to the State Supreme Court. He had announced his intention to do this a day earlier, saying that the "low priority" assigned the courts prevented him from accomplishing any further court reform.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Members of the Senate Banking Committee disagreed with each other today over the advisability of trying to pass legislation this year restricting the activities of one-bank holding companies.

GENEVA, May 12 There are a number of unanswered questions, some of which raise, the possibility of conflict of interest, in the arrangement that has given John M. King voting control over the Investors, Overseas Services mutual fund empire.
JERUSALEM, May 12 Israeli tanks and other armored forces struck across the Lebanese border early today in response to a growing wave of guerrilla attacks on Israeli frontier settlements.
BOSTON, May 12 (AP) Mayor Kevin H. White formally announced today he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor of Massachusetts, criticized Gov. Francis W. Sargent, a Republican.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 12 A dusk-to-dawn curfew was imposed on this nervous city today after a night of looting and shooting that left six Negroes dead and brought 1,200 National Guard troops with fixed bayonets into the streets.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 Allied officials said today that two weeks of operations in Cambodia had fragmented the Vietnamese Communist military and had pushed its major fighting units off balance. The officials also said that allied troops had captured enough munitions for a fivemonth enemy attack in South Vietnam.

A TYPE of contest that is popular in Europe but rarely played here is that between teams representing clubs, towns, countries or districts. American organizations are reluctant to plan such events because they lead to thorny selection problems. They should be more enterprising and risk a little of the odium that always afflicts selectors.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The Nixon Administration retreated today in the dispute over Federal tea tasting.
WASHINGTON, May 12 A bill to reform creaky legislative machinery was approved today by the House Rules Committee after more than a year of delicate negotiations.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) A $267.3-million rise in funds for the Justice Department's fight against crime, racial discrimination and pollution of natural resources was recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced yesterday that a subsidiary, the BP Oil Company, had asked the United States District Court in Cleveland for a declaratory judgment cutting the price paid for properties purchased from the Sinclair Oil Corporation by $35.37million.
Joseph C. Lauricella is a 47year-old dock worker who was wounded at Guadalcanal and who lately finds his teen-aged son asking "very tough questions about war" during meals at their Brooklyn home.
LET'S pretend we're still in the beginning weeks of the notorious bear market of 1969.
DALLAS, May 12 The General Portland Cement Company of Dallas took its first step toward diversification when it announced here yesterday that it will enter a $72-million joint venture in Florida.

HONG KONG, May 12 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the ousted Chief of State of Cambodia, has asserted in Peking that "patriotic armed forces" loyal to him are dealing "severe blows to the United States invaders of Cambodia."

NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, May 12 Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said here today that allied naval vessels had begun blockading a 100-mile stretch of Cambodian coastline to prevent enemy forces from resupplying their troops by sea.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The House sent to President Nixon today a bill authorizing $429-million for merchant marine activities, including the start of a 300-ship construction program.
LONDON Conviction rather than detection is the only deterrent understood by the professional criminal, according to Robert Mark, Deputy Commissioner of Metropolitan Police.
STOCKHOLM, May 12 Nelly Sachs, the German-born Jewish poet who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1966, died in St. G rans Hospital here today after a long illness, She was 78 years old.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 12 A former football star and a young physician fell far short today in their efforts to unseat incumbent Congressmen in West Virginia's Democratic primary election.

WASHINGTON, May 12 In explaining President Nixon's sudden decision to invade Cambodia, his foreign policy aides point to three Nixon theories about how to deal with the Communists in general and the Soviet Union in particular. These are worth examining.
Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that national issues might well be involved in the gubernatorial campaign "because they infringe on the life of the state."

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that, when a company is purchased, the new owner must abide by any existing union contracts negotiated by the previous management.

In the wake of Cambodia and Kent State, many colleges and universities have apparently written off the remaining weeks of the semester some undoubtedly as much to avoid confrontations as to enable politically concerned students to exert their energies in off-campus lobbying and organizing.
OMAHA, May 12 (AP) Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann and an Omaha businessman, Clifton B. Batchelder, waged a closed battle today for the Republican governorship nomination in Nebraska's primary election.

A three-hour baseball game can be, sometimes, an exciting event, but the 8-4 victory the New York Mets scored over the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium yesterday wasn't, largely because Montreal pitchers issued 13 bases on balls.
NEW ORLEANS, May 12 Directors of the LykesYoungstown Corporation declared a dividend of 15 cents a share on the common stock today, payable June 10 to shareholders of record May 22.

The State Insurance Department ordered sellers of airtrip accident insurance yesterday either to reduce rates by 60 per cent or increase benefits by a similar amount because, it said, the premiums charged were "unreasonable."

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Secretary of Commerce, Maurice H. Stans, asked for and won today from the House Ways and Means Committee a delay of one more month to negotiate voluntary limitations on textile imports into the United States.

There were times during Murray Perahia's recital Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium when the young pianist's performance put the listener in mind of the late Dinu Lipatti, an artist who mingled virtuosity and sensibility in rare degree. Particular was that true in four Impromptus of Chopin, when Mr. Parahia spun out the notes scintillatingly while keeping a certain aristocratic distance from their flashy surfaces.

Rhythmic certainty, personal aplomb and a sense of musical ease were some of the characteristics that trade Michael Webster's clarinet playing such a pleasure to hear Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

You'd never catch Lucy Van Pelt helping Charlie Brown rescue one of his kites from one of the many kiteeating trees they encounter, but Jim Merritt is more compassionate at least where his son is concerned.

Kenneth A. Gibson, a Negro running for Mayor of Newark, won more than twice the votes cast for his closest contender yesterday, the incumbent, Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio. However, Mr. Gibson, a 37year-old city engineer on leave, did not have the more than 50 per cent total to win election. Therefore he will face Mayor Addonizio in a runoff on June 16.
CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP) The Republic Steel Corporation announced today that effective June 1, it was increasing the prices of certain products to bring them in line "with the competition."

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Nixon Administration, the Federal Reserve and House Republicans joined today in opposition to a Democratic-sponsored plan to pump $4-billion into housing mortgages, partly by a mandatory tapping of investment funds of pension funds and private foundations.

Israel's large-scale raid against guerrilla sanctuaries in Lebanon calls attention once more to a continuing crisis in the Middle East that is even more perilous than the escalating Indochina conflict on which national and international concern has focused in recent weeks.
Guidelines for abortions, set yesterday by the State Health Department, recommend that the operation be performed only in a hospital or a hospitalaffiliated clinic.
The American Heritage Society, whose members include readers and editors of American Heritage magazine, yesterday announced the winners of 12 conservation awards totaling $50,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 Suicide among chronically ill kidney dialysis patients is 400 times more prevalent than suicide in the general population, a team of doctors from the University of Virginia School of Medicine reported here today.
NEWARK, May 12 (AP) A Federal judge denied today a motion by lawyers for Walter Zirpolo, former Woodbridge Township Mayor, for a directed verdict of acquittal in his bribery-conspiracy trial here.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Senate Republican leadership countered a bipartisan move to cut off funds for future military activities in Cambodia by suggesting legislation today that would sanction actions taken under the President's power as Commander in Chief.

A three-judge panel of the Federal Court of Appeals ruled here yesterday that the constitutional protection against incrimination by unlawfully seize evidence did not apply to a prisoner whose parole had been revoked.

Capital markets in the United States could suffer greater pressures in the next decade than they did in the late nineteen-sixties, Maurice A. Mann assistant director of the Budget Bureau, said yesterday.

One million of the city's 1.3 million families in rent-controlled apartments would pay rent increases averaging more than 10 per cent on July 1, and additional rises thereafter, under a vast reform of the rentcontrol law proposed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

Blind Jim Brewer, a big, chunky man who has been singing and playing his guitar on street corners in Chicago, St. Louis and Fayetteville, Ark., reached New York Monday night, not on a street corner but in the shelter of the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.
A citizen commitee to work on specific antipollution programs rather than simply serving as a forum against pollution was convened at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

MOSCOW, May 12 The Soviet Union appears to have chosen, for the moment, to mask in ambiguity its course of action in both the Middle East and Southeast Asia. Western diplomats have no firm information on what the sending of Soviet pilots to the United Arab Republic portends nor what, if ...
DENVER, May 12 The election of Denver as the site of the 1976 Winter Olympics today crowned an effort that began in 1963.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 12 Foreign Minister Adam Malik has declared that his country will send troops abroad to fight Communists of the Indochina war spreads to Malaysia and Thailand and represents a danger to Indonesian security.

WASHINGTON May 11 (AP) The Interior Department has begun hiring more men to inspect offshore oil operations in the Gulf of Mexico, with the goal of doubling the number of inspectors by the end of this month.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 12 Montreal was awarded the 1976 Summer Olympic Games and Denver the Winter Games today.
LORAIN, Ohio, May 12 The family of William K. Schroeder, one of the four students killed at Kent State, received a letter of sympathy from President Nixon today.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that troubleplagued George Washington High School would be reopened this morning with precautions taken to assure the safety of students and the staff.
Although higher prices were obtained at the Government's silver auction in Washington yesterday, the price of silver futures dropped on the Commodity Exchange here.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Discount store merchants, who have taken to bank credit cards much more readily than their conventional store competitors, expressed some fear at their convention here today over possible monopolistic behavior by the issuers of the cards.

LONDON, May 12 (AP) Joe Bugner, a British heavyweight, pummeled Brian London with a Flurry of right hands and knocked out the former world title contender at 1 minute 25 seconds of the fifth round tonight. London announced after the fight that he would retire from boxing.

Liggett Myers is moving its L brand of cigarettes from Young Rubicam to J. Walter Thompson, where it will join Chesterfield and Lark. Although measured media figures show that L was supported by some $10.49-million in advertising, the actual figure is understood to be closer to $6.5million. But that's still a lot of smoke.
The head of the local typographical union said yesterday that differences between the publishers of the city's four major newspapers were holding up a contract settlement with the printers.
Arthur J. Goldberg described modern multi-million dollar political campaigns as "outrageous" yesterday, then pledged to spend "far less than $2-million" on his own campaign for Governor.

Bill D. Moyers, a former White House press secretary, resigned yesterday as the publisher of Newsday after more than three years with the Long Island newspaper, which was purchased recently by The Los Angeles Times.

POCONO MANOR, Pa., May 12 The American Book Publishers Council and the American Educational Publishers Institute, whose members account for almost all books published in the United States, have merged into a single trade organization to be known as the Association of American Publishers.
Tax-exempt securities took the bond market spotlight yesterday as three large new offerings vied, with mixed results, for investor favor.

WHEN I consider most new plays, I thank God for old ones. Of course, new plays are vital to the theater, but it must also be remembered that if you have not actually seen a play, then it is new to you. And if you have seen it perhaps you will be able to welcome it back as an old friend.

Willis Reed accepted a 19970 Dodge Charger from Sport Magazine yesterday as the most valuable player in the National Basketeball Association playoff and said, "Any guy on the team that wants to use my car can have it."

LINCOLN, Neb., May 12 Republicans in this traditionally conservative state went to the polls today to decide the political future of Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann. They had the choice of renominating him for another four-year term or of replacing him with his most persistent and vocal critic, State Senator Clifton B. Batchelder.

MOSCOW, May 12 The Soviet Union has welcomed the formation of Prince Norodom Sihanouk's United National Front of Kampuchea, but so far continues to refrain from granting his government-in-exile formal recognition.
Stock prices enjoyed a brief "Melvin Laird rally" early yesterday afternoon. But, like most good things in the market these days, it did not last very long.
PRETORIA, South Africa, May 12 (Reuters) Prime Minister John B. Vorster announced some changes in his Government today and at the same time issued an apparent rebuke to one of his ministers.

Mrs. Paula Melhado Washburn was married here yesterday afternoon to Roswell L. Gilpatric, who was Deputy Secretary of Defense in the Kennedy Administration. Only members of the immediate families of the couple attended the ceremony, performed at the bride's apartment by the Rev. William A. McQuoid of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The United States Governmen announced last November that it planned to phase out most domestic uses of DDT over a two-year period. It began by ordering the halt of the use of DDT in residential areas by the end of 1969.

The 18th running of the $125,000 United Nations Handicap, which traditionally decides the year's national grasscourse champion, is scheduled for Wednesday, Sept. 16, ac cording to the Atlantic City track president, Robert P. Levy.
WITH true believers having trouble making long clothes for next fall look inviting, what's an infidel to do? Turn to Chanel, for one thing.

THE PRESIDENT Disaster. The President de clared a major disaster area in Texas. He authorized the use of Federal funds to supplement state and local resources for relief measures in several northwest Texas counties affected by a series of tornadoes April 17-18 and May 11.
Hyman Henry Butler, founder of the H. H. Butler, Inc., a chain of 53 apparel stores, died Monday at the Madison Avenue Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived at 211 Central Park West.
MOSCOW, May 13--The head of the theatrical union has accused Yuri Lyubimov, director of a Moscow avant-garde theater, of failure to show proper concern for the "ideological battle" with the West.

SCARSDALE. N.Y., May 13 Miss Anita Mitchell Schenck and Juraj Zednik, students at the Technische Hochschule in Aachen. West Germany, have made plans to be married Aug. 29 in Scarsdale.
