LONDON Remploy, a company set up after World War II to provide jobs for the severely disabled, has celebrated its silver jubilee.
The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it would spend $101-million in the next four years to control air and water pollution at all of its plants in this country.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 13 Mrs. Richard Frankenfelder has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bette Jane Frankenfelder, to Jack N. Bonne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bonne of New York. The wedding is planned for Dec. 20.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 13 At first glance, yesterday's West Virginia primary election seemed rather routine.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. Vietnam war veterans are joining the American Legion and other veterans organizations in large numbers at a time of widespread feeling against the war.
The Internal Revenue Service has apparently decided to back down on its challenge to banks' ownership of tax-exempt municipal bonds, well-informed senior banking officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 The last day of public hearings by the Commission on Obscenity and Pornography was disrupted today when a radical witness dumped a cheese pie on the forehead of one of the comission members.
CHICAGO, May 13 Continuing profit improvement is expected by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), particularly in the long term, shareholders were told at the annual meeting here today.

GENEVA, May 13 A way of life has ended at the company that Bernard Cornfeld founded, and no one is quite certain what will take its place. The scenes today at Investors Overseas Services are those of total confusion, which is about what to expect in a period of revolution, corporate or political.
ITS cup running over, as usual, the Jewish Museum has opened not one, but two really three exhibitions at once, using space indoors and out.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The House sent to President Nixon today a bill raising airplane user taxes 60 per cent to provide major financing for a 10-year airways development program.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today that the nation would have to radically revise its priorities in the years ahead to emphasize livability and eliminate destructive luxuries.

HURLINGHAM, England, may 13 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond advanced to the third round, but his Davis Cup teammate, Charlie Pasarell, was eliminated in the London hardcourt (clay) tennis tournament today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has dismissed without comment an appeal filed in behalf of Earl Caldwell, a New York Times reporter, concerning the attempt of the Justice Department to compel Mr. Caldwell's appearance before a Federal grand jury.

The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise the prices of its institutional roasted coffees, decaffeinated instant coffees and some regular instant coffees, effective tomorrow.
MILWAUKEE, May 13 The Yankees' 24-hour occupation of second place came to an end tonight when John Morris of the Brewers beat them, 3-1, with a three-hitter.
HAVANA, May 13 (Reuters)--Premier Fidel Castro acknowledged today that two Cuban fishing vessels had been sunk and the 11 men aboard them captured in the first week by a Cuban exile organization.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia (AP) A Rhodesian and his wife fought a grim tug of war with a crocodile in the Musarangadhli River and emerged alive.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13 (AP) Maj. Gen. John A.B. Dillard, head of the United States Army Engineer Command in South Vietnam, was killed yesterday when the helicopter in which he was flying was shot down, the United States Command announced today.

CAMBRIDGE England, May 13 (UPI) Prince Charles struck at pollution in unusually outspoken comments last night an said the multimillion dollar British-French supersonic transport, the Concorde, threatened the environment with sonic booms.

WASHINGTON, May, 13 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States would not become "militarily involved with troop or air support to defend the Cambodian Government, but was encouraging South Vietnam and Thailand to cooperate with Cambodia in meeting Communist threats.
Franklin J. Leerburger, a consulting engineer who was an adviser to the United Nations development program, died here Monday. He was 67 years old and lived at 301 East 66th Street.

On a recent morning Cathy Field, a green-eyed brunette who works as a film editor, stood in the street outside her East Side apartment, placed two fingers of each hand in the corners of her mouth and emitted an ear-splitting megawhistle that brought a taxi to an abrupt halt.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended for 10 days over-the-counter trading in the stock of Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., which has fallen from 32 at the close on April 29 to about 8.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 12 A Federal grand jury has indicted four major hotel corporations, a convention association and five of their officers on charges of violating the Sherman ,Antitrust Act.

The special committee investigating police corruption in New York has discussed the possibility of calling policemen to testify, but has not discussed calling either Jay Kriegel, an assistant to Mayor Lindsay on law enforcement or Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman, the former Investigation Commissioner.

Columbia Gas System, Inc., achieved record revenues and earnings in the quarter and 12 months ended March 31, the report disclosed yesterday to some 188,000 shareholders. The company noted that its earnings per share in the first quarter were 1 per cent higher than the estimate reported at the annual meeting a month ago.

The Dow-Jones industrial averaged plummeted 10.75 points yesterday to 693.84 thereby carving out a new low for a period of nearly seven years as investors and brokers reeled under the impact of the worst bear market since the Depression.

Moe than a thousand highschool students have moved their guitars, their posters and their anger into the graduate center of the New School for Social Research. There, for the last week, they have been talking, singing, sleeping and eating as they coordinate their citywide strike activities protesting conditions in the high schools, in America generally and in Indochina.

WASHINGTON, May 13 Following are excerpts from a speech that John W. Gardner, chairman of the National Urban Coalition, was to have given today to the Illinois constitutional Convention at Springfield, Ill. The speech was canceled at the request of the convention officers when the text became available in advance.

POCONO MANOR, Pa., May 13 Textbook publishing in America is facing a multitude of troubles troubles with the Federal Government, with a sizable segment of the student population that is demanding more relevant books and with students who, to some extent, are forsaking reading for political action.
In the language of Kipchoge Keino, a world-class runner who has seen his share of competitive moments and is traditionally cautious, "it is going to be a good test."

YONKERS, May 14 All hands were rooting today for a fast track for tomorrow night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway. The prospects for precisely that were bright, in view of the Weather Bureau's forecast that the precipitation probability for tomorrow was only 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 14 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is proposing sweeping changes in administering Medicare and Medicaid aimed at controlling skyrocketing hospital costs.
CINCINNATI, May 14 A dispassionate revolt by churchwomen raised its well coiffured head here today after a man was nominated for the presidency of the American Baptist Convention.
NEW HAVEN, May 14 Superior Court Judge Haroid M. Mulvey today denied a motion to dismiss murder and kidnap charges against Bobby G. eale, a national chairman of the Black Panther party.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14 Several hundred Syrian troops entered Lebanon today and President Charles Helou called his Defense Minister and senior army officers to an urgent conference at the Presidential Palace here to discuss what steps to take.

BERLIN, May 14 Four political extremists, two of them women, shot their way into a West Berlin scientific institute today, wounding three persons, to fre a 28-year-old prisoner. The four escaped with the prisoner.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy described the proposal for national health insurance yesterday as the "single most important, imaginative and farsighted legislation" to be introduced in the 91st Congress.
PARIS, May 14 The United States told the Vietnamese Communists today that their "intransigence" at the bargaining table and heightened activity on the battlefield had become "intolerable."

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 14 Mrs. Richard Stockton Emmet has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katharine Temple Emmet, to David Fulmer True, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. True of Marietta, Ohio. The wedding is planned for next month.
LISBON, May 13 The Portuguese Government acted today to forestall a new university crisis that might delay urgently needed reforms.
LONDON, MAY 14 It now appears almost certain that June 18 will be the date of the next British general election.
Revivalism is a tricky business. This New York drama season must have seen more revivals than any in recent memory and, yet, the course of these revivals has not always run true to form.
Baseball business will get a thorough airing from several directions today when all 24 major league club owners or their representatives hold a joint meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, May 14 Basic economic statistics for April, made public today by Government agencies, offered no support for the argument that business activity is already on the upturn. But they showed no significant worsening in the economy, either.
ROCHESTER, May 14 Arthur J. Goldberg criticized Governor Rockefeller today for alleged inaction and silence on civil disorders in New York State.
LOS ANGELES, May 14 Lyra Halprin was wearing a blue-and-white button on her pink, sleeveless dress. It said, simply, "Enough."

It was just as dreary inside the American Stock Exchange yesterday as outside, where the sun scarcely shone, as prices continued to drop and shares finished at their lowest level since August, 1967, in slightly stepped-up trading.

FORT WORTH, May 14 (AP) Lee Trevino carded a fourunder-par 66 today and tied Gary Player of South Africa for the first-round lead in the $125,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament.
NEW HAVEN, May 14 Harvard kept alive its slim chance for a share of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League title today by beating Yale, 4-0.

KATMANDU, Nepal, May 14 (AP) A Japanese expedition reached the summit of Mount Everest on two consecutive days this week, placing four men atop the world's highest mountain, the Nepal Foreign Ministry said today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 The way the Mutual Fund Industry has gone about opposing legislation to regulate its fees has turned many members of Congress against the entire Securities Industry, in the opinion of Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California.

The triumphant showing of fall fashions that Giorgio di Sant' Angelo unleashed in the conference room of the Seagram Building at noon yesterday was a paean of praise "to the great American civilizations, from the Arctic to the Antarctic."

PARIS, May 31 Clear plastic balloons soaring into the stratosphere over the flatlands of southern France have sent back data indicating the presence of a source of gamma rays in the remote Crab nebula.

William Verity, president of the Armco Steel Corporation, said at a news conference in Paris yesterday that the concern probably would show a decline in second-quarter earnings from the year-earlier level.

Gardner Cowles, chairman of Cowles Communications, Inc., told a stockholders' meeting yesterday that the company's cornerstone publication, Look magazine, lost advertising pages in the first quarter of 1970.

Miss Cynthia Susan Crowder, a pianist and composer, and Jonathan Eben Meyer, a flutist, plan to be married May 23 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy H. Hurlbert of New York, stepfather and mother of the bride-to-be.
WASHINGTON, May 14 The Federal Reserve Board told Congress today that action was needed "this year" on legislation to regulate one-bank holding companies.

The Metropolitan Museum has received its first centennial birthday gift of art, from a refugee couple grateful for "a chance to live in liberty and equality." The gift, a gilded silver-and-mother-ofpearl tabernacle, dating from 1494, was made by Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Blumka, New York art dealers and collectors, who fled the Hitler regime in the early nineteenforties.
HELSINKI, Finland, May 14 (Reuters) President Urho Kekkonen tonight appointed a new coalition Government, with Teuvo Aura, a Liberal who is Lord Mayor of Helsinki, as Premier.
WASHINGTON, May 14 The Office of Economic Opportunity disclosed plans today for a two-part experiment that if successful, "could revolutionize education" for all, not just poor, chidren.
DARIEN, Conn., May 14 Miss Hannah Dee Butler and Alfred Steel Jr. plan to be married here Sept. 12.

The stock market toppled yesterday to a new low since April, 1963, as measured by the Dow-Jones industrial average. A rally led by glamour issues in the final half hour on expanding volume, however, reduced the day's loss markedly from its poorest level.

She just happens to know the song, the arrangement, and the dance and she is terrific. She wins the part (immediately) and also the stage manager (in the second act).

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (AP) Twenty members of the Gay Liberation Front and Women's Liberation Movement attempted today to take over an American Psychiatric Association session on sex problems.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Friday, May 15 Autopsies were ordered yesterday on six Negroes killed here in rioting Monday and Tuesday.

Wheat futures dropped sharply again yesterday in advance of what appears to be another large winter wheat crop. Commercial interests were on the selling side to commission houses and local professionels, among others.

AT the international level it can be argued that bridge is a game for young men. After the age of 50 many experts become slightly less effective. Even if their will to win remains intact, their stamina is severely tested by the need to concentrate fiercely for day after day.

BANAM, Cambodia, May 14 South Vietnamese marines peacefully occupied this prosperous market town on the Mekong River yesterday afternoon in an operation mainly designed to restore the Cambodian Government's presence here.

The commander of a police precinct on the Lower East Side where angry crowds have been involved this week in two nights of street incidents met with community residents yesterday and singled out a rookie patrolman as a major cause of the trouble.

The Assistant Secretary of Commerce, Kenneth N. Davis Jr., said yesterday that he was "not overly optimistic" that an agreement could be reached with Japan for voluntary reduction of her textile exports to this country.

KENT, Ohio, May 14 (UPI) The commander of a National Guard unit whose members shot and killed four Kent State University students says the authorities have evidence a single shot was fired before his troops opened fire.
TEL AVIV, May 14 An Egyptian navy missile boat sent a 70-ton Israeli fishing vessel with a crew of four to the bottom of the Mediterranean last night, the Israeli defense forces said today.
JACKSON, Miss., Friday, May 15 Two persons were killed and 12 wounded early today after the police opened fire on a women's dormitory at Jackson State College here.
GREAT NECK, L.I., May 14 The Rev. Alexander R. McKechnie, rector emeritus of All Saints Episcopal Church, died of a heart ailment yesterday in his home at 37 Brompton Road. He was 74 years old.
DETROIT, May 14 The Ford Motor Company confirmed today that it would build a Volkswagen-size car this fall called the Pinto with no styling changes likely in the future.

WASHINGTON, May 14 It is clear now that there is a determined move in the Congress, and particularly in the Senate, to limit the President's warmaking powers by denying him funds to carry on the Indochina war as he pleases.
TOKYO, May 14 The Tokyo stock market suffered another sharp decline in prices today, echoing the news that Wall Street's Dow-Jones industrial average dropped below 700 yesterday.
BOSTON, May 14 At least three official investigations were under way today into what one city official described as "the worst case of police overreaction" in recent Boston history.

DETROIT, May 14 A Soviet proposal that Ford trucks be built in Russia has been rejected, Henry Ford 2d disclosed today. Public criticism, particularly by Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, was a major influence in the Ford Motor Company's decision, its officials said.

The Federal Reserve System last week withdrew a major portion of the massive amount of funds that it had injected into the money market the preceding week to support Treasury financing operations, banking data published yesterday showed.
Alexander B. Trowbridge, a former Secretary of Commerce, announced yesterday that he had resigned as president and chief executive officer of the American Management Association.
Mayor Lindsay submitted a $7.8-billion expense budget to the Board of Estimate and City Council yesterday an increase of $1.1-billion above the current year's budget.

MASERU, Lesotho, May 11 Lesotho's Prime Minister, Chief Leabua Jonathan, said in an interview this week that he was unique among African leaders because he was the only one who had put his opposition in jail and then opened political negotiations with them.

TRENTON, May 14 Bending under intense, last-minute pressure from Gov. William T. Cahill, the Republican majority in the Assembly reversed itself this evening and gave final legislative approval for a November referendum on lowering the voting age in New Jersey from 21 to 19.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 14 The Indonesians have a nickname for Adam Malik, their Foreign Minister. It is Kantjil, the name of a small, graceful deer of this archipelago nation.

CHICAGO, May 14 The New York Mets and Chicago Cubs were rained out today, and the Mets immediately switched their pitching rotation to put maximum pressure on the Cubs when they meet next in Shea Stadium in nine days.

In the 1970-71 season, five symphony orchestras will make first appearances in the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras sponsored by Carnegie Hall. They are the Melbourne Symphony, Willem van Otterloo conducting; the Zagreb Philharmonic, Milan Horvat conducting; the Atlanta Symphony, Robert Shaw conducting; the Los Angeles Philharmonic, Zubin Mehta conducting; and the New Jersey Symphony, Henry Lewis conducting.

WARSAW, May 14 (Reuters) The Premiers of the Soviet Union and six other Communist countries endorsed here today a draft agreement to set up an investment fank to finance cooperative projects in Comecon, the East European economic alliance.

At a quick glance, Tom (The Bomb) Bethea does not possess the credentials of a challenger for the world middleweight boxing championship. His brief record is mediocre 10 victories, five defeats and one draw, with five knockouts. Scar tissue over his eyes make him vulnerable to a sharp puncher.
WASHINGTON, May 14 The Democratic party moved today to try to mobilize the rising tide of youthful protest behind its candidates for state and Congressional offices.

Dr. Frank R. Mazzola, cardiologist and internist, who had practiced medicine in Queens for 48 years, died Monday of a heart attack at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 73 years old and lived at 86-29 Eton Street, Jamaica Estates.

More than 1,000 New York City lawyers announced yesterday they would stop work next Wednesday to meet legislative and administration officials in Washington to urge "immediate withdrawal from Indochina."
LITTLE CREEK, Va., May 14 A new airborne system for preventing or at least reducing maritime oil spills from damaged tankers is expected to be ready for operational use on the East Coast this fall.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 14--"It's a little early in the season," said Dick Siderow, the Metropolitan amateur golf champion and a Walker Cup team player, after posting a two-over-par 74 today in the William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament.

Earnings at the Great Atlantic and Pacific Company rose 17.8 per cent in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, as sales set a record. The report issued yesterday also showed fourthquarter profits up 32.1 per cent on a 12.1 per cent sales gain over the year-earlier period.

Jane Lauren Alpert, who pleaded guilty May 4 to being part of a conspiracy to bomb Federal office buildings here last fall, was declared yesterday to have forfeited her $20,000 bail. The reason was that she violated the conditions of bail by not checking in with the United States Attorney's office this week.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 14 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today that it had smashed a 14-state bank and loan office burglary ring and won indictments against 15 persons, including a former football star and an escape artist who listed his occupation as a burglar alarm salesman.

Mayor Lindsay and other top administration spokesmen have often referred grimly to the city's "daily death toll." It is a toll that merits even deeper attention than the Mayor or the City Council or other officials have given it.
Mrs. Mary Bergen, wife of retired Rear Adm. John J. Bergen, died Wednesday at the Mayo clinic in Rochester, Minn., after a long illness. She was 73 years old.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 The increasing impact of knitwear on the apparel industry was highlighted here today at the annual convention of the American Apparel Manufacturers Association.

OSSINING, N.Y., May 14 Sister Mary Trinita Logue, regional superior of the Maryknoll Sisters working in the Philippines from 1911 to 1946, died Monday at Bethany, Maryknoll's house for sick and elderly sisters. She was 75 years old.
A special committee investigating police corruption in New York City recommended yesterday that its task be turned over to an independent citizens group with a full-time professional staff.

RYE, N.Y., May 14 Frederick E. Shoninger, who retired last year as senior vice president and director of Yardley of London, Inc., died today in St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 81 Park Drive North.
Barry Farber, the host of a radio discussion program, said yesterday he would run for the House of Representatives from Manhattan's 19th District, now represented by Leonard Farbstein, a Democrat.
WHEN Mrs. Richard J. Fuite of San Diego hears airline stewardesses griping about sore feet and grumbling that they are "nothing but flying waitresses," she smiles and thinks of the good old days.

MADRID There are great expectations in Spain that the next month or so will see Generalissimo Franco begin to engineer a political shift in the direction of what might be called "an opening to the center." The hope is that some of the bleaker vestiges of rightwing autocracy can be shed, permitting at least a hint of democratization during the regime's final moments.

MONTREAL, May 14 (Canadian Press) Canada's finest first turbine-powered passenger train will return to service on May 25 as a result of a decision by Canadian National Railways to give the streamlined carrier a second trial on the MontrealToronto run.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) Enemy troops in the Cambodian sanctuary areas failed to follow a stand-and-fight order, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

Printers at The New York Times extended their non-working chapel meeting sessions to 18 hours a day yesterday in an effort to break the deadlock in contract negotiations with the city's four major daily newspapers.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 14 Responsible Cambodian and South Vietnamese sources say privately here that South Vietnamese troops will fight in Cambodia until the defeat of their common enemy the Vietcong and North Vietnamese.

Willis Reed, captain of the World Champion New York Knickerbocker picked up his third award in four days yesterday at the Pan American building where he was awarded the trophy as the National Basketball Association's Most Valuable player.

WASHINGTON, May 14 President Nixon decided today not to divert money from Model Cities and other programs under the Department of Housing and Urban Development for his special effort for school desegregation.

With 27 of the nation's 72 big Class 1 railroads (those with operating revenues of more than $5-million annually) operating in the red, the nation's railroads ended the first quarter this year with a net loss of $2-million. This was the worst showing for the industry since 1961 and compared with a $94.4-million profit re corded in the first quarter of 1969.

THIS Six-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House Britain's Royal Ballet is offering only one American premiere, Rudi Van Dantzig's "The Ropes of Time," seen for the first time here on Wednesday night.
KINGSTON, Tenn., May 14 Richard A. Irwin, an oil millionaire, died today at his home overlooking Watts Bar Lake in Ten Mile community near here. He was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, May, 14 (AP) Photographs of Mars taken by the Mariner 7 spacecraft indicate that Phobos, one of two moons orbiting the planet, may be the darkest-colored body of any size yet observed in the solar system.
About 60 refugees, crewmen aboard three Haitian Coast Guard cutters that shelled Portau-Prince last month, arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 14 Three ways to escape poverty a winning lottery ticket, presidential patronage or a visa to travel to the United States draw swarms of people each day to three different buildings here.

WASHINGTON, May 14 Concern over a possible Communist attempt to install the headquarters of the exile regime of Prince Norodom Sihanouk in Cambodia after the departure of American troops was reported today to be one reason for a growing expectation here that South Vietnamese forces will stay in Cambodia.

Musicians of the New York City Ballet voted to end their 24-day strike last night by accepting a fact-finder's recommendations for a four-year contract that will cutt he number of weekly performances from eight to seven in the fall of 1971.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, a heavy-rocking rock band from Berkeley, Calif., kept most of the near-capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden on its feet Wednesday evening.

WASHINGTON, May 14 The Administration sent three top officials to the Capitol today to warn Republican Senators that proposed legislation cutting off funds for future military involvement in Cambodia could impair the credibility abroad of President Nixon.

WHEN Electronic Data Systems made a bid for Collins Radio a little over a year ago, the scrappy little computer management company was well on the way to becoming a light blue chip holding for what Wall Street commonly refers to as aggressive investors.
BALTIMORE, May 14 With 14 names sent through the entry box today, the Preakness Stakes will have a gross value of $203,800 for its 95th running at Pimlico Saturday.

The New York Coalition will receive the proceeds of Monday's preview of a series of 12 oil paintings by Palmer Hayden illustrating the "Ballad of John Henry." The show at the Community Art Gallery, 28 East 35th Street, will be open free to the public from Tuesday through June 20.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14 Louis Pensak, physicist of RCA Laboratories, who developed an aluminized picture tube used in television receivers, died yesterday in Princeton Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 119 Random Road.

The nation slides toward isolation in irrationality when politicians at a convention called to draft a state's basic law can suppress as irrelevant a carefully reasoned appeal to halt the disintegration of American society. This is precisely what happened when John W. Gardner was barred from telling the Illinois Constitutional Convention that America is being torn apart by the growing tendency to tolerate violence.

Indra Neela presented a soundly conceived program of solo dances in the Indian Sharata Natyam style Wednesday night at The Cubiculo. The solo recital presented formidable problems in pacing, among other things, and Miss Neela smoothly alternated puredance works with interludes of mimed recitation.
Harry Sinden, whose Boston Bruins gained their reputation as team-wreckers under his dynamic leadership, quit the National Hockey League club yesterday to go into the building business.

The broadcasting industry was told with emphasis yesterday that it is a major contributor to the black rage sweeping the country, and warned that it will either surrender some of its power or have it torn from it in increasingly harsh confrontations.

The gloom that enshrouds Wall Street today is perhaps the heaviest since the early days of the Great Depression. The stock market keeps skidding day after day, with only feeble atattempts at recovery, and the bond market is equally depressed.

A Black Muslim prisoner in the Green Haven State Prison won $13,020 in damages yesterday for being unconstitutionally punished by 372 days of solitary confinement. He also obtained a Federal court order forbidding prison officials from isolating him again without a hearing.

WASHINGTON, May 14 Fear of campus-style antiwar demonstrations by off-duty troops and civilians at major military posts this weekend has forced the cancellation or revision of traditional Armed Forces Day ceremonies at bases across the country.
The Lucas Hoving Dance Company and the Rod Rodgers Dance Company shared the second program Wednesday night in the final week of the City Center's moderndance season.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 14 (UPI) Pancho Genzales moved into the semifinals of the $50,000 Howard Hughes invitation tennis tournament today by upsetting fourth-seeded Andres Gimeno of Spain, 8-6, 6-4.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 14 Sir William Dobell, wellknown Australian portrait painter, was found dead of natural causes in his home at Wangi, 80 miles north of Sydney, today. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 14 A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee plans to issue a report tomorrow urging President Nixon to make good on his promise of nearly six months ago to send to the Senate for ratification the Geneva Protocol of 1925 prohibiting chemical-biological warfare.
May 14, 1970 The Honorable John V. Lindsay Mayor of the City of New York, City Hall New York, N.Y. 10007. My Dear Mr. Mayor:

Howard J. Samuels, a Democratic candidate for Governor, described his party as "a disgrace" yesterday and said he was considering supporting selected Republicans for Congress to begin reforming the Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, May 14 The students who have left the campus to lobby in the Congress this week obviously thought they were leaving academics for politics, but they are caught up now in one of the most difficult intellectual problems of American constitutional law: the power to make war.
JERSEY CITY, May 14 Frank DePaula, once a lightheavyweight boxing contender, was shot at 2:45 A.M. today as he left an apartment house on Harrison Avenue near West Side Avenue here.
WASHINGTON, May 14 The United States balance of international payments worsened sharply in the first quarter by both means of measurement, the Commerce Department reported today.

Activities. The President had a morning meeting with Defense Secretary Laird and Adm. Thomas Moorer, chairman designate of the Joint Chiefs. The President signed the National School Lunch Act and Child Nutrition Act. He presented medals of Honor to 12 Vietnam veterans. The President had a joint meeting with Labor Secretary Shultz, Commerce Secretary Stans, Budget Director Mayo, Economic Adviser McCracken, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Burns and Treasury Under Secretary Volcker.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 14 Dennis Swirsky, an 18-year-old freshman from Adelphi University, scored the first major tournament victory of his career today by winning the Metropolitan Golf Association's 21st intercollegiate tournament.

Stan Bahnsen says that complete games are not so great winning games are much better. But, of course, Bahnsen can afford to be so cool about completing a game since he is the only Yankee pitcher to do so in this decade.

The Appellate Division yesterday ordered resentencing of a convicted extortionist because of the "intimation that a plot was afoot to bribe the sentencing judge" who had imposed a 7-to-14-year jail sentence on the defendant.
The Bond Buyer Index, the most widely used measure of yields on tax-exempt state and city bonds, climbed yesterday to 6.96 per cent, the highest level in the 75-year history of this indicator.
Possible strike action by members of Branch 36 of the New York Letter Carriers was postponed yesterday until June 12 after a noisy meeting at Manhattan Center.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 14 (Reuters) Rhodesia withdrew today from further Davis Cup competition this year, tennis officials announced.

The State Education Department said yesterday that Regents examinations would be given next month as scheduled despite the current antiwar strike by high school students here and their threatened boycott of the state examinations.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 14 (AP) A 31-year-old policeman says an unintentional shot from his riot gun killed a student peacemaker in antiwar disorders last April at nearby Isla Vista.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

WASHINGTON, May 14 The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that many of the recent acquisitions by conglomerate companies were made possible only with the help of large institutional investors who had bought stock in the acquired companies. These investors, in turn, became interested in the deals only because they had received illegal inside information about them, according to Hamer H. Budge, the S.E.C chairman.
A 55-by-26-root mural painted by 12 Lower East Side teen-agers and showing drug-taking, crime and street violence was unveiled yesterday.
MIAMI, May 14 (AP) A former college teacher pleaded guilty in Federal court today to a charge that he hijacked a light airplane to Cuba in 1968.
BALTIMORE, May 14 It was siesta time in the Pimlico stable area, time for the horses in Saturday's Preakness to relax after the hustle and bustle of today's work.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (UPI) The president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors said today that Vice President Agnew's attacks on the news media were a "calculated campaign" to weaken the credibility of the press.

Mrs. Betty Newell Gerhard and William Juhring Broadhurst, both of New York, were married in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday. The Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony, which was attended only by members of the immediate families of the couple.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday the Greyhound Corporation's plan to buy control of Armour Co. through the acquisition of a large block of Armour stock from the General Host Corporation.
The Lincoln Savings Bank, a $1.17-billion Brooklyn-based institution, would absorb the $163-million Broadway Savings Bank of Manhattan under plans announced yesterday by the two concerns.
BUFFALO, May 14 Governor Rockefeller assured students picketing his appearance here today that there could be no repetition of the Kent State University shooting on a New York campus.

"THIS is a bigger upset than the Mets winning the World Series," said one dismayed American Olympic official. He was still in a state of shock after learning that the International Olympic Committee had bypassed the two more obvious candidates, Los Angeles and Moscow, and settled on the unlikely third choice of Montreal as the site of the 1976 Olympic Games.

Residential rents in the New York metropolitan area rose more rapidly than in any other major urban region in the country in the last decade, despite the great proportion of rentcontrolled apartments here, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 President Nixon told a group of Medal of Honor winners today that the war in Southeast Asia was often "not understood and not supported in this country" but that eventually the American people would join him in honoring their valor.
Mike Shannon has provided St. Louis fans with a little medical education this season, and now they're hoping he can give them a lot of baseball excitement.
NEW HAVEN, May 14 Senator Thomas J. Dodd suffered a mild heart attack last night at a key point in his battle for a third term.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 14 Charles W. Yost, the United States representative, accused the Soviet Union in the Security Council today of causing "very grave risks and dangers" by sending military personnel to bolster the United Arab Republic's defense forces.
Jean Claude DeSaint, one of France's leading jockeys, was brought all the way from Europe just to guide Mrs. Raymond R. Guest's Arvidsjaur in yestterday's $18,000 Hichcock hurdles at Aqueduct.

MARJAN, Ljubo, Jurij, Romano, Slobodan, Ivica and Nevenko are seven young Yugoslavs who are helping their country, get a jump on the United States. The group recently completed a tour of American marinas and boatyards that is expected to lead to Yugoslavia ...

The Trinidad-Tobago Government's "present trend" is to encourage the development of Trinidadian-owned industry, Sir Ellis Clarke, Trinidad-Tobago's ambassador to the United States, told a group of American, British and Canadian bankers and industrialists yes terday.

The fate of the Bengal tiger and other rare wild animals may be decided in Albany early next week when Governor Rockefeller is expected to choose for signature one of two measures offered to protect endangered species.

After a mud-slinging session Wednesday that did nothing to advance the cause of Middle East peace, the United Nations Security Council turned yesterday to somewhat more constructive debate on the real issues underlying the most recent flare-up of Arab-Israeli conflict.

The White Motor Corporation and the Ethyl Corporation terminated yesterday their previously announced merger talks because of present economic conditions and the "seriously depressed state of the stock market."
ROME, May 15 Pope Paul VI today sternly reproved members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy who have criticized his way of dealing with important theological issues. He mentioned no names, however.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 15 The White House strongly asserted today its view that a move in the Senate to cut off funds for future military involvement in Cambodia would be an infringement of the President's constitutional powers as Commander in Chief.
Former Chief Justice Earl Warren said yesterday that the United States was in a crisis greater than any "within the memory of living Americans."

American demands that Japan limit exports of textiles and other products to this country while simultaneously admitting more American investment and exports were termed schizophrenic yesterday by George W. Ball, former Under Secretary of State.

The chairman of the City Council's Housing Committee declared yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's proposed revisions of the rent-control law would not be approved without "substantial changes and refinements."

CASTLE HILL, R.I., May 15 (AP) The Coast Guard said today it had found the missing sports fishing boat Mary Jane off the eastern tip of Long Island with the body of its owner, Angelo De Spirito Jr. of North Smithfield, R.I., aboard.
The record-breaking $7.8-billion general expense budget proposed for New York City for the next fiscal year is a "stringent" budget in the view of Mayor Lindsay's aides.

The Nippon Steel Corporation, a newly formed Japanese producer, has supplanted the United States Steel Corporation as the world's largest steel company and the Japanese concern will be twice the size of the American leader within five years.

MILLINGTON, N.J., May 15 The auxiliary for Boys here has arranged luncheons and fashion shows for Monday and Tuesday at Mayfair Farms in West Orange. Tickets at $6 each are available from the beneficiary's office at 605 Broad Street in Newark.

The American Museum of Natural History, which is that big red building on Central Park West between 77th and 79th Streets, the one with all the dinosaurs, is by second nature one of our first art museums. The latest...

YONKERS, May 15 Billy Haughton's gamble paid off tonight when he moved Rum Customer past the front-running Good Chase of New Zealand early in the race and won the $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, May 15 Proudly displayed on the wall of Jerris Leonard's office is a newspaper clipping quoting his teen-age daughter as telling a testimonial dinner that her father, the head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, "is far from perfect, but he is only human."'
Political activism has flared at Rockefeller University here without igniting the turmoil that has been troubling many other campuses throughout the city and nation.

FORT WORTH, May 15 (AP) Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina carded a four-under-par 66 today to tie Lee Trevino and Bob Smith for the second round lead in the $125,000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament with an aggregate of 136.

WASHINGTON, May 15 The Justice Department contended today that the segregated private schools that have grown up recently in the South should be allowed to keep their tax-exempt status. It said that the exemption did not constitute any form of Government "support" for these schools.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) New housing starts dropped sharply in April after two monthly increases, the Commerce Department reported today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 15 A Lebanese official who reported yesterday that Syrian regular troops had entered the southeastern Lebanese district of Arkoub said today that he had been mistaken.
LOS ANGELES, May 15 Billie Burke, a great Broadway beauty when the century was young and later renowned as a movie comedienne, died last night at the age of 84.

LONDON, May 15 In one of the great Supreme Court opinions on freedom of speech, Mr. Justice Brandeis wrote that those who won America's independence thought "the deliberative forces should prevail over the arbitrary" in society.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 15 (AP) Arts and Letters, 1969's Horse of the Year and Nodouble, the highweight and last year's winner, head a field of nine entered in the $100,000 added Californian at Hollywood Park tomorrow.
Everybody knows the game is never over until the last man is out, but Ted Williams and the Washington Senators can't even be sure the game is over when the last man is out.
MANHASSET, L.I., May 15 Miss Jane Louise Batten and Payson Sibley Wild Jr. plan to be married July 25. Both are graduates of Monmouth (Ill.) College.
A visiting detachment of evzones, the famed skirted warriors of Greece, will be on hand in the Astoria section of Queens today for ceremonies accompanying the demolition of an old mansion.

In an effort to reverse profit erosion, Spartans Industries, Inc., plans to restructure its $150-million apparel manufacturing division on a new incentive basis, probably a joint venture nature with a dozen key divisional executives.
Possible strike action by members of Branch 36 of the New York Letter Carriers was postponed Thursday until June 12 after a noisy meeting at Manhattan Center.
As their families and friends remembered them, neither of the two students killed by policemen at Jackson State College Thursday night was active in what Mississippi blacks call "Politics."
TOKYO (AP) Policemen from 15 nations took over the control of road traffic, each for two minutes, at one of the busiest intersections in Tokyo.

For one laugh-filled hour, hundreds of people somersaulted, danced, fell, stumbled, and crawled about on the white plastic-wrapped air mound in front of 29 West 53d Street as if they were cavorting in snow drifts.

WITH TASK FORCE 318 IN CAMBODIA, May 15 (AP) South Vietnamese forces, battling through a tiny hamlet, have discovered the press credentials of three American correspondents missing and believed captured by the enemy.

Now that the Jet, Met and Knick miracles are out of the way the New York Yankees are quietly working on their owns dreams, as is their right, and last night's 4-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers did nothing to interrupt their happy, private, wishful thoughts.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 15 (AP) Joe Fargis placed eighth for the best United States finish today in the opening jumping event in the Wiesbaden international equstrian tournament.
OCEANSIDE, L. I., May 15--National Council of Jewish Women, Peninsula Section, will hold its annual spring dinner dance at the Middle Bay Country Club here next Saturday.

CHICAGO, May 14 Three high-ranking Chicago police officers were demoted last night, apparently as a result of a controversy over a police raid last Dec. 4 on a Black Panther apartment in which two Panther leaders were killed.

KENT, Ohio, May 15 (UPI) A search of dormitory rooms vacated after four Kent State University students were shot to death turned up a small number of guns, knives and drugs, the Portage County Prosecutor, Ronald J. Kane, said today.
ATHENS, Ga., May 15 (UPI) More than 200 Negro and white demonstrators, chanting "soul power," were arrested for parading without a permit tonight and hauled away in National Guard trucks.

SARAVANE, Laos, May 15 As the 105-mm howitzer in the Government military compound kept firing at the advancing North Vietnamese troops, who are now less than four miles away, the frightened residents of this town in southern Laos appealed yesterday to a group of visitors to help them get evacuated.
In our age of affluence, the core problem is one of isolated individual bravery, not collective heroism, which is the response more appropriate in a deprived time.
ATHENS, Ohio, May 15 Ohio University was closed at 3:10 o'clock this morning.
MOSCOW, May 15 (UPI) Soviet authorities have lifted their temporary ban on the first United States traveling exhibition in Siberia, the United State Embassy said today.

Daniel Patrick Moynihan, an adviser to President Nixon, criticized social scientists yesterday for analyzing social ills without at the same time displaying a similar competence at offering solutions.

TAURANGA, New Zealand Last May I chanced to be in Israel at her twenty-first birthday party: blue-and-white flags whooping it up on pastel-tinted buildings and the young of the country celebrating in "a coat of many colors." In New Jerusalem a day-long procession of the combat forces in coats of even more colors, converging from the countryside, marching and singing to circle the Old Jerusalem. All on their way somewhere.

Two weeks ago, Tommy Trotter, the racing secretary at Aqueduct, thought today's feature race, the Acorn, might attract a dozen fillies. Last week, he increased his estimate to 18. Five days ago, he increased it again to 22.

The first Mystic Ball sponsored by the National Kidney Foundation has been scheduled for the Rainbow Room on May 25; and if the interest shown so far in its occult themes is an indication of things to come, the event could become a fixture on the crowded spring benefit calendar.
Blue Ribbon award-winners in 30 short-film categories were announced last night at the concluding banquet of the 12th annual American Film Festival at the New York Hilton.

BUFFALO, May 15 Howard J. Samuels charged today that his rival for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Arthur J. Goldberg, was not involved in the issues of the day and is the candidate of the old politics.
HANGAROA, Easter Island An American military jet slipped in from the sea past the grim old monoliths that ring Easter Island and roared to a short and dusty stop on the new airstrip.
JERUSALEM, May 15 The air war over the Suez Canal intensified today as the Israelis reported that they had shot down three Egyptian jet fighters.

Although one large producer announced an increase in list prices for industrial grades of refined sugar by 35 cents a hundred pounds in all territories, the No. 8 world sugar futures involving raw sugar were unchanged to down 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 The Defense Department extended today the list of military bases across the country at which tomorrow's traditional Armed Forces Day ceremonies and "open house" visit by civilians have been canceled to avoid confrontations with antiwar protesters.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 15 Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill's Brandan, a new mount on the circuit, captured the first open jumper class today at the opening session of the three-day Lancaster spring horse show at the Lancaster Riding and Tennis Club.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 15 Coroner Nathan F. Widener reported tonight that autopsies showed that six Negroes killed in Augsta during riots on Monday and Tuesday were "all shot in the back and all killed with O O buckshot."
Take any slice out of the music of the composer Meyer Kupferman heard at Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night and it would be fresh and idiomatic in sound and dramatic in concept.

Sidney Alexander, an American author who lives in Florence, has received the 1970 P.E.N. Club prize for his translation into English of the 16thcentury text of Francesco Giucciardini's "History of Italy."

Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell four Boeing 747 jumbo jets, which the airline was scheduled to receive from Boeing next fall and in late 1971, to Trans World Airlines. T.W.A. said it would pay approximately $88million for the four jets.
Some New York State drivers about to be forbidden to drive because they had three convictions for speeding are to get another chance.
Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had submitted an unbalanced budget because of overly optimistic projected revenues from offtrack betting and the state lottery.
A man shot and wo8nded a man and a cab driver and then killed himself in front of the Eastern Airlines terminal at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon, according to the police.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 15 (AP) Plans to dismiss two air traffic controllers and to suspend three others for their part in a "sick-out" at the Olathe Traffic Control Center have been disclosed by the Federal Aviation Administration.

JACKSON, Miss., May 15 A barrage of police gunfire that lasted 30 seconds and consisted of at least 140 shots left two students dead and nine other persons wounded here last night. All the dead and wounded were Negroes.
Two members of the Radical Jewish Union of Columbia University were arrested yesterday after they disrupted services at Temple Emanu-El to protest the war in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, May 15 At 12:05 this afternoon, Carter Burgess broke into an expansive smile and handed George Defranceaux two tens and a twenty.

Metromedia, Inc., a diversified communications conglomerate, announced yesterday that it would give its $3-million San Francisco television facility, KNEW-TV, to that city's public television station, KQEDTV.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 15 (AP) Clark Shaughnessy, one of the leading coaches of football, who revived the Tformation, died today. He was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 15 Congress is virtually staggering under an avalanche of mail, telegrams and petitions, heavily opposed to use of United States troops in Cambodia.
ROME, May 15 The Vatican's ranking prelate in charge of interfaith relations, Jan Cardinal Willebrands, presented guidelines today for ecumenism in higher education.
NEWARK, May 15 (AP) Walter Zirpolo, former Mayor of Woodbridge Township, was found guilty today in a briberyconspiracy trial.

The two one-act plays by Lawrence Holofcener and Kenneth Pressman that opened last night at the Fortune Theater are about men who inhabit basement apartments and have hyperactive fantasy lives. In each case, the playwright purposely confuses the fantasy and the reality to keep the play moving and the audience guessing.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 15 Ronald T. Bohle, 22 years old, was sentenced today to 25 years in prison on his conviction for aircraft piracy.

WASHINGTON, May 15 A Library of Congress study depicts as "a trade-off" President Nixon's decision to limit America's use of chemical and biological warfare but to continue to use tear gas and defoliants in war.
BALTIMORE, May 15 A Real dark horse only a month ago, Robert Lehmann's Dust Commander enjoys the status of favorite at 5 to 2 for the Preakness tomorrow.
The New York Post announced yesterday that the newsstand price of its daily paper would be increased from 10 cents to 15 cents starting Monday.

When four white students were killed on their campus by the Ohio National Guard last week, some black leaders expressed sympathy but not surprise. They noted that their people had been shot, hanged and burned for many decades by Guardsmen, police and self-appointed vigilantes, rarely with any great national outrage afterward.
The Police Department announced yesterday that it had made 76.7 per cent more narcotics arrests this March than in March, 1969. The total rose to 4,887 from 2,765 in March of last year.

TRENTON, May 15 A Federal judge rejected Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio's request today for a delay of his trial here on extortion and income tax evasion charges until after the June 16 mayoral runoff election in Newark.
The new-issue market ground to nearly a standstill this week as no companies found the investment climate sufficiently receptive to attempt a first public stock offering.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 A mistrial was declared tonight in the libel trial involving Look magazine and Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco.
State Supreme Court Justice Ivan Warner has upheld the right of the City Consumer Affairs Department to license process servers and processserving agencies.

Jane Lauren Alpert, who was declared to have forfeited her $20,000 bond after she disappeared last week while awaiting sentence on a bombing conspiracy conviction, was indicted yesterday for failing to appear in Federal Court.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 15 Although the Asian conference on Cambodia does not begin until tomorrow, it already seems destined to be neither a failure nor a success.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 Norman M. Hinerfeld, the newly elected president of the American Apparel Manufacturers Association, is a man with a reputation as an iconoclast in a tradition-bound industry.
HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 15--Dick Siderowf, the Metropolitan amateur golf champion, indicated he was back in form today as he gained the semifinal of the William D. Richardson Memorial tourney.
The Public Safety Committee of the City Council will begin an investigation next week of alleged corruption in the Police Department.

BALTIMORE, May 15 Baseball makes its teams qualify for the World Series, auto racing bans slow cars from the Indianapolis 500 and golf wouldn't think of letting a weekend duffer play in the Master's tournament.

OTTAWA, May 15 (Canadian Press) Canada's trade surplus soared to $655-million (Canadian funds) in the first quarter of 1970, the highest seasonally adjusted surplus on record, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) Religious Heritage of America, Inc., announced today the selection of President Nixon as its churchman of the year. He was cited for...

NEW HAVEN, May 15 Arkady V. Belinkov, a Soviet writer and literary critic, who, with his wife, received asylum in the United States in 1968, died last night of a heart ailment in Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 48 years old.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L.I., represented by James Miller, had the only undefeated record today after the first four rounds of the opening inter-club match racing regatta for the Greenwich Cup were sailed on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Yacht Club.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 15 South Africa was expelled today from the International Olympic Committee. That means the country cannot compete in the Olympic Games.

SUEZ, United Arab Republic, May 15 This shell-battered town at the southern end of the Suez Canal underwent another day of warfare today. Bomb explosions rumbled in the distance. Nearby artillery pieces barked in the direction of Israeli positions in the Sinai. Puffs of white smoke appeared briefly high in the cloudless sky as Egyptian jets fired rockets in an attack across the canal.

A meeting between Gov. William T. Cahill and 200 student leaders from New Jersey campuses turned into a shouting match yesterday as several students pressed the Governor for answers to questions on the war in Vietnam and the Black Panther party.

PARIS, May 15--France began a new series of nuclear tests today with a "low power" explosion over the lagoon of Mururoa atoll in the Tuamotu Archipelago in the South Pacific, the Ministry of Defense announced in a brief communique.

The Who, the British rock group, is preparing to present its rock opera "Tommy" at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 7, and at least one Met fan has suggested that, in keeping with the elegant ambience the Who become the Whom for the evening.

Short ceremonies, scotch, salami and Dixieland jazz were the order of the afternoon yesterday at Gracie Mansion as Mayor Lindsay acted as host for the National Basketball Association champions, the New York Knickerbockers.

The American Stock Exchange made its first advance in more than a week yesterday as most of the list ended in the plus column in fairly active trading.

Stock prices surged in a dramatic turnabout yesterday to register their best advance in more than two years. The DowJones industrial average, closing at its highest level of a busy session, boomed to 702.22 with a gain of 17.43 points.
A painting of a can of Campbell's vegetable beef soup by Andy Warhol, the pop artist, was auctioned Thursday for $60,000 to a European bidder who wished to remain anonymous.

Frank Costello, the dapper gambler once known as the "Prime Minister of the Underworld," testified for an hour and a half yesterday afternoon before a New York County grand jury that is believed to be investigating gambling in the metropolitan area.

A controversial student complaint table was opened in George Washington High School yesterday, but it attracted few complainants.

Two executives of the Delafield Capital Corporation, investment bankers for the King Resources Company in its plan to take over control of Investors Overseas Services, left last night for Geneva to confer with John M. King, chairman of King Resources.

Tight money claimed its first major victim in the computer software field, as John A. DeVries, president and chairman of Computer Applications, Inc., the nation's second largest computer software concern resigned yesterday from the company he founded.

If there is one work that no college musician should be allowed to graduate without being introduced to, it is Bach's B minor Mass. Not that it is a student work; anything but, of course. You may, if you are lucky, hear one or two entirely acceptable performances of the B minor Mass in a lifetime of professional concertgoing.

LAVINA, Argentina, May 15 (UPI) Two British drivers, Andrew Cowan and Brian Coyle, were injured today when their car crashed on a mountainous portion of the World Cup auto rally. Cowan was reported to have suffered a fractured skull and Coyle was badly shaken in the accident. Both were reported to be in serious condition.

VIFNTIANE, Laos, May 15 (Agence France-Presse) A Laotian Defense Ministry spokesman expressed today the growing concern of the military command over the situation in southern Laos and suggested that, from a military point of view, it was necessary that South Vietnamese forces intervene to help "clean up" Laos.
GENEVA, May 15 Members of the World Health Organization called today for a worldwide campaign against cigarette smoking, including restrictions and advertising.

The Royal Ballet's production of Kenneth MacMillan's "Romeo and Juliet" permits various interpretations from its protagonists. Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Antoinette Sibley and Anthony Dowell, perfectly paired as the young lovers, left their highly personal stamp on the title roles.
BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 15 Miss Susannah Ellen Sard and Robert Wallis Ward Jr., son of Mrs. Ward of Georgetown, Ky., and the late Mr. Ward, will be married here on June 27.

WASHINGTON, May 15 A special Federal grand jury in Chicago reported today that the police there had grossly exaggerated Black Panthers' resistance in a shooting incident last Dec., 4 in which two of the militants were killed and four others wounded.
WASHINGTON, May 15 The United States publicly encouraged South Vietnam and Cambodia today to produce a joint plan for the defense of the regime of Premier Lon Nol in Pnompenh from Communist attacks.

Based on the assumption that in every crisp, tailored woman there is a mysterious enchantress yearning to come out at night, two young women from India have set up a couture design house for the sort of feminine, seductive dress that immediately separates the girls from the tomboys.

MOSCOW, May 15 A prominent Soviet economist indicated today that the muchdebated national economic plan for the next five years would place continued stress on tight, centralized direction but would rely increasingly on computers and other technological innovations to help run the economy more efficiently.

Two opposing poles of pianism, the Haydn D. major Concerto and the "Burleske" by Richard Strauss, were played last night by the soloist with the New York Philharmonic. Israela Margalit was the pianist, and it was her New York debut. She is the wife of Lorin Maazel, who conducted the orchestra as part of his current Philharmonic engagement.

MOSCOW, May 15 Walter Ulbricht and other East German leaders made an unexpected trip to Moscow today for talks with top Soviet officials. The discussions were presumed to have dwelt on East German and Soviet policies toward West Germany.
Stock prices moved ahead along a broad front yesterday to register their best one-day advance in more than two years. The Dow-Jones industrial average gained 17.43 points at 702.22.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell accused the city yesterday of having mishandled antipoverty funds, and called for investigations by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Justice Department and the Office of Economic Opportunity.
DETROIT, May 15 Hank Ghant, a union man, the vice president of Local 212 in Detroit, stood behind the stage, curtains at the Ford Auditorium and sang the last good-by to Walter P.Reuther.

OPENING bids of three notrump represent a zone of mystery in bidding theory. Many experts use the "Gambling Three No-Trump," in which the bid shows a long solid minor suit together with a degree of outside strength from nothing to all suits stopped according to partnership understanding.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets to a 4-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight and allowed only one hit, the same number that Gary Gentry allowed the Chicago Cubs two days ago in the Mets last game.

DURING last summer's crisis on the Long Island Railroad, Bill Ronan lost his temper at a press conference because of a pesky questioner, who turned out to be a commuter and not a reporter. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, felt that his reaction had projected an unfortunate image for the M.T.A.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 16 (AP) Pancho Gonzales, the 42-year-old tennis pro, posted a stunning victory over the top seeded Rod Laver of Australia today in the $47,000 Howard Hughes championships.

DENVER, May 16 Miss Brooke Somerville Babcock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Babcock of Katonah, N.Y., and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, was married here this afternoon to William King Prather, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Prather of Denver.
EARLY American settlers called it "Indian turnip" because Indians col lected its acrid-tasting bulb-like roots to boil and eat. Most of us know it by the more piquant name "jack in-the-pulpit."

RAMALLAH, Occupied Jordan. THE main square of Ramallah has a fountain with seven lions' heads, for the seven first families of this three-centuries-old town. But the water no longer runs. "The Jews damaged it in the Six-Day War," a resident says.

It was to be hoped that the newly established American Opera Center of the Juilliard School would turn its attention to more than just the standard repertory and essay the new or the neglected. In their second production at the Juilliard Theater Friday night, they visited the past with a vengeance, digging up an 1837 opera, 'Il Giuramento," by a practically forgotten Italian, Saverio Mercadante.
MONTREAL, May 16 (UPI) Michel Briere of the Pittsburgh Penguins was reported to be in fair condition in Notre Dame Hospital today following a fourhour operation to remove a blood clot from his brain.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 16 The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L.I., won the first interclub matchracing regatta for the Greenwich Cup today, when the twoday round-robin series in Soling Class sloops was concluded with three races on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Y.C.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) The secretary general of the International Iron and Steel Institute predicts that world production of steel this year will be 590 million to 600 million metric tons, compared with 572 million in 1969.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) The government announced yesterday a $6.1million out-of-court settlement of a 19-year-old land claim brought by the Acoma Pueblo Indians of New Mexico.

TAMPA, FLA. Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, gave hope here recently for a nonlegalistic decision on cases before the board involving airlines that have purchased ship lines and intend to operate combination air-ship cruises.

AN antique is an antique when it is 100 years old, according to a recent ruling by the Bu reau of Customs. Prior to this latest directive, the customs people would waive duty only on items manufactured prior to 1830. For rugs and carpets, the date was 1701; for violins, voilas, violincellos and double basses, 1801.

But none is more violent locally than a tornado and none is so little understood.

Saltonstall Jr., a descendant of a famed Republican Massachusetts family. He will make an announcement soon after June 1, informed sources say.

FOR the second time in his life Yelberton Abraham Tittle is leaving San Francisco to help the New York Football Giants. He won't be able to make the physical contributions he gave in the early years of the last decade when he led them to three straight championship playoffs. But that ken football mind will be as sharp as ever in his new role as a member of the coaching staff.
WASHINGTON, May 18(UPI) Neil A. Armstrong, the first man to set foot on the moon, is leaving the astronaut corps to take a Washington desk job with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange increased 374,084 shares in the month ended May 15, marking the second consecutive monthly increase for this widely watched stock-market indicator. According to figures released by the exchange yesterday the total short interest as of the midMay settlement date was 14,579,740 shares.

READING, Pa., May 20 Miss Susan Ellen Posey and Arthur McKinne Stires, Jr., a grandson of the late Right Rev. Ernest Milmore Stires, who was Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, will be married Aug. 8 in Lexington, Mass.
BIENHOA, South Vietnam, May 20 A South Vietnamese general hinted today that South Vietnamese troops would stay in Cambodia until the Vietcong and North Vietnamese were driven back to North Vietnam.

The mother of Joan Bird, one of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places, testified yesterday that she heard her daughter scream while being interviewed in another room by a policeman.

Most college and university campuses were relatively quiet yesterday, with the emphasis as much on political planning as on demonstrations, although one episode of violence occurred, apparently unrelated to the nationwide protest movement.

A detective assigned to police headquarters here has been suspended on charges that he was making more than $10,000 a year selling confidential information from police files to banks, airlines, detective agencies and other companies.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The American Textile Manufacturers Institute was joined by the Textile Workers Union of America in urging the House Ways and Means Committee today to enact legislation on textile-import quotas.

JACKSON, Miss., May 20 Black students who said they had witnessed last week's slaying of two Negroes by the Police at Jackson State College told four visiting Democratic Congressmen today that they had seen a Mississippi Highway Patrol aptain rake a crowd of students with automatic fire.
BERLIN, May 20 Premier Stoph of East Germany will strive for "equal relations of peaceful coexistence" with Bonn at the meeting with Chancellor Brandt tomorrow.
BOSTON, May 20 Business in 1970 should be a little better than 1969, but not much.
The name of the game: "29 vs. '69 which is worse?"

LISBON, May 20 The Portuguese are openly showing their cigarette lighters now, without fear of prosecution or denunciation. This and other smaller movements reflect a slight liberalization of the Portuguese regime, but Premier Marcello Caetano has not taken action to restore fundamental freedoms.

RYE, N. Y., May 20--Mr. and Mrs. James N. Buttrick have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Ann Patricia (Dede) O'Neill, to David Mabon Knott. He is the son of Mrs. William E. Stockhausen of Locust Valley, L.I., and Dorset, Vt., and David H. Knott Jr., an Army lieutenant killed in action in Italy in 1943, and grandson of the late Mr. Knott, founder of the Knott Hotels Corporation.
The Philadelphia Women's Lacrosse Association will be hostess to the 1970 tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association at Swarthmore (Pa.) College, June 13, 14 and 15.

The Consumer Price Index in the New York metropolitan area rose by 0.7 per cent last month, pushing the total increase for the first four months of this year to 3 per cent the biggest jump recorded in a similar period since the warboom days of 1943.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The White House was reportedly faced today with the possibility of a revolt by some moderate and liberal Republican Senators if it failed to go along with an amendment cutting off funds for future military involvement in Cambodia.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 20 Charles A. Fuller, a former partner in the firm of Slocum Fuller, New York, consulting engineers in heating, ventilating and air conditioning, died Monday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco. He was 89 years old and lived at 47A Church Street. He retired in 1950.

Funds for the preservation of the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature and History will be raised Tuesday at a cocktail party and entertainment from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art.

Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., one of the country's largest operators and builders of nursing homes and child-care centers, which has had some recent reverses, announced yesterday that Jack L. Clark, its founder, chairman and president, has resigned for health reasons.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 19 (A.P) Coach Bob Leonard of the Indiana Pacers predicted early in the season that Roger Brown would score 50 to 60 points in a game. And Brown picked just the right time to do it.

MASERU, Lesotho, May 11 The French missionaries who came to Basutoland in the last century described in their journals a fat and lovely land. Hippopotamuses played in clear, willow-lined streams. Teal, waterbirds and game came to little lakes and basins "carpeted with watercress" under timbered hills.
THE mark of a truly great grandmaster is his dog ged endurance under adversity. He may split a point in a seemingly lost position.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The credibility of the Nixon Administration's efforts to control the Federal budget was dealt another blow by the disclosure yesterday of new and more realistic estimates of spending and receipts for the current and the new fiscal years.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 20 (AP) The Texas Railroad Commission today cut the state's allowable oil production for June to 59 per cent of potential. It was the second monthly reduction in a row.

MONTREAL, May 20 With an opportunity to move into first place in the Eastern Division of the National League, the New York Mets put their best arm forward tonight. But as good as it was, it wasn't good enough.

WASHINGTON, May 20 Fifty Foreign Service officers who signed a letter to Secretary of State William P. Rogers two weeks ago protesting the United States operation in Cambodia have been warned by their superiors that they acted out of turn in publicly criticizing the Administration.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 20 Martin Michael Branner, creator of the Winnie Winkle comic strip, died at the Nutmeg Pavilion Convalescent Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Waterford.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would raise prices about 9 per cent, effective June 1, on the bars used to reinforce concrete structures.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 Milton J. Shapp, an insurgent, narrowly won the Democratic nomination for Governor for the second consecutive time yesterday, again beating State Auditor General Robert P. Casey and the disorganized Democratic organization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced today that it was divesting itself of the Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, a key center for space and military research. It has developed the guidance systems for the Apollo spacecraft and various guided missiles.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 20 Tom Ulozas, a 27-year-old professional from Bamm Hollow, added a second-round 71 to his first-day 68 to retain the lead in the $25,000 Dodge open golf tournament over the lush Rockaway River Country Club course today.

MOSCOW, May 20 An underground Soviet newsletter has reported that several political trials were held recently, with the defendants in all cases accused of slandering the Soviet Union, a criminal offense.
LONDON (A.P) A dream has come true for Clyde Best, 19year-old Negro soccer star from Bermuda.

STEVENS POINT, Wis., May 20 Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Hensler, formerly of Rumson, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jeanne Hensler, to Peter P. Artaserse Jr., son of Judge and Mrs. Artaserse of Jersey City.
The stock market took another downward lurch yesterday in a broad setback that erased the vestiges of last Friday's explosive rally.

KASSEL, West Germany, May 20 On the eve of the East-West meeting in this Hessian city, Chancellor Willy Brandt disclosed heer today that he was ready to offer the Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany a 20point program that could inaugurate negotiations on a treaty between the two German states.

MOUNTAINDALE, N.Y. Gray skies and cold, wet weather had no apparent effect on the good spirits of those attending the fatherand-son shooting and fishing seminar here last weekend, which was sponsored by Winchester-Western and the Cortland Line Company.

Robert Moses characterized the proposed South Richmond project on Staten Island last night as "a gaudy trial balloon which, like so many before it, will float harmlessly off into space and evaporate."

PHILADELPHIA, May 20-- Mrs. Virginia Knauer, Presidential assistant for consumer affairs, said today that 30 per cent of community water supply samples taken in a Federal survey had shown excessive amounts of germs and chemicals.

YONKERS, May 20 Harness racing under the aegis of Yonkers Raceway was presented on two fronts, 30 miles apart, today and tonight. The action started at 1:30 P.M. with four "baby" races at Roosevelt Raceway and was completed about 10 hours later with the regular nine-event card here at the Westchester County course.
Fifty members of the Jewish Defense League occupied an Orthodox synagogue opposite the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday to protest persecution of Jews in the Soviet Union.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator whose expensive television advertising has become something of a campaign issue, says he sees no justification for charges that he is "trying to buy" the June 23 primary election.
BUFFALO, May 20--About 1,500 construction workers demonstrated in support of the Nixon Administration's policies in southeast Asia at a rally this noon in front of City Hall.
George Meany described the nation's unemployment situation yesterday as "very serious."
