WASHINGTON, May 20 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel argued Israel's case before hesitant State Department officials today, calling for more forthright American military support against what both sides agreed was a potentially dangerous Soviet presence in the Middle East.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 20 Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy bluntly warned Japan and the nations of the European Common Market today that, if they do not lower their barriers to increased world trade, Congress might well take action to restrict imports into the United States.
ESCONDIDO Calif. (AP) Wedding bells are ringing again for Carl Blake and Miss Hilma Barnes almost a halfcentury after they were divorced.

"From an esthetic point of view, your position is perfect," says Sayer to Maria, whom he has just hung from a rack by her manacled wrists, the better to take his pleasure. A little, later he declares that he tends to murder his mistresses exactly at the moment of climax. "Have you always had Sex this Way?," she asks. "Always."

Jane R. Larkin, the sholarly daughter of a Manhattan police detective, is scheduled to become the second woman member of the New York Stock Exchange in Wall Street history. The trim, auburn-haired partner in Hirsch Co. appeared before the exchange's nominating committee Tuesday and probably will be voted into membership by the board of governors June 4 after the customary two-week waiting period.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The United States today publicly acknowledged for the first time the possibility that South Vietnamese troops might remain in Cambodia after the withdrawal of United States forces, scheduled to be completed by June 30.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The nation's capital, inundated in recent weeks with students lobbying against the war in Indochina, had a new lobby on its hands today more than 1,000 New York City lawyers, mostly well barbered, well-tailored and well-prepared with legal arguments against the war.

NEWARK, May 20 The Republican chairman of Hudson County and a reputed Mafia figure were indicted by the state grand jury in Trenton today on charges of conspiring to gain the appointment of a Hudson Prosecutor who would not move against gambling.
INWOOD, L.I., May 20 "Oh Jimmy, that 15th was simply marvey!" exclaimed a woman club member today as she kissed Jim Wright, seconds after he captured the 46th Long Island open golf championship.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 20 (UPI) Orval E. Faubus, who served as Governor of Arkansas for 12 years, announced today that he would run for Governor again.

FREIBERG, West Germany, May 20 (Reuters) The United States breezed past Yugoslavia, 3-0, today in the secnd round of the Federation Cup women's tennis team championship. The Americans dropped only three games in the three matches.

Dr. Lyman R. Fisher of Ithaca, N.Y., a 63-year-old surgeon, has become the new dog show committee chairman of the Westminster Kennel Club, whose annual event is a February fixture in Madison Square Garden. The appointment was made public after the club's annual meet-...

Two persons were killed and at least 71 were injured yesterday morning when an empty IND subway train smashed into a crowded rush-hour train as it switched tracks near the Roosevelt Avenue station in Jackson Heights, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The rate of inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, worsened slightly in April after an improvement in the first quarter of this year, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 President Nixon asked the Senate today to consent to the ratification of two treaties dealing with the threat of oil pollution by ships at sea and the liability of ship owners for coastal damage from oil spills from tankers.
WASHINGTON, May 20 President Nixon is expected to ask Congress tomorrow for $500-million, including $150million on an emergency basis, to ease school desegregation problems in the next fiscal year.

Schubert's "Winterreise," a gloom-ridden cycle of 24 songs about a man whose fiancee married someone else, is not a usual choice for a New York debut recital program, but Eugene Flam, a baritone, selected it for his appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night.

NEW ORLEANS, May 20 (AP) The Federal Appeals Court here denied today a request by the former heavyweight boxing champion, Cassius Clay, to leave the country for a fight with the champion, Joe Frazier, in Canada.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20 The United States announced here today that it would henceforth actively discourage American investment in South-West Africa as long as South Africa continued to rule the area in defiance of the United Nations.
LONDON A School has apologized over the case of a 5-year-old boy who was gagged with sticky tape for talking in class.

The General Foods Corporation recorded a sharp earnings increase in its fourth fiscal quarter ended March 28, but the company showed a decline in earnings for the full year, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The departure of John W. McCormack, one of the Capitol's most conspicuous symbols of the Old Politics, may not usher in that new era in the House of Representatives that his critics have been seeking at all.
NAPLES, Fla, (AP) The Florida Trail is being blazed because James Kern, a Miami real-estate man, likes to hike.

Shock and grief are the instant reactions to the subway disaster in Queens that killed two passengers and injured many others yesterday. But beyond the anguish for the victims, the accident calls for an unsparing investigation. Confidence in the city's mass transportation system is badly shaken. It can be restored only by the speedy elimination of all factors human, managerial and mechanical which were, or could be, responsible.
WASHINGTON, May 20 Speaker of the House John W. McCormack announced today that he would retire from Congress at the end of this session.

HONG KONG, Thursday, May 21 In one of his rare public pronouncements, Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of the Chinese Communist party, issued a personal call yesterday for world revolution against "United States imperialism."

Deceit, E.P. Taylor's undefeated filly, extended her victory streak to four in taking the $29,750 Fashion Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The Kentucky-bred daughter of Prince John and Double Agent surged in the stretch to overtake the front-running Campagna, whom she defeated by four lengths. Campagna, with Jorge Velasquez up, had another four lengths on the third finisher, Lady Herald.
Miss Marlena Maduro, an editorial assistant at Harper Row Publishers, and Donald L. Block Baraf, a lawyer with Graubard, Moskovitz, McGoldrick, Dannett Horowitz here, plan to be married next month.

Dr. Herman Nunberg, a psychoanalyst who had been a member of Dr. Sigmund Freud's group, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 11.48 Fifth Avenue.

Of the first 10 college football players drafted by the National Football League, only five are expected to be graduated with their classes. Teammates of the top 10, a fairly representative sampling of the next 432 players selected, had a slightly greater proportion of baccalaureates-to-be: 23 of 41 would be graduated with their classes.
The Roman Catholic Church in the United States experienced its first decline in membership in this century, according to figures released in the latest edition of The Official Catholic Directory.
Edwin F. (Win) Young, an outstanding diver at the University of Indiana and a member of the 1968 United States Olympic team, has been named diving coach at Dartmouth College.

HAMBURG, West Germany, May 20 (Reuters) President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic was quoted in an interview published today in the newspaper Die Welt as having said that Soviet pilots were flying Egyptian Air Force jets and could have encountered Israeli planes.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday to their lowest level in almost three years as most issues continued to decline in more active trading.

A postal burglary ring that yielded more than $6-million in United States savings and postage stamps and cash from 15 post offices in the New York metropolitan area and upstate was reportedly smashed yesterday with the arrest of six suspects.

Mario Merola, the chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, attacked the Lindsay administration's proposed automobile-use tax yesterday and said, "the Council's number-one objective is to knock it off."

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The Nixon Administration challenged today the railroad industry's claim that economic disaster will follow if it is denied a 6 per cent across-theboard increase in freight rates.

After dropping sharply early in the session, wheat futures staged a rally on the Chicago Board of Trade and finished higher yesterday. The day was saved by a late wave of buying and short-covering, which trimmed the early lows.

LIVERPOOL, England (UPI) Nick Watson, having a run of bad business at his cafe, added 18-year-old Miss Diane Bell as waitress-in a see-through negligee..
ALBANY, May 20 (AP) Governor Rockefeller signed legislation today to permit welfare officials to remove an endangered child from his home without waiting for a court order.

Howard J. Samuels opened a television campaign yesterday against Arthur J. Goldberg, his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Governor, questioning both the nature of his rival's sponsors and his independence of them.
The long-awaited annual meeting of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., was adjourned yesterday without taking any action when it was determined that there was not a quorum present.
CHICAGO, May 21 A 54year-old Indiana preacher is the new moderator of the 3.2million member United Presbyterian Church.

John M. King, the 43-yearold Denver millionaire who has been in Geneva negotiating for control of the beleaguered Investors Overseas Services, returned to New York yesterday to outline his plans for the first time.

WASHINGTON, May 21 The White House and its Senate critics were at an impasse today in their attempt to reach an accommodation on a move to prohibit future military activities in Cambodia without the consent of Congress.
GREAT NECK, L. I., May 21 Somerset Hills, the New Jersey representative, successfully defended the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub intersectional team championship today.

Ten after-school centers that have been operating throughout downtown Manhattan for the last fifty years closed down yesterday because of lack of funds. They will reopen July 6 when the 1970 school budget goes into effect.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 121--Acts of insurgency were reported today from two regions of Cambodia considered secure by the Government until now.
Heavy buying by commercial interests and large local professionals, together with heavy exports, sent soybean futures prices soaring yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

By serving notice now of his intention to step down from the Speakership, John McCormack may well be staving off a rebellion of historic dimensions in the House of Representatives. Had he chosen to run again, there is no question that a large segment of Democrats would either have fought his re-election to the end or demanded as the price of acceptance a pledge of reforms in the institutional workings of that chamber.

WASHINGTON, May 21 Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel welcomed today the movement of thousands of college students into the political process, saying that, regardless of its effect on political parties, "it will help the country."

Dr. William Levine, director of the department of obstetrics and gynecology of Brookdale Hospital Center from 1953 to 1963, died Wednesday in Presbyterian Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 303 Beach 149th Street. Neponsit, Queens.

DENVILLE, N. J., May 21 It took Tom Ulozas, the 27-yearold pro at Bamm Hollow, about four minutes to add his final scorecard. Amid the sound of spectators' voices in the scorer's tent, Ulozas just was making sure that his figures were correct.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel delayed the private development of Western oil share resources because of possible damage to the environment, an offical for the Interior Department told Congress today.
WASHINGTON, May 21 An American Jewish leader criticized Jewish organizations tonight, saying they had failed to confront the problems of the inner city.

Nine antiwar demonstrators were injured yesterday when the police forcibly dispersed at Avenue of the Americas and 39th Street a militant group that had marched uptown from a peace rally of 20,000 at City Hall.
Philadelphia fans made Richie Allen feel at home last night, and he almost spoiled the homecoming for them.

Serious television drama will be even scarcer next season than it has been in recent years, a victim of tightened budgets and a paucity of good plays. The major casualties will be two of television's most prestigious series--"Prudential's On Stage," which will not be back, and "C.B.S. Playhouse," which will have fewer productions.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

PENN VALLEY, Pa., May 21 Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Biddle Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Biddle, to Bradford Flint Whitman, son of the late Clarence Whitman of New York and the late Mrs. Carolyn Whitman.

Terry Sawchuk, one of hockey's biggest names, was taken yesterday from the intensive-care unit of Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital, where he has been a patient without fanfare for more than three weeks. He is expected to remain in the hospital at least another week.

CHICAGO, May 21 Gerald H. Trautman, president and chief executive officer of the Greyhound Corporation, in a press conference here today expanded on some of the details of the fight for control of Armour Co., which has been going on for 16 months between the General Host Corporation and Greyhound.

WASHINGON, May 21 The Government filed suit today against six American and 12 foreign drug companies for recovery of money it said it had "fraudulently" been deprived of. The alleged fraud was connected with the sale of large amounts of quinine, quinidine and othe chinchona products that had been stockpiled by the Government.

MACON, Ga., May 21 Clapping their hands and singing, "Nixon, you cannot jail us all," at least 60 white girls at Wesleyan College here joined the spirited and predominantly black "march against repression" late today.

WHITE PLAINS, May 21 A. Warren Norton, a newspaperman and publishing executive who became a Christian Science practitioner, died yesterday in a nursing home in Bedford, N. Y. He was 73 years old and lived at 37 Ethelridge Road.

PARIS, May 21 (AP)--Robert J. Sweeny, 59-year-old Californian now living in London, was one of 10 of America's 15 original starters to advance today to the second round of the French amateur golf championship.

The Dziga-Vertov Group, named for a Soviet documentary filmmaker and experimentalist whose real name was Denis Kaufman (18961954), consists of Jean-Luc Godard and a young French revolutionary named JeanPierre Gorin. Sometimes, according to Gorin, it consists only of Jean-Luc Godard.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of a special five-man commission to investigate charges of widespread police corruption in New York City. The group also is to develop methods to prevent departmental corruption.
The New York Times announced yesterday that it would temporarily suspend publication after Sunday's issue unless a contract settlement was reached with Typographical Union No. 6.
W. J. (Josh) Barney was named president of the National Horse Show yesterday, succeeding Walter Devereux, who died two weeks ago.

Junior High School 120 in East Harlem was closed yesterday morning after more than an hour of disorder, including the occupation of an office by pupils, a telephoned bomb threat and a skirmish outside in which eggs and bottles were thrown at the police.
RAHWAY, N. J. May 21 (AP) Several cars were set ablaze and more than a dozen persons were arrested here tonight in the second night of racial disturbances.

If there was an award for outstanding performance in amateur bridge organization it would surely go to Mrs. Samuel Stayman, known to all tournament players here as Tubby. Largely due to her efforts, the annual charity game of the United Jewish Appeal produces more money for a worthy cause than any comparable event anywhere in the world.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 21?Governor Rockefeller faced angry students who were denouncing him as a "Fascist pig" and businessmen who were saluting progress with American flags in a two-day swing across the northern arc of the state that ended today.

TEANECK, N. J., May 21 Alfred B. Lorber, president of the Transcontinental Music Corporation and a former vice president of the Columbia Records division of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of cancer today at Englewood Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived at 631 Wyndham Road.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) A Circuit Court judge has upheld a motion to prevent the issuance of subpoenas for newsmen and their accounts of street disorders that ocurred last October.
Glenn Walker Ferguson, Chancellor of Long Island University for 11 months, announced yesterday that he was resigning, effective July 1, to become the president of Clark University in Worcester, Mass.

Net income of the International Harvester Company fell in the second fiscal quarter ended. April 30 to $21,696,000, or 79 cents a share, from $23,605,000, equal to 85 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year. During the period sales advanced 3.7 per cent to $731,422,000.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 21 The spokesman for Cambodia's military command today stepped beyond his normal military briefing to address correspondents emotionally on his feelings toward the Vietnamese, Venturing outside the present policy line, Major Amrong declared that any Cambodian would rather die than live under Vietnamese domination.
BUFFALO, May 21 (AP) Natheniel James stood before a City Court judge today, accused of public intoxication. "Were you drunk?" Judge Michael E. Zimmer asked Mr. James, 43 years old.

PARIS, May 21 Ministers from the industrial countries expressed the conviction today that the world can avoid sliding into a general recession despite the economic slowdown and stock market drop in the United States.

The United States Court of Apeals for the Second Circuit upheld yesterday a series of Special courtroom rules imposed for the trial of eight Black Panthers accused of murder and kidnapping in New Haven.

Two members of Baseball's Hall of Fame and the only relief pitcher of modern times who is the author of two published books testified yesterday against the present form, of baseball's reserve-clause system on the second day of Curt Flood's antitrust trial in Federal Court here.

Robert K. Dix, president and a director of the Enjay Chemical Company, has been elected a senior vice president and director of the Esso Chemical Company, effective June 1. Enjay is the United States affiliate of Esso Chemical, the chemical affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

The Xerox Corporation expects to have "very substantial increases both in revenues and profits" this year, C. Peter McColough, president, told some 2,000 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in the Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, May 21--An official of the Food and Drug Administration said today that the agency would probably issue a statement tomorrow concerning a long-term study that casts doubt on the usefulness of an antidiabetes pill for treating mild adult diabetics.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has told a panel of Federal judges that criminal courts in Manhattan are so badly overcrowded and congested that many defendants seek delays in hopes that he will reduce the charges against them.

YONKERS, May 21 An overabundance of speed may help fashion the season's fastest mile when eight free-for-all standardbreds go to the post for the National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
DETROIT, May 21?The elevation of Leonard Woodcock to president of the United Automobile Workers was assured today by the withdrawal of his single opponent.

The Dalton School's threeday fair will begin Monday at 8 P.M. with a gala champagne preview for adults and an auction and a couture boutique of new designs from Donald Brooks, Norman Norell. Bill Blass and other fashion designers.

Sunny and dry weather will cover much of the nation today. Thundershowers, however, will occur from the Plains States and the western Mississippi Valley to the upper Midwest. Showers will also occur in the Pacific Northwest and in south Florida. It will be warmer from the northern Rockies to northern California and cooler from the central Rockies to the upper Midwest.

By using the electron microscope, the most powerful type microscope known to man, scientists are making electronic circuits such as are used in computers, on a scale that, for compactness, may rival that within the human brain.

WASHINGTON, May 21Daniel B. Brewster, the former Senator from Maryland, informed a Federal District Court in Washington today that he had "recovered his health" and was ready to stand trial on charges that he took $24,500 for his votes against higher postage for "junk mail."

WASHINGTON, May 21 Now that Speaker McCormack of Massachusetts and the House of Representatives has announced his retirement, the Democratic party has a problem and an opportunity. As the party in opposition, it has been howling at the Nixon Administration to change with the changing times, and now it has a chance to change itself.

Two novel resolutions will he voted on at the annual meeting of General Motors in Detroit today, designed to emphasize the role of responsibility that such giant corporations as G.M. must expect to play in respect to the social and environmental problems directly affected by their operations.
Black, red and green, the colors of the black liberation flag, representing color, blood and country, symbolize the theme of the first black arts festival now under way at the Riverside Church.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 The United States command said today that 217 American soldiers were killed in Southeast Asia last week. This was the highest weekly toll since last August.

LONDON, May 21 It is no surprise to find Arnold Wesker equating his own social obsessions with those of the community at large: What is surprising about his new play "The Friends," at the Roundhouse, is its change from doctrinaire optimism to a context of defeat.
Seymour Dribben, a senior vice president of the International Division of Chemical Bank, died yesterday at his home in Colebrook, Conn., after a long illness. His age was 60.
WASHINGTON, May 21(Reuters) Democrats were quick to zero in on the Administration today after the disclosure of the latest upward leap in the cost of living.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin designated 14 more counties and six towns today for Government food stamp programs for needy families.
Three teen-agers have been arrested and charged with homicide in the slaving of a man during a holdup in Central Park Saturday night.

MILWAUKEE, May 21 Michael F. Cudahy, board chairman of Patrick Cudahy, Inc., the meat processing company, died in a Milwaukee nursing home last night after a stroke. He would have been 84 years old next Wednesday.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 21 Four months after the $200,000 Tennis Champions Classic began its sporadic, helter-skelter worldwide schedule, the first of the world's nine top professionals was eliminated tonight when Ken Rosewall of Australia defeated his countryman, John Newcombe, 5-7, 7-5, 6-1, 6-2, at South Mountain Arena here.
New one-of-a-kind creations by the Artist-Craftsmen of New York are having their first public showing through June 1 on the street floor of the First National City Bank, Park Avenue and 53d Street.

If capital appropriations are criteria, it is apparent in vestment for new plant and equipment this year will not be quite as heavy as recent surveys have indicated, according to the National Industrial Conference Board.
Ogilvy Mather, it is understood, is going to allow nonclients to avail themselves of the expertise of its media department. For a fee, of course.
ST. LOUIS A patrolman gestures at the dark, threeblock corridor of small stores, cafes, and row houses. "Not even a rat," he says drily, "Abandoned."
Will someone please say something nice about the brokerage business? "Fred" will. Fred's broker sent Fred's letter along saying that some favorable publicity certainly wouldn't hurt.

Directors of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation voted yesterday in Pittsburgh to omit the regular quarterly dividend on the company's common stock, an action that surprised many Wall Street analysts.

A poll of 394 political scientists who teach at United States colleges shows that, if American involvement in Indochina continues at its present level, two-thirds fear a struggle between the President and Congress over whose decision on foreign policy shall prevail.

LONDON, May 21 Lady Alexandra Jellicoe, granddaughter of the late Admiral Jellicoe, British naval commander in chief in World War I, and Philip Wilson, son of the chairman of Sotheby Co., of London and its New York affiliate, the Parke-Bernet Galleries, were married here today.
The giant of the photographic industry, the Eastman Kodak Company, announced yesterday a change in its high command and the, formation of a new division.

WASHINGTON, May 21 The president of Bloomingdale's, the head of Random House, the author of "The Rothchilds," an investment banker, the former Gloria Vanderbilt and her husband, Wyatt Cooper, and assorted envoys from New York's worlds of culture, business and fasihon became lobbyists today.
CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 21 (UPI) Garth Patterson stole the spotlight at Garden State Park today by winning five races in the nine-race card.

The stock market moved through another shock session yesterday, with the Dow-Jones industrial average hammered down by 18.49 points at 2:30 P.M. before a final-hour rally reduced the loss to 11.30 points. Closing at 665,25, the Dow industrials hovered at their lowest level in more than seven years and four months. The poorest previous closing was
Intrepid slid into opaque water at the Minneford yacht yard on City Island yesterday with her rear quarters draped in canvas maxi skirts that were worn for secrecy, not some sort of fashion.

In upholding the constitutionality of the 1970 New York State law redrawing Congressional district lines, the United States Supreme Court has underscored the need for this boundary-drawing task to be performed by an independent, nonpartisan commission.

WASHINGTON, May 21 With Representative Carl Albert of Oklahoma all but assured of the speakership, House Democrats turned their attention today to a wide-open race for majority leader among a half-dozen or more candidates.
Stuyvesant won its first Manhattan Public Schools' Athletic League outdoor track and field championship in more than a decade yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

The Harvard-Yale crew race, the oldest intercollegiate sports event, will not be quite the same this year. The preliminary freshman race was eliminated yesterday for the June 13 regatta when Yale dropped out because of its inability to man a freshman boat.

WASHINGTON, May 21 In a preliminary assessment of the United States and South South Vietnamese troop thrusts into Cambodia, the Pentagon said today that enemy head quarters units had suffered "se rious disruption" and had been forced to flee deeper into the interior.

DETROIT, May 21 The American automobile industry has reached a critical point in its history and its actions in the coming months could affect the business health of the nation in years to come, Lee Iacocca, president of Ford Motor Company's North American auto operations, said in an interview.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 21 The executive council of the 3.5-million-member Episcopal Church passed a resolution yesterday calling for "total withdrawal of all American forces from Southeast Asia now and and end to the war."

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 21 For the United States, which has been deeply involved in the Dominican Republic since its military intervention here in 1965, the peaceful re-election of President Joaquin Balaguer has brought a mixture of relief and preoccupation.

MOSCOW, May 21 Soviet authorities today were reported to have arrested Andrei A. Amalrik, a dissident author, on the ground that he slandered the Soviet state through his book "Will the U.S.S.R. Survive Until 1984," which was published abroad.
DEVON, Pa., May 21 The eight-day Devon horse show gets under way with Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill's Idle Dice favored to dominate the open jumner division.
Prices took another beating on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in the heaviest trading of the year.

BOSTON, May 21 The exhibition entitled "Afro-American Artists: New York and Boston," currently on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, is the largest survey of American black artists ever mounted. Consisting of 158 works painting, sculpture, drawing, graphics, and other visual media by 70 artists, the show occupies the museum's main exhibition galleries, and is being promoted by the museum as one of the major events of its current centennial celebrations.
Even if a somewhat unseasonable blizzard were to swirl into Shea Stadium today, the chances are that Ernie Banks of the Chicago Cubs would hardly notice it.
The New York Knicks gave additional titles yesterday to Frank Blauschild and James Wergeles of their publicity department.

The Hudson Highland State Park at Little Stony Point in Philipston, which will be dedicated by Governor Rockefeller tomorrow, marks an important victory in the continuous struggle to safeguard the famous scenic gorge and riverbank from exploitation. What might have become a gypsum wallboard factory will now be preserved as parkland. But the struggle goes on.
PARIS, May 21 The 67th session of the Paris conference on Vietnam today produced agreement only to meet again next Thursday.

ALBANY, May 21 Governor Rockefeller today vetoed a bill imposing new restrictions on the mass marketing of auto insurance, thus clearing the way for insurers to offer low-cost auto insurance on the payroll deduction plan.

Edmund R. Seergy, leader of the 49th Assembly District Republican Club and a major figure last year in John J. Marchi's mayoral campaign, will announce tonight that he is a candidate for the Republican leadership of Brooklyn.

The firmness with which Senators of both parties are resisting efforts to kill or cripple the CooperChurch amendment on Cambodia is encouraging evidence of a new determination in Congress to restore the constitutional balance in reaching vital decisions on war and peace.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, May 21 (UPI) Renzo Bariviera scored with six seconds remaining tonight, enabling Italy to upset the United States, 66-64, in the world basketball championship. It was the Americans' first loss.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)--The House Appropriations Committee approved today an additional $290-million for continued development of a civil supersonic transport aircraft.

A 21-year-old Phi Beta Kappa student at Barnard College was arrested last night and charged with being "a major supplier of drugs" at Columbia University after detectives said they found $100,000 worth of illegal drugs in her Upper West Side apartment.

JACKSON, Miss., May 21 The funeral of a 17-year-old Negro delivery boy, shot down at Jackson State College by Mississippi highway patrolmen, was expected to bring together tomorrow the largest group of civil rights sympathizers since the funeral of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. two years ago in Atlanta.
The Columbia Broadcast System re-ran with supporting evidence last night a film that the network said was the target of a White House " undercover campaign to discredit C.B.S. News."
ATLANTA, May 21 Bounding the ball long distances over hard fairways today, Tom Weiskopf carded a 65 and shared the lead with Homero Blancas, in the opening round of the $125,000 Atlanta Golf Classic.

Thirty-eight policemen were called to clear the Board of Estimate chamber yesterday after more than 100 low-income Coney Island residents set up a clamor over a delay in a new housing plan for their area.

WESTWOOD, N.J., May 21 Darius A. Davis, who directed aid to war prisoners for the Young Men's Christian Association during both World Wars, died here yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived at 90 Hurlbut Street.

The head of the Mayors' Subway Service Watchdog Commission said yesterday that Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, had ignored his repeated requests to discuss thousands of complaints by subway riders about safety.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky declared today that South Vietnamese troops were determined to remain in Cambodia after the planned withdrawal of American troops from that country by the end of June.

Mrs. Shirley Chisholm, who went to Congress as the first black woman member of the House of Representatives 16 months ago, sat forward in her office chair and succinctly assessed herself and her colleagues.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt. To get to the Herbert Elliotts, it is necessary to leave U.S. Route 91, cross an iron bridge and follow a dirt road to the summit. There, on a rolling, green hill, sits the clapboard farmhouse with its tidy white shutters and matching red barn.

Dr. Frederic de Hoffmann, a physicist, vice charman of Gulf General Atomic, Inc., has been elected to the new post of chancellor of the Salk Institute in San Diego, Calif. He was formerly a vice president of the General Dynamics and Gulf Oil Corporations.
Marvin (Vinny) Giles of Richmond has forfeited his amateur status because of his acceptance of golf balls, the United States Golf Association announced yesterday.

City health authorities said yesterday that abortions should be performed only in hospitals when the liberalized law goes into effect on July 1, and they indicated that hospitalization would be made mandatory later.

DETROIT, May 21 When the spring offensive against the General Motors Corporation ends late tomorrow, the businessmen will be able to claim victory. Their proxy count will show more than 200-million shares voted for the corporation and no more than a few hundred thousand for the insurgents.

WASHINGTON, May 21 President Nixon formally asked Congress today for $1.5-billion over the next two years to be used primarily to help finance the desegregation of Southern schools and to provide incentives for Northern school districts to integrate.
WASHINGTON, May 21 New orders for durable goods turned upward moderately in April after having dropped sharply in March, the Commerce Department reported today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., May 21 (AP) The Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association today acquired Mel Counts, a 7-foot center, from the Los Angeles Lakers for Gail Goodrich, a guard.

DETROIT, May 21 He could have been an ambassador, to Taiwan or Pakistan, or a Government official at the sub-Cabinet level. Those who know him say he would have fitted in intellectual, analytical, and yet an operator in the world of action. But Leonard Woodcock said no to these offers from

Contending that its members are being forced to breathe "noxious, unwholesome, and injurious oil fumes," the United Transportation Union has sought a court order to prevent the Penn Central from operating diesel locomotives at Grand Central Terminal.

LONDON, May 21 The Government today asked the controlling body of British cricket to withdraw its invitation to a South African team whose tour threatened to divide and disrupt England during the June election campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 21 The Nixon Administration, clearly embarrassed by the controversy over the future status of South Vietnamese forces in Cambodia, was reported today to have instructed its two senior representatives in Saigon to discuss the problem urgently with the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.
When the New York Mets open a four-game weekend series against the Chicago Cubs tonight, Shea Stadium will be vibrating with at least 50,000 spectators.

The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York threw his prestige yesterday behind the call by the Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, for an "incomes policy" to help speed the return to price stability.
The credit market deteriorated markedly yesterday, pushing interest rates to their highest levels on record.

WASHINGTON, May 21 The Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, accused President Nixon today of failing to generate an essential "atmosphere of confidence" in the foreign and domestic policies of his Admistration.

THE full impact of Sylvia AshtonWarner's latest novel probably depends on identification with its el derly protagonist, and I confess that my underlying inclination was to shun the bleak landscape of her interior. All the same, one recognizes art when one sees it. And one respects one's elders.
The bright, ringing sound of a hammered dulcimer enlivened a program of folk songs by Ed Trickett and Harry Tuft on Wednesday night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

An order for four supertankers to operate mainly between Middle East oil fields and northwestern European ports for the Royal Dutch Shell group of companies was announced in London yesterday by Shell International Marine.
Brad Park became the youngest Ranger ever seleected to the National Hockey League's all-star team yesterday. The 21-year-old defenseman joined Bobby Orr on the defensive pairings for the first team.
WASHINGTON, May 21 The House handed President Nixon a major victory today by voting to tie future Social Security increases to increases in the Consumer Price Index.
Prices on the London stock market again finished lower yesterday after a rally near the close collapsed.

The New York Times announced yesterday that Teaching Resources, Inc., its wholly owned subsidiary, had agreed in principle to purchase for cash the assets of Filmfax Productions, Inc., of Bedford Hills, N. Y., and Educational Enrichment Materials, Inc., of Norwalk, Conn., both producers of filmstrips for classroom, industrial and other uses.

WASHINGTON, May 21 The United States and the Soviet Union are discussing an agreement on the control of strategic arms that would impose a freeze on the current level of offensive missiles and would limit anti-ballistic-missile defense to the protection of Washington and Moscow.
WASHINGTON, May 21 President Nixon signed today a vast development program for aviation facilities, designed to meet an expected threefold increase in the use of air transportation in the 1970's.

KASSEL, West Germany, May 21 The second meeting of Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany and Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany took place here today in a stiff atmosphere made more tense by political incidents in the streets.

A 25-year-old woman who had been taking a fertility drug gave birth to sextuplets five girls and a boy at the New York University Medical Center last night, but hospital authorities reported that all died within seven hours.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Retired General Lucius D. Clay was picked today as the first board chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association after its reorganization as a private corporation.

The classics remain the touchstone of ballet, and while the Royal Ballet's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House is past the midway mark, there could not fail to be an openingnight flavor to its first "Swan Lake" of the season Wednesday evening. Antoinette Sibley and Anthony Dowell headed the superb cast.

A visitor from Paris, who was a New Yorker himself but in calmer days, finds many New Yorkers who say "I have had it up to here," or "the country is being torn apart," or "we are in a prerevolutionary situation," or "I'm frightened."
GREENWICH, Conn., May 21 Sydney Brayton Redecker, a retired career Foreign Service officer, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here at 111 Park Avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (UPI) Samuel (Cappy) Hoffman, who had a reputation "vice king" of Atlantic City in the 1930's died of cancer yesterday at Lankenau Hospital. He was 65 years old.

There is so little that need be said of a poor minor comedy, "The Engagement Baby," which turned up at the Helen Hayes Theater last night, that I find it difficult to raaise the energy to say it. It was written by someone called Stanley Shapiro, who once won an Academy Award for a Doris Day movie. He should have rested on his laurels.
MOSCOW, May 21 (UPI) The Soviet Union's supersonic jetliner has broken the sound barrier for the second time and has attained its highest speed since flight tests began in 1968.
ROME, May 21 (Reuters) A general strike was threatened today by three major labor union federations dissatisfied with a Government pledge for social and economic reform.
WASHINGTON, May 21 President Nixon said today that the Government's budget, despite recent revisions that throw it into deficit this year and next, is still restrictive
MOSCOW, May 21 The Soviet Union appeared today to be opening a campaign to discredit charges that its military and to the United Arab Republic threatened the security of Israel.

WASHINGTON, May 21 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel called on the United States today to stir up an "international climate of criticism" against Soviet military involvement in the United Arab Republic.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the United States Commissioner of Education, who was appointed by President Nixon, disagreed today with the Administration over the Indochina war.
Danny Cater's stiff back and Mel Stottlemyre's stiff elbow loosened up sufficiently for a 2-0 Yankee victory over the Senators last night.
A declares who is prepared to plan the play conscientiously when the dummy appears can sometimes visualize an end-game possibility, such as a throw-in or a squeeze.

FREIBURG, West Germany, May 22 (UPI) Peaches Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., and Julie Heldman of New York won their singles matches today as the United States routed South Africa, 3-0, and gained the semifinal round of the Women's Federation Cup tennis tournament.

DEVON, Pa., May 22 Jim Hulick of Sterling, Mass., the son of two professional riding instructors, piloted Hombre to victory in the first junior jumper class today at the opening of the Devon horse show.
Los Angeles Jose Luis Martinez, 128 pounds, Mexico City, outpointed Rodolfo Lobat 126 1/2, Juarez, Mexico, 10 rounds.

The Ice Follies of 1970, in the 34th edition of the rink show that opened Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, is playing it cool, restrained and lovely. The taste and restraint of it all, amid the swirling verve and skill, is a delightful surprise for anybody expecting a gaudy, Cecil B. DeMille salute to the hot months ahead. Like the old-fashioned revue it is, the show is simply constructed, clean-cut and charming.
WASHINGTON, May 22 Arthur F. Burns has let it be known that he is disturbed by connotations of a "clash" between himself and the Nixon Administration on the issue
Three Arabs were severely beaten here yesterday in their offices near the United Nations.
MODESTO, Calif., May 22 (UFI) John Carlos, never at a loss for words, has taken Charlie Greene's measure this spring and now it's for him to find out how good Eddie Hart really is.
The new-issue market, which has been virtually stagnant in recent weeks, continued in the doldrums this week as only two companies made first public offerings of their common stock.
WASHINGTON, May 22 Two new groups with the power to screen reform recommenations being prepared for the 1972 Democratic National Convention were created today by the partys executive committee.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel delayed the private development of Western oil share resources because of possible damage to the environment, an offical for the Interior Department told Congress Thursday.
More than 1,000 steel executives will pack and head for New York early next week, most of them in a rather bleak frame of mind.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) Mary Ann Vecchio, 15 years old, whose picture kneeling beside a slain Kent State University student was circulated throughout the world, waited in an Indianapolis juvenile detention center today for her parents to send an airplane ticket to bring her home to Florida.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., May 22 Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Lasher Barnette and Lawrence Brumfield Myers of Snyder, were married today at the bride's home. The Rev. J. Donald Johnston of the Unitarian Universalist Church of Niagara Falls performed the ceremony.
BONN, May 22 Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany appealed today to the East German leadership to show "a bit more goodwill and a little less legal formality" in its dealings with his government.

MANILA, May 22 The Foreign Policy Council decided today that the Philippines would not grant Cambodia's request for military assistance but would offer humanitarian aid as a civic undertaking through several organizations. Direct Government aid, the council was told, would imply full recognition of the new Cambodian.

JACKSON, Miss., May 22 The second victim of the police shooting at Jackson State College was buried today, and the rich and the powerful came to Jackson to pay their respects and to express concern over this ...

VIENNA, May 22 American and Soviet disarmament negotiators met today for two hours the longest session to date amid indications that slow but significant progress was being made in the five-week-old Vienna talks on the limiting of strategic arms.

West German Chancellor Willy Brandt had no illusions from the beginning about how difficult he would find the task of trying to normalize relations with East Germany. Even so, however, he must have been staggered by the harshness of East German Premier Willi Stoph's attitude at Kassel.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) The Senate agreed today to a test vote next week on the drive to curb United States activities in Cambodia.

One of Robert Schumann's least-played yet most ambitious scores was presented by the New York Philharmonic Thursday night to start the final week of subscrpition concerts. It was "Das Paradies und die peri," a secular oratorio composed an 1843 to a section of Thomas Moore's poem "Lalla Rookh." It is safe to saw that this city has not heard a performance for generations.

Miss Ella Milbank Foshay and Michael B. Rothfeld were married yesterday afternoon in the Georgian Suite at 1A East 77th Street. State Supreme Court Justice Theodore R. Kupferman performed the ceremony.
The nation's car makers came up with their best news in several months as they announced yesterday a sharp improvement in new-car sales during the May 11-20 period.

MEDIA, Pa., May 22 Dr. Robert P. Brecht, a leader in management education, who retired as professor of industry at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania, in 1967, died yesterday after a short illness. His age was 71.
The arts, which in recent years have been grappling with inflation, are now threatened by the slowed economy and the precipitous fall in the stock market.

Edward J. King is a 29year-old transit patrolman for whom civic action is a consuming avocation. In fact, he keeps a mimeograph machine in his Bedford-Stuy vesant residence and carries a polished gavel in his attache case.

LONDON, May 22 A scheduled tour of England by an allwhite South African cricket team was called off today following pressure from the British Government and threats of demonstrations against the racial separation policies of South Africa.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The Justice Department's antitrust division is examining the possibility of bringing suit against the unusual, but long-standing, two-price system under which copper is sold in the United States.

Robert R. Nathan, the economist, testified yesterday that the reserve-system arrangements common in baseball and other professional sports had "no parallel in any other sector" of the American free-enterprise system and that it "tended to depress the level of wages" paid to players who had "no opportunity to bargain with an alternative user of their skills."

Meyerson Co., Inc., a stock brokerage concern based in San Francisco, announced yesterday that it had ended its geneneral bockerage business and would close its offices in Burlingame and Modesto, Calif., and New York.

There are few, performances that remain comfortably beyond critical question and Margot Fonteyn's "swan queen" is one of them. Thursday night, the Royal Ballet presented "Swan Lake" at the Metropolitan Opera with Rudolph Nureyev as Siegfried and Miss Fonteyn as the inevitably doomed heroine.

Stores that sell a general line of retail goods do better than stores specializing in one type of merchandise, according to a study of retail sales trends made by the Meinhard-Commercial Corporation, which supplies many millions of dollars in credit to retail stores every year, United Press International reported.

A detective working with the headquarters unit that collects intelligence about top figures in organized crime in New York has been dismissed from the Police Department for having unauthorized "dealings with known criminals."

HONG KONG, May 22 Mao Tse-tung's call this week for world revolution against "United States imperialism" and yesterday's mass rally that he attended in Peking's Tienanmen Square supporting the call are regarded here as moves to emphasize further Communist China's revolutionary leadership role.

Pro football scouts call them "producers," and they are the colleges and universities that serve as a farm system for the National Football League. Some of them offer their athletes a quality education, and some of them make an effort to keep their athletes eligible for graduation as well as for games. But others lose interest in their athletes when the season is over and let them leave school without a degree.

Frank Costello, who once served an 18-month prison term for refusing to answer the questions of a United States Senate crime committee, has given a New York County grand jury not only the name of a man with whom he said he placed recent bets but also the dates and amounts of the bets.

Since Moscow and Peking coordinate virtually nothing important these days, it was sheer coincidence that on the same morning this week the Chinese called off the scheduled meeting with American representatives in Warsaw while Pravda loosed one of its most severe attacks against Mao and his policies. Nevertheless the juxtaposition of these two events helps provide a useful perspective on present relationships in the vital Washington-Moscow-Peking triangle.

Mrs. Elizabeth Gilbert Lyman, widow of Dr. Alexander Victor Lyman, was married in the chapel of St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday to James Blanchard Crosby, a stockbroker with Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill, Noyes. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick M. Morris.

Louis A. Gibbs, who retired last year as vice president and a director of Laird, Bissell Meeds, stockbrokers, died Thursday of a heart ailment in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 70 years old and formerly lived in New York and Larchmont, N.Y.

Sales at chain stores and catalogue houses rose 8.3 per cent in April from the year-earlier level, according to a monthly survey by The New York Times. It was the lowest dollar volume increase so far this year, reflecting a lag in retail buying and the fact that the figures were compared with the Easter month of 1969. This year Easter fell in March.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The United States was reported today to be prepared to continue air cover, if needed, for South Vietnamese forces that are considered almost certain to remain in Cambodia after the American withdrawal deadline, July 1.
The sextuplets born here Thursday, all of whom died within seven hours, had less than a 3 per cent chance of surviving because of their immaturity, the obstetrician who delivered them said yesterday.
CAIRO, May 22 (Reuters) The authoritative Cairo newspaper Al Ahram reported today that the United States had agreed to supply Israel with 130 military helicopters.
CAIRO, May 22 Cairo's most authoritative editor declared today that a turning point had been reached in the Arab-Israeli conflict, with the war now in "the beginning of the end."

Two young patrolmen have gone into business to prove that policemen have a sense of humor. With an initial investment of $500, the two, both members of the special events squad assigned to patrol demonstrations, formed Keystone Pig Enterprises.
An early 18th-century German porcelain teapot and a 1960 American porcelain figure of a bird were both included in last week's important ceramic auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 22 (AP) Dave Marcis drove a. Dodge Daytona at 153,082 miles on hour today and led 12 qualifiers for the $193,080 World 600 stock car race that is scheduled Sunday at Charlotte Motor Speedway.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday dropped to their lowest level since June, 1967, as most stocks continued to decline in slower trading.

A group that has been picketing the New York headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, at 69th Street and Third Avenue, called yesterday for a Congressional inquiry into the alleged harassment of Italian-Americans by the F.B.I.
Mrs. Delia Akeley Howe, African explorer, big game hunter and writer, died yesterday in Daytona Beach, Fla., where she was living, at the age of 95. She formerly lived in New York and Dorset, Vt.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) The Nixon Administration plans to ask Congress on Monday for an increase of almost $16-billion in the public debt celling, which would raise it to a record $393-billion.

Even, before the multiple investigations of this week's fatal subway crash get under way, several points are painfully clear. One is that an understaffed, partially dilapidated and poorly maintained subway system endangers the safety of its four-and-a-half million daily riders. Another is that sweeping reforms are called for. Still another is that no real improvement is likely without basic changes in attitudes.
Some students at Columbia University are grossing from $200 to $3,000 a month dealing in LSD, mescaline, marijuana, hashish and amphetamines, a number of undergraduates said yesterday.

Paul O'Dwyer, who is 20 years older than any of his three opponents for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, says that reelection would never be on his mind if he became a Senator, and that he would play an independent Washington role, "like the LaFollettes."

DETROIT, May 22 James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, told the shareholders at the annual meeting today that, although "it appears that the low point in automobile sales is behind us," the world's largest corporation still faced serious financial problems.

The demonstration at City Hall this week by students and workers opposed to President Nixon's policies in Indochina followed by a day a far larger demonstration, led by construction workers, supporting these policies. A nation that rests on the will of the people moves by consensus, but implicit in this is the need to respect differences of opinion and to defend freedom of expression and assembly as the basis of democracy.

Nearly 500 participants in the New York Art Strike artists, art students, art teachers and gallery employes sat in yesterday on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum and succeeded in drastically reducing its normal daily attendance of 4,000.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (Reuters) The "Banned in Boston" label was removed from the musical "Hair" today by the Supreme Court.

ONEONTA, N.Y., May 22 Howard J. Samuels, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, pledged today to be an "18-hour-a-day Governor" dedicated to thwarting "vested interests" ranging from "featherbedding" laborers to high-salaried "full professors" who balk at carrying full teaching loads.

LONDON, May 22 Through all the years of war and frustrated negotiation and plans for American withdrawal, there has been one central question for the United States in Vietnam: to what extent would we be committed to the objectives of the Saigon Government?
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Adm. John J. Ballentine, former commander of the air arm of the Atlantic Fleet, died yesterday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 73 years old and retired in 1954.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The nation's mass media were warned today against being diverted by Vice President Agnew and other critics from their central role of reporting and analyzing significant issues of the day.
PARIS, May 22 A compromise between the United States and the European Economic Community brought a fresh advance today toward establishment of generalized trade preferences for developing countries.

Miro J. Pansky, a Czech conductor in his early thirties who has been living here for a couple of years, made his American debut Thursday night in Town Hall leading an ensemble called Musici of New York. In a way it was a resumption of a career, because one of Mr. Pansky's chief activities in Europe was touring with a chamber orchestra, Musici XIII.
TRENTON, May 22 (UPI) For the second time, Federal Court Judge George H. Barlow has denied a delay of Newark Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio's conspiracy and extortion trial until after the June 16 election.
WASHINGTON, May 22 A New York engineer and businessman was granted a patent this week for Varad, a window that controls light. The panel can be changed

WASHINGTON, May 22 Robert H. Finch, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was discharged from Walter Reed Medical Center today. He will fly to President Nixon's home in key Biscayne, Fla., for a week's rest.
President Nixon sent a young aide to Columbia University to find out why he had a "problem" with the academic community.

Negotiators for the typographical union and the four major daily newspapers here met for about 90 minutes last night but failed to resolve their contract dispute.

CHICAGO, May 22 An attempt to take the 3.2 million members of the United Presbyterian Church out of the Consultation on Church Union was defeated here today after brisk debate. WASHINGTON, May 22 A tentative agreement on a proposed Senate bill that would give President Nixon most of what he seeks in regard to postal reorganization and increased postal rates was announced today.

PONTA DELGADA, Azores, The biggest event here in recent months was the mad dash of a pig from the wharf along the main avenue and into the window of a Portuguese Airlines agency.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The National Security Council staff headed by Henry A. Kissinger is losing at least four more members and there are unverified reports that one other is also quitting.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22 National Guardsmen with loaded rifles kept Ohio State University sealed off today while students pondered an unusual streak of interracial violence that has suddenly surfaced here.

DETROIT, May 22 Leonard Woodcock was elected president of the United Automobile Workers today. He is the fourth president in the union's 34-year history, and he immediately pledged that the U.A.W.'s direction for social causes and economic goals would not change.

PINEHURST, N.C., May 22 (AP) Kathy Hite of Florence, S.C., and Mrs. John Griffith of Fort Worth, Tex., scored 3and-2 victories today to gain the final of the Women's Southern amateur bolf championship.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 22 D. Earl Fleming, vice president and a director of Clark Metal Products, Inc., Fairfield, Conn., died Wednesday in his home at 16 Hillview Drive. His age was 87.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed slightly firmer yesterday after a weak opening. Most Continental markets eased further, but the downtrend appeared to be slackening. The Tokyo market advanced moderately with a late rally.

Miss Eleanor Pam, associate dean of Queensborough Community College in Bayside, Queens, was married last evening to Robert Juceam, a lawyer with the New York firm of Strasser, Spiegelberg, Fried Frank. Rabbi Louis I. Newman per formed the ceremony at the St. Moritz.

PARIS, May 24 A well known American accounting concern had a larger hand than is generally realized in the controversial mark-up of assets late last year in one of the mutual fund portfolios of Investors Overseas Services.
PANAMA, May 24 (UPI) The 26 remaining crews in the London-to-Mexico auto rally began the final 2,000-mile leg today to Aztec Stadium in Mexico City.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 24 Walt Whitman once wrote of "my own beautiful town of Huntington." That was in 1839, when the town's population was about 6,500 and its borders stretched from Long Island Sound to the Atlantic Ocean.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 24 Miss Edith Bette Mossberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Mossberg, was married here this afternoon to Mark Howard Medoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney L. Medoff of Larchmont.

MUNICH, West Germany, May 24 (UPI) Fresh Yankee, the North American trotting champion owned' by Duncan MacDonald of Nova Scotia and driven by Joe O'Brien, won the $36,000 Grand Prix of Bavaria trotting race today by a halflength over American-bred Dart Hanover of Sweden.

Since its founding in the summer of 1968, the Jewish Defense League has withstood the criticism of most major Jewish organizations and has pursued its vision of militant preparedness with karate classes and neighborhood patrols.

WASHINGTON, May 24 A White House aide disclosed today that President Nixon would appoint this week a high-level commission "to get to the bottom of the Kent State tragedy" in which four students were killed during an antiwar demonstration May 4.

Steve Sandier, the national Amateur Athletic Union onewall handball champion, took another step yesterday to retain his title. The 92d Street Y.M.H.A. star scored a 13-21, 21-4, 21-10 second-round victory over Charlie Shelvon of the Brownsville Handball Club.
Last week ended up with Benton Bowles setting up a new division geared tp providing a whole bagful of merchandising and sales promotion services to clients and non-clients.
Alex Orban, the national champion, yesterday won the metropolitan saber championship on his home strip at the New York Athletic Club.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 24 Dominican leftist opposition to a scheduled meeting of American foreign ministers here next month is causing concern among diplomats here.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) Injuries further crippled the Philadelphia Phillies as they lost a third catcher today.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has fixed a subscription price, of $22.50 a share for the 3,263,751 shares of common stock being offered to holders of record as of the close of business on Thursday, May 21. The offer is based on one new share for each 12 shares held on the record date.

No one can accuse the Rouse Company of failing to "think big" about the development potentials of South Richmond, that vast and underdeveloped southern third of Staten Island for which Rouse proposes a $6.5-billion "city within a city."
Gray skies added somber touch yesterday to an otherwise spirited memorial parade honoring Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Fifth Avenue as 15,000 spectators white and black turned out.

For weeks after he heard there were plans afoot to plant flowers in a trashstrewn lot on Freeman Street, the Bronx, Raymond Medina would stop at the Bethany Family Circle office, summon up the courage of his eight years and ask if the big day had come.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 24 Billy Edwards, hitting straight from the tees and rarely having to scramble, became the second golfer to win the Walter J. Travis Invitation tournament a fourth time when he beat Paul Wise, 2 up, in the final today at the Garden City Golf Club.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 24 (UPI) Billy Graham said today that he believed all the "signs are now in place" for the second coming of Christ.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., May 24 Howard W. Burns, a stockbroker and noted Harvard athlete, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 66 years old and lived here.

WASHINGTON, May 24 "Normally, we don't talk about the stock market at all. Now we do, of course. But it's just one of a dozen things we discuss and consider not the beginning and end of everything the way it is in New York."
BUENOS AIRES, May 24 Argentina's political police last night closed the daily newspaper Cronica, which claims the largest circulation in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, May 24 The Nixon Administration is expected to delay for several months the signing of a new agreement with Spain on military bases because this commitment is being questioned by key members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
WASHINGTON, May 23 Washington's greatest cave of the winds, the United States Senate, is about to be wired for sound.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 24 Springboard won two of the three classes to capture the open jumper championship with 11 points today at the Stratford Stables horse show.

"What's bothering the consumer these days?" merchants are asking with some exasperation in the face of a continuing flatness in retail sales. "Is it the new life-style or a reaction to the troubled economy? they wonder.

With the support of Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton, a community board with planning jurisdiction on the Upper East Side will hold a public hearing Wednesday night to air protests against plans to dig up sections in the southeast corner of Central Park for a new subway tunnel.

The importance of preserving the objectivity, and thereby the credibility, of United States Information Agency libraries is illustrated in India, where the Government has just bowed to leftist demands and closed down five American cultural centers, charging they were engaging in "undesirable activities."
NAHA, Okinawa, May 24 Okinawan leaders denounced today the White House decison to cancel the planned shipment to Oregon of 13,000 tons of nerve gas and chemical weapons stored here.
Sir Frederick Ashton, director of Britain's Royal Ballet, who has just come to town, is going.

Mr, and Mrs. Charles E. Rogers of Rome and Washington have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Lane Rogers, to Theodore Roosevelt 4th, a great-grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt. The wedding is planned for Aug. 1 in Woods Hole, Mass.

TOKYO, May 24 Business circles here are optimistic about expansion of trade in mainland China, despite Peking's recent tough four conditions that Japanese companies must accept in order to do business with Communist China.
MOSCOW, May 24 Leonid Leonov, a prominent novelist and conservationist, today condemned the use of forest and game preserves for private hunting parties by leading Soviet figures.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 24 (AP) Sandy Alomar's single in the ninth inning enabled the California Angels to nip the Minnesota Twins, 6-5, today after losing a 5-1 lead. The victory moved the Angels within a half game of the first-place Twins in the American League's Western Division.
MANILA, May 24 (AP) About 200 leftist Filipino youths ended a noisy but peaceful anti-Government and anti-United States demonstration here tonight by burning an American flag.

Several thousand schoolchildren from the metropolitan area marched from Eastern Parkway and Kingston Avenue to the Boys High School stadium at Maple Street and Troy Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday tom mark the Jewish festival of Lag B'omer.
Public zeal against littering is on the upswing across the country, but not yet enough so to offset a costly worsening in the scourge of trash.
ROME, May 24 (AP) Policemen battled rampaging youths in Milan today for the second day in a row.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 24 (AP) Five newsmen, including a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer, were detained by North Vietnamese soldiers in Cambodia this weekend but were quickly released.

WASHINGTON, May 24 A group of 93 leaders, represent ing a broad cross-section of the economy and acting under the auspices of the National Planning Association, recommended today that a larger share of the nation's resources be devoted to attacking poverty.

CARLISLE, Pa., May 24 Tom Wicker, associate editor of The New York Times, told the graduating class of Dickinson College today that "the deepest hunger in the American soul today ... is for something truly useful to do with one's life."

THE United States Grandmaster Pal Benko achieved a signal triumph early this year when he finished in first place with the Yugoslav master, B. Kurajica, in the 16man international round robin played in Malaga, Spain.

One of the finest performances of a major work this Ilistener has heard in many a season was given Saturday night by the Pro Arte Double Chorale and Orchestra with John Nelson conducting at Carnegie Hall.

In commercial television's slow season it is enlightening to realize how often its output can come close to that of noncommercial TV. A case in point over the weekend was the National Broadcasting Company (Channel 4), which wandered interestingly through several fields without undue concern for ratings.

ALBA-IULIA, Rumania, May 24 (Reuters) Thousands of Rumanian families were evacuated today from towns in central Rumania as new floods threatened. At least 130 have died so far in widespread flooding that has left 265,000 homeless.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 24 Jacques F. Bulterman led with Onrust over the entire 8.5mile course on Long Island Sound today and won the Luders-16 Class race by 1 minute 50 seconds and 15 boat-lengths during the Riverside Yacht Club regatta.

HOUSTON, May 24 Vice President Agnew proposed today that the "nations of this world, plagued by many ills some of our own making, some born of nature" declare the nineteen-seventies the decade against disease.
Four seeded players won matches yesterday in the third annual Brooklyn men's tennis championship at the Hiway Club in Flatbush.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 24 (Agence France-Presse) Laotian Government forces, seizing the initiative with the advent of the rainy season are launching a series of attacks against Communist forces.

WASHINGTON, May 24 Secretary of State William P. Rogers indicated today that the Administration would not oppose continued South Vietnamese operations in Cambodia after American forces are pulled out, and he left open the possibility that American air support would be provided.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia May 23 A scheduled visit of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia next month is further evidence of the growing ties between Malaysia and the Middle East.
TUNIS, May 23 The spectacular failure of Tunisia's collective-farm program was flaunted here at the show trial of the country's former economic boss.

Miss Ruth Ann Slawson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Slawson, was married at the Central Synagogue yesterdary to Allan Bennett Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Schwartz of Hamden, Conn. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony.

But no immediate change in the 162game schedule is part of the package.

LES SAINTES MARIES DE LA MER, France, May 24 (Reuters) About 10,000 gypsies gathered today for their annual pilgrimage in this Mediterranean town near Arles, carrying the statue of their patron saint, Sarah, along the beach in a centuries-old ceremony.

METUCHEN, N.J., May 24 Dr. Elsie Neustadt paced nervously outside the show ring today the way the West Hanover, Mass., psychiatrist usually does when one of her greyhounds is in the ring for the best-inshow judging.

Clifton Luther (Cliff) Jackson, a popular jazz pianist here for many years, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 818 Ritter Place, the Bronx, after playing the night before at the RX Room, 1638 York Avenue. His age was 67.

Without consulting the Lindsay administration, the State Division of Housing put forth a plan yesterday for a $1.35billion housing development, industrial park, recreation center and shopping mall on the 1,282-acre Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. Andrzej Panufnik is Polish by birth (1914) but in 1953 he settled in England. How remarkably he has adapted to the language of his new home was heard yesterday in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, where Leopold Stokowski led the world premiere of Mr. Panufnik's setting of Alexander. Pope's "Universal Prayer."

EAST ORANGE N.J. May 25 Eleven graduate students at John Jay College of Criminal Justice of the Ctiy University of New York all but one of them law-enforcement officers are jointly engaged in producting a master's essay that will not, like thousands of others written each year, molder unread on a library shelf.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 24 (Reuters) An arrest warrant has been issued against a young British millionaire, George Drummond, on suspicion of involvement in the disappearance in London of $500,000 in American Express traveler's checks, the police said today.

LONDON An American professor now teaching at Oxford has just made a brief visit to his old campus in the United States. He came back here with a new insight into the psychological gulf between so many American students and their elders.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 (AP) Three San Diego errors helped the San Francisco Giants get seven runs in the fifth inning today and beat the Padres, 7-6, to complete a double-header sweep in the managerial debut of Charlie Fox.

A new painting of the sailing ship Wavertree in her days of glory 85 years ago has taken its place in the South Street Seaport Museum, where the refurbished ship itself is to become the largest exhibit. Charles Lundgren is the artist.

President Nixon's request to Congress to appropriate $500 million for the coming school year and $1 billion for the year after that to speed integration is a commendably forward-looking step. Western Union International, Inc., reported yesterday firstquarter operating revenues of $13,256,000 against $8,521,000 a year earlier.

Francis Brewster Taussig, president of Grolier International, Inc., and executive vice president of its parent company, Grolier, Inc., publishers of encyclopedias and textbooks, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 14 Sutton Place South.

NEWARK, May 25 The Prudential Insurance Company the largest insurer in the world took the plunge today and announced its long-expected entry into the emotion-charged automobile and homeowner insurance business.

Goldberg, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, said yesterday that the state should act as an "employer of last resort" providing jobs for people who can't find them in private industry. WASHINGTON, May 25 about 35 Mayors and scores of other city officials and community workers from across the country began a special nonpartisan lobbying effort today to raise the urban renewal appropriation from the $1-billion recommended by President Nixon to $2.3-billion, the amount authorized by law.
PARIS, May 25 Battle damage to French investments in Cambodia is aggravating both the pessimism on the Paris Stock Exchange and the anxiety in France over latest American policy in the Far East.

Hancock Pfizenmayer, former secretary of the National Association of American Composers and Conductors, and twice president of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs, died today at the A. Honey Patterson Home for the Aged. She was 75 years old and had lived until recently at 292 Maryland Avenue, Freeport.
Prices on the Tokyo stock market fell sharply yesterday, sending the main market index to its lowest level since last August.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 (UPI) Hugh Scott, the Senate minority leader, urged the nation's banks today to lower their interest rates and allow easier credit for small businesses, nonprofit housing and pollution-control projects.

The American Stock Exchange had its biggest daily loss in almost 10 months yesterday as prices fell to their lowest level in almost three years. Trading was moderate. The exchange's price-change index dropped 0.49 to 19.57, its sharpest daily drop since July 28, 1969, when the indicator tumbled 0.80 to 25.36. The index's close yesterday was the lowest since June 16, 1967, when it touched the same figure.
Bache Co., the brokerage house, announced yesterday a reorganization of its branch management group, involving separation of its branch-office structure into four regional divisions.

Richard S. Mitchell has been named executive vice president of Pan American World Airways. He succeeds General Laurence S. Kuter (U.S. Air Force retired) who is retiring from the company.

The board of directors of The New York News has announced the election of W. H. James as president, succeeding F. M. Flynn, who was elected to the newly created post of chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, May 25 A Presidential commission appointed to plan for the 200th anniversary of the American Revolution is reported to have rejected the idea of a world's fair in any single city.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 25 (Canadian Press) The captain of the tanker Arrow said today his ship was operating with faulty radar, a disabled echo sounder and a gyro compass that read several degrees off course when the ship grounded in Nova Scotia's Chedabucto Bay on Feb. 4.

MILAN, Italy Ken Scott, the designer, opened a better mousetrap at the entrance to his boutique here last November. Three weeks later, city authorities snapped it shut and, temporarily at least, closed off Milan's only commercial source of apple brown Betty, corn bread and chili con carne.

Pete Rozelle, the Commissioner of the National Football League, testified yesterday that professional football had been able to "live with" its player option rule and profitably so "on occasion."

Governor Rockefeller, who had promised earlier that the Hudson River would be clean enough to swim in this year, set back that date yesterday to 1975.
