SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 A Federal judge here today ordered a draftee released from the Army and thereby may have begun a process that will lead to discharges for 6,000 men inducted because their draft boards decided they were delinquent.
A two-year college that combines academic study and onthe-job training for impoverished students was chartered last week by the State Board of Regents.
The New Amsterdam Ensemble, a friendly group of chamber music experts, played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he did not agree with Mayor Lindsay's call for immediate wage and price controls to curb inflation.

YONKERS, May 25 On a damp, fog-bound night when the 25,093 fans had trouble seeing the horses they were backing, the first-half season at Yorkers Raceway was concluded tonight with $3,123,726 poured into the mutuel machines. It was the third time in the sport's history that the $3-million mark has been surpassed and all three were accomplished at the Westchester County course.

Last week a Federal judge in New Haven handed down a decision on a request by Consumers Union for a preliminary injunction against the Theodore Hamm Brewing Company from using material from its Consumer Reports in advertising and promotion.

The Secretary of State's office is expected to hand down its decision today on a challenge being mounted by Theodore Sorensen against qualifying petitions filed in behalf of Representative R. D. Max McCarthy in the Democratic Senatorial primary contest. Paul O'Dwyer and Representative Richard Ottinger are the other candidates in the June 23 election, but are not directly involved in the present dispute.

CINCINNATI, May 25 (UPI) Kennesaw, Ga., and not Chattanooga will become the final resting place of the Civil War locomotive "The General," the United States Court of Appeals for the sixth Circuit has ruled.
VIENNA, May 25 (Reuters) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian Chief of State, arrived in Hanoi today amid indications that North Vietnam would not send more troops into Cambodia.

Angel Cordero took possession of Belmont Park yesterday. The amiable Puerto Rican rider was the star of the opening day's program at the huge plant as he came through with four winners in eight attempts.

Natalie Lamb, who usually belts out blue songs from the repertoires of Bessie Smith and Ma Rainey with the Red Onion Jazz Band, gave a dinner recital last night at the Roosevelt Grill, accompanied only by a pianist, Dick Miller. It was the first of a series of one-hour recitals she will give there, Tuesdays through Friday at 7:30.
About 200 landlords filled a hearing room at City Hall yesterday to denounce Mayor Lindsay's plan for revising the city's 27-year-old rent-control law.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 25 Marymount College is still feeling the effects of a court suit filed earlier this month against a strike at the college even though the suit was settled out of court and the college says it was never on strike to begin with.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 25 Charles A. Rubens, founder and former president of Filigree Foods, Inc., wholesale grocery distributors in Totowa, died yesterday at the Inglemoore Nursing Home. He was 92 years old and lived at 192 Chadwick Road, Teaneck.

A group of Yale University professors, law students and leaders of the New Haven black coalition have filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission asking a curb on President Nixon's access to the television networks when opponents of the Indochina war have not been accorded an equal opportunity for air time.
WASHINGTON, May 25 The Administration has informed Congress that it has decided to give about $7.5-million worth of arms to the military Government in Cambodia on

The cavernous sound, strangely melodious, began on a low pitch, rose slowly to a higher frequency at which it sounded for a moment like a combined oboe and muted cornet, trailed off into an eerie high-pitched, undulating wail like melancholy bagpipes and then faded into silence.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 Former Assistant Secretary of Defense Paul C. Warnke and three United States Senators called here today for speedy disengagement by the United States from the wars in Vietnam and Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Countering Democratic charges that Americans are losing confidence in President Nixon, the Republican National Chairman released poll figures today indicating that a majority of the voters approve of the President's decision to send American troops into Cambodia.

GENEVA, May 25 The agreement that now regulates the international trade in cotton textiles will probably be extended for three years beyond its present expiration date of Sept. 30, 1970, qualified sources said today.

The stock market was battered down yesterday to its lowest level in nearly seven and a half years as the DowJones industrial average, falling 20.81 points to 641.36, posted its biggest one-day break since the assassination of President Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963. More than half of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange set new 1970 lows.

The joint Algerian-American plan for liquefied natural gas (L.N.G.) into this country from Africa in giant tankers is being stepped up, Dr. Robert L. Purvin, a leading industry consultant, announced yesterday at an industry conference at Seattle.
A 24-year-old Bronx resident was arrested yesterday and charged with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide following the death of his 21year-old sister apparently from an overdose of heroin.

WASHINGTON, May 25 The withdrawal of all United States ground troops from Cambodia is to be completed ahead of the June 30 deadline under present plans of the Nixon Administration, senior Government officials said today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Former Senator Daniel B. Brewster pleaded not guilty today to charges of accepting a bribe to influence his vote on postal rate legislation.

James Earl Jones, who won star status last year and the Tony award as Broadway's best actor for his role of the black heavy weight champion in "The Great White Hope," will appear in an Off Broadway show next month.

Ron Davis, a charismatic young man whose involvement in social projects led him to form the Ron Davis Dancers in 1964 a group of young black and Puerto Rican performers seen last year at Carnegie Hall presented another concert by the Ron Davis Dancers last night at Alice Tully Hall.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 The University of California's Board of Regents and its Los Angeles campus are heading for a confrontation over the case of Angela Davis, an assistant professor of philosophy who belongs to the Communist party.
PALMDALE, Calif., May 25 (UPI) A huge C-54 transport plane caught fire today as it was preparing to take off from an Air Force test and training facility at Palmdale Airport.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., May 25 Francis M. Seaman, Perth Amboy's city attorney, senior partner in the law firm of Seaman Clark, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Perth Amboy General Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 442 Barclay Street.
A top-quality electric utility bond issue was offered to investors yesterday at a record 9.20 per cent yield 15/100ths higher than a similar issue marketed only four days earlier.

A state survey indicated yesterday that hospitals in New York City needed 8,791 fulltime doctors, dentists and other health personnel beyond the 106,392 people that they had on their staffs a year ago.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation from an order that it pass about $10.5-million in refunds on to its customers.

DENVER, May 25 (AP) Frontier Airlines said today it would lay off more than 200 employes and embark on a costcutting program in an effort to reduce losses totaling $13-million since the first of 1968. Frontier has 3,455 workers.

HONG KONG, May 25 Two public ceremonies this month in Peking attended by Mao Tsetung and the hierarchy around him have provided an unusual opportunity to study the ranks of the Chinese Communist leadership.

Most of the country's college campuses were quiet yesterday, although National Guardsmen still patrolled Ohio State University and 19 students were arrested for occupying a graduate school building of the New School for Social Research in New York City.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 25 (UPI) Jake Yoder of Fort Wayne, Ind., who bowled the tournament's only 300 game, was crowned regular division singles champion today as the 67th American Bowling Congress closed.
WASHINGTON, May 25 From the mailbag of Miss Cornelia de Rigor, the distinguished authority on contemporary American etiquette:

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., May 25 The Rockville Links golf course turned into a soggy green monster today and not one of the players trying to qualify for the United States Open was able to equal the par of 72 for the 6,700-yard course.
Arthur Tracy, well known in the nineteen-thirties on radio as "The Street Singer," greeted an assembly of 1,900 senior citizens yesterday with his theme song, "Marta."

It is undeniable that Lar Lubovitch has sense of theater, for he shows flashes of it throughout his works. That which his pieces lack for the most, part is a sense of sustained flow. Last night at the American Theater Laboratory he presented three dances of which "Variations and Fugue on a Theme of a Dream" was the most completely realized.
PAKSONG, Laos, May 22 Jean Fivaz is the last French farmer on the verdant Boloven Plateau, which has become the target of the new Communist offensive in southern Laos.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 25 "Until this spring most folks didn't even bother to read the labels on the bug spray cans," said Joseph Roberts, manager of the Farmers Cooperative Association Garden Supply Center here. "Now they are asking some really sharp questions about what insecticides really do and how dangerous they are."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Urban living has much to offer: noise, pollution, crowding, the assaults of mass media, and the drudgery of factory work or bureaucratic routine.
Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would propose a new one-way "space available" trans-Atlantic fare enabling college-age youths to fly between New York and Europe for $99.

The annual "epidemic" of open fire hydrants with water cascading down filth-strewn streets, inevitably leading to clogged catch basins and flooding, has become of growing concern to the city's Water Resources Department.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25 (AP) The United States command reported today that American battlefield deaths had reached 201 in 25 days of operations in Cambodia.

NEW HAVEN The effect of Robert Brustein's Yale Repertory Theater version of Moliere's "Don Juan" is to stand the play on its head. That the production is eminently successful is a tribute not only to Mr. Brustein's direction and Yale's ensemble of actors but also to the solidity and depth of Moliere's play. It is a classic that can be enforced by reinterpretation.
Two attempts to postpone the local school board elections in Manhattan, again because of the racial and ethnic makeup of the six school districts in the borough were denied yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) Brushing aside charges that banks give favored treatment to businesses they control, the banking industry asked the senate today to reject "destructive" bank-regulating legislation adopted by the House.

A world in which "environment" has become the word of the day might profit from looking back at the prescient works of Joseph Wood Krutch, who died last week in Arizona. Twenty years ago that cultivated critic and teacher exchanged Manhattan for an adobe home in the Southwest to escape the crowds, to get air he could breathe and to enjoy "the natural beauty of the desert and its wildlife."

The engagement of Miss Gwynedd Anne Gowen, a junior at Vassar College, to Guy Felix, a law student at the University of Paris, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William E. W. Gowen of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 25 Treasury bill rates advanced sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
LONDON, May 25 The bewildered American, viewing a cricket match for the first time, turned to a British spectator in the stands and asked when it would get interesting.
A hijacked American Airlines Astrojet landed its passengers at Kennedy International Airport, refueled and took off for Cuba yesterday on orders of a stealthy pirate who never left the rear galley.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Sagging corporate profits and other economic woes have reduced the Government's tax revenue, Administration spokesman said today as they asked Congress for $18-billion more in borrowing authority.
BELIZE, British Honduras, May 25 (UPI) A chartered Cessna aircraft has been missing 24 hours on a scheduled 20-minute flight with Five Americans aboard, authorities reported today.
WOOLWICH, Me., May 25 (AP) Dr. William M. Hekking, a seascape painter who directed several art museums, died at his home here Saturday. His age was 85.

Dave Morehead's unspectacular career has not been without its high spots. There were, for example, the nohitter he pitched against Cleveland in 1965 and the three innings of hitless relief he pitched for Boston in the 1967 World Series.
WASHINGTON, May 25 The power of big-city Mayors to avoid disturbances by forbidding public gatherings during periods of urban unrest was upheld today by the Supreme Court.
SURBITON, England, May 25 (Reuters) Four American women advanced today in the Surrey tennis championships.

KENOSHA, Wis., May 25 New evidence supporting the view that internal biochemical defects are an important factor in schizophrenia was reported here today at an international symposium on the chemistry of the brain.
Marvin Miller, Director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, announced yesterday details of the new contract agreed to by negotiating committees for the players and club owners.

Dave Morehead's unspectacular career has not been without its high spots. There were, for example, the nohitter he pitched against Cleveland in 1965 and the three innings of hitless relief he pitched for Boston in the 1967 World Series.

Security markets came under relentless pressure yesterday as Wall Street registered the biggest single-day decline since the assassination of President Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963. The Dow-Jones industrial average plunged 20.81 points to 641.36, its lowest close since Dec. 18, 1962.
DETROIT, May 25 Bill Freehan's leadoff homer in tihe bottom of the ninth inning off Steve Hamilton gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-3 victory over the New York Yankees tonight.
Microfilming Corporation of America, a subsidiary of The New York Times, announced plans yesterday to publish, on microfilm, the complete editions of 14 college newspapers on a continuing basis.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes said today that he would file a $12million libel suit against Life magazine and Denny Walsh, author of a Life article accusing the Mayor of having personal ties with underworld figures.

The General Electric Company made four top-level executive changes yesterday as "part of an evolving plan designed to separate the staff work for planning and shaping the future of the company from the day-to-day operating work required at the corporate level."

ATLANTA, May 25 William H. Schroder, the Atlanta lawyer who represented Wallace Butts, former University of Georgia athletic director, in his successful libel action against The Saturday Evening Post, died today after a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

Thursday night's concert by Bertram Ross and members of the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance in Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association has been postponed until June 17.

The President also met with Samuel Pierce, general counsel-designate of the Treasury Department and he met with David A. Keene, national chairman of the Young Americans for Freedom.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 (AP) Roger Brown and the Indiana Pacers finally grunned down the plucky Los Angeles Stars tonight, 111-107 and won the American Basketball Association championship. Indiana, the Eastern leaders, beat the Western Division representative, 4 games to 2, in the final playoffs.
TRENTON, May 25 (AP) The State Division on Civil Rights charged today that 18 of the largest apartment complexes in Parsippany-Troy Hills discriminated against Negroes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25 Pacification in South Vietnam is reported to have suffered a slight setback last month.
LONDON, May 25 (AP) Rampaging gangs of youths "skinheads" with short hair and "greasers" with long hairbattled with bottles and boots on the southern seacoast today.

TORONTO, May 25 The business leaders of Quebec told their new provincial premier, Robert Bourassa, today that an investment increase of more than 50 per cent was needed to reduce the province's chronically high unemployment and raise living standards.
A woman and her five Children were rescued by firemen last night after a three-alarm fire broke out in their apartment house in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

Sagging consumer purchasing tied into the accelerating economic slowdown has taken its toll on operating results of four department store chains, all of which reported yesterday lower profits for the quarter ended with April.
PARIS, May 25 Soviet rockets will launch two French research satellites into orbit in the next two years, Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced today from Leningrad.

Four downtown businessmen and the head of a Long Island moving company were accused yesterday in State Supreme Court of scheming to defraud the Port of New York Authority by submitting exaggerated statements for moving business concerns during relocation for the World Trade Center.

WASHINGTON, May 25 The Senate Interior Committee delayed today a vote on confirmation of President Nixon's nominee to head the Bureau of Mines until it could examine two background reports by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Average prices of mortgage purchase-commitments continued to drop in all three categories at this week's free-market auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association, according to Fanny May president, Oakley Hunter.

The strong public opposition to widening the war in Southeast Asia has not prevented the Administration from pursuing the Cambodian intervention by proxy, sustaining South Vietnamese troops in operations that go far beyond the announced objective of cleaning out border sanctuaries.
WASHINGTON, May 25 Average interest costs on conventional mortages declined slightly in April, the first dip in 16 months, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 Former Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson of Canada opened a conference on human survival here today with a call for drastic reforms in the United Nations.

AVIVIM, Israel, May 25 Israeli forces made three limited incursions into southern Lebanon today, one of them with a tank column that was said to have engaged and knocked out a Lebanese Army artillery position north of Yarun.
Raimon, a Catalonian singer and poet in exile, last night sang his songs "about peace, against fear" at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.
The New York Mets were advised yesterday that Jerry Koosman, their No. 1 lefthanded pitcher, was suffering from tendonitis near the elbow and that his immediate return to work considered doubtful.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 25 Illinois legislators, disturbed by recent student unrest in the state, were told today to pay more attention to its root causes.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) Four of the country's leading bankers asked today that Congress avoid placing their industry in a legislative straitjacket. Banks need flexibility to meet the needs of a growing and complex economy, they contended.
LOS ANGELES, May 26 (UPI) The American Basketball Association finally has a champion that is going to stay put.

Muriel Spark, the British poet, playwright, novelist and critic, said yesterday that art and literature of sentiment and emotion, "however beautiful in itself, however striking in its depiction of actuality, has to go." She declared: "It cheats us into a sense of involvement with life and society, but in reality it is a segregated activity."
It was a wonder that Wilbur Daniel Steele wrote. To hear him tell it, it was an awful process.

The Anaconda American Brass Company, a major fabricating subsidiary of the Anaconda Company, announced yesterday in Waterbury, Conn. that it would not impose a price increase, tentatively scheduled for Monday, on copper water tube.

TRENTON, May 26 At least 300 fraudulent licenses have been issued to unqualified drivers by a ring that involved up to six "responsible members of the State Motor Vehicle Division," the director of the division said today.

The New York Cloak Joint Board, which represents 42,000 coat and suit workers in the metropolitan area, yesterday announced agreement on a new contract granting wage increases totaling 21.3 per cent over three years. Included were "fringe" benefits, such as dental-care coverage, scholarships for workers and a drug-addiction rehabilitation program.

PARIS, May 26 An economic body representing 22 nations has cautiously suggested that the United States resolve its growing difficulties in combining high employment with price stability by installing formal wage and price guidelines.

ADAMS, Mass., May 26 James Patrick McAndrews, a former state representative and senator, died at his home Sunday. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican, today introduced President Nixon's $1.5billion proposal to help school desegregation after the Administration backed down on its prohibition against busing to achieve racial balance.
DENVER, May 26 Leaders of a newly organized union of policemen said today they would ask the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for a charter next week to bring the weight of organized labor behind their goals.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., the largest retailer in New York and one of the country's leading department-store chains, reported yesterday its biggest decline in earnings for a fiscal quarter in at least 30 years.

The Appellate Division yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the city's four-year-old air pollution law, ending a three-year challenge by the real-estate industry.

A City Councilman and four individuals filed suit yesterday changing Bruce A. Gimbel, president of the department store chain, with conflict of interest in planning for a new store on the East Side while he was a board member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

PARIS, May 26 A quarrel between the United States and France over development aid has been settled with a provisional, compromise agreement that would dump $800-million a year into the Soft Loan Agency of the World Bank over the next three years.
BUFFALO, May 26 (AP) Franklin R. Brown, a former president of the New York State Bar Association, died today in Deaconness Hospital. He was 84 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, announced today the Federal Aviation Administration would conduct noise control tests for a four-month period at Kennedy Airport in order to reduce jet aircraft noise in the surrounding communities.
William J. Hawkins, a 24year-od electronics specialist by vocation and avocation, has parlayed his hobby of tinkering into $20,000.

PORTLAND, Me., May 26 A former Marine Corps lance corporal who was convicted by a court-martial of murdering five Vietnam civilians in 1968, is trying for the third time to be released from his 20-year sentence.
WASHINGTON, May 26 Wholesale prices resumed their rise in May after being level in April, the Labor Department reported today on the basis of preliminary estimates.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The Pentagon repeated today its announced intention to deploy multiple warhead missiles next month and said some missile launchers without warheads were already in place.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The Senate Post Office Committee today approved proposed reforms removing Congress and politics from the postal system and giving post office employes an 8 per cent pay rise.
JERUSALEM, May 26 Premier Golda Meir warned today that the Soviet Union's involvement in the Middle East threatened not only Israel's security, but also that of all the smaller nations in the world.

MOSCOW, May 26 Leonid I. Brezhnev, the head of the Communist party, said at the opening session of a congress of the Young Communist League today that the "stormy upsurge" of youth in the West provided evidence of the "deepening social crisis of capitalism."

ROME, May 26 Mrs. Elisabetta Pacelli Rossignani, sister of the late Pope Pius XII and his closest surviving relative, died here Saturday, the Vatican announced today. She was 89 years old, and had suffered a fall six months ago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 Peace and stability have settled over this archipelago nation of some 120 million people.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The nation's export surplus widened again in April after narrowing in March, the Commerce Department reported today.
Numerous tenants and their organizers threatened rent strikes yesterday if the City Council approved Mayor Lindsay's proposal to relax the city's 27-year-old rent-control law.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 26 (AP) Bobby Moore, the British soccer star held in connection with the theft of a $1,300 bracelet, is expected to be detained here at least until tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The Nixon Administration, under a barrage of criticism from politicians and financiers, stood firmly by its economic policies today.
ATLANTA, May 26 (AP) Donna Caponi has vaulted from 17th to 10th place on the Ladies Professional Golf Association money-winning list for 1970.

WASHINGTON, May 26 Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz was accused today by supporters of the late Joseph A. Yablonski of "a deliberate effort to try to sweep under the rug" the numerous government investigations of the United Mine Workers of America that began when Mr. Yablonski was murdered five months ago.

WASHINGTON, May 26 Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Robert H. Finch told the White House today that he intended to return to his department and "proceed with vigor" to overcome departmental problems.
Amid last-minute campaigning by candidates and nonpartisan appeals to the public to vote, preparations were being completed yesterday for tomorrow's community school board elections in Manhattan.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 27 The Governments of South Vietnam and Cambodia agreed here today that South Vietnamese troops would be pulled out of Cambodia "as soon as their mission is completed."
The Board of Education announced yesterday that all public schools in the city would close this Friday in honor of Memorial Day.
GUILDERLAND, N.Y., May 26 Governor Rockefeller called on state electric utility leaders to coordinate their planning of future installations and not limit such joint efforts only to power operations.

ROME, May 26 Secretary of State William P. Rogers endorsed today proposals by European allies of the United States for a mutual and balanced reduction of the forces of the Atlantic alliance and the Warsaw pact in central Europe.

DEVON, Pa., May 26 The engagement of Miss Alberta Pancoast Reath to Grant Coffin Manheim of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Manheim of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Pancoast Reath.
Two men convicted earlier this spring of murdering a policeman were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of 25 years to life by Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson.
Two members of the Women's Liberation movement tried to get onto the stage of the Dick Cavett show last night as the program was being taped for presentation later in the evening on Channel 7.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26 (UPI) State Senator Romano J. Mazzoli, 37 years old, a dove on the Vietnam war, won today the Democratic nomination for Representative from the Third District (Louisville and southern suburbs) by a substantial margin over his hawk opponent, State Senator Tom Ray.
John Delaney of 48 East End Avenue went to the police yesterday to find where his black and white MG convertible was. The answer was: at the bottom of the Hudson River.

TROY, N.Y., May 26 The Rev. George Borthwick, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church here, and Mrs. Borthwick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Anne Borthwick, to John M. Morgan of New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26 (AP) United States infantrymen were reported battling enemy forces at four points around the Cambodian town of Memot today, the third straight day Americans have reported increased enemy attacks in the Fishhook region over the border north of Saigon.
Saul I. Birnbaum, a wealthy accountant, was sent to jail yesterday to begin serving a one-year prison sentence imposed on him in Federal Court four years ago for bribing a tax agent in 1961.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association called upon the City Council yesterday to deny subpoena powers to the special commission set up last week by Mayor Lindsay to investigate charges of widespread police corruption in the New York Police Department.

The public accounting profession counterattacked yesterday its critics both from within and without that are trying to sidetrack its controversial proposal to reform rules governing accounting for corporate mergers.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 26 (AP) The Rev. John E. Brooks, 46 years old, vice president and dean of Holy Cross College, has been elected the 25th president of the college, it was announced tonight by Charles S. Horgan, chairman of the board of trustees.
Ray Charles and His Orchestra and the Raylettes will open the fifth season of the Schaefer Music Festival at the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park on June 25. They will perform at 7 and 9:30 P.M.

Wallace S. Girling, a former publishing executive and chairman of Adelphi University's board of trustees, died after a, heart attack at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L. I., Monday night. He lived at 40 Fairview Avenue, in East Williston, and was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The House Banking Committee approved by a vote of 32 to 1 today an emergency housingfinance bill very similar to the one already passed by the Senate.

NEWARK, May 26 On a normal lunch hour here, the downtown stores are busy, the restaurants and dining clubs are crowded and the streets teem with shoppers, students, office workers, executives and lawyers dodging traffic.

President Nixon's proposal to declare the ocean floor beyond the depth of 200 meters (660 feet) "the common heritage of mankind" marks a significant advance in United States policy toward a more responsible role in promoting international law, cooperation and development.

A blond actress from Shaker Heights, Ohio, playing the role of a nude witch in an Off Broadway play, complained yesterday that she was dismissed from an office job because her employer felt hers was "not the right image for the company."
ARCADIA, Calif., May 25 The right-wing John Birch Society stands on the verge of a major political victory.

Metals futures continued to drop and closed irregularly yesterday with platinum futures sales at a record of 3,647, compared with the previous record of 3,264 sales achieved on Nov. 3, 1969. Trading in these futures started in 1948.

BRICKTOWN, N.J., May 26 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Wohlgemuth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Louise Wohlgemuth, to David Purinton Chamberlain, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Roe Chamberlain of Northport, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 21 here.

MADRID, May 26 A longawaited draft providing for the establishment of political associations was made public yesterday by Torcuato Fernandez de Miranda, the Secretary General of the National Movement.

Judge Irving Ben Cooper denied yesterday a motion to dismiss Curt Flood's antitrust suit against baseball's reserve clause after attorneys for Flood had finished presenting their case. The trial will continue today in Federal Court here with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn as the first witness for the defense.

IEROPIYI, Greece, May 24 Townspeople and soldiers in this sheepherding village of stone houses on Greece's desolate and mountainous border with Albania find it hard to believe that relations between the two countries are thawing.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26 Premier Rashid Karami said tonight in the National Assembly that the Lebanese Government was considering calling in troops from Morocco and Tunisia or other Arab countries to help defend Lebanon against Israel.

Plans for the construction of a rail container transfer yard, especially intended for the handling of international cargoes, were announced here jointly yesterday by the Port of New York Authority and the Penn Central Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26 The Ambassadors of the Big Four The United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union met again today in their search for a permanent peace settlement in the Middle East based on the Security Council's Nov. 22, 1967, resolution. They announced only that the work would continue.

ELMONT, L.I., May 26 Proceeds from the Belmont Ball, to be held at the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park here on June 5, will go to the National Museum of Racing, the Saratoga Performing Arts Center and Skidmore College.

Arthur J. Goldberg, bidding for the Democratic nomination for Governor, declared yesterday that, rather than being "too far to the left," his polls indicated he has "great support in the conservative community."
RAHWAY, N.J., May 26 (AP) Four students were suspended today when fighting broke out between black and white pupils at the racially tense Rahway High School.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 26 Dr. Thomas H. Johnson, an ophthalmologist, died today of a heart attack. He was 91 years old and lived at 167 Nelson Road.
Representative Richard Max McCarthy's nominating petitions were upheld yesterday, without a signature to spare.

The New York Times announced yesterday that the newsstand price of the daily newspaper would be raised to 15 cents on Monday and that advertising rates would be increased later as a result of a wage settlement with union printers.

WASHINGTON, May 26 The Federal Aviation Administration disclosed today memoranda of telephone conversations by leaders of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization in support of the agency's contention that the organization's "sick-out" last March 25 to April 15 was a concerted strike.

A 30-year old black student who had spent time at Sing Sing Prison for armed robbery and a philosophy major who dropped out of college to become an actor, were among 61 students honored by the City University yesterday and given awards for advanced study.

"Wilson in the Promise Land," which the Trinity Square Repertory Company of Providence, R.I, brought to the ANTA Theater last night, is a play about Woodrow Wilson and a play about America. In it, as the author Roland van Zandt states in a program note, there are "confrontations between Dream and Reality, the Past and Present, Fathers and Sons, the Presidents and the Hippies."

RED BANK, N.J., May 26 Ward W. De Groot, a former official of the Diamond Match Company of New York, died yesterday in Riverview Hospital of a heart attack. He was 70 years old, and lived in Atlantic Highlands.

Citing a "new ingredient" in the coming summer's tensions a faltering economy with fewer jobs available Mayor Lindsay asked yesterday for an additional $5-million for the city's Federally financed Neighborhood Youth Corps program.

Anthony Quinn has agreed to become a major stockholder of Four Star International, Inc., it was announced by David Charney, president of Four Star, producers of television and motion pictures. The multimillion dollar deal, it was stated, involves "all the assets of Mr. Quinn's wholly owned company, the Franlor Company, including several story proper- ties." Mr. Quinn will function as a producer and director of movies and television properties, as well as an actor.

ROME, May 26 Raffaele Minichiello, the 20-year-old United States marine who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet plane from California to Rome last October, appeared in court here briefly today to learn that his trial had been postponed because of a lawyers' strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26 Secretary General Thant called on all governments today to establish "enforceable world laws, world police and world courts" to preserve peace and justice. Otherwise the United Nations cannot survive, he said.

PITTSBURGH, May 26 (UPI) A plan to put more blacks in high-paying skilled construction jobs has been approved by leaders of the Black Construction Coalition and the city construction industry, ending a 10month stalemate.
Chico Salmon doesn't deny he used to sleep with the lights on, the windows closed and the keyhole plugged. How else was he supposed to keep the evil spirits away?

ESSEX, Conn., May 26 Wilbur Daniel Steele, whose carefully crafted short stories put him in the first rank of American storytellers for many years, died at a nursing home here today after a long illness. He was 84 years old and a resident of Lyme.
DARIEN, Conn., May 26 Mrs. Marjorie D. Farmer, a former state legislator, died last Thursday in Phoenix, Ariz. She was 72 years old. She and her husband, Glenn Farmer, lived in Old Saybrook.
A bright green spot moved swiftly down the East River late yesterday afternoon. It was of mysterious origin to river viewers who did not know it was a work of art.

Restaurant eating is going the way of other regular luxuries for many New Yorkers by the boards. The soaring cost of eating out one of the most popular topics of current conversation has just been confirmed by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. One of the fastest rising elements in the Consumer Price Index is the price of restaurant meals, up 13.2 percent during the last year.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26 The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has developed packaged mathematics and engineering courses to be sent to industrial corporations under lease or rental.
VIENNA, May 26 (Reuters) Waves whipped by high winds pounded the dikes protecting Rumania's industrial ports on the Danube River today as new flooding swept across the country.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will blow a whistle tomorrow to signify completion of the Filene Center at Wolf Trap Farm Park for the performing arts in nearby Vienna, Va.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26 (AP) About 300 youngsters in the Cambridge school system from first through twelfth graders will be paid $10 a week this summer as tutors.

OAK BLUFFS, Mass., May 26 (UPI) Clarence A. Barnes, former state attorney general and a power in the Republican Party for half a century, died yesterday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 87 years old.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 26 (AP) The Newport Folk Festival, an annual event since 1959, will be postponed until 1971, according to George Wein, producer of the festivals.
HONG KONG, May 27 Communist China will provide more military and economic aid to North Vietnam under an agreement announced today.
PARIS, May 26 (AP) Roy Barth, America's eighth-ranked player, and Peaches Bartkowicz, No. 4 among the women, were eliminated today from the $100,000 French open tennis championships.

The name of Herman Badillo, former Bronx Borough President, was removed from the ballot as the Republican designee for Representative from the 21st Congressional District on Monday, the Board of Elections said yesterday. According to the board, he lacked sufficient Republican petitions.

WASHINGTON, May 26 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has charged that minorities do not benefit from Houston's growing economy and it has scheduled public hearings in the nation's space headquarters next week.

The New York Court of Appeals yesterday rejected a request from the faculty of the New York University Law School to allow striking law students to take the state bar examination without first taking this semester's final examinations.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) David Eisenhower, son-in-law of President Nixon, has taken a temporary job with the Washington Senators, the White House said today.

SERQUIGNY, France The Mediterranean has traditionally been regarded as a vital seaway by the Western world and, more recently, as NATO's critical right flank. Yet rarely in peacetime, if such a euphemism is permitted, has the Mediterranean been more disrupted.

JERICHO, L.I., May 26 Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, the 1962 and 1967 winner, took a one-stroke lead today with 38, 41 79 in the 20th annual Women's Cross County 54-hole medal play championship at the Meadow Brook Club. Par for the 5,919-yard course is 36, 36 72.

Vice can as easily be taken for granted as virtue. The fact is the despair of moralists the world over. Now that we have become so accustomed to the glaring faults and more marginal infelicities of the Royal Ballet's current production of Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake," there in a temptation to take them in our stride. It is, like few temptations, one to be resisted.

The Justice Department said yesterday it would press its efforts to prevent International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation from acquiring the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, whose combined assets of about $7.09-billion would make it the largest corporate merger in United States history.
Judy Heumann, a 22-year-old polio victim, filed suit in Federal District Court yesterday for the right to become the city's first teacher in a wheel chair.
DETROIT, May 26 The name Horton continued to bedevil the Yankees tonight as Willie Horton, the Tiger left fielder, broke up a scoreless game with a three-run homer in the ninth inning.
The chancellor of Rollins College, Hugh F. McKean, has proposed a new system of granting college degrees to those unable to attend regular classes.

CONCORD, Mass., May 26 Dr. Ronald M. Ferry, a former associate professor at Harvard University and the first master of the institution's Winthrop House, died at his home here this morning. He was 78 years old.
The conductor of the IND local that smashed into a crowded rush-hour train last Wednesday testified for more than an hour yesterday before a Queens grand jury looking into the accident.

Joan Turner chose Carnegie Recital Hall for her American debut last night, and she probably shouldn't have. Even with spotlights and twin amplifiers, the, formal atmosphere of the place worked against the cal culated mayhem of the British music hall star.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Members of Congress of both parties, led by President Nixon and an occasionally tearful Lyndon B. Johnson, joined today in praise for Speaker John W. McCormack, the Democratic legislator from Boston who is retiring after 42 years in the House.
DEVON, Pa., May 26 Until a year ago; Melanie Smith never rode a jumper. And her horse, The Irishman, never had competed in a jumper class.

Manhattan residents tomorrow have a special opportunity to help improve public education by voting in the delayed community school board election. In each of the borough's six districts, the voters will elect nine candidates.

WASHINGTON, May 26 In the first vote in a prolonged Cambodia debate, the Senate made clear today that it endorsed President Nixon's troop withdrawal plans, although it remained divided on curbing any future military involvement in Cambodia.

"We've been lucky so far this season," said Red Schoendienst with a cheerful and reassuring smile. "We haven't gotten straightented away yet but neither has anyone else in our division. All the top teams Cubs, Mets, Pirates and ourselves got beat together.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) Government attorneys have been instructed by the Justice Department to avoid prosecuting interstate automobile thefts unless there are "exceptional circumstances" in an effort to ease the load on Federal prosecutors, courts and prisons.

MIAMI, May 26 (AP) Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the headquarters yesterday of Alpha 66, a militantly anti-Castro group, days after a Government decision that attacks on Cuba from United States territory by exiles must stop.

The word "jawboning," as used by most Government officials and businessmen these days, refers to public exhortations and/or implied threats by the Administration as a means of convincing business or labor to adopt certain attitudes and policies.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 26 The lightest player, the 124pound Juan Gonzalez of Dorado Beach, Puerto Rico, proved a heavyweight today in the Westchester section's United States Open qualifying round.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) A $650-million authorization for the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, the Federal agency designed to help local officials fight crime, was approved unanimously today by the House Judiciary Committee.

When school-age children paint and draw, they often reflect in their work some of their interests, their surroundings or their culture, for by the time a child becomes 8 or 9 or 10, he begins to be concerned with reproducing the reality he sees.

A highly radioactive rock from the moon's Ocean of Storms was reported yesterday to be 4.6 billion years old, making it the oldest lunar material yet discovered and the first lunar rock found that apparently dates back to the formation of the solar system.
Phil Jackson, who missed the New York Knickerbockers' world championship season while recuperating from a spinal fusion operation, has signed his contract for the 1970-71 season.

Howard J. Samuels, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, called yesterday for a complete restructuring of the Legislature and pledged that if elected he would campaign actively in future primaries against legislators who did not support such reform.

ROCHESTER, May 26 (AP) Paul Miller announced at the annual stockholders meeting today that he had relinquished the presidency of the Gannett Company Inc. to Allen H. Neuharth and had become chairman of the newspaper and broadcasting concern.
Richie Allen made his New York debut with the St. Louis Cardnials last night and the Mets survived.
Bond prices tumbled broadly to record lows again yesterday with no sign of any outside development that could reverse the market's course and revive its confidence on the horizon.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, May 26 (Reuters) President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt today briefed the heads of state of the Sudan and Libya on developments in the Middle East at the start of their third conference since signing a tripartite alliance.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 For the first time ever, the entire field of 33 cars in the Indianapolis 500 have engines augmented by turbochargers, which account for the high-pitch wail that dominates the sound effects at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Noise is part of the excitement the fans come to enjoy, but for the drivers turbochargers mean more horsepow er, as much as 40 per cent more. What is remarkable...
PORTLAND, Ore., May 26 State Treasurer Robert W. Straub won an eight-way fight tonight for the Democratic nomination for Governor, setting up a rematch in November with Gov. Tom McCall, a Republican.

Bernard Botein, former Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division's First Department, was elected president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at the group's annual meeting last night.

A 48-year-old correction officer was arrested on Rikers Island yesterday and accused of selling five packets of heroin to an inmate who was acting as an undercover agent for the Bronx District Attorney's office in a continuing investigation of narcotics traffic in the island's prison complex.

WASHINGTON, May 26 A State Department official said today that the department agreed completely with statements made yesterday by the United States Ambassador to Sweden, who complained of "disgraceful" demonstrations by Swedes protesting American policy in Southeast Asia.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 26 Rain that had fallen through most of the afternoon and through the first race had little or no effect on the synthetic rubber surface at Roosevelt Raceway as the second harness racing meeting of the season started at the Nassau County course tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) The chief actuary of the Social Security Administration has resigned after charging that Democrats in the agency have attempted to undermine the Nixon Administration.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission heard some serene testimony yesterday, favoring the establishment of a 22-block "historic district" in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 26 (UPI) Don Combs said today he had resigned as trainer of dust Commander, the recent Kentucky Derby winner, because his owner, Robert E. Lehmann, "didn't seem to trust my judgment."

Litton Industries, Inc., a diversified industrial producer on the West Coast, achieved the second highest quarterly sales in its history and a record volume for the nine months ended April 30, the report disclosed yesterday. Earnings, however, declined 25.6 per cent in the three months ended April 30 and 12.6 per cent for the nine-month period.
A Bronx patrolman has been suspended from the Police Department after being Accused of refusing to give a receipt to a man who had found a "very large sum of money" and turned it over to the police.

The majority of heroin addicts being treated under the Dole-Nyswander methadone procedures have stopped regular use of heroin, reduced or eliminated previous patterns of antisocial behavior and have either got jobs or started school, according to an evaluation of the program released yesterday.
Jockeys may be the brightly plumaged peacocks of the sports world, but they have eyes like hawks when it comes to sizing up a muddy track.

A Syracuse man who accused the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company of dismissing him because of his religion has been awarded a settlement of $100,000, the New York State Division of Human Rights announced yesterday.
MEMPHIS, May 26 Golfers on the pro circuit utilized a day off from the tour today to play in the local qualifying trials for the United States Open championship.
A student in Australia, an observatory attendant in Chile and a mystery man in the Indian Ocean have discovered a new comet, bright enough to be seen without a telescope.
WASHINGTON, May 26 Two relatively modest proposals to tighten its code of ethics were approved today by the House of Representatives after an hour of explanatory speeches but no debate.
It was another installment of the same story on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as prices continued to decline, finishing at their lowest level in almost three years.

Leon E. Panetta, who was forced out as director of the Federal Office of Civil Rights after accusing the Nixon Administration of softening its stand on equal rights, was appointed an executive assistant to Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

SEVERNA PARK, Md., May 26 Mrs. John O. Jones has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Deborah Anne Wood, to Robert Bracewell Appleyard Jr., son of the Right Rev. Robert B. Appleyard, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh, and Mrs. Appleyard.

In 1929, when he went to Oxford as a Rhodes scholar, John King Fairbank found an old Chinese textbook and began to teach himself Chinese because he had heard that the Chinese Government was beginning to publish its previously untouched 19thcentury diplomatic archives.

Joe Kapp, an inventive athlete who quarterbacks for the Minnesota Vikings, brought hurdling back to professional football last season but the coaches have decided to ban the practice. The coaches concluded their meeting here yesterday with this news while the owners began theirs at the National Football League offices on Park Avenue.
BUENOS AIRES, May 26 (UPI) Oscar Ruiz, publisher of Cronica, said tonight that the Government had lifted its ban of the paper and that the daily would be on the streets tomorrow morning.

NEWARK, May 26 Federal District Court Judge Lawrence A. Whipple formally approved an out-of-court settlement today to compensate 66 black persons whose homes were entered in a mass search for weapons during the Plainfield riot of July, 1967.
One of the annual signs of the start of the wholesale buying period for women's fall merchandise arrived in New York yesterday with the first performance of the 1970 Milliken Breakfast Show.

William B. King, former acting principal of Junior High School 120 in Harlem, charged yesterday that he was dismissed May 14 without due process, a victim of an effort to rid the public school system of black principals.
Tricia Nixon, the President's 24-year-old daughter, proved a charming, lively and poised hostess last night in a televised tour of the family living quarters on the second floor of the White House.

The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed yesterday to let 88,060 shares of the Parvin-Dohrmann Company stay in escrow pending the outcome of the S.E.C.'s suit to block a sale of the shares to Harold Butler, president of Denny's Restaurants, Inc.

The American Stock Exchange announced plans yesterday for a major step forward in automation, in which data on transactions will be routed by computer directly from the trading floor to the exchange's Clearing Corporation.

Stock markets in London and in the major Continental centers slumped heavily yesterday in reaction to the continued slide on Wall Street Monday. The Tokyo market made a partial recovery from the previous day's sharp decline.
NEW ORLEANS, May 26 More than 1,600 barrels of crude oil poured from a damaged barge into the Mississippi River south of New Orleans last night.

About 5,000 subway passengers, some of whom had been trapped for more than two hours, had to be evacuated from powerless trains last night after a heavy downpour caused flooding that resulted in a short circuit on the Fourth Avenue BMT line in Brooklyn.
A brisk selling breeze snuffed out a rally attempt in the stock market at mid-session yesterday and prices then ground downward to a new low for the last seven and a half years.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) Estimates have been made by experts that hospital costs in 1980 will reach $1,000 a day in major urban centers, Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, said today.

The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, delivered "a plea" in defense of the younger generation last night and said that "the conscience of America today is coming from its youth."

There are so few ballets that merit the accolade wondrous in our pantheon that it is indeed a pleasure to welcome "Jewels" in its first appearance in this truncated New York City Ballet spring season. Last night at the State Theater, the company presented its varied humors with genuine consideration if not always glittering brilliance.
ATHENS, May 26 Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis brushed aside today rumors of strain in her marriage with the Greek shipowner.
Arts. President Nixon announced the appointment of 49 persons to be members of the Advisory Committee on the Arts of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 26 (AP) A light plane missing with five Americans aboard, including an official from the University of Bridgeport and his family, crashed on a beach in British Honduras, the university reported today.

Silkscreen posters by Andy Warhol and Jack Youngerman went for $200 each; others by Ernst Trova and Charles Hinman brought in $175 and $155. A painting by Gloria Vanderbilt Cooper sold for $425. A five-bottle wine basket went for $200 and a magnum of Dom Perignon 1961 for $40.

WASHINGTON, May 26 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is said to have asked American commanders in Vietnam whether, in light of recent operations against suspected enemy base areas in Cambodia, the United States can withdraw more troops from Vietnam by May 1, 1971 than the 150,000 announced by President Nixon last month.

The suspended general counsel of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission pleaded guilty yesterday to attempting to extort money from a company that was trying to settle a $1million claim against the commission.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 26 In the Princeton University Chapel this afternoon, Mrs. Elizabeth Sophia Sidney, daughter of Viscount De L'Isle of Penshurst Place, Tonbridge, Kent, England, and the late Jacqueline Viscountess De L'Isle, was married to Andrew H. Lane Paneyko. He is a son of Mrs. Lane Paneyko of Princeton and Mirko Paneyko of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, dean of the chapel, performed the Presbyterian ceremony.
WASHINGTON, May 26 A Senate subcommittee has recommended placing, for the first time, a specific limit on Pentagon spending for independent research by private contractors.

TROY, N.Y., May 26 Ten sealed indictments resulting from a grand jury investigation into charges that officials of this Republican-controlled city were involved in corruption were presented today to a State Supreme Court justice by the Rensselaer County District At torney.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 Ralph Ginzburg, the publisher, will have to spend three years in prison instead of five, Federal District Judge E. Mac Troutman ruled today.

GENEVA, May 26 Board members and senior executives of the troubled Investors Overseas Services mutual fund empire hold $2.5-million in "secured" loans obtained from its banking subsidiaries, according to a notice sent to the parent I.O.S. Company's shareholders. The notice was mailed earlier this month with proxies for the first shareholders' meeting that the Canadian incorporated I.O.S., Ltd., is to hold in Toronto on June 30.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26 (AP) Kentucky's largest school system, Jefferson County, will turn to an all-year operation, perhaps as early as the fall of 1971.

LONDON, May 26 (AP) Armed police in El Salvador broke up a mob that stoned a Soviet car in the World Cup auto rally after the automobile's windscreen was smashed by a rock, organizers here said yesterday.

A record field of 312 players, including almost 50 experts, took part in the annual United Jewish Appeal charity event Monday night at the Essex House on Central Park South. The event produced more than $25,000 toward its objective of building a library in an Israeli border village.

Tempers flared at a pretrial hearing for 13 Black Panthers in Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, causing Justice John M. Murtagh to halt the hearing and order a defendant removed from the courtroom.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 George Meany, who was billed as the sole speaker Thursday at the convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, will not come here to address the 417,000-member union.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland vetoed today legislation that would have removed all state restrictions on abortions. The Governor emphasized that he had based his decision on legal rather than ethical grounds. He said:
WASHINGTON, May 25 An "antipoverty railway" is being designed with Federal funds to bring social services to thousands of poor families in West Virginia's remote coal mining country.

WASHINGTON, May 26 President Nixon welcomed President Suharto of Indonesia to the White House today and told him during a 90-minute conference that the joint United StatesSouth Vietnamese operation in Cambodia was a success. The stock market, struggling to fight its way out of one of the deepest slumps in history, soared yesterday to the largest one-day advance ever recorded.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 The Department of Interior asked today for title to Alcatraz Island and said that the former prison in San Francisco Bay would be converted into a national park.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America today criticized Vice President Agnew for public statements that the union contended threatened dissent, free speech and freedom of the press.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 27 A high-level Thai Government delegation, dominated by military leaders, flew to Cambodia today for a critical conference to decide the amount and kind of aid including possibly even combat troops that Thailand will give her embattled neighbor to the east.
Pessimism about the economy is adversely affecting buying plans of many American families, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, May 27 The new United States Ambassador to Sweden, Dr. Jerome H. Holland, is winning applause here for his spirited efforts to repair Swedish-American relations despite the eggs and epithets hurled against him by youthful extremists.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday that profits fell while sales rose in the fiscal quarter and six months ended April 30.

About 140,000 more teenagers will be seeking jobs this summer in the New York metropolitan area, beyond the 240,000 youths aged 16 through 19 employed this spring, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated yesterday.
GENEVA, May 27 Major importing and exporting nations agreed today to extend for three more years a pact regulating international trade in cotton textiles.

RICHMOND, May 27 In a 4-to-2 decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit ruled today that not every school within a district must be integrated in order to meet the Supreme Court's demand for a unitary, nonracial system.

MOSCOW, May 27 A sense of gloom and despair hangs over Anatoly Efros's unusual production of Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet," which has quickly become the theatrical sensation of an otherwise mediocre season.

Alpheus Lincoln, a motion picture actor of silent days, who had also appeared in the theater, died Friday in La Puente, Calif. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The Alaska legislature is expected to vote tomorrow on a $120-million appropriation bill to finance state construction of a 390-mile pipeline access road from the Yukon River to Prudhoe Bay on the Arctic north slone.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The House narrowly defeated today the first concerted effort against the supersonic transport, approving a $290-million appropriation to extend the development of two prototype aircraft. The roll-call vote, against a motion to consider a complete halt in SST spending, was 176 to 163.

LONDON, May 27 Britain today moved toward the official opening of her election campaign this weekend with the publication of Labor party and Conservative party platforms, both built on promises and compassion for all and derision for each other.

WASHINGTON, May 27 State Department officials disclosed today that the South Vietnamese and Thai Governments were empowered to turn over to the Cambodian Army military equipment that had been supplied by the United States.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 27 The eight Ivy league football coaches agree there is little reason to expect interruptions in the sport next fall as a result of protesting or politically active students.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The Democratic party, pleading a lack of funds but not of issues, started its 1970 Congressional campaign tonight with a $500-a-plate dinner, starring former President Lyndon B. Johnson.

Mayor Lindsay has retained a private lawyer to oppose an attempt to have him testify about a $3,000 campaign contribution by a friend that was allegedly made in lieu of payment for legal services due the Mayor's twin brother, David.

Prices on stock exchanges in London and on Continental markets in general closed mixed yesterday. Although most markets abroad showed weakness in reaction to Tuesday's slide on Wall Street, the downturn appeared to be easing.
A trio of award-winning radio spot announcements underlining some subtle manifestations of white racism will be offered for broadcast nationally next month under the auspices of the Episcopal Church.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 27 The bishops of Brazil, meeting in Brasilia the capital, today urged the Government to carry out social reforms, give more voice to the opposition and investigate reports of the torture of prisoners.
PARIS, May 27 Signs of widespread outrage over violence by young dissidents are mounting here as the Government presses efforts to stem a wave of property destruction and other acts of protest.
LONDON In rented rooms and bleak homes on the fringe of London, the "stayat-home daughters" grow old in despair.

ROME, May 27 Fifteen Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization tonight invited the Soviet Union, the Warsaw pact powers and other interested governments to explore mutual and balanced reduction of forces in Central Europe.
Mrs. Kate Slatin, widow of Jacob Slatin, a civil engineer, and mother of Dr. Harvey Slatin, an atomic scientist here, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 82 years old.
Michael E. Benjamin, a public accountant for 60 years, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 320 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, May 27 Friends of Sargent Shriver are trying to persuade him to accept a new national role as campaign speaker and fund raiser for the election of liberal antiwar Democrats to Congress. He was said to be undecided.

The bond market, which has been declining more or less steadily since late March, rallied yesterday in a recovery sparked by a seemingly spontaneous decision by many traders and investors that the market had sunk far enough.
WASHINGTON, May 27 President Suharto of Indonesia declared today that "other foreign troops" must be prevented from replacing those of the United States as Americans withdraw from the Asian mainland.

Patrolman Louis A. D'Alessio of the Tactical Patrol Force was suspended without pay yesterday pending trial after being accused of failing to report the receipt of a quantity of money last Saturday night.
Skyscraper skeletons of luxury, apartment houses are rising over Lincoln Center and Sherman Square. In the West Sixties and Seventies, sleazy rooming houses are becoming posh apartments.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its best performance in almost eight years yesterday as stocks rose sharply in the heaviest volume of the year.

Wives and children of inmates in state prisons pleaded yesterday at a public hearing of the State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction for provision for informal family visiting to prisons so the convicts and their wives can maintain family ties.
George X. McLanahan, president of the Polynesian Food Products Company of Honolulu, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

New student disorders broke out yesterday at George Washington High School as union teachers refused to take building-patrol assignments and to, perform certain other duties. They were protesting the Board of Education's recent reinstatement of two students accused of taking pan in earlier disturbances at the school.

Voters in Manhattan will go to the polls today to elect members to the new community school boards being set up under the school decentralization law. At stake in the elections are 54 board seats nine in each of the borough's six local school districts.

A Port Authority patrolman wto had read a Federal Bureau of Investigation "wanted" listing brought about the arrest of a suspect in a bank robbery yesterday in the Midtown Bus Terminal, the police reported.

City Parks Administrator August Heckscher said last night that he would refuse to grant a permit to construct the controversial subway tunnels underneath Central Park until he was "satisfied that both in design and construction every measure has been taken to protect the park and the park users."
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday receipt of a $60-million order from the Duke Power Company for the design and construction of two nuclear turbine-generators.

WASHINGTON, May 27 A month has passed since President Nixon ordered American troops into Cambodia and there are now three quite different views here about how his Administration is reacting to the turmoil that ensued.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 27 Tempered Yankee, on the strength of his 1970 record (five victories in seven outings, including his last four straight, was made the 2-to-1 favorite today to capture Saturday night's ninth annual Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

Coy D. Smith, one-time chief fiscal officer of the Neighborhood Youth Corps, was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to two and a third to seven years in prison for the 1968 theft of nearly $400,000 in Youth Corps paychecks.
Longer subway platforms, housing, a new street layout in, a downtown renewal area and a Queens park occupied the City Planning Commission yesterday.
It would not be too far fetched to think that when Woody Fryman and the Montreal Expos went to bed last night, they fell asleep counting home runs.
FORT WORTH, May 27 Shareholders of the General Dynamics Corporation, a major defense contractor, met quietly here today in an atmosphere of rigid security.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27 The Government today quietly put aside the proposal to ask troops of other Arab countries into Lebanon as a response to the Israeli patrols that cross into Lebanese territory.

Col. Richard Gimbel, U.S.A.F. retired, curator of aeronautical literature at the Yale University Library and a former department store executive, died of a heart attack in Munich, Germany, yesterday, while on a tour with the Grolier Club. He was 71 years old and lived at 801 Forest Road, New Haven, and 405 Newbold Road, Jenkintown, Pa.

A lot piled with garbage, rat-infested slums and the dismal lives of their black and Puerto Rican tenants in the East Bronx were shown in slides yesterday to a shocked audience at Automation House, a labor-management foundation for the study of modern technology and its impact on society.

The chief assistant district attorney of Brooklyn testified yesterday that a Black Panther informant told him in November, 1968, of an attempt by members of the governing board of the Ocean HillBrownsville Experimental School District to arrange the assassination of Albert Shanker.

WASHINGTON, May 27 A Pentagon spokesman said today that two American fighter-bombers attacked antiaircraft gun sites in North Vietnam on Monday after a reconnaissance plane they were escorting had been fired on about 90 miles north of the demilitarized zone.

DETROIT, May 27 The Yankees, whose bats had been silenced yesterday by the pitches of Earl Wilson, erupted for three runs in the first inning tonight and went on to a 4-2 triumph over Detroit at Tiger Stadium.
Gil Hodges, the genius, had an idea last night. He would bat Cleon Jones at leadoff and drop Tommie Agee to third in the batting order "just for a change," as the manager put it.

As antiwar demonstrations continued on some campuses yesterday, a student group in Washington announced plans for demonstrations in several cities on Memorial Day and a drive to spread the protest movement beyond the colleges and universities into union halls, military installations and migrant labor camps.

Activities. The President had a morning meeting with his economic advisers Treasury Secretary Kennedy; Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; Dr. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Budget Director Mayo. The President had a private meeting with former President Johnson. He gave a...
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27 The foreign ministers of South Vietnam and Cambodia signed documents here today giving South Vietnam a broad and open-ended mandate for military operations in Cambodia.

The Appellate Division yesterday ordered a hearing for June 4 on a charge by 53 Democratic primary candidates for Federal, state and local office that a section of the new election law assuring incumbents first place on the ballot was illegal.
NEWARK, May 27 Former Union County District Court Judge Ralph DeVita was sentenced today to one to two years in State Prison on his conviction last month of obstructing justice.

CHICAGO, May 27 The general assembly of the 3.2million-member United Presbyterian Church overwhelmingly approved today a campaign to raise more than $70-million to be used its "depressed areas and among deprived people."
The prompt sale of United States jet planes to Israel was urged yesterday by two of the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senator.

Federal Bureau of Investigation agents were investigating yesterday the reported theft of a $217,500 shipment of currency at Kennedy International Airport by two armed bandits who waylaid a Pan American Word Airways courier vehicle.

MADRID, May 27 United States reluctance to give Spain even a vaguely worded security commitment appears to be the principal difficulty facing a new agreement on American bases, according to qualified sources here.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 27 Anthony Sansone, spokesman for Westchester County villages in the State Conference of Mayors for the last 21 years, died yesterday at his home, 640 Wood Street. He was 73 years old.
When a local socialite telephoned Fred Bridge, who owns what may be the finest pot and pan shop in America, he was in the middle of a sale.
WASHINGTON, May 27 Extensive use of a new compound in detergents to replace phosphate, which has been criticized as a water pollutant, was reported today at a Senate hearing.

Organized landlords and tenants have had their say on Mayor Lindsay's rent plan, and have made no useful contribution whatever. Emotionalism all but pushed reason out of the City Hall hearings, giving the City Council's Housing Committee little help in revising the Lindsay proposals for overhaul of the World War II rent control law.

MEMPHIS, May 27 A new era for the Memphis open golf tournament begins tomorrow. After being a homely 12year old on the circuit, it will blossom with a touch of show business and be associated with a nationally known charity.
A 1,250-room addition that will make the New York Hilton the world's largest hotel will start to rise soon on the West 54th Street site of the George Abbott Theater.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The Justice Department has notified members of Congress that it will not prosecute political committes and candidates for alleged 1968 violations of the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.
BONN, May 27 A court in Frankfurt today imposed prison terms on two former officials in Hitler's euthanasia program of killing mentally and physically handicapped persons.
The plight of the Atlantic salmon, a glorious gamefish prized by many anglers above all other species, is attracting international attention.
Soybean futures prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board Trade, with the July contract advancing 2 cents a bushel in the early trading before losing some of the gain near the close.
Spring may be "busting out all over," but the dismal economic weather over Wall Street has turned quite a few budding securities into weeds for the small investors who own them.
The number of young people arrested in 1969 for crimes prompted by drug use was more than double the 1967 figure, a police study revealed yesterday.

Sergio Asti's wife wanted him to design a baby's feeding dish. But his manufacturer wanted him to devise a desk accessory for paper clips, pencils and note paper. What resulted was a desk organizer that looks like an outsized baby's feeding dish.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The Securities and Exchange Commission turned down today a request by John M. King that it permit him to assume control of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., without having the commission's order that bars most I.O.S. operations in the United States, automatically extended to other companies controlled by Mr. King.

ROSENDALE, N. Y., May 27 Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. MacKinlay have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol MacKinlay, to Francis A. Malley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Malley of Port Washington, L.I.

MEXICO CITY, May 27 (UPI) Hannu Mikkola of Finland and Gunnar Palm of Sweden finished in first place, an hour and 18 minutes ahead of their nearest rivals; today in the 16,000-mile, London-to-Mexico City World Cup auto rally.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Deputy Secretary of Defense, David Packard, urged Congress today to approve budgeted funds permitting the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to continue Government projects such as the C-5A super transport. But he said the ailing firm must get private financial support to avoid bankruptcy.

Miss Elaine Lois Berol, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Berol of New York and Waynesboro, Ga., plans to be married on Sept. 16 to Scott Bevan Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Palmer Taylor of Darien, Conn., and Pompano Beach. Fla.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 28 Wall Street and other business leaders, worried about the slump in the stock market and in the economy generally, received private assurances last night from the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board that it would continue to supply enough credit to the economy to keep it moving ahead.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., May 27 Miss Corinne Valerie Praus, daughter of Alexis A. Praus, director of the Kalamazoo Public Museum, and Mrs. Praus, plans to be married to Robert Chia-Ting Sze, son of Palmer C. Sze of Chatham, N. J., and the late Mrs. Sze.
Miami Beach Frankie Otero, 130 pounds, Hialeah, Fla., outpointed Casto Ramirez, 129, San Juan. P. R., 10 rounds.

Andrew Soltis continued his victorious ways by taking first place in the finals of the 1969-70 Marshall Chess Club championship. He won five games and drew two for a 6-1 tally. Second place went to A. Deutsch, with 5 -1 . Nat Halper was third with 5-2, and Dr. Edward Lasker, the vigorous 86-year-old grandmaster, was fourth with 4 -2 .

ROME, May 27 (Reuters) Following is the text of a declaration issued today by the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on their proposal for a mutual and balanced reduction of forces in Central Europe:

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 27 Mr. and Mrs. George Waldo Emerson of Northampton and of Newport, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Randolph Emerson, to John Francis Driscoll Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Driscoll of Holyoke. The wedding is planned for Aug. 22 in Newport.

Oscar Myers, a systems-planning director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died yesterday after heart surgery at the New York University Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived at 190 East 72d Street.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) The Army denied today a statement attributed to Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of New York, that it had developed a "secret poison dart gun-type weapon."

Bruce A. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., told shareholders at yesterday's an nual meeting that the sales trend continues at about the same pace as in the first fiscal guarter, ended April 30. That period's volume, as announced, Monday, was $153.8-million, up from $150-million a year earlier when there were five fewer stores.

JERUSALEM, May 27 A right-wing bloc of parties in Israel's coalition Government today withheld approval of Premier Golda Meir's policy speech to the Knesset yesterday. Their action raised the prospect of a Cabinet crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 27 Space agency investigators reported tonight that the oxygen tank that exploded aboard the moon-bound Apollo 13 "probably" had been damaged during launching pad operations just prior to blastoff.
Shell Oil Company has come up with a new method to dispose of large oil spills at sea.
