Kenneth G. Judson, a commodity broker, whose family was among the founders of Forest Hills Gardens in Queens, died yesterday at his home, 61 Olive Place, in Forest Hills. He was 75 years old.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 27 (UPI) The suspension of a police captain here that led to the dismissal of the Police Commissioner was thrown out today by a hearing officer.
TROY, N.Y., May 27 The Rensselaer County Republican chairman and three others were indicted today an felony charges resulting from a yearlong investigation of government and politics here.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry V. Bogack have made known the engagement of Mrs. Bogack's daughter, Miss Maureen Ann Cain, to Andrew J. Grieco, son of State Assemblyman Salvatore J. Grieco and Mrs. Grieco. Both families live in Brooklyn.
Stock prices rallied strongly yesterday in a dramatic recovery that carried some leading market indexes to their largest one-day gains in history.

BROOKLINE, Mass., May 27 Dr. Robert Shapiro, an orthopedic surgeon, and Mrs. Shapiro have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Shapiro, to Marc Saperstein, son of Rabbi Harold Saperstein, president of the New York Board of Rabbis, and Mrs. Saperstein of Malverne, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 17 in Boston.
A strike by newspaper deliverers that had prevented 100,000 copies a day of The Wall Street Journal from reaching the city's newsstands since last May 17 was called off yesterday.

American Brands is not in the practice of announcing agency switches. Instead, once a year it issues a news release that lists the company's agency line-up and the cigarette and other tobaccoproduct brand assignments.

Mayor Lindsay was urged by the acting president of the 2,500-member Uniformed Fire Officers Association yesterday to adopt a program to curb what he said was an increasing number of unprovoked assaults on firemen.

BONN, May 27 Chancellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Mindster Walter Scheel told Parliament today that they saw positive signs in the current West German dialogue with the Soviet Union that could lead to negotiations on a pact renouncing the use of force.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's District II baseball championship will open at Princeton University today. The winner will represent the district at the College World Series in Omaha June 12 through 19.

MEXICO CITY, May 27 As the Soviet Union's soccer team prepares to meet Mexico in the opening game of the World Cup tournament on Sunday, Lev Yashin practices guarding the goal as the probable substitute for Yevgeny Rudakov, the firststring goalie. Rudakov broke his left clavicle in an exhibition in Bogota, Columbia, against Millonarios, May 13.
"The day of the scofflaw is over." Transportation Administrator Constantine SidamonEristoff said yesterday as he announced details of his administration's new parking violations bureau.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Thursday, May 28 (AP) Former Prime Minister Sirima Bandaranaike's Communist-backed coalition headed today toward a landslide victory in yesterday's parliamentary elections.

Fifty members of the Young Republican and Young Democratic Cubs of New York City voted last night at a joint meeting here to support two Senate bills aimed at ending American involvement in Southeast Asia.
Directors of the Babcock Wilcox Co. voted yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend to 12 cents a share from 34 cents, which had been paid quarterly since 1967.

Lonesome River, with Bobby Woodhouse riding, and Royal Tom, guided by Braulio Baeza, shared honors in the main activity at Belmont Park yesterday. Each won a section of the feature presentation of a mile and a sixteenth, Lonesome River by five lengths and Royal Tom by a neck.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) Companies that own banks that produce less than half of their total income asked the Senate Banking Committee today for exemption from legislation intended to stem the creation of billion-dollar bankdominated conglomerates.

Many players appreciate the advantages of duplicate bridge the competitive quality, the elimination of the luck of the deal, and the possibility of scoring well with bad cards but still prefer to play rubber bridge.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 The creation of a national organization to improve foundation practices and represent foundations to the public and government has been urged by a committee formed by foundation leaders.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) Few top officials of the Nixon Administration will take part in commencement ceremonies on the nation's troubled college campuses.
The City Council voted last night to grant subpoena powers for six months to Mayor Lindsay's recently formed fivemember commission to investigate alleged police corruption.

The Royal Ballet has had three great influences on its life. First, foremost and obvious is Dame Ninette de Valois, who founded the company in 1931. Second, equally obvious, is Sir Frederick Ashton, who not only has been the company's principal choreographer for all those years, but also has made his concept of the classic style the very touchstone of British ballet style.

An agreement to ease tensions at Junior High School 120 in Harlem was reached yesterday, leaving open the case of William B. King, who was summarily dismissed as acting principal May 14. The ensuing disorders caused the temporary closing of the school last week.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 27 (UPI) A force of Thai and Malaysian border police captured a Communist guerrilla camp on the border of the two countries yesterday after bombarding it for two days with mortars, Thai police officials said today.

COLUMBUS, May 27 The Republican State Central Committee of Ohio called upon the party's nominees for Attorney General and treasurer today to appear before it on June 4 to explain their role in a scandal that has enveloped party officials.
DETROIT, May 27 The Ford Motor Company said today it would be closer to full production at its United States plants in June than in any other month this year.
The resignation of two top executives in widely divergent businesses was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, May 27 Howard J. Samuels declared today that if he were elected Governor he would press for a four-point program to improve the Long Island Railroad and for freezing fares until the program was in effect for at least a year.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 (UPI) Lawyers for Earl Caldwell, a reporter of The New York Times, moved today to set aside a second subpoena by a Federal grand jury investigating the Black Panthers on the grounds it is "a sort of instant replay" of the earlier one.

PARIS, May 27 (AP) Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey moved into the third round of the $100,000 French open tennis championship today, but Charlie Pasarell, Jim McManus, Tom Gorman and Barry MacKay of the United States were beaten.

Abraham Markhoff, a specialist in workmen's compensation law, a partner in the law firm of Markoff, Gottlieb, Lazarus D'Auria, 401 Broadway, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 255 Pennsylvania Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, May 27 Democrats on the House Banking and Currency Committee voted today to push for legislation giving President Nixon, for eight months, the power to freeze wages, prices and rents. The President has consistently opposed any form of controls, mandatory or voluntary, and there is no sign that he would use the power if Congress granted it.
Navy balloon flights into the stratosphere have shown that humidity in that extremely dry region has risen 50 per cent during the last six years.

Arthur J. Goldberg took time out yesterday from his own campaign yesterday to aid an antiwar Roman Catholic priest in Boston in his bid to take the Democratic nomination away from an incumbent Congressman generally favorable to President Nixon's policies on Vietnam.

The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, announced yesterday a complete reorganization of its nationwide Bank Americard credit card program designed, its officials said, to give a greater voice to the 300 or so other banks that are now licensed to offer the card.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (UPI) Rod Laver of Australia and Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., gained the quarterfinals tonight in the $30,000 Rawlings professional tennis tournament at the Dwight Davis Tennis Center.

Prof. Joshua E. Matz, treasurer of Yeshiva University and a member of the faculty and administration there for almost 50 years, died Tuesday at Albert Einstein College Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 320 East 176th Street, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 27 Highly placed columnists, editorial writers and cartoonists of the Eastern press may at last be ready to come to the bargaining table for cooler-rhetoric talks with Vice President Agnew.
LONDON, May 27 (Reuters) British Leyland, one of the world's largest automobile manufacturers, announced today a share drop in profits.

An array or Democrats, most of whom had supported Mayor Lindsay for re-election, gathered on the steps of City Hall yesterday to attack Mr. Lindsay's proposal for revising rent control as "ill-conceived" and "fashioned in haste." They urged the Democratic-controlled City Council to reject the Mayor's recommendations.

WASHINGTON, May 27 If Congressional mail is any gauge of the mood of the country and most Congressmen have no doubt that it is there is a feeling of quiet anguish simmering in the big cities, the suburbs and the small towns across America.

Charges were dropped yesterday against Harold Prezzano, a 24-year-old graduate of New York University who was arrested last week in an apartment where large quantities of drugs were allegedly being supplied to Columbia University students.

Senator Jacob K. Javits called yesterday for an acceleration of the United States withdrawal from Vietnam and termed it "the biggest single thing the Administration could do" to restore business confidence and reverse the economic downtrend.

The nation's railroads wonthe Interstate Commerce Commission's approval yesterday of an interim freight-rate increase of 5 per cent, while the regulatory agency investigates their right to a requested 6 per cent increase.

FROM the beginning of his career, the Rev. Leo Plow den McLaughlin has been attracted to controversy and, the way he looks at it, "the excitement of new ideas." A fellow classmate at the Jesuit-run Loyola Preparatory School in New York City, where Father McLaugh lin received his primary and secondary education, once recalled that "he was always getting thrown out of the room for doing or saying something dangerous."

WASHINGTON, May 27 James V. Bennett, who served as director of the Federal prisons system for 27 years, has given Congress a hard-headed, practical, down to earth appraisal of the Nixon Administration's proposals for preventive detention. They are likely to make a bad situation worse, Mr. Bennett told a Senate subcommittee.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 A it often does just before the running of the Indianapolis 500, the afternoon heat had a searing effect on race cars and on the edgy nerves of men with so much at stake.

Ernie Wheelwright, once a fullback with the New York Giants and now with the New Orleans Saints, has been requested by Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of pro football, to divest himself of ownership in a New Orleans bar because of alleged relationship with undesirable associates.

A $250,000 damage suit has been filed against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority charging that the idling engines of diesel buses at a Staten Island bus depot violate a constitutional right to breathe clean air.
The Sun Oil Company announced plans yesterday to buy 18-million common shares of Great Canadian Oil Sands, Ltd., at $4.50 a share.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 27 (UPI) John Jacobs, the trainer, confirmed today that Eddie Belmonte would rise the Preakness winner, Personality, in Saturday's $100,000 added Jersey Derby at Garden State Park.
DEVON, Pa., May 27 Mrs. Susan Gaffney of Ridgewood, N. J., rides one of the country's super show horses, but except for once a year the mount is never seen in the metropolitan area.

There is a strong precedent for the composer who sits in as violist in performances of his own works (Mozart, eminently, can be cited), so Herbert B. Feldman in that respect stood in a great tradition last night at the New York Cultural Center.

If you see a man walking a wirehaired pointing griffon around 51st Stret and First Avenue, the man most likely will be Bernard Cooper, president of Cove Advertising, Inc., and his charge a strong looking, shaggy dog named Griff. The neighborhood is where they live.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, announced today his candidacy for Democratic House leader next year.
HOPEDALE, Ill., May.. 27 Milburn P. Akers, retired editor of The Chicago Sun-Times, died today when his car collided with a truck, 10 miles south of Hopedale. He was 70 years old.

In a landmark case in 1922, Federal Club vs. National League, the United States Supreme Court said that baseball was not engaged in interstate commerce and therefore not subject to the antitrust laws. That same year in "Babbitt," Sinclair Lewis wrote about things of eternal importance "like baseball or the Republican Party."

LONDON, May 27 Two Boeing 747 jumbo jets stood silently today in a maintenance area of London's Heathrow Air port, the focus of a labor dispute between airline pilots flying the 360-seat aircraft and the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 The Economic and Social Council today reaffirmed the status of B'nai B'rith, the Jewish organization, and the International Criminal Police Organization, or Interpol, as nongovernmental organizations affiliated with it.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 28--Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thailand declared today that if Communists in Cambodia threatened Thailand's border "there isn't any doubt our military authorities will take whatever steps are necessary."
Dr. Albert Ellis, wellknown psychotherapist and author on sex, dropped back on his couch and waved his caller to a chair.

DARWIN, Australia, May 23 --"Djakawu put the people here at the beginning, long before white men came," said Dadaynga Roy Marika, leader of 11 aboriginal tribes in Arnhem Land, 400 miles northeast of Darwin.

Oliver C. Reynolds, a founding partner of the law firm of Reynolds, Richards, Ely LaVenture of 68 William Street, died Wednesday night at Presbyterian Hospital after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in New York and Washington, Conn.

Bond prices turned in impressive gains for the second straight session yesterday, but the combined advances fell somewhat short of erasing the precipitous declines that most issues suffered on Monday and Tuesday.
Stockholders attending the annual meeting of the Interpublic Group of Companies Tuesday were told that the company would delay going public, according to a person close to the power structure.

Leaving their chairs in front of the dismal tenements where they spend their lives, five thousand elderly and impoverished New Yorkers manage to escape every summer from lonely and confined rooms for a few weeks in the country. There, they suddenly come alive again by taking up painting, gardening and the creative arts. And they make new friends that lift them from the slough of despond.
H. Kenneth Philips, who retired as treasurer and vice president of the Nestle Company, Inc., in White Plains in 1967, died Wednesday at his home in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 67 years old.
LONDON, May 28--The British Government today announced a series of steps to protect the environment, ineluding a proposal to prevent sonic booms by commercial planes over Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)--An association of 6,500 small banks said today that big bank systems want Congress to postpone new bank-regulating legislation because they "have the taste of power and they want more."

The chief counsel of the railroad industry yesterday expressed the carriers' disappointment with the 5 per cent interim freight rate increase that the Interstate Commerce Commission approved on Wednesday.

At a synagogue luncheon in the financial district yesterday, Theodore C. Sorensen spoke out for the use of the White House-Kremlin hot line to warn the Soviet Union against aggression in the Middle East.
Cigarette smokers will shortly have to pay a minimum of two cents a pack more for most of their favorite brands.

As almost everyone knows, Charlton Heston, an astronaut who crashed into a future, engrossingly imaginative, action-filled, simian-dominated world first made by the novelist Pierre Boulle in "Planet of the Apes" two years ago, is practically indestructible.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night passed a vigorously debated resolution urging the immediate withdrawal of American forces from Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --Prices paid to farmers for their products rose one-third of 1 per cent in May, ending a decline of two straight months, and were 1.5 per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.

A senior official of the Commerce Department made a surprise appearance yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, where he expressed wholehearted support for the industry's campaign to restrict imports of foreign steel.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Federal Maritime Commission rejected today a bid by Soviet merchant shipping to gain a foothold in the $40-billion-a-year oceanborne United States trade.

WASHINGTON, May 28--By the end of June, four of the six top staff positions in the United States Office of Education will be vacant. This development is viewed within the office partly as a symptom of widespread frustration over these matters:
GALVESTON, Tex., May 28 (AP)--Four men were killed and five were reported missing tonight following an exposion and fire aboard an offshore oil platform that was undergoing repairs.
President Suharto of Indonesia said here last night that his Government favored private foreign investment as a means of speeding his country's economic development.

BOSTON, May 28 (UPI)--A telephone call to Mrs. Aristotle Onassis' Cape Cod home, charged to Senator Edward M. Kennedy's credit card, was made shortly after Mr. Kennedy reported his automobile crash in which Mary Jo Kopechne died, documents showed today.

MADRID, May 28--A group of distinguished Spanish opposition figures who had asked to meet Secretary of State William C. Rogers to discuss negotiations on American bases in Spain were advised by the American embassy today to write a letter instead.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Federal Government was given a share of the blame for job discrimination against Mexican-Americans in the Southwest-in a study released today by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- The East Room of the White House was blue with Presidential bloodlines today--one sitting President, two First Ladies, 11 descendants of James Madison and two of James Monroe.

CARSON CITY, Nev., May 28 --Howard Hughes, who owns six gambling clubs on the Las Vegas Strip, asked the Nevada Gaming Control Board today for permission to extend his holdings to Reno with the purchase of Harolds Club.

Commissioner Bowie Kuhn insisted yesterday that collective bargaining was the only satisfactory method for making any changes in baseball's reserve clause, and that the "totality of players are better off in the present system," as his cross-examination was completed in Curt Flood's antitrust suit in Federal Court here.
The six-lane, $26-million Cross Bay Bridge linking Broad Channel Island in Jamaica Bay with the Rockaway Peninsula was dedicated yesterday in time for the Memorial Day weekend rush.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended all trading in stocks of the Consolidated Oil and Gas Company of Denver while it clarifies its role in the purchase of Canadian oil permits.
WASHINGTON, May 26-- William J. Pachler, president of the Utility Workers Union of America, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived in nearby Kensington, Md.

BUFFALO, May 28--Howard J. Samuels charged today that Arthur J. Goldberg was "running scared" in their contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor and that Mr. Goldberg and his campaign aides were putting increasing pressure on party leaders to win their support.
BURBANK, Calif., May 28 (AP)--Audie Murphy was booked for investigation of assault with intent to commit murder today in connection with a fight he allegedly had May 18 with a dog trainer.

Modernizing the mails moves a long step closer to accomplishment with the approval of a postal reform bill by the Senate Post Office Committee. The bill contains some unfortunate features, but these are outweighed by the certainty that, when harmonized with the parallel measure under consideration in the House, it will bring important gains in postal efficiency.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Mayor Lindsay, who has said in the past that he has no plans to change his Republican enrollment, appeared to strengthen that stand today.
ATHENS, May 28--The International Red Cross enabled the impoverished families of 149 Greek political prisoners to visit them at their camps on the Aegean island of Leros today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28 --John Yovicsin, who has coached Harvard football longer than anyone else in its 96-year history, will step down from that position at the end of his 14th season this fall on the advice of his physicians, university officials said today.
LONDON, May 28--Virtually all sections of the British public reacted with mounting anger today over the arrest in Bogota, Colombia, of Bobby Moore, "the golden boy" of British soccer.

CHICAGO, May 28--The Government will have to either institute wage and price controls, increase taxes, or reduce its own expenditures if the United States is to combat inflation, Gaylord A. Freeman Jr., chairman of-the First National Bank of Chicago, said today.

Listening at length to Donald H. McGannon is like being tossed to a pack of roaring urban planners. One is besieged with talk of "renewal" and "rehabilitation" and "rebuilding" and thoughts of West Side brownstones fill one's head until one realizes that what he wants to reconstruct is evening commercial television.

The next phrase of the political campaign could be anybody's. It might even be the candidate's. But in the race for New York Governor and Senator the chances are much better than it will have originated in the mind of a speech writer.
The Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company announced yesterday that it would make a cash tender offer of more than $50million for 80 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Detroit Steel Corporation.
A 23-year-old patrolman was fatally stabbed yesterday as he sat in a patrol car outside a junior high school on the Lower East Side, and the police accused a former mental patient of the slaying.
LONDON, May 28--An allparty committee of members of Parliament today criticized the Bank of England, the venerable symbol of British financial power, as too secretive and as a law unto itself.

John C. Helenore, Mrs. Kim Sim Chiu and John V. Lindsay helped make history yesterday. They, along with thousands of other Manhattan residents, took part in the first community school board elections held in the borough under the school decentralization law.

The Agency for International Development, a State Department bureau, yesterday allocated $4,850,000 to Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, to expand its medical research and activity in Israel.
TEL AVIV, May 28--The case of an American woman who converted to Judaism in 1967 poses a new problem for Premier Golda Meir's coalition Government.
ALEXANDER CITY, Ala., May 28--For all its national import, the run-off primary for Governor of Alabama has been a strangely tepid affair.

A call for members of the women's liberation movement to recognize prostitutes as the most courageous leaders of the revolution against male domination highlighted an all-day conference here yesterday to explore woman's changing role in society.
The pace of monetary expansion is accelerating rapidly, banking data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System showed.

The seasonally adjusted Dodge index of nationwide construction-contract value was 203 in April, the fifth consecutive month that it remained above 200. It was 208 in March. The index, in which 1957-59 contracts equal 100, is about the only principal business indicator that has shown such stability and strength in recent months.

Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley last night issued an order obliging every member of the Police Department to protect antiwar demonstrators here against "actual or threatened physical harm" during the Memorial Day weekend.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 28 --A three-party leftist coalition headed by Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike won an overwhelming victory in the general election yesterday, dealing a crushing defeat to the governing conservative alliance of Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake.
High officials got involved yesterday in the dispute over proposed subway tunnels under Central Park, and some tart words were exchanged on the subject under the trees.

"I was hungry," said the Rev. Leo McLaughlin-- hungry for direct involvement with students in the front lines of social action. It was this drive to be in the vanguard of constructive change, which in the past marked his activities at Fordham University, that has prompted him to resign his post as that institution's chancellor and to become director of freshman studies at Johnson C. Smith University, a small Negro college in Charlotte, N.C.
Two specialists in aerodynamics have concluded that large migrating birds fly in V formations because in that way each bird boosts the other, increasing their flight range as much as 71 per cent.
"The Out-of-Towners" covers 24-hours in the life of an Ohio businessman (Jack Lemmon) who, with his wife (Sandy Dennis), flies to New York City to be interviewed for a company vice presidency.

Dr. William J. Shultz, economist and author, who retired in 1964 as professor of business administration at the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business Administration of the City University of New York, died Saturday of a heart attack in Camden, Me. He was 68 years old and lived in New Harbor, Me.

Haaren High School was closed yesterday morning after a student was arrested on charges of assaulting a policeman, fires burned briefly in two classrooms and students started a fire in the principal's automobile.

BALTIMORE, May 28--Attorney General John N. Mitchell was strongly criticized by a special Federal grand jury today for refusing to authorize new indictments based on the panel's investigation of Government corruption.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--Senator J.W. Fulbright, describing Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam as "an Asian Agnew," charged today that Saigon's leaders were determined "to keep the Americans mired in the swamp" of Cambodia.
Extension of the Indochina war to Cambodia has been sharply criticized by one of the most important Asian leaders friendly to the United States.

Track huts have an insatiable thirst for record performances and their exultant shrieks at a thrilling finish will take an abrupt U turn into groans of disappointment if the winning time doesn't measure up to their expectations. But they should slurp up their fill today and tomorrow at Franklin Field in Philadelphia during the 94th track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.

The city's public and parochial schools and many of its commercial and government offices will be closed today in observance of Memorial Day, which is tomorrow. Banks and major stock exchanges, however, are to stay open and there will be normal mail service.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Ernest H. Van Fossan, a retired judge of the United States Tax Court, died yesterday at his home in Lisbon, Ohio. He was 81 years old.
DUBLIN, May 28 (Reuters)-- Two dismissed Cabinet ministers were charged today with having conspired to smuggle arms into Northern Ireland.

PARIS--Despite computers and polls it is hard to calculate the real issues in next month's British election but the indications are that personality and prosperity will be the basic factors. In both of these the incumbent Labor party seems to hold an advantage.

This latest Beatles endeavor, "Let It Be," simply documents their recording rehearsals and provides a climactic, impromptu concert the quartet gives atop their building headquarters in London. It stops traffic and clogs the neighborhood with fans and the curious.

United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. called for replacement of the Federal detention center here yesterday after disclosing that there had been two escape attempts in the last two raonths at the 41year-old facility.

Alfred Kazin, the author and literary critic, denounced yesterday what he called the "flag business," the use of the American flag by construction workers and others as a patriotic symbol against war dissenters.

NEWARK, May 28--City Hall officials disclosed yesterday that Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio was being denied a major share of New York television coverage of his campaign for re-election here because of his refusal to comply with an order by the United States Attorney's office not to discuss his impending trial.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

MEMPHIS, May 28--Dave Hill left the pro tour last week and went home to Evergreen, Colo. While there he hit some 600 balls in practice daily and listened to the advice of a neighbor on how to improve his swing. Today in the opening round of the $150,000 Danny Thomas Memphis classic, he scored a seven-under-par 63.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 28 --Mrs. Thorne Dempsey, Piping Rock, the metropolitan champion, finished with a 36, 39--75 for a total of 238 to win the 20th Women's Cross County Golf Association's 54hole medal-play championship at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today. Par for the 5,876 yard course is 37, 37--74.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 28--A Conference on Human Survival here attended by scientists and statesmen urged the United Nations today to assume leadership in controlling the man-made "environmental menace."
WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended May 26:

A $1-million damage suit for injuries in the May 20 IND subway crash in Jackson Heights, Queens, in which two persons were killed and 71 hurt, was filed in State Supreme Court here yesterday. The plaintiff is a 56-year-old lithographer, Ephraim Harvard of 67-71 152d Street, Flushing, Queens.

Arthur J. Goldberg said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was responsible for a "school crisis" on Long Island, asserting that cuts in state aid for education had forced a tax load on communities that they were unable to bear.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28--The allied commands reported today that American combat deaths declined by 35 per cent last week while the number of South Vietnamese soldiers killed rose by 25 per cent.
As the frantic closing hours of the 1970 session of the New York State Legislature demonstrated once again, the law-making process desperately needs reform.
MEXICO CITY, May 28-- With only four days until the opening Of the World Cup championship, the Mexican national soccer team has been shaken by the loss of one of its key players.
Stock prices continued to rally yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to the highest level of the year.
Overoming an awkward start and surviving a foul claim, Augustus Bay succeeded in taking the $18,200 Bushwick Hurdle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

It was 20 years ago, give or take a month or so, that I first saw George Balanchine's version of "Firebird." I did not care for it at all, and last night, understandably, Mr. Balanchine at the New York State Theater presented a completely, or almost completely, new version. I did not like that either, but at least Mr. Balanchine was showing willingness.
ROME, May 28--Pope Paul VI visited a suburb tonight and saw a large sign urging him to come more often and thus spur Rome's city government to do more for the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, May 28--Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans is expecting word from the Japanese Government in the next three days on whether a meeting should be held to pursue talks on limiting exports of textiles from Japan, he disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Nixon Administration is preparing to deliver a strong warning to the Soviet Union next week about increasing Soviet involvement in Arab-Israeli combat, senior officials said today. They added that the decision about future aircraft sales to Israel would hang largely on the Soviet response.

Mrs. Pauline Gray Keyes was married here yesterday noon to Paul H. Briger, who is with the New York law firm of Olwine, Connelly, Chase, O'Donnell Weyher. State Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey performed the ceremony in his chambers.
Once Sirimavo Bandaranaike spoke through tears, and those who opposed her dismissed her as a political novice and dubbed her "the weeping widow," a title she detested.

The Air Force is considering further changes in the wing of the Lockheed C-5A cargo plane that would enable it to withstand more rigorous operations than originally called for, reliable sources said yesterday.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 28--The annual fair of the auxiliary of Phelps Memorial Hospital will be held June 6 on the hospital grounds here. It will be part of Tarrytown Centennial Week.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 28 --Two years ago, Lloyd Lloyds, a Manhattan coat manufacturer, went to considerable trouble to design a handsome silver trophy that was eventually presented to the winner of the first Margaret Lloyds Memorial Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
Lay teachers of the 39 Cath olic high schools of Brooklyn and Queens voted yesterday to strike in September unless their contract demands are met.

The Giants won't play the Jets at Yankee Stadium until 1974, and their rivalry won't resume after that at Shea Stadium until 1979 at the earliest, according to a tentative schedule of opponents through the 1978 season announced yesterday by the National Football League.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

Malthe Hasselriis, an illustrator and portrait painter known for his miniature portraits, died Tuesday on vacation in Gentofte, Denmark. He was 82 years old and had lived for the last 50 years in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP)-- Jim Hickman's two-run homer in the ninth inning, his second of the game, gave the Chicago Cubs an 8-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.
PARIS, May 28--Maoist student rioting swept the Latin Quarter for the second successive day today, and the police occupied a university building to keep rioters from smashing laboratory equipment.

GENEVA, May 28--Investors Overseas Services declined to elaborate on a statement it issued today about the Securities and Exchange Commission's refusal to grant a stay of its 1967 order denying I.O.S. companies the right to operate in the United States.
The New York State lottery's highest prize--$250,000--was won yesterday by a New Jersey man and his family.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The Justice Department answered inquiries today about the Federal grand jury action in Baltimore by saying only that the unidentified investigation at issue there would be reviewed further.

Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, persisted yesterday in his attempt to block-- at least temporarily--the $1.5billion merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.
NASHVILLE--The Grand Old Opry discovered America about the time America discovered the Opry, and neither has been quite the same since.

"This may be really the start of something." This comment by a broker summarized his opinion of the performance of the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Prices on the exchange rose sharply for the second consecutive session in the heaviest trading of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 28--Intercity truck tonnage still affected by work stoppages throughout the country and feight traffic on United States railroads in the latest week ended May 23 were both below the volume in the corresponding 1969 week.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 28--Twenty-two Africans who have been under detention are to be charged or released within a few days, Justice Minister Piet Pelser said here today.

Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem held a spring festival dedicated to serendipity yesterday but, as might be expected there, the exercises led to further expressions of black and Puerto Rican consciousness.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --Mrs. Rose McDonnell Long, widow of Senator Huey P. Long, died last night at her daughter's home in Boulder, Colo., Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, announced in the Senate today. She was 78 years old. Cancer was given as the cause of death.
Stock markets abroad rose sharply yesterday in response to the massive Wall Street rally on Wednesday.
The National Council of Women of the United States has scheduled its eighth annual Country and City Art Tour for next Tuesday and Wednesday.
ALBANY, May 28--Miss Vicki Irene Meduna was married this morning to Dr. Spencer Silverbach at Congregation Beth Emeth. Rabbi Bernard H. Bloom performed the ceremony.

DEVON, Pa., May 28--It didn't mean a thing, but Mr. and Mrs. J. Markley Freed's Best Chance won the secondyear green working hunter stake at the Devon Horse Show today. It was something like a football team running up a big score against a weak opponent.
PARIS, May 28--A high aide to Prince Norodom Sihanouk appealed here today for Soviet support for the Cambodian insurgent movement.
Somebody has been telling lies about Bob Gibson. Somebody has been accusing him of losing ball games, not striking out many batters, having a high earned-run average.
The start of the 41st Eastern Regional Championships at the New York Hilton this afternoon marks the focal point of the tournament year for enthusiasts in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) --The Justice Department gave United States Attorneys blanket authority last Jan. 30 to dismiss draft evasion charges against men who had been declared delinquent and listed for accelerated induction because of antiwar protest activities.
PARIS, May 28 (AP)--Fourthseeded Julie Heldman of New York led a trio of American women into the third round of the French open tennis championships today.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 28-- What happens to a race driver after he passes the age of 40?

Mrs. Alice Crimmins, obviously under emotional strain, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Queens Supreme Court to the strangling in 1965 of her 4-year-old daughter, Alice Marie, beginning what may be her second trial.

The approximately 1,700 members of the Ohio National Guard remaining on the recently embattled Ohio State University campus were withdrawn last night, after a day in which student demonstrators pelted them with marshmallows.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28-- Harlan Fengler, chief steward of the Indianapolis 500-mile auto race, regards with fond paternalism the 33 drivers and crews who reached an initial pinnacle by qualifying for Saturday's race.
Lawyers for 13 Black Panthers moved yesterday to suppress for use as evidence at their trial tapes secretly made of conversations between them and police informants.

Deere Co. showed sharply lower profits in the quarter and six months ended April 30 with somewhat higher sales, reflecting reduced domestic farm-equipment purchases in the face of record farm-cash receipts in 1969 and 1970, William A. Hewitt, chairman, reported yesterday.

At an age when most men are thinking of retirement, 65-year-old Henry Lish is on a youth kick. His latest venture is in the field of junior sportswear; under the Geronimo label, he's turning out hippie-inspired separates that are sellnig like Bob Dylan records.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --The United States Court of Appeals told the Department of Agriculture today to suspend the use of DDT within 30 days or justify to the court its failure to do so.

The American Association of University Professors has been asked by the City College faculty senate to investigate why 11 C.C.N.Y. teachers were not reappointed. The investigation could lead to censure of the institution by the association.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28-- Strong pitching by Jack Donovan or Seton Hall and Ted Zink of Delaware enabled the Pirates and the Blue Hens to gain firstround victories in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's District 2 playoff at Clarke Field today.
Joseph Neitlich, who retired in 1959 as chief court reporter of the State Supreme Court, First Department, here, died Wednesday in Hallandale, Fla., where he lived. His age was 78.

A pipe bomb exploded yesterday at the rear of a small, second-floor lecture hall on the cloistered Rockefeller University campus, shattering six windows and showering fragments of glass onto the walkway below.
NAGS HEAD, N.C.--A gentle wind came through the open windows of our room at the Carolinian Motor Hotel, forming beads of moisture on the screens and carrying with it the sound and smell of the sea.
Controller Arthur Levitt has urged state employes to use buses or trains when they travel between Albany and New York City, instead of the much more expensive airliners.

Representative Shirley Chisholm was accused yesterday of being part of a "sinister cabal" that "coerced" the Democratic state committee into designating State Senator Basil A. Paterson as its candidate for Lieutenant Governor.

The Vietnam wars of this century, involving Japanese, French, Americans and Vietnamese, have left more than enough ruins in Indochina. These ruins we could do without; but there is one ruin, from another century, that we could not do without. It is of course Angkor Wat, potentially endangered by extension of the war into Cambodia.
ATLANTIC CITY, May. 28-- Senator Edmund S. Muskie today accused the Nixon Administration of dividing the nation and threatening democracy by its military and economic policies.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Yesterday's ruling by a Federal Appeals Court that Southern cities may retain some all-black schools points up how important Administration policy is in the judicial enforcement of school desegregation.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., May 28--Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Malcolm Graham of Chappaqua and North Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Virginia Graham, to Stuart Edward Graham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Graham of Forty Fort, Pa. The families are not related. An August wedding is planned.

PROVIDENCE, R.I.--"The whole mob" will attend Lillian Gardner's commencement on June 7. At least a dozen members of her family, including her husband, her 5-year-old granddaughter and her six children (one of whom, a 22-year-old son, will be receiving a business administration degree at the same time) will be on hand when Mrs. Gardner is awarded her bachelor of arts degree from the University of Rhode Island.
Following is the transcript of President Nixon's remarks at the Billy Graham Rally in Knoxville, Tenn., last night, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
M. Milton Glass announced his resignation yesterday as chairman of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- This is the season when the President and members of his Cabinet usually show up at the university graduation exercises to explain the facts of life to the departing scholars, but this year things are a little different. The graduates are explaining the facts of life to them.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Arthur F. Burns has pledged that the Federal Reserve Board, acting as a "lender of last resort," would not let the economy collapse because of a shortage of ready funds in banks or tother financial institutions.
JENKINTOWN, Pa., May 28 --J. Whiting Friel, who retired as executive vice president of Standard Pressed Steel Company in 1957, died yesterday. He was 78 years old.
Grain futures prices were irregular yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade while soybeans futures prices fell after rising the day before.

ALBANY, May 28 (AP)-- Samuel B. Gould, who will be stepping down as Chancellor of the State University of New York next fall, warned today that the greatest challenge of the times was "the growing assault on reason."
Seth Allen is an actor of great elasticity--in several senses of the word. He can bend his talent as well as his body, and distort himself into the most grotesque, hugely comic characters.
Ladies of the evening in New York have switched to the afternoon.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 28 --With the help of a sympathetic audience, President Nixon overrode a small but vocal group of peace demonstrators tonight and pledged himself to world stability and a restoration of spiritual values.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28--North Vietnamese troops are reportedly conducting an intensive recruiting and proselytizing campaign among the rural population of Cambodia in what official sources here see as an attempt to create a broadly based Communist guerrilla organization similar to the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28 --Mrs. J. Taylor Woodward has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen McNeil Woodward, to Robert Froome Boyd, son Of Mr. and Mrs. J. Cookman Boyd Jr. of Baltimore, and Fisher Island, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Army charged two junior officers today with attempted murder in connection with a 1969 incident in South Vietnam in which an American platoon was allegedly directed to fire at some huts for "target practice."
Mrs. Georgiane Schenck Gregersen of Englewood, N.J., executive director of the International Foundation, died late Wednesday in an automobile collision near Parry Sound, Ontario.
WASHINGTON, May 28--A White House advisory panel has recommended to President Nixon that environmental programs now distributed among several departments be combined in a new independent agency.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Milton Friedman, the noted and contentious economist, and a group of other scholars whom he described as "free enterprise radicals" today conducted a festival of political ideas from the right.
The State Department's legal adviser yesterday defended the American invasion of Cambodia as legitimate self-defense, legal under international law.

TJIKUPA, Indonesia, May 22 --Sustina, the 39-year-old chief of this West Javan village, sat inside the dark little general store watching a detachment of soldiers working on a road across a dusty square filled with ragged children, unemployed men sitting indolently on benches and scrappy goats nibbling at the scant grass.

The help-wanted index fell sharply in April, according to the National Industrial Conference Board. At the end of the month it stood at 186 per cent of the 1957-59 average, 8 points below the March reading and 48 points under the level of April, 1969.

In the six-player trade between the Cleveland Indians and the Minnesota Twins last December, the key figures were a couple of pitchers--Luis Tiant, who became a Twin, and Dean Chance, who moved closer to his farm in Wooster, Ohio.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28--Is Marty Liquori ready for his first sub-four-minute mile of the season? Can Larry James become the leading gold medalist in I.C.4-A. competition? How strong is Ron Stonitsch?
WASHINGTON, May 28-- Republicans promoting G. Hartold Carswell for the Senate are organizing a $1-million fund-raising effort across the country to finance his primary campaign in Florida.
Two of the world's noted heart surgeons, Dr. Adrian Kantrowitz and Dr. C. Walton Lillehei, will leave their present posts here at the end of June.
NORWALK, Conn., May 28-- Wilford H. Fawcett Jr., chairman of the board of Fawcett Publications, died early today at Norwalk Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 335 Chestnut Hill Road here.

A snug, briskly cheerful "Amphitryon" with a tart, take-it-or-leave-it tone winked--minus a leer--into the Forum Theater last night, flashing a tiny but telling set of philosophical teeth. The snug intimacy of its new home, through June 20, suits it.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 28 --American Eagle, the former 12-Meter yacht, was given the start timed to split-second perfection today when the 25th annual Block Island race of the Storm Trysail Club began.
Hathaway, whose manwith-the-eyepatch advertising helped make Ogilvy Mather famous, has been resigned by the agency. The C.F. Hathaway Company, a division of Warnaco, had been a client for 18 years.

The stock market rally continued in high gear yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to the highest level of the year. Prices raced upward in the first hour of trading in a continuation of Wednesday's strong recovery, slipped downward for the next two hours, and then began a new advance that carried major market indi cators to their top levels of the day at the close.
About nine months ago the New York headquarters office of J. Walter Thompson set up a Corporate Communications Group.

HONG KONG, May 28--Further evidence that part of Prince Sihanouk's government in exile is operating within Cambodia was provided today by reports of a meeting of members and supporters of the regime in a "liberated area" of the country.

MOSCOW, May 28--The Soviet Union, in its first public assessment of the meeting in Rome of the Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, reacted coolly today to the proposal for EastWest talks on a reduction of forces in Europe.

Samuel Plesser, founder and chairman of Plesser's appliance stores in New Hyde Park, Babylon and Patchogue, L.I., died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived at 15 Stoner Avenue, Great Neck, L.I.
SUMMIT, N.J., May 28-- Miss Deborah Hawes Johnston and Kevin Clark were married today in the chapel of the Central Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Robert H. Stephens.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28 (Reuters)--The police used tear gas today to forestall two student demonstrations, and some of the students retaliated by throwing Stones and firebombs.
The 16 board members of Blair Co. met yesterday afternoon and rejected a merger proposal from the brokerage firm of Francis I. du Pont Co. as "unacceptable."

TRENTON, May 28--New Jersey officials disclosed tonight that the State Attorney General was seeking a court order that would outlaw any further construction in 29 northern New Jersey communities until they stopped polluting New York Harbor.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 28 --Vice President Agnew sought to reassure the financial community today by predicting that "1970 is going to be a good year for business, with an upturn in the second half."
The General Electric Company has succeeded in producing diamonds of gem quality in its laboratories. But the company doesn't really know what to do with them yet.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) --Rising meat costs have slowed the Agriculture Department's hamburger donations for school lunch programs, which currently help feed about 22 million children.

PLAINFIELD, Ind., May 27 --In the Buick showroom, a salesman was listening with affability and patience--attitudes that sometimes wear thin in this rigidly conservative town--as a long-haired young customer in shorts and sandals expounded on the dangers of pollution.
Eva Hesse, a well-known young sculptor, died at New York Hospital yesterday, morning of a brain tumor. She was 34 years old and lived at 134 Bowery.

Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman, adviser to the Radical Jewish Union of Columbia University, and 22-year-old Annie Rosen, a member of the union, were arrested last evening after they disrupted services at Temple Emanu-El. They were charged with interfering with a worship service.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 29 Summer A. (Huey) Long's 73foot ketch, Ondine, out of Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club and the scratch boat in the Storm Trysail Club's 25th annual Block Island race, was reported leading the fleet home this afternoon.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., May 29 Miss Leslie Robinson Rogers and August Bernard Schilling were married here this evening in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Michael Lease performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. G.P. Mellick Belshaw, rector of St. George'sby-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

LIMA, Peru, May 29 The private banking system in Peru, still groggy from the heaviest blow dealt foreign banks in Latin America since the Cuban revolution, is awaiting a second punch from the military regime that is expected to put at least two foreign banks out of business here.

The cancellation by the United States Court of Appeals of a lower court order requiring the New York Police Department fulfill its legal obligation to protect anti-war demonstrators on this Memorial Day weekend removes, an unwarranted slur on the entire police force one that was particularly unfortunate in a week when two young policemen were brutally killed in the line of duty.

Praising Paul O'Dwyer as a man "with a commitment on all of the really critical issues that have faced the country in the last ten years," Senator Eugene J. McCarthy endorsed Mr. O'Dwyer yesterday for Senator from New York.

WASHINGTON, May 29 A spokesman denied today rumors that Walter J. Hickel would resign as Secretary of the Interior because of differences with President Nixon. The Secretary, the spokesman said, will not leave the Cabinet to return to Alaska to run for Governor or any other public office.

LONDON, May 29 (UPI) Queen Elizabeth II, acting at the request of Prime Minister Wilson, today dissolved Parliament until July 2. Her royal warrant opened the official campaign for the June 18 national elections.
WASHINGTON, May 29 Dan Rostenkowski was born the year that John W. McCormack entered Congress. That was 1928.
Three youths were shot yesterday by a Brooklyn grocer while they reportedly were looting his store in the BedfordStuyvesant section.
J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., the nation's second largest textile manufacturing company, announced yesterday sharply lower sales and earnings for the fiscal quarter and six-month period ended May 2.
JUNEAU, Alaska, May 29 (AP) The Alaska House reconsidered and defeated today a bill that would have prohibited compulsory service by Alaskans in undeclared foreign wars.
SCRANTON, Pa., May 29 (AP) The father of an Army captain charged with attempted murder "of an unspecified number of human beings" in Vietnam says the charges are ridiculous.
Roosevelt Entries

"We'll do almost anything to get people to come into the library," said Lillian Lopez, director of the South Bronx, project of the New York Public Library. "We've found so many people that have never used a library or know that they exist. They don't know that they can take books out free."
ATHENS, May 29 An Athens magistrate today released from custody Paul Vardinoyannis, a former member of Parliament who has been held since his return to Greece six days ago after three years in exile.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said yesterday that the increasing polarization of Americans over age, race and geography was threatening to "really tear the nation apart, and is doing so today."
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 29 Toledo's City Council, after a long dispute, approved last night a controversial measure banning the carrying of rifles and other long guns.

John Gunther, journalist and author of the best-selling "Inside" books, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 1 East End Avenue.

PAWLING, N.Y., May 29 College chaplains have found a new sense of purpose as a result of recent turmoil on the nation's campuses, where they have more and more been acting as mediators between conflicting factions.

LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) The largest diamond mining combine in the world today said it had little to fear and was not altering future plans because of an announcement by General Electric yesterday that it has developed a process to make clear, gem-quality diamonds.

DEVON, Pa., May 29 Anita's Lad won the green conformation hunter championship at the Devon Horse Show today under Dave Kelley to give the Southern Pines, N.C., professional two foxchaser titles. Yesterday, Kelley rode uncertain Sign to the first-year green working hunter crown.

Prices on foreign stock markets continued a general advance yesterday in response to the further gain by Wall Street on Thursday. The rise yesterday was more moderate, however, than on the previous day.

The municipal hospital system here has committed itself to full implementation of New York's liberalized abortion law, to take effect July 1, and funds were earmarked this week to make possible 25,000 to 30,000 abortions a year on city residents.

Miss Alexandra Brenda Russell, granddaughter of the 10th Duke of Marlborough and a descenant of Commodore Cornellus Vanderbilt, was married here yesterday to Specialist 5 Timothy Campbell Birch, whose Army service has included duty in Vietnam.
CORDOBA, Argentina, May 29 The civil strife that has gripped this inland city sporadically for the last year broke out again today, and the smoke of burning vehicles began to rise.

A public hearing will be held next Friday by the City Council on five new taxes proposed by Mayor Lindsay that are designed to raise $84-million a year. The Council will also consider the Mayor's proposal to raise the 5-cent Staten Island ferry fare to 25 cents.

A 26-year-old man and his pregnant wife, wanted for questioning in connection with bombings in California, were arrested last night in an Upper West Side apartment in which detectives said they found a cache of loaded guns and radical-left literature.

The chief engineer of the sewage authority in the Passaic Valley said yesterday that most large industries in the most heavily populated areas of New Jersey would have to be shut down if the court granted a far-reaching order being sought by state officials to control water pollution.
Arthur J. Goldberg yesterday called for a permanent state subsidy for mass transportation operating expenses as the only way to prevent new fare increases and to improve services.

MOUNT ANGEL, Ore., May 29 Importing the work of a famous Finnish architect known for his beautiful use of wood to the Pacific Northwest may seem like bringing coals to Newcastle. The woods here are as full of architects as they are of Douglas fir.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 29 (AP) A band of urban guerrillas overpowered personnel at a Uruguayan naval training center here today and fled with more than 700 weapons and a large quantity of ammunition.

BONN, May 29 Franz Stangl, who commanded the Treblinka extermination camp in Poland in World War II, was caught on a tip from his sonin-law, Mrs, Therese Stangl, the former SS officer's wife, told a D sseldorf court today.
Valiant took another step along the America's Cup trail yesterday, and this one was literal as well as figurative. The recenty launched 12Meter yacht had her mast stepped.

"Pro football is a silly game," says Chip Oliver. "It dehumanizes people. They've taken the players and made them into slabs of beef that can charge around and hit each other. But where is their esthetic soul, the feeling they can accomplish higher things?"
Kimberly dresses change more quickly than Bentleys, but only because fashion is more volatile than cars.

HONG KONG, May 29 Prince Norodom Sihanouk said in Hanoi yesterday that while in office he had given to "the Vietnamese people fighting against the United States imperialists an effective support and assistance that is not verbal."
LOS ANGELES, May 29 Harold Willens, Los Angeles businessman, is desperately poring over Fortune's list of the 500 largest corporations.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit nullified a Federal District Court order yesterday that would have required the city's Police Department to remind every member of the force this weekend of his duty to protect antiwar demonstrators from physical assaults and threats.

The Mets finally figured how to knock Tom Griffin out of a ball game hit him on the elbow. But they still haven't figured out how to beat him or score on him, and they still haven't figured out how to beat the Astros, either.

MOSCOW, May 29 Andrei A. Amalrik, the dissident Soviet author who was arrested on May 21, has been transferred from Moscow to the city of Sverdlovsk in the Urals for his pretrial investigation, reliable sources said today.

A group of Ohio State University students, angered by campus strikes and violence, filed suit in Common Pleas Court in Columbus yesterday asking $1-million in damages and a permanent injunction against further disruptions of academic life.

A declaration that the screen industry's self-regulating film ratings system and its Production Code face "danger of failure unless remedial action is initiated immediately" has been made by two leading church film offices.

ATLANTA, May 29 Gov. Lester G. Maddox announced today that the would personally picket the offices of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution next week. He ordered sales of the two papers stopped in the vicinity of the Capitol.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 29 (Reuters) A joint Thai-Malaysian border force has driven Communist guerillas from four main bases in four weeks, police sources said today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 29 The Yankees relied on two trustworthy items strong hitting and superb relief pitching to down the Minnesota Twins, 4-2, tonight before 14,194 damp-and-disappointed fans at Metrotiolitan Stadium.
TRENTON, May 29 (AP) A 10-year-old boy, two of whose brothers died when they were hit by cars, was killed in the same manner today while attempting to cross a street here.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 29(AP) An all-white jury has decreed the death penalty for a Negro convicted of robbing a white girl of $30 and a wrist watch.

ROME The meeting of the NATO Council just concluded here was quite a satisfactory one by the standards of alliance gatherings. The foreign ministers did enough to achieve the underlying purpose of such occasions a demonstration that NATO is alive and well and still has a purpose in international life.
Diversity is the theme underlying the current Museum of American Folk Art exhibition, Collectors' Choice, Part II.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP) Alan Pifer, president of the Carnegie Foundation, said today that organizations such as his must relate to minority groups, youth and the poor or face extinction.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 Seton Hall battled into the championship of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's District II baseball playoff today and joined Delaware in tomorrow's final round.
Townes Van Zandt, a pleasant-sounding folk singer from Houston, is ,appearing through June 7 at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) The Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, accused the Nixon Administration of a negative, footdragging attitude toward Congressional efforts to improve the lot of Vietnam war veterans.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 An eyewitness to a shooting incident in South Vietnam that led yesterday to charges of attempted murder against two Army officers said today that he and other soldiers saw civilians moving around a cluster of huts in the Mekong Delta before the huts were fired on for "target practice."

In this era of militants who throw four-letter words around and are avowedly bent on overturning the Establishment, Constance Baker Motley's mild manner, soft voice and amiability come as a shock to those who knew her only by her formidable reputation.
CHARLESTON, S.C. A hospital workers' strike last spring so thoroughly upset the hoary equilibrium of this historic port city that even those who would now prefer to forget it cannot.

One of the less easy aspects of being a kindly neighborhood critic is that once in a while would you believe the next night? you have to venture into territory that was not altogether happy with what would you believe the past morning? you last wrote about it. To any critic in this situation, I would most seriously suggest that this is the price he pays for not working.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 29 (UPI) The Laotian military command announced the start of an offensive today and reported successes against Communist troops in wide areas of the countryside.

James Radice, president of the Traffic Squad Benevolent Association, charged yesterday that there was a nationwide conspiracy to degrade law enforcement and said that his organization was offering a $10,000 reward to anyone who could supply information to identify the alleged conspirators, and lead to their prosecution.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 30 More than 1,000 South Vietnamese marines battled North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops today in the besieged Cambodian town of Preyveng, 30 miles southeast of Pnompenh.

Ron Field can't see having a house in the country. "I have too many frustrated friends with places in the Hamptons or Connecticut who can't get out to their house on weekends or can't get people to visit them because everybody else has a house too."

Office Queen's ability to keep a straight course, while her favored rival, Cathy Honey, had to change paths several times, enabled the filly to carry Stephen Calder's colors to victory in the $119,625 Mother Goose at Belmont Park yesterday.

PARIS, May 29 Daniel Wildenstein has reluctantly joined a select circle of thoroughbred horse owners, including Queen (Elizabeth II of England, who have had winners disqualified because of, the awesome sternness of the French racing stewards.
Ban the short sale? That's what one Wall Streeter suggested here a couple of days ago. In his view, it would prevent the "killers" from stopping rallies cold.

Howard J. Samuels told audiences in Manhattan and Westbury, L.I. yesterday that the state needed a new direction in domestic policy just as the nation did in foreign policy a direction "challenging the Establishment and the status quo" at home and abroad.
MADRID, May 29 Secretary of State William P. Rogers met with Generalissimo Francisco Franco today as their countries hailed "substantial progress" toward a new agreement on American bases in Spain.
SAN CLEMENTE Calif., May 29 After nearly seven weeks of almost continuing crisis, President Nixon settled in here today for a vacation weekend at his Western White House.
PLANDOME, L.I., May 29 Mrs. Lenore Lyons was married today to Jonas Rosenfield Jr. in the North Shore Unitarian Church by the Rev. J. Harold Hadley.
John M. King, 43-year-old Denver oil millionaire, gave up yesterday his battle for control of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the giant mutual-fund complex based in Geneva.
HONG KONG, May 29 (AP) The current slowdown in business in the United States is affecting the Hong Kong textile industry and industrialists say they expect the situation to worsen before it improves.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) Henry J. Richter Co., a brokerage concern enjoined earlier this week from engaging in stock transactions, filed an involuntary bankruptcy petition today in United States District Court.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 29 (UPI) Several thousand students today staged the biggest anti-Government demonstration in recent weeks at the state funeral of Phan Khac Suu, a former South Vietnamese Chief of State.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 29 Good Chase of New Zealand and Del Insko of South Beloit, Ill., collaborated handsomely and daringly tonight to break their losing streaks at Roosevelt Raceway.

TEMECULA, Calif. Vincent Cilurzo regularly joins the Friday exodus from the Los Angeles metropolitan area for the great outdoors of weekend California living. But instead of heading for the beach or his boat, the camping sites or the desert dune buggy romping areas, Mr. Cilurzo drives down here to oversee his vineyards.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 29 Miss Leslie Steen and Gary Clifton Gomes were married this evening at the Reformed Church by the Rev. Charles Copenhaver.

WINCHESTER, Va., May 29 (AP) Mary Mills, the former United States women's open champion, clipped three strokes from par on the front nine and finished with a four-under-par 68 today for a one-stroke lead after the first round of the 54hole O'Sullivan open golf tournament.

In a new exhibition at Cordier Ekstrom, 980 Madison Avenue near 76th Street, called "Black and White," which this time is not a reference to the skin colors of the participants, there are drawings by such big names as Marcel Duchamp, Jean Dubuffet, Max Ernst and Richard Lindner, as well as a group of sculptures in black or white marble by Isamu Noguchi.

SURBTTON, England, May 28 (UPI) Patti Ann Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., upset Mrs. Mary Ann Curtis of St. Louis, last year's tourney winner, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2 today and reached the women's singles final at the Surrey grass courts tennis championship.

MEXICO CITY, May 29 Bobby Moore, captain of the English soccer team that will participate in the World Cup tournament starting here Sunday, left Mexico City today for Guadalajara, where he will rejoin his teammates. England, the defending champion, plays its first game Tuesday against Rumania.
The bear market has forced a brokerage house out of business and has discouraged another from replacing employes who have left the company for one reason or another.
Terry Sawchuk, the New York Rangers' goalie was transferred to New York Hospital yesterday from Long Beach, (L.I.) Memorial Hospital and was reported in serious condition.
Massive subway tieups affecting thousands of riders are occurring almost daily at a dozen stations in the city, even when no equipment failures slow down the trains.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 29 (AP) The United States and the Soviet Union recorded team victories today in an international shooting competition.
The appointment of Donald F. Benjamin as chief executive of the Commerce Labor Industry Corporation of Kings has been announced by John C. Hilly, chairman of the organization's board of directors.
Albert Shanker was released from Civil Jail yesterday after serving a 15-day sentence for leading the illegal teacher strikes in 1968 here.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 29 The allied military campaign in Cambodia is a month old.

The Mississippi River is considered a barge waterway these years, but now Greenville, Miss., on the river 450 miles above its mouth, has become an ocean port, the Fairplay International Shipping Journal reports.
MIAMI, May 29 (UPI) Vice President Agnew said today he believed dissent between opposing factions in the United States was lessening "because we have opened lines of communication."

WASHINGTON, May 29 A report of the Central Intelligence Agency asserts that Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia, who led the ouster of Prince Norodom Sihanouk as Chief of State in March, sold rice to the Vietcong on several occasions a few years ago.
The new-issue market, where shares of companies that had been privately held are traded over-the-counter, bounced back a bit in the general stock market rally the last three days of this week.
Could New York City diminish the high crime rate among heroin addicts by adopting a legal heroin program similar to that in Great Britain?

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 A.J. Foyt, who wants to be the first four-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, and Al Unser, seeking his first victory, are the favorites to win the 54th running of the race tomorrow if it does not rain.
Mayor Lindsay yes terday appointed four-man, high-level committee to review recommendations to curb unprovoked assaults on firemen.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 21 The Dutch are returning to Jakarta.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., May 29 Miss Mary Susan Wallau was married this evening to Jos Enrique Rohm at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lee Wallau 2d, parents of the bride. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. John J. McLaughlin.
Hans Pfitzner called his opera "Palestrina" a "dramatic legend." Ironically enough, the work itself has become legendary to music lovers outside the Germanspeaking countries.
Miss Leslie Joan Nathan was married here yesterday afternoon to Daniel Roy Weinberger in the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Allan Shedlin of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 29 The Government has privately assured scholars and art experts that steps are being taken to protect important cultural sites, including the historic temples at Angkor Wat, during the fighting in Cambodia.

STOCKHOLM, May 29 Kerstin Thorborg,Swedish mezzosoprano and contralto who sang at the Metropolitan Opera in New York from 1936 to 1947, died April 12 in a hospital in Falun in the Swedish province of Dalarna. She was 73 years old.

At a "Conference on Human Survival" held here this week to consider the prospects for the United Nations on its 25th birthday, Canada's Lester B. Pearson warned that unless the world community begins to deal more effectively with problems of peace and development "we will not be celebrating a fiftieth anniversary of our world organization."

DUBLIN The lionization of Christy Brown is the new "in" thing in Dublin Christy the writer, Christy the painter, Christy the poet, Christy the embodiment of heroic human resilience, Christy the living proof that an artistic mind can gloriously blossom in a desolate physical waste.

The Goldman Open Pairs, one of the most famous events in the history of the game, will begin this afternoon in the New York Hil-, ton Hotel, on the second day of the Eastern Regional Championships. Among the competitors will be most of the top-ranked experts in the metropolitan area and many from farther afield.
The SCM Corporation said yesterday it will indemnify users of its disputed interior coating for self-cleaning ovens against any damages resulting from patent infringement suits.
DETROIT, May 29 The American automobile industry apparently is looking abroad, as a possible source for steel.
"Will the Chinese make aggressive war one of these days?"

ROME, May 29 The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI would visit the Philippines and Australia in the second half of November. The projected 25,000-mile air journey will take the widely traveled Pope farther from Rome than he or any of his predecessors has ever been.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 Dick Buerkle, a 22-year-old senior who entered Villanova without an athletic scholarship, started the Wildcats toward another I.C. 4-A. team championship today with an impressive 30-yard victory in the six-mile run.

WEST POINT,N.Y., May 29 Army's powerful track and field team defeated Navy, 11143, at Shea Stadium today for the cadets' fifth consecutive outdoor track victory over the middies and a gratifying conclusion to Coach Carl Crowell's 20th season with Army.

PARIS, May 29 Maoist youths seized a suburban high school building today. Riot-police patrols kept the Latin Quarter calm, but there were widespread signs that the last two days of rioting there had bred fresh bitterness within France's already polarized body politic.

BRASILIA, May 29 (Reuters) Official sources said today that thousands of starving peasants were invading towns in drought-stricken northeastern Brazil and were breaking into stores and private homes in search of food.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 29 (AP) A captured Vietcong officer said today that his superior told him a month ago that captured American, Japanese and French correspondents had been moved to rear areas and were alive.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) The food stamp program began its 10th year today, having grown from a one-county program in hard-core Appalachia to an operation that covers more than 60 per cent of the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP) For the first time, student protest on University of California campuses encompasses a majority of the academic community, the system's president, Charles H. Hitch, said today.

MEMPHIS, May 29 As scoring records were broken, Homero Blancas, winner at Forth Worth two weeks ago, smothered par with a nineunder-par, 36-hole aggregate of 131 in the $150,000 Danny Thomas Memphis Golf Classic today.
