The Indianapolis 500 today will be broadcast by many radio stations and will be carried on closed-circuit color television in many theaters.
COPENHAGEN, May 29 A battle over who is to manage a system of clearing international bonds sold in Europe Americans or Luxemburgers broke out on the floor of a bond dealers' annual meeting today.
The American Stock Exchange scored its third consecutive advance yesterday as the list continued to make gains in fairly active trading.
BUENOS AIRES, May 29 (AP) Twelve hours after Mr. Aramburu disappeared, a group of followers of Mr. Peron announced it had seized the former president.
BINGHAMPTON, N.Y. May 29 A group of about 45 Army Reservists escaped from their chartered bus moments before flames engulfed it on Interstate Highway 81 here at noon today.

A large portrait by Thomas Eakins that failed to reach its reserve price at auction on May 21 has been purchased by Dr. Armand Hammer, art collector and chairman of the board of the Occidental Petroleum Company.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 29 (AP) Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike was sworn in today as Ceylon's Prime Minister while 5,000 of her supporters attacked the offices of the country's largest newspaper group. Later, a policeman was killed during another demonstration.

GENEVA, May 29 (Reuters) The World Lutheran Federation said today that it was reconsidering a decision to hold its fifth assembly in Brazil because of concern on the part of some members about alleged violations of human rights there.
BAGNAIA, Italy, May 29 The foreign ministers of the European Common Market agreed today on the Italian Communications Minister, Franco Maria Malfatti, as its next president.

PARIS May 29 (UPI) An American oil executive warned today that American dependence on foreign petroleum would increase unless the United States Government helped tap further resources in the Alaska region.

A study sponsored by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education indicates that the big urban universities that focus on graduate research and the granting of doctoral degrees are more likely to encounter a high incidence of student protests than the national norm.

Seymour Rosen, chairman of the board of Combined Media, Inc., a holding company of communications concerns at 10 East 40th Street, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 52 years old and lived at 147 Darling Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) Senator Joseph D. Tydings, a millionaire Democrat from Maryland said today he had suffered heavy losses in the declining stock market over the last year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. May 29 Rutgers University today dedicated a new $18-million medical science building on the Piscataway Campus amid doubts as to whether the medical school will remain part of the state university.

Alexander Hamilton, a greatgreat-grandson of the American statesman and first Secretary of the Treasury, died of emphysema yesterday in London, where he was on vacation. He was 67 years old and lived in Sloatsburg, N.Y.
Vetreans organizations and antiwar groups have announced plans for competing patriotic and peace demonstrations today as the nation observes Memorial Day.

Miss Rosita Arias, daughter of Dr. Roberto Arias, the former Panamanian diplomat, was married here yesterday afternoon to George B. Hanily, a former Marine captain, who is with the treasury department of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here.

A potential small boom in the transfer of air rights over landmark buildings is blowing up the usual storm that touches any aspect of zoning in this city. Money, as always, is at the root of the, matter, in the form of the grotesquely high cast of Manhattan land.

In what they call the first scientific dig on the site of old New Amsterdam in lower Manhattan, an archeologist and a research historian for the Landmarks Preservation Commission have unearthed what may be portions of the foundation of New York's first City Hall.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 The voluntary manslaughter conviction of Huey P. Newton, the imprisoned Black Panther leader, was overturned today by the California Court of Appeal.

DETROIT, May 29 (UPI) United States auto output continued on a strong note this week despite the Memorial Day holiday as the major auto makers produced 172,356 cars during the week, the second best of 1970, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
PARIS, May 29 (AP) Arthur Ashe advanced to the quarterfinals of the French open tennis championships today along with Cliff Richey, a fellow American.
TOKYO, May 29 (UPI) Foreign Minister Kiichi Aichi said today a proposal to settle the United States-Japan textile-export issue would be completed over the weekend.

GENEVA, May 29 A proposal for an across-the-board emergency increase in North Atlantic passenger fares of $5 in each direction is being voted on by member airlines of the International Air Transport Association.
JERUSALEM, May 29 The Israeli Army spokesman said today that Israeli troops along the Jordan River drove off a landing party of Arab guerrillas last night, killing 11 of them and capturing a 12th.
The stock market continued to steam full speed ahead yesterday, fueled by a White House statement that stopped early profit taking and pushed the averages to higher ground.
FRANKFORT, Ky., May 30 (AP) At least six infants have died of whooping cough in Bell and adjacent Southeastern Kentucky counties this year, the State Health Department says.

GALVESTON, Tex., May 29 (UPI) Crude oil from an offshore explosion that left four dead and five missing oozed onto the most popular resort beach in Texas today, coinciding with the arrival of thousands of holiday tourists.

SUVA, Fiji The image projected by Fiji, a British colony of several hundred beautiful islands that will become an independent state on Oct. 10, has to include a magnificently proportioned race of tall, robust, smiling women with a distinctive bushy hair style.
WASHINGTON, May 29 A Virginia inventor will receive a patent for a heartlung machine next week, a few days before he gets his high school diploma. Craig R.

BUENOS AIRES, May 29 A former Argentine provisional President, Lieut. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, was kidnapped this morning by four men, two of them wearing army officers' uniforms. The Interior Minister, Gen. Francisco Imaz, confirmed the kidnapping this afternoon at a news conference.

BUDAPEST, May 29 (UPI) Janos Peter, the Hungarian Foreign Minister, said today that the Warsaw pact nations should take into consideration the proposal of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on mutual troop cuts in Europe.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 29 Heour Lay Inn is the Na tional Assembly Deputy from Snoul and Chhlong, his native town. He cannot go home to his district because the ruins of Snoul, leveled and captured by the Americans earlier this month, are inaccessible from here and the Vietnamese Communists hold Chhlong.
PARIS, May 29 Eightyseven years after Paul Gauguin quit banking to become a painter and poor, two of Europes most prestigious bankers have gone into art, part-time, to get richer.

The resignation of Delbert L. ("DebS") Mills as senior vice president of consumer products and components of the RCA Corporation has been announced by Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and president. Mr. Mills, who is 62, was a key figure in the development of color television into a multibillion-dollar commercial industry.

City health officials told Mayor Lindsay yesterday that a man suspected of fatally stabbing a policeman on Thursday was considered to be in an "improved condition" two days earlier when he was released from Bellevue Hospital after three weeks of psychiatric care.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that it was proceeding with its plans to merge with the Hartford Fire Insurance Company despite a third round of legal maneuvers by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, to delay the plan.

In a farcical ending, during which 3,000 fans were allowed to run onto the field, the Inter Milan Soccer Club of Italy defeated the great Santos team of Brazil, 1-0, at Randalls Island last night as the game was halted with 11 minutes to play.

The New York Post and Typographical Union No. 6 reached "an understanding" in their contract negotiations yesterday.

The Rev. Michael Allen, rector since 1959 of historic St. Mark's-in-the-Bowery Episcopal Church, yesterday was named dean of Berkeley Divinity School in New Haven.
Talk shows will have their own category in the Emmy Award nominations next year.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) Ogden Phipps's King of The Castle and Frank C. Sullivan's Te Vega won divisions of the $50,000 added Governor's Cup Handicap today as Arlington Park opened its 72-day meeting before a crowd of 29,412.

A young couple in whose West Side apartment the police said they found a cache of weapons and some drugs in a raid Friday night were held in $150,000 bail in Criminal Court yesterday after an assistant district attorney said they were wanted in California on charges of attempted murder, arson and other crimes.
The New York Mets crossed one of their last frontiers yesterday before 54,424 persons in Shea Stadium, the largest crowd of the major league baseball season.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. President Nixon was busily marking time last week. He rushed between conferences with prowar students and antiwar students, hawkish labor leaders and nervously dovish financiers, university presidents and Bible Belt fundamentalists. Yet there was something oddly static about all this activity, as if he had decided to let his twin crises of Cambodia and the economy simmer for a while.

WITH dramatic suddenness, the stock market pulled out of its deep nosedive in the middle of last week and shot sharply upward, fanning Wall Street hopes that the prolonged bear market might have ended at last.

By tonight some 8,000 American families will have had their Memorial Day weekend ruined because someone stole their car. And to make matters worse about 1,500 of these 8,000 stolen cars will have been involved in accidents, some of them fatal.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 For the entire month of May Al Unser had the Indianapolis 500 in the bag, dominating, all practice and qualifying sessions without even breathing hard. Today all he needed to do was go 200 laps around the 2 -mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway to make a formality of winning the annual auto race.

NEW HAVEN, May 30 Lawyers for Lonnie McLucas, a defendant in the impending kidnapping-murder trial here of Black Panther party members, have subpoenaed representatives of 16 news organizations in an effort to show that prejudicial publicity has made a fair trial for their client impossible.

Probably the most exciting specimen brought back by either of the first two successful Apollo missions to the moon is a rock, the size of a small lemon, that is not only more ancient than any other moon sample studied so far, but is also far more radioactive.

WASHINGTON, May 30 Behind the widely publicized agonizing of Sargent Shriver over whether to run for Governor of Maryland and if not, what political alternative would be "useful" there lies an assessment by a group of young liberal Democrats in Congress that their party is nationally leaderless and next to dead at a time of unequalled American peril.

DAVID BLOMBERG loves walls. He dotes on, walls: nice, big, flat walls of buildings on which artists can paint vibrating blues, yellows and greens, arranged in abstract patterns. He walks around New York with his head in the air, looking at walls, thinking how nice it would be if the dirty, weathered bricks could be covered with art forms that would bring gaiety to the neighborhood and joy to the viewer.

ADENAU, Germany, May 30 (UPI) Hans Laine, a 24-yearold Finnish driver, was killed today in the flaming wreckage of his Porsche 908 after the car crashed during a practice run for tomorrow's 1,000-kilometer (621 miles) sports car and prototype race on the Nuerburgring circuit.

The 18,655-ton Matson Line cruise ship Lurline, the last active unsubsidized ocean-going passenger vessel under the United States flag, has been sold to Chandris Lines of Greece.

They were shelled from posi tions in Israel and emptied of their populations after an Israeli school bus was ambushed close to the border a week ago Friday, leaving 12 children and teachers dead and the rest of the 20 people on the bus injured.

WASHINGTON, May 30 Vice President Agnew's most pungent speech writer does not intend to tone down Mr. Agnew's comments. The Vice President's most pungent writer is the Vice President.
LONDON British governments since World War II have searched for ways to moderate wage and price increases and thereby slow the rate of inflation.
Two Memorial Day parades, widely separated in ideology, were held here yesterday to honor America's war dead.
DEVON, Pa., May 30 Lieut. Col. Harry Llewellyn, probably the greatest rider of show jumpers in the history of Britain, hasn't been in the ring in competition for 13 years.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 30 With the election three days away, the race for the governorship between Gov. Albert P. Brewer and George C. Wallace is predictably enmeshed in a racial controversy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 31 (AP) The Cambodian radio said today that martial law would go into effect in Cambodia tomorrow and that heavy prison terms or death sentences would be imposed for a long list of crimes.

BUILDINGS as diverse as a skyscraper apartment house in Chicago, a small residence outside Washington and a laboratory complex at Cornell University have been selected for honors in excellence of design fly the American Institute of Architects.

DOVER, Del., May 30 (AP) Tiny Lund, seeking his record tying 12th straight victory recorded the best qualifying time of 129,917 miles an hour today to win the pole position for tomorrow's Diamond State 250 at Dover Downs International Speedway.

SAIGON, South, Vietnam, May 30 Enemy troops attacked the mountain resort city of Dalat and surrounding military posts early this morning. It was the most serious attack since the Tet offensive in early 1968.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., May 30 Alan Burtis's Gauchero, winner of the Star Class EyeOpener series on Long Island Sound two weeks ago, led an 11-boat fleet home in the opener of the Hempstead Harbor series today.
Big Ed Johnson, a Democrat, served as Governor from 1933 to 1937, as Senator from 1937 to 1955, and again as Governor in 1955-56.
Six former St. Francis College athletes have been elected to the Terriers' Hall of Fame, making a total of 19 to date.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 No auto race driver ever won so much money, about $300,b00, so easily as did Al Unser today capturing the Indianapolis 500. In an event fraught with dangers and disasters, everything went well for Unser, the little brother of a famous racing family from Albuquerque, N. M.

WASHINGTON The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that the city of Charlotte, N.C., need not go so far in the desegregation of its school system (84,000 students, about 30 per cent of them black) as District Judge J. B. McMillan had ordered. Instead, the Circuit Court directed for the city's

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30 For the last year the right of a Lebanese theater workshop to present a play advocating domestic revolution as well as all-out war against Israel has been something of an obsession among Lebanese intellectuals.
"Wait until next year" the Dodger fans used to say at the end of a disastrous season when that often-inept baseball team played in Brooklyn.
THE five-story walk-up at 120 East 102d Street in East Harlem went through a change in life a few days ago, unknown to most of the 18 impoverished families that live there.

MADRID, May 30 Secretary Rogers has come and gone after spending 23 hours here the number was sharply noted by the Spanish press leaving behind a decided air of public unhappiness with the United States and the base agreements he came to talk about.

While a New York magistrate from 1948 to 1953, Mr. Brenner served on a special panel of three judges in Brooklyn Adolescent Court. After he became a State Supreme Court Justice in 1953, he was known as a champion of the helpless aged.

BUENOS AIRES Inexplicably, the French movie "Z," an attack on military totalitarianism, got by Argentina's censors. Crowds of Buenos Aires residents packed the street waiting to see the film and cheered the downfall of the movie's main villain, a general who bears a striking physical similarity to Argentina's Interior Minister.
NEW ORLEANS, May 30 An organized crime strike force coordinated by the Justice Department will join other investigators next week in scrutinizing alleged Mafia influence in the New Orleans area.

Elizabeth of New Jersey, who earlier this year took the United States Challenge Cup away from the New York GreekAmericans, suffered a 4-1 defeat to the Greeks yesterday at Throgs Neck Stadium in the Bronx.
With thousands of Americans poised for the annual trip to Europe this year, quite a number mmust be wondering if any part of their trip can be regarded as "business" and hence tax deductible.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 31 (UPI) Ohio National Guard reported it had received 9,513 letters, telegrams and post cards expressing reaction to the guard's handling of Ohio campus disorders, including the fatal shootings of four Kent State University students.

Planes Strike at Israelis After 2 U.A.R. Ambushes CAIRO, May 31--The Egyptian Air Force struck today at Israeli positions along the northern section of the Suez Canal to follow up two of the most successful Egyptian commando ambushes in the conflict with Israel.

The new vice president of marketing services at Grolier, Inc., the country's largest publicly-held publisher, is a warm, womanly blonde named Irene Waller. Grolier's sales last year topped $207.2million.
Terry Sawchuk, who died yesterday at the age of 40, had a dual attitude in recent years toward the game of hockey that he played probably better than any other goaltender.
Will the North Sea become another North Slope? This is the big question making the rounds of corporate board rooms and government offices from Oslo and London to Cairo and Teheran.
BELOIT, Wis., May 31 (UPI) George W. (Zip) Zabel, a former Chicago Cubs pitcher, died today in Beloit Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old.

The Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's new operating budget involved "an alarming one-year rise of 17.6 per cent" and called for "economically harmful new city taxes and charges."
STOCKHOLM, May 31 (UPI) Eileen Eden, a former American trotting star now owned by Scuderia Reda of Italy, upset Fresh Yankee today in capturing the European Elite mile trot by a neck.
A 31 year-old man was stabbed to death near the fountain in the center of Washington Square Park at 12:30 A.M. yesterday as scores of people were sitting and walking in the leafy plaza.

BIRMINGHAM, England, May 31 In the red-brick ghetto outside this Midlands industrial city, the British election campaign began this chilly weekend with local candidates ringing doorbells, holding rallies and making speeches aimed at winning the decisive immigrant vote.

LONDON Ten years ago two waiters, Franco Lagattolla and Mario Cassandro, quit their restaurant jobs and placed $2,800 of savings into a tiny Soho club where Italian workers sipped espresso and played cards.

James S. Norton, a retired city fireman who held the Fire Department's highest award for heroism, died Friday at his home, 164-20 Highland Avenue, Jamaica Estates, Queens. He was 84 years, and had retired from the department at 70.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 31 (AP) Ted Uhlaender singled home the winning run in the ninth inning today after Dick Ellsworth, in relief, quelled an eighth-inning uprising as the Cleveland Indians edged the Oakland A's, 3-2.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) J. Edgar Hoover charged today that the real objective of civilian groups who want community control over police departments was "to intimidate and harass police."

NORWALK, Conn., May 31 Mrs. Isabelle Berlin Yolen, writer and creator of syndicated crossword puzzles, died Saturday in Norwalk Hospital. She was 59 years old, and lived in Shorefront Park here and at 45 Tudor City Place in New York.

BOSTON, May 31 The nation's electric power industry firmly believes it can supply ever-increasing quantities of energy and still preserve the environment, A.H. Aymond, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said at a news conference in the Sheraton Boston Hotel here today.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 31 Jacques F. Bulterman, with Onrust in the Luders-16 Class, and Banjamin H. Bryon Jr., with his Soling sloop, Impulse, won their fourth races in as many starts today as the Riverside Yacht Club staged the season's seventh championship regatta for Connecticut area classes of the Yacht Racing Association based east of Rye on Long Island Sound.

TORONTO, May 31 In palmier days, Doherty, Roadhouse McQuaig Brothers, a brokerage firm with 30 offices across Canada, gave generous bonuses to its staff. Sometimes, said chairman D'Arcy Doherty, they came to six months' salary.
PEAM CHIKANG, Cambodia, May 31 (UPI) Chi Boun Thong died today at the age of 25.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 29 Paced in part by youthful clamor on street and campus, Australia clearly is starting a significant new chapter in her brief history as an industrialized state and a power in the Pacific region.

MILBURN, N.J., May 31 Miss Dianna Lynn Medoff and Robert Ian Lachman were married here this afternoon at the Chanticler by Rabbi Rabbi Morris Shoulson. Both will start their senior year at Fairleigh Dickinson University in the fall.

The Rev. Charles R. Hulac, director of the New York Program for Laymen Overseas, died yesterday of a heart attack at State College, Pa., while on a vacation trip to West Virginia. He was 55 years old and lived at 117 Locust Drive, Maywood, N.J.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 31 (UPI) Two armed men hijacked a Colombian Avianca airliner with 43 other persons aboard today, permitted it to make two stops in Colombia for engine repairs and refueling, and then forced the pilot to fly to Cuba.

MEXICO CITY, May 31 With all the pomp and ceremony attendant upon an Olympic Games extravaganza, the ninth World Cup soccer championship opened today before 100,000 spectators in Aztec Stadium and 400 million television viewers around the world. The point of all the festivities was the opening match between the national teams of Mexico and the Soviet Union.

The city's voluntary child care agencies are considering hiring outside experts to analyze the complex child care network here in hopes of untangling some of the red tape that the agencies say has made the system almost unmanageable.

WASHINGTON, May 31 Ever since the publication of Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" in 1962, conservation groups, with the help of allies on Capitol Hill, have tried to get the Federal Government to ban the use of DDT.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 31 (Reuters) Three terrorists were killed and a number were captured during gun battles with security forces early today as authorities pressed a hunt for guerrillas who raided a navy training center two days ago, official sources said.
ROME, May 31 Franco Maria Malfatti, the bookish bachelor newly selected to become "Mr. Europe," didn't seek the Brussels job.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 31 Howard Seymour's Mutiny completed a weekend sweep in the Resolute Class today as 76 boats sailed in the Cow Bay area Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition.

Arthur J. Goldberg, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, proposed a five-point campaign yesterday to fight water pollution in the state, including a $1.6-billion clean-waters bond issue and controls on atomic power plants stricter than those currently enforced by the Federal Government.
BERKELEY, Calif., May 31 (UPI) Among June graduates at the University of California is Isaac Bonewits, who will receive a bachelor of arts in magic.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The Securities and Exchange Commission, long noted as one of the most vigorous and effective agencies in the entire Federal Government, has lost its zest.

Robert V. Roosa, a leading financial strategist in the Kennedy Administration and now a partner in the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., has been elected president of the Economic Club of New York for the coming year, the club announced yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., May 31 (AP) Miss Budweiser, the unlimited hydroplane national champion, was leading the field of nine in the Sun Coast unlimited regatta today before choppy water and heavy winds forced the postponement of the last two heats. They have been rescheduled for tomorrow.
